name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: Author. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The question posed by the two Committees of the European Parliament is of strategic importance for progress, development and innovation in the agricultural sector. It concerns patent problems in the area of biological progress, that is, in an area where the laws of nature are very important.  You have all received this question, so I will not read it here. Let me make some comments on my part. Agriculture is characterized by a specific manufacturing process, because in the production process we are dealing with living organisms of plants and animals. The representation of copa-cogeca farmers in its position to Parliament therefore rightly indicates that patent law originating in the technology sector of industry is difficult to transfer to biological processes. Nature, plants, existing genetic material are not inventions after all. Patenting plant features will not only reduce innovation, but will expand administration and inventive costs.  The main concerns concern the restriction of access in the plant breeding process to the biological material covered by the patent, since the new value contained in the improvement of plant quality should become a common good. However, the financing of agricultural progress must be borne in mind and taken into account if we want its effects to be a common value.  Our expectations of the European Commission impose extremely difficult tasks on it to reconcile different interests. However, we believe that food security, the preservation of biodiversity, the possibility for farmers to access and choose certain varieties are their right. At the same time, we want to maintain breeding work carried out in small and medium-sized enterprises, so that they are not forced out of the industry by large companies in this sector. To sum up, we therefore want the European Commission to explain the legal situation regarding patent matters in the area of plant breeding.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: author. – Mr President, the Committee on Legal Affairs, which I have the honour of chairing, was in charge of Directive 98/44 on the legal protection of biological inventions when it was adopted. The Directive contains, inter alia, certain exclusions from patentability. Article 4 of the Directive excludes plant and animal varieties and essentially biological processes for the production of plants and animals from patentability provisions, reflected in the implementation regulation of the European Patent Convention. Article 53b of the Convention itself prohibits patents on plant varieties and on essentially biological processes for breeding. However, as a result of consecutive decisions by the European Patent Office (EPO), the content of these exceptions has been eroded. Parliament already adopted a Resolution on this matter in 2012. Unfortunately, it did not have much impact on the decisions of the Patent Office. In two precedent-setting decisions of March this year, the enlarged Board of Appeal of the Office declared that, while processes for conventional breeding cannot be patented, plants and animals stemming from these processes are patentable.  Speaking on behalf of the Committee responsible in this Parliament for the application of EU law, I would like to emphasise the need to ensure that the EPO demonstrates appropriate respect for EU law. The EPO will play a central role in the implementation of the European Patent with unitary effect. It is, therefore, worth bearing in mind that Article 27c of the Agreement on a Unified Patent Court states that ‘the rights conferred by a patent shall not extend to […] the use of biological material for the purpose of breeding or discovering and developing other plant varieties’. I hope that this second attempt by this House to bring its concerns to the attention of the European Patent Office will help to convince the Commission to raise the matter with the EPO and will help to prevent, and possibly reverse, interpretations of law which erode carefully considered exceptions to patentability and patent protection.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, on behalf of my colleague Elżbieta Bieńkowska, I wish to thank you for giving the Commission the opportunity to address Parliament on the important issues surrounding patenting and plant breeding rights.  Let me start by reassuring you that the Commission is well aware of these issues. More specifically, we are aware of the breeders’ concerns related to the patentability of plant traits that pre-exist in a plant obtained by essentially biological processes. We are aware that breeders fear having more limited access to biological material. The Commission has been closely following the discussion in both the Agriculture Council and the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development of the European Parliament following the rulings of the Enlarged Board of Appeal of the European Patent Office. In order to help address the concerns raised by breeders, the Commission is currently analysing this issue with the objective of finding a quick and workable solution for all the stakeholders involved. For this very reason, the Commission will be cooperating with the forthcoming Dutch Presidency that has supported such a pragmatic approach which does not entail the need to revise the Biotech Directive. Our wish is to avoid creating long-standing legal uncertainty for the biotech sector when revising or recasting the Biotech Directive. In particular, this could hinder the development of new biotech products for the benefit of European consumers. The re-opening of the Directive would not only put the specific breeders’ issue under the spotlight, but would also trigger discussions on issues that the Directive and subsequent decisions of the Court of Justice of the European Union have clarified. Examples of these issues are the limit on the patentability for inventions relating to embryonic stem cells and the scope of protection of inventions relating to genes.  The solutions brought forward by the Directive and the subsequent decisions of the Court have integrated ethical considerations. They are considered to offer the appropriate balance, by both researchers and the industrial sectors most linked to biotechnological inventions. Having said that, the Commission is highly aware of its task to monitor scientific and legal developments as well as their implications on current patent law in the biotechnological field in Europe. The Commission is also aware of its responsibility to report on these issues to Parliament, the Council and the broad public as well. Before concluding, let me stress that a Biotech expert group has been set up with a mandate to provide the Commission with expertise, analysis and comments on the rapid evolutions in this field. The Group is discussing, among other issues, the patentability of products obtained by essentially biological processes and the report that this Group will soon produce will further support our analysis. I wish to assure the House that the Commission is giving high importance to working on a timely and pragmatic resolution of this issue so that the current legal uncertainty is resolved in the interests of all concerned. We will, of course, keep Parliament informed of any progress.

name: Albert DESS
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, representatives of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Across the political groups, we have always agreed by a large majority that the breeding of plants and animals must not be patented, that no patents may be granted on plants and animals. For thousands of years, agriculture has been able to breed without patents, and it must continue to do so. The possibility of continuing to breed varieties and breeds must be guaranteed by patents to agriculture without hindrance. Food security requires that agriculture can develop without patents from large corporations. The judgment of the Enlarged Board of Appeal of the European Patent Office on broccoli and tomatoes of 25 March 2015 is simply incomprehensible to me. This judgment is also the cause of this question to the Commission and also to the motion for a resolution that is being tabled today. The Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, S&D, ECR and ALDE have today proposed a joint resolution here in order to call on the Commission to clarify this so that biodiversity can continue to be guaranteed for agriculture and for all stakeholders. That is the aim of our question and our motion for a resolution.

name: Paolo DE CASTRO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, as Albert Dess said a moment ago, parliament's Committee on Agriculture felt that this debate was necessary in order to ask the Commission to clarify certain ambiguities in the legislation on the legal protection of biotechnological inventions.  There is broad agreement on the non-patentability of essential biological processes for the production of plants and animals, as clearly expressed in Article 4 of Directive 98/44/EC. However, some recent decisions by the European Patent Office call for greater clarity on the legal interpretation of European patent law.  Innovation in agriculture and the development of new plant varieties are crucial to meet the challenges of food security and climate change and can at the same time give a significant boost to Europe's small and medium-sized enterprises. While patents serve precisely to stimulate competitiveness and innovation while safeguarding economic investment, in some cases they can act as a brake on innovative development, particularly when essential biological processes used by farmers freely over the years are involved.  We hope that, in view of the future decisions of the European Patent Office, clarity can be found by finding the right balance between the defence of intellectual property and the legitimate access and use of biological material from essentially biological processes.

name: Bas BELDER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Commissioner, if we want to maintain an innovative plant breeding sector, we must stop patents on plant material now. If not, a real race will ens to come from nature. This puts the sector in a state of emergency, and I think it is also ethically incorrect.   Plant material does not belong in patent law; for plants, there is the specific plant right. The basic principle of the plant variety right is the complete exemption from growers. This allows growers to make variety by variety. We must continue to guarantee this basic principle.   Commissioner, 'no patent on life'. Together with my colleagues, I received a petition with more than 17,000 signatures. We are happy to pass this petition on to your colleague, Commissioner Bieńkowska.   Commissioner, it is high time that the loophole was closed in the legislation. Clarity is needed and urgent. In the resolution, the EP asks the Commission to do this quickly and properly. The Commission is now on the move.

name: Jan HUITEMA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Growers use natural properties of fruit and vegetables and other plants to continue growing. With this, new flavours or colours are grown in tulips or tomatoes, for example. Recently, it has become possible to patent these natural properties. This is dangerous, both growers and consumers can bear the brunt of this.  When someone naturally grows a new property in a broccoli or tomato, you don't want someone to be able to apply for a patent on it. You create a monopoly on a property of fruit or vegetables and therefore also on our food supply. The natural properties of plants are no longer freely available to all growers.  This jeopardizes innovation and can have consequences on the variety of varieties. Our small and medium-sized growers, farmers and gardeners are among the world's top in improving plant varieties and developing new seeds. Seeds that are sometimes worth more than gold in their weight. If you've really invented something, you should be able to patent it. But the natural properties of plants must be freely used. Two months ago, I raised this issue in the Committee on Agriculture. I am pleased that a large majority of the European Parliament is now supporting this call. I also call on The Dutch Secretary of State Van Dam to take action during the Dutch Presidency of the European Union.  The European Parliament is loud and clear. The Commission must give ample resources to innovation and ensure that the natural properties of plants remain available to all.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Vegetables, cereals, legumes and fruits form the basis of a healthy and good diet. These are of excellent quality in Europe and for centuries farmers and later breeders have kept the seeds and products every year to make new improved products.  For example, the breeding of these green varieties has led us to have hundreds of varieties of potatoes. Some are suitable for french fries, some are suitable for the puree and others are very suitable for growing on dry or very wet soil. We can be very proud of this sector and it is important that we keep those products, the seeds, freely accessible. This is important for biodiversity, which is important for innovation in this sector.  And that is not possible if agrofood companies apply for patents on products that have arisen from essentially organic processes. Characteristics of nature belong to no one or perhaps to everyone. But at least they don't belong to Monsanto and Syngenta. It would be bad if these multinationals were to decide which varieties we are going to grow or not in Europe. These companies do not want competition and the market has no ethics.  Mr President, it is crazy! Farmers should simply have free access to these seeds. This means, for example, an extensive breeders' exemption in European regulations. Because if we continue down this path, we will create monopoly positions in our food supply and such dominant positions, and the resulting loss of biodiversity will also be a threat to our food security here and elsewhere in the world. Commission, do your job, ensure a breeders exemption in European patent regulations. I also believe that European agricultural subsidies should be abolished.

name: Martin HÄUSLING
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. I am one of the co-authors of the first resolution in 2012, which dealt with the issue.  In essence, we have said exactly what is also the subject of the new resolution today. We can hope that the Commission will finally wake up from its deep sleep and take seriously what we decided three years ago. It is incomprehensible– I must be honest – because we expressed the same fears back then. Innovation is being restricted, because it is small businesses, the small breeders, who are the ones who are taking things forward. Farmers' privilege is being jeopardised and the Commission should consider whether we will continue to accept what the European Patent Office has been doing in terms of legislation for years. We are talking about broccoli patents, patents for tomatoes or peppers, while processes are clearly biological breeding processes patented by the Patent Office. This is a legal practice that we simply cannot accept. The Commission must finally intervene, because this is contrary to Directive 98/44/EC, and that is, so to speak, the law. Then the question is: why does the Patent Office do this? The question can certainly be asked. Well, that is quite simple: the patent office earns money by granting patents, and it will not stop by itself. That is why the legislator must intervene. The second point is that, of course, more and more large companies are trying to keep the market free of competitors by securing patents. This will primarily affect the European seed industry or European farmers, because these are large companies that have nothing to do with the mass of breeders in Europe. That is another reason why the Commission should intervene. I have heard today that the Commission has said that it is monitoring the matter. She has also watched the discussion, and she is now analysing it. To date, they have failed to report on the effects. You have been asking for this since 2003, and since then you have not complied with this request. So when do you wake up from your deep sleep, Commissioner, when do you finally deal with these serious problems, and when do you give farmers and breeders an answer? One more comment: we have tabled amendments to what you have probably forgotten: the farmer's privilege still has to be included in this resolution.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, without the efforts of commercial plant breeders we would not have kept abreast with the challenge of feeding a growing population. Having farmed since 1971, I have witnessed all the improvements produced by fertilisers, pesticides and mechanisation.  In my opinion, though, the biggest single factor in increasing yields has been improved crop varieties. These provide the potential from which all else flows. For every successful variety there may be 10 expensive failures, and the winners must bear not only their own costs, but those of the losers as well. Our commercial plant breeders therefore need the assurance that their work will bring significant financial rewards and not simply provide a shortcut to others who can quickly build on a novel feature that took many years to isolate and consistently replicate itself within a stable variety.  In the past, it was usually safe to assume that by the time a competitor breeder had taken advantage of breeders’ privilege and brought a successor variety to the market, the original variety would have had its few years at the top of the hit parade, earned its royalties and been superseded. Skill and technology, though, is now so advanced and correspondingly expensive that occasionally a breeder can produce something that is a step change or a defining moment in the history of plant breeding. The implications of this need to be recognised and catered for. Having watched the EU make a complete hash of legislating on the topic of GM crops, I do not want this institution to spoil yet more innovation in plant breeding.  I would like to see my own country, Britain, take the lead in this field and consult with the whole agricultural industry, because a balance must be struck between maintaining the confidence of the breeders in the principle that a successful idea will yield a financial reward, but, on the other hand, the concern that the market will be permanently cornered and subsequent potential improvements discouraged. The debate then becomes a very straightforward decision on the amount of time a breeder can have the exclusive use of his variety. I believe the industry in the UK is more than capable of reaching a decision on this with minimal interference from politicians. A system may develop where the breeder of a high-flying variety may take the option of purchasing a longer period of purdah from the government, to the benefit of the taxpayer – a simple commercial decision, taken within agreed limits.  We do not need to get involved in semantic arguments about the difference between a discovery and an invention. We just need to let the plant breeders have their moment in the sun. Now, let us never forget that a farmer can always multiply up old varieties himself if he feels that this is a more economic choice, thereby waving two fingers at the perceived greed of big business. This inconvertible reality will always ensure that this issue remains rooted in the ground, the earth, the soil and the dirt, just where a seed belongs.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, the EPO's decision to liberalise the patents and rights of seed breeders is a very bad thing. This is tantamount to giving a blank-seing to multinationals such as Syngenta, Monsanto, etc., by allowing them to take control, in reality, of our food. I think it's a very serious thing.  This is indeed a danger to our food sovereignty because this EPO policy will promote market concentration, increase farmers' dependence on a few multinationals, as you know, and will inevitably have consequences for consumers. In addition, we will have less control over manufacturing, which will be more and more standardized. With this project, industry groups will be able to organize the control of all seeds, including those that farmers take directly from their crops.  In addition, this new constraint will restrict access to the market for traditional local and organic seeds. In France and Europe, the seed sector is made up of many SMEs and cooperatives. Globally, on the other hand, ten companies share 60% of the market. This concentration, coupled with intellectual property issues, will hinder the maintenance of diversified agriculture.  On the contrary, the seed industry must be under control in order to avoid any monopoly and questionable practice, against which are filed, as in 2013 against a patent granted to Syngenta guaranteeing it exclusive rights to all peppers with resistance to white flies. This patent prohibited farmers and breeders from using these plants without paying a licence fee to Syngenta. However, this was not an invention, but a discovery by cross-breeding of species. Another appeal was filed at the end of May 2014 against a European patent held by Monsanto on mushroom-resistant tomatoes. Again, this was a discovery that the multinational has appropriated.  This privatization of the living threatens small and medium-sized seed companies, which are at risk of having their own varieties patented. This was the case, for example, of the French company Gautier, which has been obliged since 2013 to pay the Dutch seed company Zwaan to market a lettuce resistant to an aphid that it had itself long selected. It's still aberrant! Plant certificates were already questionable as they called into question the possibility for farmers to reseed their own seeds free of charge. But despite this constraint, these plant certificates still protected our seed companies and farmers from patenting. This even more expensive, and much more restrictive, practice is already in effect in the United States. Today, the EPO's scandalous decision and the incomprehensible silence of the European Commission seriously call into question what had been adopted, without enthusiasm, as an effective bulwark. Worse still, this decision raises, once again, the question of the alignment of European law with that of the United States, with the obvious aim of not holding back the ongoing trade negotiations. If, in order to achieve this objective, the European Commission intends to trample on the text adopted in 2012, let it say so frankly!

name: Tadeusz ZWIEFKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Colleagues, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. I would like to remind you that the European Parliament did not so long ago, because in 2012, it adopted a resolution in which it expressed its position in an extremely clear and precise manner on the interpretation of the rules, both the European Patent Convention and the so-called Biopathy Directive. In 2012, just three years ago, it's worth remembering what was written there. The directive makes it clear: patentability is excluded, i.e. it is impossible, for plant varieties and animal breeds, as well as for purely biological processes of plant and animal production, for example through cross-breeding or selection. These are fairly clear and precise words, so it is difficult to understand the decision of the Appellate Council of the European Patent Office. I would point out that it was the Board of Appeal, which is such a kind of court, not the patent office, that took this decision – a decision that raises our concerns about narrowing the interpretation of the existing rules, which, as a consequence, can make it possible to maintain the widest possible biodiversity. Growers also express their serious concerns that this opens such a side door, a gateway, to patenting plant varieties and, consequently, to limiting the possibility of access to increasing crop yields. That is why we are asking the European Commission to interpret EU legislation with a clear interpretation, and we also ask you to provide us with information on the report on the development of the impact of patent law on biotechnology activities.

name: Sergio Gaetano COFFERATI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, as you have heard, all political families are concerned about this behaviour on the part of the Commission, which interprets directives differently from time to time.  In this particular case, your opposition to the use of patents stems precisely from the commission's appeal to the European Office, especially since the subject of this further request for interpretation is very sensitive for us, it concerns biodiversity, because the idea of patenting plant material is not only wrong, it is dangerous.  I would like to draw your attention to two aspects. First, who can promote mass patenting? Big companies. In this area, innovation and research into biodiversity have always been the heritage of small businesses, which have fulfilled a meritorious task and which, for this reason, must be protected and helped. Secondly, if we move towards a concentration produced by patents, it is clear that this will not only stop at the products we are debating today, but will become the criterion, the system that will be adopted for the entire supply chain, from agricultural production to food production, introducing negative innovations that would contradict this species, as opposed to what has been the important step forward that the Union has taken in the defence of biodiversity and in research and innovation linked to this species. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: blue-card question. – Mr Cofferati, would you agree that one of the reasons that plant breeding is getting into the hands of larger corporations is the expense of registering and going through the whole process of bringing these materials to the market? It is only the big corporations that are able to do this. Would you also agree that the farmer does have the option of multiplying up an old variety and waving goodbye to the large corporations? Seed is the one item on a farm we can produce ourselves. We do not need anyone’s help to do it. Would you agree?

name: Sergio Gaetano COFFERATI
text: Answer to a blue card question. I would like to point out to you that, unlike what has historically happened in the industrial production sectors in agriculture, innovation and research have never been developed towards the new by large companies. It has always been the small producers who have built niche positions, which then extended, to look with interest, with positive competition to the themes of biodiversity. If we open up a space in which larger companies can fit in, here we will have the opposite effect of what has historically happened in industry, the big ones will destroy innovation.

name: James NICHOLSON
text: – Mr President, when two patents were granted by the European Patent Office on broccoli and tomatoes in March, the implications of those decisions in the long term were enormous. Over 300 applications for patents on plant material are currently awaiting decision by the European Patent Office. One patent has already led to claims of 900 varieties. European legislation is currently based on plant breeders’ rights, as has been said, and does not allow for patents in plant varieties. Essentially, it is a biological process. However, through claims on the products obtained from those two processes, varieties are in practice being patented. Patents granted for plant traits and varieties obtained through biological processes set a dangerous precedent. We need clarity from the Commission on this issue. Plant breeders need to be able to equip themselves better for the future, and I have to say, Commissioner, you were less than persuasive in your opening remarks. I hope you do better when you wind up.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Mr. President, certainly a "yes" for research in agriculture and certainly a "yes" for innovation in agriculture, but one safe and firm "no" for patents in agriculture and one firm and certainly "no" to monopolies in agriculture. What has been done today and what the Patent Office has done is leading to great danger right now because it challenges our shared values. It calls into question the biodiversity of the European continent. It also questions food safety. He's questioning the freedom to breed. We as the European Parliament need to be united and make it clear to the Commission that we expect the Patent Office to withdraw its decisions, as it definitely needs to be known that life simply cannot be patented.  (The Speaker agreed to answer the question by raising the blue card on the basis of Article 162(8) of the Code of Health. Rules of procedure.)

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – Would you agree that due to the mess that the EU has made of legislating over GM crops, this whole issue should be left to the nation states and to those who understand the land best in their own nation states? Would you agree with that?

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – First of all Merry Christmas and you. I am definitely sure that we need a common plant protection at the European level because I think it is quite clear today how interconnected our industry is. I do not want to diminish the importance and role that Member States need to play in this part, as they too can exceptionally preserve biodiversity, but I am sure that one principle of joint cooperation between european and national level must be maintained in this part of the business.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: – Mr President, the fact that we already have a directive and a 2012 resolution on this matter makes the issue clear: that the EPO’s Enlarged Board of Appeal has again issued a finding to create the possibility to patent biological processes, and this is unacceptable, Commissioner. What we are witnessing is entrepreneurship on the part of the Patent Office, the logic of whose entire existence depends on the granting of patents. If we allow this sort of practice to continue, then we threaten food production, food security, plant innovation and biotechnology and essentially give further power to multinationals over our food supply.  What the EPO has done with its decision of 25 March 2012 basically amounts to commercialisation of the natural world. It is my understanding – and maybe the Commissioner can clarify this – that there are currently 260 such patent applications pending in the pipeline, which is why the Commission must urgently clarify and consider revising Directive 98/44/EC so that unrestricted access to biological material is safeguarded.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: Mr President, Commissioner, plant improvement is a particularly innovative sector. This is evidenced by the high investment in research and development, in the order of 15% of the sector's turnover, and, on the other hand, the genetic progress made to farmers around the world. Operators need a clear and effective framework and protection tools, but we must also respect a number of ethical principles in relation to the world of life.  The sui generis law created by the UPOV Convention and the plant certificate, which materializes it, remain the tools best suited to the protection of plant varieties, and we must defend their exclusive use for this purpose, thus supporting the exclusion of plant varieties from the field of patentability. The acceleration of innovation processes leads to a mismatch between the time and the pace of innovation and commercial obsolescence. We therefore expect the Commission to secure this important sector for our economy.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: Mr President, Commissioner, as we know, international law and The Patent Directive 98/44/EC explicitly prohibit the patentability of plant varieties, essentially biological processes, animal breeds and native traits, including when they are obtained by natural processes.  However, by a surprising and questionable broad interpretation of patent law, the Grand Chamber of the European Patent Office took a dangerous step towards patenting plants derived from essentially biological processes in its decision last March. The danger of no longer allowing any breeder to access existing varieties and use them to create new varieties, as well as for any farmer to draw his own seeds from his crops, is proven, but also that of allowing only a few powerful groups, able to obtain patents, to build a monopoly on life for a single commercial and financial purpose, rather than to work for innovation and shared progress. For these reasons, I call on both the Commission and the Member States to clarify and enforce international law.

name: Janusz WOJCIECHOWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I am pleased that there is, in principle, unanimity in this House on the need for a strict ban on patenting plant varieties and animal breeds. Man is not the inventor of life and has no right to patent living organisms. This is against progress, it hinders the natural development of agriculture. Patenting also means that food security would remain in the hands of biotech companies, that we, all farmers, but also all consumers, would be held hostage to such concerns. This is not safe, it is not a good way, so it is good that the European Parliament strongly opposes such a practice of patenting living organisms. I therefore support a joint, very good motion for a resolution. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. I would like to ask you a very short question. Everything that you have just said, and although I will not discuss it, how do you think this matter, which is being discussed in the European context, will come about when it becomes a subject of the TTIP negotiations?

name: Janusz WOJCIECHOWSKI
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – I consistently believe that any restrictions that apply to producers in Europe should be required of those who export their products to the European market, so we should aim to establish a uniform rule in this regard. We do not import products that cannot be produced in Europe. We should stick to this principle.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: – Mr President, what is at stake here is the privatisation of biodiversity, the private appropriation of humanity's genetic heritage, which has been built over centuries of history by generations of farmers and breeders. This step, recently taken by the European Patent Office, is unqualified. In this sense, the resolution is positive. It also strengthens positions already taken by this House and also meets Article 53 of the European Patent Convention.  However, we must go further. We must ensure the full protection of native genes by preventing their own private ownership that strongly cares against farmers and breeders who would now be in the hands of multinationals. We insist on the idea that humanity's genetic heritage, biodiversity, must be a public good. We must create protection mechanisms that prevent any private appropriation of this heritage. This heritage must be protected, valued and placed at the service of humanity and development.

name: Esther HERRANZ GARCÍA
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are faced with two decisions of the European Patent Office which we cannot overlook because of the insecurity and harm they can cause to the research sector in the primary sector. It is important that the current model continues to be respected, with the exception of breeders, so that breeders can continue to use plant varieties in the agricultural sector.  While it is true that intellectual property must be safeguarded so as not to discourage certain research, for years the existing model has now worked very well and allowed a very important work of innovation and development to be carried out throughout Europe, which has achieved, thanks to the efforts of all Europeans engaged in this, that our agri-food sector reaches the highest levels of quality and recognition worldwide.  The exemption of breeders must be respected, and it must continue to be allowed to be investigated without the need to pay licences or charges. Otherwise, we would be beginning to dig the grave of a very important innovation sector for the economy of many European regions, especially regions linked to the rural world. Not only that, the diversity of plant varieties that we now enjoy and would take the freedom of choice of European consumers themselves would also be seriously jeopardized.  I hope that the Commission will be fully aware of this problem which now stems from the harmful interpretation that the European Patent Office has made of Article 53(b) of the European Patent Convention with its recent decisions. And I also hope that the means will be put in place to ensure the future of the agri-food sector.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, today, all the spokespersons of all the groups in this House agree to a great extent, and that is that the decisions of the High House of Resources of the European Patent Office have generated great doubts, and therefore I believe that it is their obligation to clarify this situation as part of the work of the Commission and especially of its portfolio. These great doubts concern a directive, a model — the present one — which, I agree with Mrs Herranz, is a model which is good, but the decisions taken by the European Patent Office, especially the last two decisions which have caused this great confusion, are not so good.  Articles 4, 12 and 13 need to be clarified in particular in order to ensure that legal clarity in the prohibition on patenting products obtained by essentially biological processes.  As I said, the European Patent Office has raised this question, which the Commission must certainly clarify as to the application of the rules.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Mr President, colleagues, the decision of the European patent office nearly 7 months ago has led to today's debate. This decision set a precedent. Many farmers and the entire European Union are affected by it. For them, it is contrary to existing international conventions and European norms. Small and medium-sized enterprises in the sector feel threatened by international giants and feel that their competitiveness is being disrupted.  It is essential that a balanced approach is taken in this case. We must be able to promote the development of innovation on the one hand, but on the other hand we need to distinguish between situations where biological characteristics are obtained for research and development purposes. And when these derived biological characteristics are used for personal purposes and commercialized.  When we talk about this commercialisation, I think we fall into a different category from that of research development. It is important that we be able to distinguish these situations and be able to strike a balance, because the wider the exceptions, the smaller the scope of the rules.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: – Mr. President, farmers throughout history, but still today in the world, are the first seed farmers. Their role is important for food security, biodiversity, adaptation to climate change and therefore farmers must retain the right to grow their own seeds, adapted to local conditions. Plant varieties are normally protected by the rights of plant varieties, which is a better form than intellectual property because it allows farmers to use protected varieties to create new ones. Patents, by contrast, block the flow of genetic resources, hinder research and lead to monopolies. European legislation does not allow the patenting of animal and plant varieties and necessary biological processes in the production of plants and animals. I am vehemently opposed to the patenting of life and am outraged at the decision of the European Patent Office, which ruled in the "tomato and broccoli" case that plant products coming from conventional farming can be protected as patents. I consider such a decision illegal and unethical and expect an immediate response from the European Commission. I advocate that farmers be undisturbed in their own seed farming because they have been its guardians for millennia.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: Mr President, Commissioner, the imperfections in the drafting of the applicable texts allow the seed industry to appropriate the plant characteristics that pre-exist in nature and therefore belong to our common heritage, to our public domain. Behind the legal and technical assessments, this is the whole point of the current debate.  The seriousness of the previous state of the art review, which in the European Patent Office is supposed to avoid private ownership of elements of our public domain, is seriously threatened, on the one hand, by the performance targets in terms of patenting, which are completely unsustainable, and, on the other hand, by problems of management of the Office of extreme gravity. It should be noted that these have led to numerous suicides within the Office and convictions by the courts in The Hague, which the President of the Office refuses to apply. This deplorable situation cannot continue. This is unacceptable! What measures does the Commission intend to take to put an end to these serious excesses which endanger the conditions under which our academic operators, SMEs in the sector and farmers can express their capacity for innovation?

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: – Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Schwa I am very pleased that we are unanimous and oppose the possibility of patenting plant varieties and animal breeds. The European Parliament has already made a clear statement on this issue in 2012. However, recent decisions allowing patenting plants force us to ask the question of whose interest it is to patent plant varieties and animal breeds. Who bends the law to profit? I think that the European Parliament and the Commission should defend the rights of farmers and livestock farmers. Article 4 of the Directive makes it clear that the possibility of patenting plant varieties and animal breeds is excluded, and I therefore call on the Commission to react quickly and effectively on this matter, because that is what we are called to do in order to defend the rights of farmers and livestock farmers.

name: Annie SCHREIJER-PIERIK
text: Mr President, thanks to the development of new plant varieties, our farmers and gardeners are able to feed 7 billion people today. In order to guarantee employment and food security in the future, the preservation of the small breeders and their knowledge is of great importance. This knowledge is in danger of being lost as multinationals dominate the market. The cause is patent law. By patenting natural plant properties, the pond for the small breeders dries up further and further. By recognising only 20 patents, Commissioner, 900 varieties are already covered by the exclusivity of the patent holders. That is already a fact.  It is almost always powerful non-European companies that have the capital to buy up plant properties en masse, and I am thinking of Monsanto. It was once agreed by the plant variety law not to prevent each other from developing varieties further. That basic right has been violated. Mr President, if the European Commission does not intervene now, monopolisation of the breeding sector will be a reality. There is great unrest in the Netherlands, I have said this many times here and I hope for a clear answer from our Commissioner. (The speaker is prepared to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: Blue card question. I wanted to ask my colleague, as I fully agree, what she proposes to defend small farmers, that is, what she would actually do to defend them against multinationals?

name: Annie SCHREIJER-PIERIK
text: "blue card" answer. – In concrete terms, I would simply suggest that we rectify today, through the amendments and the resolution, what is now the leak in all the proposals. Because that is what is being discussed today, and that is something we must clearly initiate. If we leave it the way it is, nothing else will happen.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the One request to the Commission: please take the unity of the House with you and step up your activities. The four points that are important to us have been mentioned by my colleagues: firstly, the prevention of monopolies. Secondly, it is a question of scientific freedom, the so-called breeder's privilege, and the word privilege annoys me again. This is not a privilege, it is simply a question of breeders retaining their scientific freedom, of keeping the farmer free to choose, and of ensuring that living beings are not patented. Once again, this motion for a resolution is a wake-up call to the Commission. The actual practice of the Patent Office is contrary to our political convictions. You must now clarify: is it the legal basis, or is it the implementation? If it is the legal basis, then we need to change the legal basis. If it is the implementation, then the patent offices need appropriate handouts.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the recent decision of the European Patent Office only creates a new obstacle for the little ones. The european office's right to patent must not hinder innovation and must not create problems for SMEs, small producers.  Commissioner Bieńkowska, you yourself, Mr Juncker, often talk to us about the importance of innovation, the need to support SMEs, but words are not enough. The Commission has an obligation to ensure that the exact opposite does not happen on the ground. You now have the opportunity, Commissioner, to demonstrate that you understand this. It cannot be that an office, be it also a patent office, annuls a regulation of the European Parliament by a narrow interpretation. It is important to strike a balance between regulations in the field of intellectual property and the development of biotechnology.  Commissioner, the Commission must give a very clear answer to Parliament and the producers in the field on this issue. Don't let biotechnology development, competitiveness, innovation get blocked. Also take into account the speed of decision-making, Commissioner. Manufacturers can't wait months, even years.  In closing, I wish you Merry Christmas, but think that your work also depends on the quality of people's lives.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, the recent decision of the European Patent Agency to patent characteristics of plant varieties developed through biological processes is completely unacceptable. This decision poses a threat to food production and food security, as it undermines their availability. It is a development that could lead to a monopoly of parts of the food market and give the real culprit of agricultural production to the multinationals in the agri-food sector, while crushing small and medium-sized farmers as well as farmers, for the benefit of the large producers in Germany and France. Large multinationals use patents to make super-profit and to determine economic developments in agriculture and livestock farming, ignoring the fact that they marginalise small farmers and deprive societies and citizens of useful agricultural goods, which they are now turning into expensive consumer products. Immediate intervention by the European Union is required. Thanks.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: – The Commission's reply has been much talked about the need to protect the biotechnology industry, but it seems to me that the protection of farmers' rights should be one of the most important for us. We are well aware that the vast majority of farmers themselves are engaged in breeding. We cannot allow small farmers to be destroyed by imposing on them the need to pay even for varieties derived from traditional breeding. Dear colleagues, I want to ask the question today – what do we have to defend – whether large corporations or farmers and consumers? If you choose farmers, then I call for support for the green registered amendments, especially in protecting farmers, so that they are not sued for inadvertent contamination of their varieties with the pollen of the patented plant.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: – In fact, there are some lessons to be learned from this debate today that we have talked about even less, but perhaps it will be worth it later, and I would like to turn to the Commission first and foremost. The big companies, especially multinationals, do indeed seek a monopoly position, but the only way capitalism works is that they want their investments, i.e. the money spent on research, to be somehow guaranteed to come back. If we tell them not to do this – I say, by the way, they do not – then european research institutes, European academies, should be at the forefront of development, and from this point of view I think that the Commission should consider how the European community can use taxpayers' money to help innovation at the level of academic research. That's what I'm suggesting.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I have listened carefully to the exchanges on the issues surrounding plant-related patents and plant breeders’ rights. I would like to thank the honourable Members for all their comments. I personally share some – and maybe several – of the concerns mentioned, and I intend to convey all these concerns to my colleague Elżbieta Bieńkowska, who is in charge of this matter. In closing, I will stress again a few key points. I could see the political will here to clarify the current legal situation on this issue, and I wish to assure you that the Commission is already considering all possible solutions. I am convinced that a pragmatic way of ensuring legal clarity can be found without the need to revise the Biotech Directive. We are ready to cooperate with the forthcoming Dutch Presidency in looking for workable and well-balanced solutions that can be put in place quickly and can be used by all parties involved.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The debate is closed. I have received four motions for resolutions to conclude this debate, in accordance with Rule 123 of the Rules of Procedure. The vote will take place today, Thursday 17 December at 12.00 p.m. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. – It is essential to safeguard the right of farmers to use and reproduce plant genetic material. This is a scale sufficient to, without compromising quality, allow the continuity of traditional and ancestral practices, such as the exchange of seeds in horticulture and agriculture, which contribute to preserving the diversity of plant varieties, especially those with little commercial interest. We must ensure a regulatory framework that promotes this diversity because it is up to them that the resilience of ecosystems depends and, ultimately, the preservation of the natural landscape as we know it today.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Ibrahim Halawa is facing the death penalty, which is accused of numerous crimes, but these are summed up in a single law, which is the protest law.  Ladies and gentlemen, let us be clear about this, since Al-Sisi ruled Egypt, we are well aware that this is a delicate situation and that we need to maintain a fruitful dialogue with that country, given precisely its geographical location and the tensions around it. But it is also true that it is not acceptable for us to use laws such as this and that we can only risk the death penalty in order to disagree. We should therefore use the force of dialogue that many of the Member States have with Egypt precisely to try to press for such a law to be removed and for Ibrahim Halawa to be released.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Author. – Colleagues, crammed into a cell in Egypt, beaten and tortured, as Irish citizen Ibrahim Halawa recently spent his 20th birthday. And why? Because he invoked his right to freedom of expression and freedom of association. With his hunger strike, he is now demanding the attention and help of the international community.  The 2011 elections gave millions of people a political voice for the first time, and there is no doubt that the Muslim brothers had little ear for dissident voices. But does the current regime do better? Is it less repressive, less autocratic? Personal freedoms in Egypt are even more limited today than under Mubarak and human rights abuses are widespread. Waving the death penalty exceeds all decency. It does not reflect the desire of the majority of Egyptians for a free, stable and democratic country. I therefore call on the Egyptian authorities to give Halawa and the hundreds of other prisoners a free and fair trial and to finally assume a role model for many other states in the region.

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: Author. – Ibrahim Halawa was arrested when he was 17. It's a child. There are international rules about how to deal with children in prisons. He's a few years on and he's not doing well. It's also not going well with the hundreds of people who have been arrested with him, people who are being brought into mass trials, who can't even hear how the trial is going, whose case hasn't actually been sorted out at all because they're all facing the same charge. This is the Egypt under el-Sisi.  This is also the Egypt where a lot of colleagues here say 'the Egypt with which we have to establish relations because it is our friend, our strategic partner in a troubled region, a partner who should help us to stabilise the region'. We are painfully wrong about that. This is a country that helps destabilize the region and el-Sissi is Mubarak 2.0.  People came out in opposition to Mubarak after heavy repression of decades and decades and will do so again in the future and we are actually looking away. We are now calling attention to Ibrahim Halawa. We hope he gets out, but we look away from what el-Sisi and his government are doing to the local Egyptian people. I want to mention three more names: Rena Netjes, Sue Turton and Dominic Kane. They are European journalists who were convicted in that whole Al Jazeera case when they were not there. They too deserve justice.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: author. – Mr President, Ibrahim Halawa and myself have a number of things in common. Two of them are that we are Irish citizens and we are European citizens. In that context, and crucially because Ibrahim Halawa was a minor when he was detained, I would ask the Egyptian authorities to unconditionally and immediately release Ibrahim Halawa to the Irish authorities. I use those words ‘immediately and unconditionally’ because Ibrahim Halawa has spent 849 days in prison and his trial has been adjourned ten times. I use those words ‘immediately and unconditionally’ because Ibrahim Halawa has been declared a prisoner of conscience by Amnesty International. I use those words because Ibrahim Halawa, along with 493 individuals, awaits a mass trial without any guarantee of a free and fair trial. Finally, I use those words ‘immediately and unconditionally’ because the Irish Government has requested his release under Presidential Decree Law 140. Finally, I acknowledge and commend the diplomatic and consular efforts of the Irish authorities and many of my MEP colleagues, who have raised this issue in Parliament on a number of occasions, and in particular my colleague Lynn Boylan, who has ensured that his name and his case will be remembered.

name: Seán KELLY
text: author. – Mr President, firstly I would like to thank all Groups in the House for their cooperation in tabling this resolution. As a result, we have unanimity. Also particular thanks to my co-authors, especially Marian Harkin and Lynn Boylan. As has been stated, it was Lynn Boylan’s initiative to bring the family out here that led us to table this resolution.  I also recognise the strategic role of Egypt in that part of the world and the good cooperation Europe, and indeed Ireland, has with Egypt on many fronts, but the case of Ibrahim Halawa is totally unacceptable. A 17-year-old Irish citizen caught up in the protests in Cairo in August 2013, arrested and kept in prison ever since in diabolical conditions, contravenes all declarations on human rights, and particularly the rights of a child. So I hope this resolution, in conjunction with the efforts of the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Charlie Flanagan, and the Irish Government, will convince the Egyptian authorities to resolve this issue and return Ibrahim to Ireland forthwith.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: author. – Mr President, I would first like to welcome Ibrahim’s sisters, Somaia and Omaima, who have campaigned tirelessly on their brother’s behalf, and who I am proud to have had the opportunity to work with over the last two years. This Resolution rightly condemns the fact that Ibrahim – a juvenile at the time of his arrest – faces a mass trial at which he is unable not only to testify, but even to hear the proceedings. I welcome that it is supported across the political spectrum, and especially by my Irish colleagues. Others have discussed the contents and the case of Ibrahim Halawa, so what I would like instead is to read the most recent note that Ibrahim had smuggled from prison. ‘Today is my 20th birthday, and, for the third time, I spend it alone. On this day, I would like to send my best to all those who believe in freedom and defend humanity; those who light a candle every night to remember the weak and oppressed. I do not know you personally, but I pray every sunset that it is time for your candles to light the path of freedom’.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Ibrahim Halawa faces a very difficult and harsh sentence in a mass trial, as has been mentioned, for his participation in the demonstration in central Cairo in August 2013 and, despite being 17 years old and therefore minor at the time of his arrest, the Egyptian Court did not take this into account, in violation of the International Convention on the Rights of the Child to which Egypt acceded.  Several sources report that Halawa was subjected to torture and other ill-treatment during his arrest and detention and, if found guilty, risks the death penalty. In May 2015, Egypt sentenced five people to death, one of whom was the same age as Ibrahim Halawa. Any death sentence is wrong, but it is even more wrong if it is imposed on a person who, at the time he committed the crime, was seventeen years old, and it is clear that this is incompatible with Egypt's international obligations. We are therefore concerned and call for the full release of him and other detainees who demonstrated that day.

name: Brian HAYES
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I join with other colleagues in welcoming this joint motion from all parties. I especially congratulate those who have campaigned tirelessly for Ibrahim Halawa in the course of the last number of years, and I recognise especially the work of Ms Boylan in that regard. Ibrahim Halawa is not just an Irish citizen: as Ms Harkin said, he is a European Union citizen. The European Union is built on freedom, rights and fundamental human rights, which are inscribed in European law. We expect the European Union to believe in those rights and to apply them, and equally we expect third countries with which we have a relationship to uphold those rights as well.  I ask the Egyptian authorities to take note of the fact that this Parliament is speaking with one voice today. I ask them, especially, to use Law 140 which, as I understand it, requires a presidential decree allowing Ibrahim Halawa to come home to Ireland, and which has been used in other cases. We need to speak with one voice, and I think the House has done a great service today in highlighting this case.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Ibrahim Halawa is a tragic case because it shows what can happen to an individual if human rights and the rule of law are not taken seriously. It would be easy for the Egyptian authorities – in this case at least – to prove the opposite image. However, Ibrahim Halawa is not just an isolated case, it shows a systematic contempt for human rights and the rule of law in Egypt, and it is particularly painful that it is happening in Egypt, because Egypt is an important partner for the EU, because we appreciate Egypt's efforts in the fight against terror and because we are interested in a stable Egypt. Real stability can only be achieved if democracy and the rule of law are respected. Otherwise it's like a pressure cooker: at some point it explodes.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, in Egypt human rights, the rule of law, the right to a fair trial and fundamental freedoms are trampled on, and el—Sisi’s oppressive regime has too many victims. Egyptians seeking freedom and democracy say that the repression is now worse than it was under President Mubarak. The EU should not turn a blind eye, because cooperation without addressing human rights gives a false sense of stability and will prove unsustainable. Do I believe that the Muslim Brotherhood seeks to advance justice, freedom, democracy and pluralism? No. I worry about the dogma and sectarianism of Islamist politics. Yet those Muslim Brotherhood supporters who demonstrated in 2013, as Ibrahim Halawa did, are innocent until proven guilty – or at least they should be. His human rights must be respected. A mass trial cannot be a fair trial. On Sunday last, as one of the 420 co-defendants was not present, the trial was postponed. The circumstances in Egyptian prisons are notorious. Given the fact that Mr Halawa is Irish and was 17 when he was arrested, we call for his release by presidential decree under Egyptian Law 140.

name: Diane JAMES
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, the British have a phrase ‘the elephant in the room’ to describe a matter that is completely obvious but which no-one wants to recognise. In the area of breaches of human rights, the European Union has its own elephant in the room and it is called Turkey. I raise this today because, at every Strasbourg session, we debate human rights abuses and here we are this morning debating Mr Halawa. Yet Turkey is a country which will receive EUR 3 billion to stem the migrant flow, and nothing has been demanded in relation to its human rights abuses and standards. What message does that send? I should love to see something positive come out of our deliberations and speeches this morning, but I fear it will be more hot air and double standards. Unless we actually resolve the confusion created yesterday in terms of Turkey’s accession to the EU, we will not address the issues or the double standards that this Chamber keeps on applying to cases like that of Mr Halawa and others across Europe.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). Mr President, Ibrahim Halawa is a young Irish-Egyptian who has been held since 2013 in a Cairo prison along with 493 other people, accused of a string of criminal offences including destruction and damage to public property and even the murder of civilians. According to european Union data, Mr President-in-Office of the European Union has been violated. Halawa because he has been held for two years without his trial yet to be determined because he has been tortured because he has been deprived of the possibility of receiving medical treatment and, finally, because he faces the risk of the death penalty, despite the fact that he was only seventeen years old when he was arrested. For its part, Egypt says that Mr. Trump's human rights have not been violated. Halawa, mentions the offences to which he has committed and suggests that he will receive a fair trial and that, where appropriate, the President of the Republic will release him from serving the remainder of his sentence when the outcome of the trial is announced. The Halawa case is one of many cases of human rights violations around the world. My view is that the awareness and mobilisation of the European Union, combined with the fact that the Halawa case is being closely monitored by the officials of the Irish Consulate in Cairo, will result in the release of Mr Halawa. Halawa regardless of the outcome of the trial. After all, Egypt is one of the countries that has close economic and political relations with the European Union and will not want to destroy them for the sake of Mr Halawa. What we need to be interested in is finding and treating and vindicating many cases of people who look like Mr. Halawa but not yet known. Finally, it would be good for the European Union to ensure that the rights of European citizens in its Member States are not violated, which, as you know very well, has happened in our country Greece with our own party as a victim.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Ibrahim Halawa was 17 when he was accused, along with 494 others, of attacking national security forces during protests in Cairo. He faces the death penalty. The number of death sentences in Egypt has increased markedly in recent years. Twelve people have already been executed this year. Halawa exercised his democratic right to freedom of expression and peaceful assembly. His trial has been postponed many times. After the last such ruling, this young man began a hunger strike. He and the other defendants should be treated fairly, openly and fairly in accordance with international standards. He was also restricted from accessing correspondence in English. There are suspicions that he may have been tortured. I call on the Egyptian authorities to stop the widespread human rights violations, the acquittal of Ibrahim Halawa, a citizen of the European Union. Egypt must also ratify the Convention on the Prohibition of Torture, signed in 1986, and move away from the death penalty.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Human rights violations in Egypt are of great concern to the international public. The Egyptian authorities ignore fundamental civil liberties, including the right to assembly, protest or freedom of expression. Irish teenager Ibrahim Halawa has been held in a Cairo prison for more than two years and is one of five hundred other prisoners of conscience. He faces the death penalty. Officially, the process cannot start for organisational and logistical reasons. None of Egypt's courtrooms can accommodate a record number of defendants.  On the day of his arrest in August 2013, the military and police stormed a mosque in Ramses Square, where several hundred demonstrators were sheltering, killing 97 people and arresting the rest. Condemning the restriction of the right to freedom of association and freedom of expression, we call on the Egyptian authorities to release without delay all prisoners convicted of fighting for civil and political freedoms. In accordance with Article 10 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, every person has the right to be heard fairly and publicly by an independent and impartial court. There is still a lack of respect for this principle in Egypt.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I profess the value of universality of fundamental human rights, and I am therefore shocked by this case, which really concerns an Irish citizen, a citizen of the European Union. I would like to remind you that our delegations go abroad very often. I think that, for example, we should send special commissions as part of our travels, asking the Egyptian authorities to be able to visit this citizen directly by our representatives, because I cannot imagine actually waiting in his shoes somewhere in the stinking dungeon of an Egyptian prison for my fundamental human right to a fair trial for so long. I would very much like us to have, for example, our delegations that go abroad. they were heading towards those citizens, and this is not the first case, this case of Ibrahim Halawa. Earlier, we discussed the case of a Baltic national who was also detained by Russian authorities. For this reason, I would also like our delegations to go to these countries where human rights violations are taking place.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, we are talking about Irish national Ibrahim Halawa, a European Union citizen potentially facing the death penalty in Egypt, for his participation in a demonstration in Cairo. The Egyptian authorities have not yet proceeded with Halawa's trial, since it is constantly postponed, and there is a possibility that, if convicted, he will be given the death penalty. At the same time, his detention has already lasted two years. We therefore call on the Egyptian authorities to release Ibrahim Halawa and we stand by the struggle of colleagues from Ireland, pointing out, furthermore, Mr President, that the European Union must seek the abolition of the death penalty, where it is applied, and ask the countries that still apply it to comply with international standards.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Mr. President, Ibrahim Halawa is an Irish citizen. A citizen of one Member State of the European Union and ours, in addition to this debate that is necessary in this Parliament, to ask the High Commissioner and our Committee for Cooperation with Egypt to immediately put on the table a discussion with our Egyptian friends on how to free Mr. Halawa and how to prevent him from experiencing the worst, which is the death penalty.  Egypt is our partner, Egypt is our friend, we want cooperation with Egypt, but Egypt also has its obligations to us, especially when these obligations are related to our nationals, citizens of our Ireland, our member states. We expect President al-Sisi to resolve this situation by decree, as this would be the best way and the best indication that Egypt wants cooperation with the European Union.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Mr President, listening to this debate I was motivated to speak when I had the opportunity. I rise to thank the House for the cross-party support across Member States with their genuine concern for an Irish citizen, because he is a citizen of the European Union. I hope his family take heart from today’s presentation, but more importantly, I hope the Egyptian authorities understand our concerns, and listen to the words we use. We have got to work with them to find a resolution, and this is releasing Mr Halawa and sending him home to his family. As we speak he languishes in prison. I can only begin to imagine what that must be like for him. Yesterday at the Sakharov Prize we heard of a similar situation. So thank you to the House. I hope our words resonate. I hope we get the result we all call for.

name: Nessa CHILDERS
text: – Mr President, I am hoping that the debate today will give at least some comfort to Ibrahim’s family, some of whom are here. I would like to remind everyone that this is not only about the situation with human rights, but also the rights of the child. Ibrahim was 17 when he went to jail, when he was imprisoned. How many others are in prison at that age? How many others have lost their lives? We really have to imagine what it might be like to be a child in those circumstances, if it were our child – and it is, in fact, as Ibrahim is an Irish citizen. I hope the Egyptian authorities are listening to our concerns. I hope they are taking on board the concerns of the European Union. It is a case concerning the rights of the child, as well as the rights of an adult human being.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: – Mr President, thank you for the opportunity to contribute to this debate. At the outset, I would like to thank all those who supported this motion and particularly to congratulate our colleague Lynn Boylan for her efforts in bringing us to this point. I welcome the family of Ibrahim Halawa, and that they are here today to witness the contributions. In my view, the most important point in this debate is that this young person, Ibrahim, was a child, just 17 years of age when he was arrested and detained. I think that should be at the forefront in all our deliberations. He has been in prison for some considerable time and is now 20 years of age. I, like others, would appeal to the Egyptian authorities to recognise that he is an Irish citizen and a European citizen, to hear our words today and to release Ibrahim so that he can return to Ireland and to his family. I understand that they have their own systems there, but I think that at this point, for a young man who has been detained for so long without his case reaching trial – the trial has again been deferred this week to Saturday – it is a very difficult situation. He was a juvenile, only 17 years of age, and I think that is a very important consideration.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, of course we are deeply concerned about the possibility that one of our citizens might face the death penalty. Ibrahim Halawa, an Irish-Egyptian citizen, now faces the risk not only of a lengthy sentence but also the death penalty, should he be convicted.  We have closely followed Ibrahim Halawa’s situation since his arrest in 2013. The High Representative/Vice President Federica Mogherini herself has been in regular contact with the Irish and Egyptian authorities concerning his case. While this remains a consular issue, we have aimed to support Irish efforts to achieve the release and improve the detention conditions of Ibrahim Halawa, working in full agreement with Ireland in addressing his case in a coordinated manner. At the same time, we have sought to tackle the case in the context of a broader EU effort to address the human rights situation in Egypt.  Last month we resumed the political and human rights dialogue with Egypt, the first in five years. It is of particular relevance to the case at hand that we urge Egypt to meet international fair trial standards. This includes trials without undue delays and requires that Egypt refrain from mass trials and, consequently, handing down mass sentences. We of course noted our strong opposition to the use of the death penalty under all circumstances. We will be continuing discussions with Egypt on justice in the relevant dialogue, in the framework of the EU-Egypt Association Agreement. We will thus seek further improvements, including on judicial proceedings: not least with regard to minors who are detained with adults, rather than in juvenile detention centres, and who are tried as adults rather than by juvenile court judges. You will be aware that Ibrahim Halawa was 17 years old when arrested.  We also systematically address mass trials, which violate due legal process as they fail to determine individual criminal responsibility by bringing identical charges against groups of accused. In addition, such mass trials bring prolonged detention conditions which are in breach of Article 9 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. We are very pleased with the good cooperation with this House in our effort to improve the human rights situation in Egypt and count on your continued support. (Applause)

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place at the end of the debate. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. – The arbitrary detention of Irish citizen Ibrahim Halawa represents a violation of human rights, international and Egyptian law. It is totally unacceptable for people to be detained, tortured and treated in an inhuman manner just because they have exercised their core human rights of freedom of expression and assembly. What is more, Ibrahim Halawa is potentially facing the death penalty for both his ‘crimes’ (freedom of expression and peaceful assembly).  The EU is the leading institutional actor and largest donor to the fight against the death penalty and is committed to abolition of the death penalty worldwide. Having regard to that, we should condemn not only the application of the death penalty in Egypt but also we should call on the country’s authorities for the immediate release of the European citizen Ibrahim Halawa who has faced unfair trial.  Last but not least, the EU should engage in a constructive dialogue with the Egyptian authorities in order to change its low level human rights record. As our common European history teaches us, better human rights record equals development, peace and prosperity. These are things that our partner Egypt needs right now.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: Writing. – I would like to join those who express serious concerns about the fate of Ibrahim Halawa. I am not doing this because he is an Irish citizen and therefore a citizen of the European Union. Not even because I dare say he's completely innocent. I do so because I consider the death penalty that Ibrahim Halawa faces to be fatal. This cannot be remedied under conditions where there can be additionally proven innocence or lesser guilt than stated in the action, or when the political situation and thus the political order change. I don't think any of us should be entitled to judge the degree of guilt in situations like this. We are too far away, and the time when the alleged law was law enforcement was very tumultuous. But what we must always and always promote is the right to a fair trial. And a court hearing in which nearly 500 people are suddenly found guilty at once does not allow a fair trial. What is certain is that Egypt and the entire MENA region, the Middle East and North Africa, need stabilisation, reconstruction and new pathways of development. Egypt, in particular, more than two years after the military coup and a year and a half after the new presidential elections, should be looking for ways to a broader national dialogue. This is very important at a time when Egypt, together with us, is facing terrorist attacks. It's time for reconciliation gestures.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: in writing. – The case of Mr Ibrahim Halawa is considered to be in breach of both international law and human rights. Mr Halawa is potentially facing the death penalty. According to the Egyptian authorities Mr Ibrahim Halawa, who is an Irish and Egyptian citizen, is guilty of exercising violence and direct involvement in killing several civilians, and therefore is tried in accordance with the Egyptian law.
