Moreover, the Egyptian authorities claim that all of the accusations directed at their legal system and the fact that they are breaching international law are invalid and that the Egyptian judiciary is considered to be an independent and just unit.  However, I find this to be not exactly true. Apparently, the defendant is being kept in a court in a soundproof cell, which means that he is denied his right to follow the allegations. Moreover, the potential death penalty is a breach of the right to life and the situation should be handled by people who have respect for human rights. Mr Halawa, even if guilty, should be given a just, unbiased trial by the independent judiciary without a threat of facing the loss of his life.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on the situation in the Maldives.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Maldives archipelago is not only the place enchanted by the beautiful beaches, blue lagoons and wide cliffs with which we are all familiar, but it is also the place where many rights are violated.  Many workers, especially from Bangladesh and India, employed in luxury facilities are exploited and underpaid. There is also a continuing abuse of the judicial system where many political opponents are wrongly accused and imprisoned. What is more, growing religious intolerance increases the climate of terror and reduces the space for all kinds of public discussion. The government continues to violate international obligations on issues relating to torture and other cruel acts, discrimination against women and issues relating to political and civil rights.  However, the worst violation of human rights in the Maldives at the moment concerns the reintroduction and possible application of the death penalty as an instrument of political repression. We call on the European Union and therefore all the Member States to remember our strict position against the death penalty and the fact that the death penalty violates the most important right, namely the right to life, and inflicts the additional condemnation of psychological torture.

name: Jean LAMBERT
text: author. – Mr President, I also speak in my capacity as Chair of the Delegation for relations with South Asia, which includes the Maldives.  I would agree that the current situation in the Maldives is of very great concern to us. We have heard the reference to looking again at the death penalty, which has not been used in the Maldives since the 1950s, and that is a huge concern. The new Constitution of the Maldives is less than 10 years old and we are obviously seeing a process of democratic development with which this Parliament had been closely engaged. But we are seeing things moving backwards, not forwards. Key elements of a democratic constitution are the separation of powers, not least between the President and the judiciary, and that is not what we are seeing at the moment. We want an impartial judiciary, where people are equal before the law, where the law applies equally to everyone and where we do not see laws adapted to deal with particular individuals, most notably former President Nasheed. We also want to see a judiciary which is improved. It is widely recognised by all political parties in the Maldives that the quality of the judiciary needs upgrading.  Strong independent institutions are also important. We have seen the Human Rights Commission there under attack. We are seeing the media clamped down on again and greatly reduced space for civil society and democratic opposition. This is the wrong direction of travel, and that is why the idea of sanctions is in the resolution to try to encourage progress in the way we wish to see.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: Acting author. Mr President, forgive me, I am replacing Mr Nart, who is late. There are singular places around the world, Mr. President. Those who just spend there, especially on holiday, usually describe an almost heavenly experience, but among those who live there, many experience hell. This is the case in the Maldives, a country that re-established Sharia law in 2014 and provides that the death penalty is applicable in some cases to children as young as 7 years old, a minor sentenced to death until he or she is executed and then executed, a country that provides for non-marriage sex to be sanctioned by the whip or stoning. , even in cases of rape - a young woman was recently flogged in public after being gang-raped. Commissioner, we in the Commission and in Parliament are multiplying the mandatory instructions on food or other products, which are handing out quality labels, do you not think that we should think or ask tourism operators to think about adequate labels to distinguish tourist destinations according to their respect for fundamental human rights.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: author. – Mr President, in 2008 Mohamed Nasheed was elected President of the Maldives, bringing an end to Maumoon Abdul Gayoom’s 35 years of dictatorship. Nasheed stood on a platform of promoting democracy, secularism and the rule of law. Nasheed did much to enact such a programme, as well as to address the long-term problems that this small island nation continues to face from global warming and rising sea levels. Nasheed was replaced in what is widely accepted to have been a coup. Today, Gayoom’s daughter is the country’s Foreign Minister and his half—brother Abdulla Gayoom is President. Not content with targeting opposition figures from former President Nasheed down, the administration has resorted to arresting its own members. Following what was allegedly a staged assassination attempt on Gayoom, his Vice-President has now been arrested and charged. As freedom of the media, expression and association are clamped down on, Gayoom appears to be reconstructing a one—party authoritarian state, based on the model of his half-brother, and pandering to local Islamist radical influences. Today’s resolution calls for the European Union and the Member States to consider the implementation of targeted sanctions and travel bans against leading members of the Government and their financial backers. Anything short of this will fail to secure the release of former President Mohamed Nasheed and to bring about the change that this small country so desperately needs.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: author. – Mr President, the situation in the Maldives is alarming on three levels: firstly, the worsening of the democracy in the country; secondly, the lack of impartiality of state institutions; and thirdly, the politically motivated case of the former President Nasheed. The gradual curbing of fundamental freedoms, including the right to protest, freedom of expression, freedom of assembly, freedom of association and media freedoms is alarming. We are also worried about the judiciary and its politicisation. The conduct of the trial of former President Nasheed is proof in itself, with a clear political agenda and a flawed process. This is why we have a broad cross-party consensus in the European Parliament and why we call for targeted sanctions on certain members of the Maldivian Government and their supporters.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: Author. Mr President, in 2008 the Maldives did experience the first multi-party elections in its history. This was short-lived because, as early as 2012, Mr. Nasheed, the president, was overthrown by a coup d'état. Since then, he has been sentenced to 13 years in prison for terrorism after a trial deemed contrary to Maldives law, including by the UN Commissioner for Human Rights, and his detention has been described as arbitrary. He is ill and needs care that requires transfer abroad.  It is a symbol, as more than 1,700 people are now believed to be held in prison for political reasons in the Maldives. The repression is all over the place. The moratorium on the death penalty has been abolished and criminal liability is effectively set at 10 years or even 7 years. In this liberticidal climate and this context of high inequality, the Maldives would be the country in the region that sends the most young people to Iraq and Syria, relative to its total population.  In this country heavily dependent on tourism, and in particular European tourism, the government recently passed a law prohibiting any call for a boycott. Catastrophe is on the rise in this small country, which is threatened by rising waters as a result of climate change.  So yes, the European Union must act and it has the means to do so.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are deeply concerned about the progressive deterioration of democratic standards and the rise of authoritarian impulses in the Maldives, as well as the repression of political opponents and intimidation of the media and civil society.  We want to insist that the Maldives Government must respect the decisions of the United Nations, which called on the authorities to release former President Nasheed immediately. In addition, members of the opposition who face charges must be guaranteed legal proceedings, in compliance with the Maldives Constitution and the international obligations of due process. All forms of violence, including violence against peaceful demonstrators, must be stopped immediately, and we call for an immediate end to political interference in the Maldives judicial system.  Urgent reforms are needed to ensure the independence and impartiality of the Maldives judiciary, with the aim of restoring internal and international confidence in its functioning.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, this is not the first time this year that we have been talking about the Maldives. We have done it before, to signal that things are going in a very bad direction in this country. Since then, former President Nasheed has been imprisoned again, although for two months it had been said that, for medical reasons, he could serve his sentence at home. It's a political condemnation, and that's the key issue, because after the state we're talking about started to function normally, everything was overturned by the long domination of a family. As my colleague Kukan also suggested, I believe that we must consider individual sanctions concerning those who are responsible for an unacceptable situation, for the control of justice, for blocking the opposition, for sending those who fight for rights to prison.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, the current human rights situation in the Maldives is not a picture postcard. The crackdown on political opponents, the state of emergency invoked by executive powers, the reintroduction of the death penalty, and the disappearance of journalists like Ahmed Rilwan demonstrate that democracy is spiralling out of control. But it is not just the human rights of journalists and political opponents that are at risk. According to diplomats, the Maldives are sending more fighters per capita to Iraq and Syria than any other country in the world. More than 200 jihadists – from a nation of just 350 000 – are believed to be fighting there. This Parliament should be concerned that President Yameen’s call for increased reliance on Sharia Law, and the threat of punishments such as flogging, risk legitimising rather than combating such radicalisation.  In our last resolution in April 2015, we called on the European External Action Service and Member States to issue warnings about the Maldives’ human rights record on their travel advice sites, and to consider targeted sanctions should human rights further deteriorate. In the meantime, an execution chamber has been prepared for former President Nasheed. Now is the time to make good on our own words and to intensify European action for human rights in the Maldives.

name: Javier NART
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I think it's all said; and, Commissioner, you must be a little tired of constantly listening to the same expressions. When in the European Parliament all political groups agree and there is no discordant voice, it means that reality is what is and is extraordinarily harsh.  I do not want to list here the human rights violations, something that those who have previously used the word have done very well. What I mean is, if we don't go from words to deeds and statements to realities, what we do is a beautiful exercise in rhetoric. Consequently, the Union's necessary response is the prohibition of access to the European Union for certain people, the freezing of their assets in Europe and the warning to people who go on tourism there as to what type of tourism they are going to find. If not, we will stay in an exercise in hypocrisy, to say the right thing but to do the wrong thing.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, as my colleague has just said, when we see the image of European citizens in the Maldives, we say to ourselves: 'it is a paradise on the sea, with the floating villages of Club Med'. Yet there, for the people, it is hell.  Former President Mohamed Nasheed, the first and only democratically elected president, remains in prison. What for? Because he rightly accuses his rivals of instrumentalizing Islam.  We see that constitutional rights are being violated, that the justice system in the Maldives is totally corrupt. The death penalty has been reinstated and even children over the age of 7 can face the death penalty, imprisoned up to 18 years, the age of their execution.  In addition, a state of emergency was declared by the government for six days last month. But what can we do? First of all, as far as travel agencies are concerned, I think we have to tell them that it is imperative that we no longer offer this destination to holidaymakers. I also call for the responsibility of tourists: they must no longer go to the Maldives. Alone, we have the power to suffocate the only rent available to the power in place, which is precisely tourism. If we want to change this regime, we need sanctions. Sanctions are first and foremost us: it is up to us, the future tourists, not to go there. But Europe too can act, because it is the Maldives' second largest trading partner. We have to find ways to coerce power. In particular, we must put in place targeted measures against government supporters, from freezing their assets abroad to banning travel to Europe.  We must act, Commissioner. We are all responsible, also with regard to the situation in the Maldives.  (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (in accordance with Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Thank you for accepting my question, congratulations on your speech. I agree with you, I have only one question that I do not hide, not only in this debate about the Maldives. Is it not the case that we, as the European Union, should not only benefit from the tourist boycott instrument – as you say, I agree with this – but also exert some economic pressure on this country? Perhaps this would be the only effective pressure for the state to change its policy in the Maldives.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: "blue card" answer. "I agree, and that is the meaning of my intervention. There are several responsibilities. First, if we decide to go to the Maldives when we know the hell that the population is going through, we become co-responsible. You have to say no to the travel agencies that offer to go to the Maldives, because if you go there, you strengthen the power in place.  Secondly, at the european level: why am I calling on the current European Commissioner? Well, because if we have trade agreements, we have to be able to lobby. How do we get these people moving? If we don't do something, we're complicit. To do nothing is to be complicit in the situation. So we all have a role to play.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this is not the first time that we have found ourselves talking about the Maldives, a country that is at the same time a still tourist paradise, but increasingly a hell of democracy and human, civil and political rights.  The current government is now prey to an incredible authoritarian turn that has also led to a strong politicisation of the judiciary and corruption and, above all, to tolerance of Islamic extremism. We have seen pictures of Daesh flags parade through the streets of the capital and all this is happening while there is still a great curtain of silence, while our tour operators continue to propose it as a destination, as if there were no population that is even 16% below the poverty line; As if there were not, moreover, the problem of climate change, which had been vigorously addressed by former President Nasheed, who was deposed and has so far been imprisoned without due process.  Yes, we need strong and appropriate sanctions against those who are committing these blatant violations of the rule of law. Yes, goods must be frozen and tourism must be stopped in order to strangle those who are destroying human rights. Let the Democrats in the Maldives feel our support because they never need us today.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, this is a point where there is, in principle, absolute agreement among all Members on the situation in the Maldives and that this matter must be addressed and not just discussed. I am joining in what has been said here, I just want to emphasise, as a person who monitors and studies the form of the laws of the countries of the world, that the law situation in the Maldives is deteriorating significantly, that the judiciary there is simply objectively under the influence of the current President, and that the former democratically elected President of The Nasda has been removed, among other things, because he was referring to corrupt judges. That was one of the reasons he was removed from office at the time. I also point out that under the current government, the current administration, the Attorney General has been unlawfully removed from office. Thus, there is no law in the Maldives, and we should not only talk about it, but I join other colleagues who say that this must have an impact on relations between the European Union and the Maldives and that our tourists should not go to the Maldives and that we should freeze the assets of the local government and prevent access to the countries of the European Union.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: – We are deeply concerned, because in the Maldives we are seeing a growing trend towards the establishment of an authoritarian regime of repression against political opponents, the intimidation of the media and civil society, which could jeopardise the progress made in recent years in strengthening human rights, democracy and the rule of law in that country.  The conviction of former Maldives President Mohamed Nasheed to thirteen years in prison on terrorism charges, as well as prominent state politicians following trials that have failed to comply with national and international justice rules raises great concerns about the fairness and transparency of judicial proceedings.  The European External Action Service has a duty to play a proactive role in the Union's bilateral relations with the Maldives, including at international level, in order to achieve stability, strengthening democracy and the rule of law.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I am really proud of the incredible unity that is being heard from this Parliament, and thank you, colleagues, for that. I would like to begin my speech by quoting what the imprisoned President of The United State said in February of this year. 'It's good and necessary to have a relaxing holiday, but it's important to understand what's happening here too.' And I think that is precisely what our message expresses, not only in the Maldives, but also in our own European citizens. I would also like to quote what specific freedoms are now suspended in the Maldives. It is the freedom to do what is not errant, the protection of privacy, the right to strike, freedom of assembly, freedom of movement, entering and leaving the islands, the protection against gratuitous arrest and attachment, the confiscation of property, is suspended. All these freedoms are stopped and European citizens should be informed of this when they go to these islands. Otherwise, I join the call for sanctions and suspension of trade agreements. (The speaker agreed to answer the question asked by raising the Blue Card (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: Blue card question. I wanted to ask my colleague, I think like him about what he said, but given that Europe, looking at the world, says human rights and we must be careful, would he agree to sanction, for example, China on the death penalty or Saudi Arabia on the death penalty? In other words, would he agree to ensure that Europe not only in words but also in concrete actions, or some country, some State of the United States applying the death penalty?

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – I also spoke yesterday about relations with China, I profess the universality of the values of fundamental human rights, that is what I said here, and I do not think that the European Union should give up the right to speak on these issues, which you have also shared here. I share my concerns with Respect to China, to Saudi Arabia, but also to other states, and I do not think that the European Union should remain silent, even if they are, for example, essential trading partners. We certainly have the right to say our point of view.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, the Maldives, this land-based tourist paradise to the delight of European and American holidaymakers, is in fact a human rights hell. The country's president had declared a state of emergency, which has been lifted due to diplomatic pressure. The young democratic regime in the Maldives, established in 2008, remains extremely unstable and fragile, while at the same time the threat of jihadists in the country is real. The state of emergency was declared almost at the same time as anti-government protests were organised due to the imprisonment of the country's former president. European states should not interfere in the internal affairs of third states. At the same time, however, the human and political and trade union and labour rights of citizens in the Maldives must be respected. European citizens should be aware that the idyllic beaches in the Maldives are only the tip of the iceberg, while its unseen side includes human rights violations, poverty, social impoverishment and the imposition of the Islamic State, where Sharia is applied.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, political interference in the Maldivian judiciary undermines the credibility of the country’s judicial system, and the reported detention and intimidation of government opponents contributes to a climate of instability in this country. Moreover, it seems that human rights in the Maldives have been seriously eroded and are at risk of further deterioration, while the government is failing in its duty to stop the trend and while human rights NGOs face increasing attacks, intimidation and harassment in the country. I therefore express my deepest concerns about the gradual deterioration of democratic standards and increasing authoritarian tendencies, such as the use of violence by police against peaceful protesters. It is the duty of the security forces to protect peaceful demonstrators against violent gangs. We must continue to monitor closely the political situation in the Maldives and to play a proactive role in increasing stability, strengthening democracy and the rule of law, and ensuring full respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms in this country.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I am speaking here on behalf of my colleague, High Representative/Vice- President of the European Commission Federica Mogherini, who cannot attend today’s debate. We are here today to debate the human rights situation in the Maldives. Let me remind this House of the continued leadership of the Maldives in the Alliance of Small Island States (AOSIS) in the context of the COP21 negotiations in Paris. What happened in Paris is an important example of the role the Maldives can play in the international community. The last debate in the European Parliament on the Human Rights situation in the Maldives took place in April. In the last eight months, the government of the country is increasingly pursuing policies that will isolate it from the international community – policies that are reversing the hard-won advances in freedom and democracy for which so many Maldivians have dedicated their lives. The increased intolerance of opposition and free speech breeds a climate of fear and anger, with the very real risk of radicalism emerging in the country.  The persecution and continued incarceration of opposition political figures undermines the credibility of the government. The lack of judicial independence raises serious questions about the rule of law in this country. Serious concerns continue to be expressed, not only by the European Union, about, firstly, political interference with the judiciary; secondly, the unconstitutional interpretation of laws; and thirdly, the overnight changes to the constitution aimed at consolidating power. It is essential that the government moves quickly to alleviate these widely shared concerns and restore the rule of law. Real independence of the judiciary is paramount in preserving trust in the system and equitable treatment of all Maldivians. On the positive side, the Maldives are applying a de facto moratorium on the use of the death penalty. We encourage the authorities to maintain it in all circumstances, particularly in cases that involve juvenile offenders, and to work towards abolishing the practice altogether. The European Union wants to make it absolutely clear that there will be a serious setback in relations with the EU if the Maldives restarts executions after more than 60 years of moratorium. It would be a backward step which would not go unnoticed by the European public at large. The European Union is increasingly concerned about the risk of radicalisation in the Maldives and about the number of Maldivians who are, unfortunately, joining Da’esh or other fundamentalist groups in Syria and Iraq. The EU is ready to work with the Government of the Maldives to further the fundamental values of democracy, human rights and the rule of law, but it is the responsibility of the Maldivian Government to ensure the safety of the hundreds of thousands of tourists who currently visit the archipelago every year. The Government of the Maldives has accepted, fortunately, the offer of the EU to send a legal expert to assess the legislative framework, the procedures and practices of the judiciary, and the implementation of the new penal code. We hope this will help highlight those areas where respect for rule of law should be improved, in line with international standards. Progress in the rule of law can be an important step for the government to show its willingness to cooperate with the international community on the critical issues of democracy and human rights. I hope to see this in practice.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place at the end of the debate. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: in writing. – The Maldives reintroduced the death penalty last year after 60 years was banned, and last month the Maldives government included in the budget an amount of more than 200,000 euros to build execution rooms by lethal injection. Women continue to be whipped or sentenced to death for adultery. The Maldives authorities are blatantly violating human rights and the situation has worsened in recent years. Mahfooz Saeed, a human rights lawyer, was stabbed in September. Ahmed Rilwan Abdulla, a famous journalist, disappeared in 2014. The Maldives authorities must abandon the death penalty and other serious human rights violations. Terror does not strengthen, but weakens any government.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on Malaysia.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union's free trade agreements are based primarily on economic criteria, taking into account respect for environmental and social standards, including human rights, within the framework of coherent policy. Human rights are mentioned in the preamble to the agreement, but it is not binding.  Malaysia, with regard to the human rights of indigenous peoples and minorities, is unfortunately still very late and there are numerous violations. Land rights are a major concern of NGOs, the state envisages the construction of fifty hydraulic dams in the east of the country by 2030 to the detriment of the environment and the lands of the indigenous peoples. Dams that could lead to the displacement of tens of thousands of inhabitants and flood hundreds of square kilometers of tropical forest.  There are major corruption problems, the state of Sarawak is the subject of speculation by all foreign investors. According to NGOs, 80% of the rainforest has already been destroyed to make way for palm oil plantations. Malaysia is in fact one of the most corrupt countries in the world. Now I say, let us use the instrument of free trade agreements to strengthen this defence of human rights because this is our chance.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Author. – Malaysia is slipping into an authoritarian state. Today it is risky to manifest peacefully and to wear, for example, a yellow T-shirt, because that color became synonymous with treason. So much fear of democracy does not bode well. The National Front - or Barisan Nasional - has been in power for 58 years, but still bases its legitimacy on archaic colonial laws: freedom of expression and the press can be too easily restricted. The legislative proposals are largely based on Sharia law. And did Malaysia not declare that it wishes to present itself as a moderate Islamic state fighting Islamic extremism? And what about the rights of minority groups? Indigenous peoples such as the Orang Asli continue to face the problem of recognition of their property rights. I call on the government to respect parliamentary democracy. The Union must exert pressure and use the ongoing negotiations on the Free Trade Agreement and the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to thank the In Malaysia, restrictive laws are used to severely restrict the right to freedom of assembly and expression.  In particular, civil society actors who are critical of the government risk being imprisoned and get politically motivated trials. Critical voices are regularly confronted with accusations of alleged activities that endanger the state. This Sedition Act of 1948 dates back to the colonial era.  In the first half of this year alone, more than 40 people were interrogated, detained or charged with alleged activities that endangered the state. In October, for example, blogger and political activist Khalid Ismath was indicted by a court on the basis of the Communication and Multimedia Act and this Sedition Act for publications in which he criticized abuses of power. People have also been arrested under security laws, according to politician Khairuddin Abu Hassan, who was arrested in September for reporting on the corruption scandal of a state-owned investment company.  That is why we are calling on the Malaysian Government to release and lift the charges for all those persecuted for their peaceful exercise of their rights to freedom of assembly and expression, and for the reform or abolition of these laws. This includes the National Security Council's law, adopted in December, to further restrict freedoms.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Yes, the development in Malaysia of the restrictions on freedom of expression and other fundamental freedoms is alarming.  The government is doing its best to silence critics and the political opposition, and that is why parliament must deplore today that the human rights situation has been eliminated, and that the legislation allows the attack on representatives of civil society, academics, the media and opposition.  That is why the resolution calls on the government to immediately release the political prisoners and ordinary people who have only used their freedom of expression but who do not in any way pose a danger or risk to the country's security, and also to immediately stop the increasing persecution and violence directed against LGBTQ people in the country.  It is important that we adopt the emergency resolution on the political situation in Malaysia today. We must show the regime that freedom of expression is a fundamental human right that must not be curtailed anywhere. This is the EU's most important mission to safeguard fundamental rights both at home here in Europe and in the rest of the world.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: author. – Mr President, our resolution here today reaffirms our commitment to and our friendship with the Malaysian people and it is because of this commitment and friendship that we share our concerns here today: concerns about the sedition act which Malaysia had committed to repeal, but instead renewed and strengthened; concerns about the new Security Act, which was adopted without any public debate or involvement of civil society and which gives widespread powers to the National Security Council to declare a state of emergency; and, more generally, concern about the atmosphere in which opposition politicians, journalists and civil society find it increasingly difficult to function.  We share these concerns not because we enjoy criticising Malaysia but because we feel that these issues are so important to mention and that they should be the starting point of a constructive dialogue both within Malaysia and also in the bilateral relations between Malaysia and the EU, especially at a time when our bilateral relations are growing ever stronger.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: Author. Mr President, Anwar Ibrahim is a symbol. This liberal fell out of disgrace because of his handling of the Asian crisis in the late 1990s, by which he imposed a very harsh austerity cure, but he also cancelled a number of opaque industrial mega-projects, which is unbearable in a country where corruption reigns supreme. He created Pakatan Rakyat by trying to overcome community divides. Every electoral success has led him to prison for sodomy, an infamy in an ultra-conservative country from the point of view of morals. Security and liberticidal laws are multiplying. Minorities, LGBTI and women are the first victims, but also journalists, intellectuals, NGO activists and political opponents. The fight against terrorism is a pretext for all-out repression. The government of the day is sinking into violence to preserve the interests of an elite and safeguard its power. Only a better distribution of wealth and a political dialogue respectful of all cultural components can break the deadlock in which it is locked, by instrumentalizing the religious question, at the risk of sinking into extremism of the same name. Again, there is an urgent need for action.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there has been a considerable restriction of freedom of speech in Malaysia because of criminal laws used to silence critical voices.  Of particular concern is the Sedition Act, which has allowed more than a hundred people to be charged and arrested since the beginning of 2015. Anwar Ibrahim, a former opposition leader, was convicted on charges of sodomy, as he was reminded in February 2015, and denied adequate medical treatment. Malaysian cartoonist Ulhaque has been charged under the Sedition Act with some tweets critical of the government in reference to Ibrahim's conviction. The media is facing increasing difficulties in reporting corruption allegations made against the prime minister, and Malaysian LGBTI people are being criminalized under the anti-somy law.  It should be remembered that Malaysia is a member of the United Nations Security Council and the current President of ASEAN. The European Parliament's request is clear: to release the condemned, to withdraw the draft law of the National Security Council, in particular with regard to the extensive powers granted to the Prime Minister, and it is right to maintain a balance between safeguarding national security and, for us, the imperative to protect civil rights and political rights.

name: Seán KELLY
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, as a member of the ASEAN Delegation, I am well aware of the growing trade relations between the EU and Malaysia. Indeed, it is second only to trade with Singapore.  But while trade is improving, the opportunities within Malaysia for free speech and freedom of expression are deteriorating. Particularly worrying is their strengthening of their sedition law. Instead of repealing it, as previously announced, they have strengthened it. This has had serious implications for freedom of expression, with several people arrested, charged or investigated as a result of this. This is not acceptable.  They have also taken for themselves the power to declare a state of emergency if they feel it is warranted, and the treatment of LGBTI people is ridiculous. At a time when we are moving in the opposite direction – even in my own country – and giving them equal rights in all facets of life, it is unacceptable that a growing trading partner of ours is moving in the opposite direction. We have to address these things in our relations with Malaysia.

name: Neena GILL
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I had the opportunity to visit Malaysia recently and was surprised to find that the perception we collectively hold about the country really is divorced from reality. Yes, it is modern and dynamic, but underneath the surface of its Western-style economy we see a state that is increasingly authoritarian, where politicians and commentators cannot speak freely. The spike in the number of people facing charges under the Sedition Act, and the recent passing of the National Security Council bill that gives sweeping powers to the Prime Minister and security forces, are prime examples of increasing repression. Ironically, Malaysia hosted the Global Anti-Corruption Conference in September. I would ask the Prime Minister: why not allow your own anti-corruption commission to conduct transparent investigations into corruption charges against you? Why not allow the media to report on it and allow people to peacefully express their views in the streets? Why not honour the pledges to repeal the Sedition Act and make sure security laws actually contribute to more security for people, rather than using them as a tool for repression? Why be afraid of open dialogue with the opposition and civil society, including Anwar Ibrahim and all the academics, activists and bloggers facing charges? Why not let the country’s brightest minds contribute to making Malaysia a beacon for development and democracy? The Malaysian authorities and Prime Minister Razak seem to fear that taking these steps will weaken their position. The exact opposite is, however, true.

name: António MARINHO E PINTO
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, human rights violations in Malaysia, as in many countries of the world, occur predominantly through a perverted justice system, with wicked laws, such as the sedition law. Political power uses the courts to persecute their opponents and even eliminate them through aberrant death sentences.  There are over 1,000 citizens waiting in Malaysian prisons for the state to kill them. There are two complementary ways to combat human rights violations in Malaysia and around the world: economic sanctions, including freezing trade agreements with these countries, on the one hand, and strengthening the International Criminal Court on the other. It must be said clearly that the disrespect for the fundamental rights of the human person does not pay, it cannot compensate, because it will bring economic damage to its violators, who will also sooner or later end up answering before the international criminal justice system.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI). – There can be no doubt that the situation in Malaysia is not good at all and that it is in no way in line with European principles and values, as each of us understands them. Indeed, Malaysia is rapidly evolving into a police state with limited freedom of expression, political persecution and fabricated accusations. Moreover, corruption takes on frightening dimensions. In any case, however, no one has appointed the Union as a global monitor, nor has it given it the power to intervene so blatantly in the internal affairs of third independent States. We do not possess the absolute truth, nor can we say that all this is not happening in the countries of Europe. And we have political persecution, and accusations made and directed against political opponents we have, interventions in justice we have, false witnesses in abundance we have and, respectively, immunity we grant according to the political beliefs of each. As for corruption, every few months we have a new scandal in Europe, with disappearing money, undeclared money, and gifts from large corporations. I therefore think that it goes a long way to waving our finger at the whole world, still clinging to post-colonial complexes, without first putting our house in order. Finally, if we really want to pressure Malaysia or any other country to respect human rights and civil liberties, let us try another way. Let us cut off all commercial contact with this state and any financial support, since there are corrupt political officials, as you say, and there is a risk that the money will be taken into ownership and let us prohibit large European multinational companies from any activities in that country if we have the courage. Otherwise, keep your hypocrisy within European borders.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, when Malaysia is a country of remarkable and rapid growth, and is a model for the South-East Asian region, how can it remain attached to past practices, such as torture or the death penalty? Although Malaysia has signed a number of international conventions, it is clear that human rights are not yet a priority and that there is even some regression.  As a reminder, Malaysia is one of 58 countries that have yet to abolish the death penalty. It is also one of 38 states that voted against the resolution for a moratorium on the application of the death penalty, adopted at the UN General Assembly on 18 December 2014, where others simply abstained, demonstrating a willingness not to move in this area.  But if Malaysia can be an economic example, why can't it do the same in areas that are just as important to the population, namely the fundamental freedoms of citizens? (The speaker agrees to answer a question "blue card" (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Thank you very much, Mr Tarabella, for accepting my question. I know your commitment to defending human rights in the world. On this particular point, I will ask, and I often ask, this in the European Parliament, because is it not the case that we need to involve the European Commission and the Council more, even the Member States, in the economic pressure on those countries that do not respect human rights? This instrument would, I think, be more effective. What do you think of this, Mr President?

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: "blue card" answer. I very much share your concern, Mr Czarnecki, Mr Vice-President. Indeed, when it comes to taking a position, for example, on free trade treaties, we should - and certainly do - balance the fact that we can make progress in terms of human rights. We did it with a whole series of countries, I am thinking in particular of the agreement with Colombia, for example, which was special because we remember that one out of every two trade unionists murdered in the world was in Colombia.  There has certainly been progress, but we need to do more. In any case, we must give priority first to respect for human rights and progress, then to business and not the other way around, or at least to put them on an equal footing.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I want to support the previous speaker on the issue of human rights in Malaysia. I deal with legal states in individual countries of the world. I must say that Malaysia, unfortunately, is not close to the rule of law model. It's already been mentioned here. There is, for example, the Law on Subversive Activity, which was adopted in 1948, during the colonial era of Malaysia. This law clearly allows anyone to be prosecuted for verbal criticism of the government. Recently, during the autumn of this year, the Constitutional Court of Malaysia said that this law is fine, that it complies with the Malaysian Constitution. We can see that this is a very clear political decision by the constitutional court there. The second problem is the form of criminal law. Today, up to 1,000 people are waiting in prisons for execution in Malaysia. The penal code there is very vague. I therefore interted, Commissioner, with what my colleagues have said. We need to communicate, cooperate with Malaysia, but we should only conclude agreements with it if it is willing to rectify its rule of law and remove laws that do not make Malaysia the rule of law.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, the lack of freedom of expression, religious oppression, discrimination against indigenous peoples and immigrants in Malaysia are now on the agenda. The Malaysian Government, under the guise of counter-terrorism, arrests and, citing national security reasons, imprisons indefinitely any person deemed supposedly suspicious, while arrests of those fighting for human rights are frequent. Moreover, the country's government has imposed restrictions on freedom of speech and has therefore been described as one of the countries with the worst degree of freedom of expression, a country where sharia is applied. There are many cases where the Malaysian authorities have imposed sanctions for reports opposed to the government. In the face of the violation of human rights in Malaysia, the European Union is called upon to put pressure on the government of the country in order for the latter to repeal the Law on Mutiny and to guarantee the rights of freedom of expression, assembly and all that is based on the international covenant on civil and political rights.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – In the Czarnecki-Tarabella debate, I would like to add that, during yesterday's Preda report, it has been repeatedly said that the Council and the Commission could do more to set a good example of calling for respect for human rights, including the rights of those belonging to minorities, in its Member States. The mere fact that malaysia has been prosecuted for sodomy on a total of seven occasions in its history, and on two occasions opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim has been targeted says a lot about the conditions there. The removal of political opponents by judicial means certainly reflects the fear of power that the opposition could prevail in a democratic election. To me, a stand for Anwar Ibrahim also indicates that the opposition in Malaysia is growing and that a retreat in power will be inevitable in the foreseeable future. It is not the european Union's job to interfere in Malaysia's domestic policy, but merely to emphasise that we expect respect for the values we profess from all our important trading partners.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Sedition Act, Printing Presses and Publications Act, Peaceful Assembly Act, Communications and Multimedia Act, the list of legislative acts and the various reforms of the criminal code that affect the exercise of freedom of expression and assembly in Malaysia is unfortunately very long.  The country also suffers from high social dumping, corruption is spread to the highest levels of government, and forced politicisation of the judiciary has led to trials against the opposition and political dissidents and also against journalists, as was the case, for example, with the former opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim, who is now in prison on a frankly ridiculous charge, which also shows how far islamic courts and Sharia law have taken over within the country. Not to mention the systematic destruction of the environment and the crazy plans of the government to which Mr Corrao referred earlier.  As the European Union, we are a market of more than 500 million people, we are an economic superpower and our trade agreements can be the ultimate weapon for becoming a superpower of human rights as well. We can do that. If not now when? Europe wake up and demand respect from our partners for the sacrosanct rights accorded to every human being.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: – Mr President, I would like to believe that our discussions today and today's resolution will be seen as part of a discussion with a partner with whom I hope we have a common interest in cooperation. I would like to recall what the previous presidents have already said about the rule of law situation in Malaysia, that development cooperation, trade agreements concluded by the European Union, are conditional on respect for human rights; and I would therefore like to call on the European Commission to take this seriously in this regard and to apply the conditionality of development and trade cooperation with countries such as Malaysia in order to genuinely improve the human rights situation in that country.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, Malaysia holds a prominent place for the European Union in the South-East Asia region. Malaysia currently holds the presidency of ASEAN at a time when important decisions are being taken towards creating an ASEAN Economic Community. Our bilateral ties have strengthened significantly through enhanced trade and investment, political dialogue and a variety of cooperation activities. But against this background, the European Union is concerned about some of the developments that have taken place in this country since 2014, developments which have affected freedom of expression and the rule of law. We are notably concerned about the increase of the use of the so-called Sedition Act, as well as about the judiciary decisions regarding Mr Anwar Ibrahim, the leader of the opposition. As regards freedom of expression and as you all recall, the EU regrets the increasing use since 2014 of the Sedition Act, despite the Prime Minister’s pledge to repeal it. In this context, I would like to recall that in April 2015 the High Representative expressed public concern that this step would have implications for the exercise of freedom of expression.  The High Representative raised serious concerns regarding the due process of law after the conviction by the Federal Court of Malaysia and the five—year imprisonment of the opposition leader in February this year. Mr Anwar had initially been acquitted before the decision was overturned. As a consequence he was deprived of his civil rights and lost his seat as a Member of Parliament.  On 8 December, the European Union concluded the negotiation of a new—generation Partnership and Cooperation Agreement (PCA) with Malaysia. The European Parliament has repeatedly called for the conclusion of this negotiation, which started in 2011. The new Agreement includes specific provisions on human rights and the rule of law which will allow for an enhanced engagement on these matters, in particular through the establishment of a meaningful, broad-based human rights dialogue. During the negotiations, Malaysia agreed to recognise that respect for democratic principles, human rights and the rule of law constitute an essential element of the Agreement. We will continue to engage with the Government of Malaysia to step up our cooperation in the promotion of human rights, including as regards LGBTI issues bilaterally as well as at the regional level with ASEAN.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place at the end of the debate.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: I will start by making an announcement, which reads as follows: ‘In accordance with Rule 166 of the Rules of Procedure, the President has decided to impose a penalty on Mr de Graaff for his conduct during the votes at the sitting on  28 October 2015 and it will consist in the forfeiture of his entitlement to the daily subsistence allowance for a period of five days. The decision has been notified to the Member concerned’.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the vote. (For the results and other details of the vote:  see Minutes).

name: James CARVER
text: – Mr President, it seems most unusual that this proposal we are about to vote on was only announced at 19.00 last night in this Chamber, when there were just a handful of colleagues present. I would like to remark how unaccountable that is, bearing in mind that objections and comments had to be noted with the President’s Bureau before 20.00, and with just a handful of Members from all political groups across Parliament. I find that quite bizarre and undemocratic.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: I can inform you that I was told that it was also running on the website at the same time.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: – Mr President, I just wanted Parliament to acknowledge that Ibrahim Halawa’s two sisters are here today to hopefully witness unanimous support calling for the release of their brother, Ibrahim Halawa. So I would just like to welcome Somaia and Omaima.  (Applause)

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Rapporteur. Thank you, Mr. President. The proposal we want to make is that, in Amendment 3, we remove the penultimate part of the paragraph, the one that starts with "highlights" and ends with 'area of origin', because this part is interpreted primarily by Bosniaks as a support for ethnic cleansing, and I think it is unacceptable for our Parliament to adopt a text that can be read by Muslims in Bosnia and Herzegovina as a call for ethnic cleansing.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The vote is over.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. The Volskwagen emissions scandal has once again demonstrated the complicity of the Commission and the Member States with large multinational groups, since leaks in the press have shown that they knew of the manipulation of emission limits long before the American environmental agency uncovered the scandal. These political responsibilities and connections must be urgently clarified, since the Commission intends to re-register transatlantic car regulation through TTE. I think this issue is fundamental: not only because of the serious impact of emissions on the quality of life of Europeans (especially in urban areas), but because the scale of the scandal is such that the future of the car industry and its workers in Europe comes into play. The establishment of a commission of inquiry should clarify responsibilities and lay the groundwork for an environmentally and socially sustainable industrial policy.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP voted in favour of setting up a European Parliament committee of enquiry on this issue. The committee intends to investigate the Commission’s role in the scandal. UKIP fully support anything which will hold accountable the unelected EU Commission. However the committee also intends to investigate Member States and national authorities. While we do not support the legitimacy of EU bodies investigating Member States, it may shine a light on wrongdoing by our own government. UKIP will oppose any recommendations made by the committee which call for more EU powers, legislation or harmonisation.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 As revealed following a complaint by a Non-Governmental Organization and following the audits carried out by the US Environment Agency, more than 8 million Volkswagen cars are in circulation in Europe with illegal software. It was also revealed that, as early as 2013, the European Commission had identified differences between declared and actual emissions without doing anything. The facts demonstrate the inability of the Union and the National Audit Authorities to implement the laws effectively. For these reasons, I consider it necessary for Parliament to set up a Committee of Inquiry so that we can find out what really happened and who is responsible for the cover-up.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. A commission of inquiry into the measurement of polluting emissions in the automotive sector, following the famous Volkswagen case, would damage the image and valuation of European car manufacturers, at a time when the sector is subject to an increasingly intense global competition and economic war. While we deplore the fact that industrialists have circumvented the existing regulations, my colleagues on the National Front and I believe that defending the economic interests of the Member States of the Union is essential to maintaining a viable economic and industrial environment in Europe. I have therefore abstained on this text which calls for the establishment of a commission of inquiry.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ In the end, I supported the Committee of Inquiry.  It is important to hold the Commission to account, and for us to have answers to the tough questions about the emissions scandal – not least to find out what, if anything, the Commission knew about it. I do, however, have concerns about any committee set up in this place being used as a mechanism to drive for ‘more Europe’. It seems that just about anything is used as a call for ‘more Europe’ here.  Any success is seen as a green light for further harmonisation, whereas any failure requires harmonisation as the solution.   Furthermore, I do oppose the shockingly short timescale on this issue which has been rushed through in a manner unbefitting a supposedly democratic institution.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 With my vote I support the setting up of a committee of inquiry into the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector, I believe it is the EU's duty to shed light on this scandal that has affected the automotive sector, in order to give definite answers and ascertain the responsibilities behind it.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ I support the establishment of a commission of inquiry. The scandal of rigging exhaust tests is actually an attack on the health and consumer rights of citizens and the economy of the European Union and the Member States. The release of nitric oxides, which are particularly harmful to the liver, lungs and blood count of citizens, was set up. They were cheated into selling more expensive cars that were supposedly less harmful to the environment. Consumer confidence has been building for years, and it's losing overnight. Therefore, it is necessary to thoroughly and transparently investigate the whole case and establish a new system that will measure exhaust gases while driving.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal calls for an investigation into the Commission's alleged failure to comply with its obligation under Article 14(3) of Regulation (EC) No 715/2007 to verify the test cycles used to measure emissions and to adapt them, if they are no longer adequate or no longer reflect real emissions, to respond adequately to emissions generated by real road driving, despite information on serious and persistent exceedances of emission limit values in the normal use of vehicles, in breach of the obligations set out in Article 5(1) of Regulation (EC) No 715/2007, including the 2011 and 2013 reports of the Commission's Joint Research Centre and research by the International Council on Clean Transportation (ICCT) made available in May 2014. Is it requested to investigate the reported failure of the Commission and the authorities of the Member States to take appropriate and effective measures to monitor and implement the application of the explicit prohibition on the use of defeat devices laid down in Article 5(2) of Regulation (EC) No 715/2007; I am voting in favour.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the setting up of a Committee of Inquiry on emission measurements in the automotive sector. I retain concerns regarding whether such a committee will have the requisite powers needed to address this matter fully; however, it is a positive and progressive move, therefore I voted in favour of such a committee.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of setting up a European Parliament committee of enquiry on this issue. The committee intends to investigate the Commission’s role in the scandal. UKIP fully support anything which will hold accountable the unelected EU Commission. However the committee also intends to investigate Member States and national authorities. While we do not support the legitimacy of EU bodies investigating Member States, it may shine a light on wrongdoing by our own government. UKIP will oppose any recommendations made by the committee which call for more EU powers, legislation or harmonisation.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this Resolution as I believe that this matter should be dealt with in the appropriate European Parliament committee without creating additional burdensome committees. The creation of an Inquiry Committee will not solve the problem. I believe that we should build a legal framework which makes European cars the cleanest, most competitive and most efficient in the future. We need to implement the new emission norms and tests which resemble real driving conditions as soon as possible.

name: Nessa CHILDERS
text: in writing. ‒ Together with other MEPs, our request to set up a Committee of Inquiry to probe into the automobile industry’s illegal practices was accepted and I am very pleased that Parliament voted in favour of this. On Monday, I voted in the Environment Committee to reject lax ‘real driving emissions’ standards for measuring compliance with EU car pollution limits. My political group had vowed to veto the proposals in a letter to the EU Environment Ministers, criticising the Commission and the Council of EU Ministers for the technical proposals on driving emissions tests, diluting the decade-old Euro 6 standards. We cannot fail to take action on foot of a scandal with serious impact on respiratory health, the environment and corporate governance at the heart of Europe. If we just pay lip service to the principles we are supposed to uphold, we will be validating our citizens’ fears of regulatory capture of our institutions by big corporations. The EU automobile industry cannot be allowed to keep dictating the main thrust of public policies that affect these industrial giants, to the detriment of our citizens’ health and the environment.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 From the outset we have expressed our reservations about the political purposes behind this initiative. We are always in favour of checks on the merits but against the service of purpose. That's why we're against it.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the scandal that has hit Volkswagen in the United States is something unheard of in market economies that base many transactions on trust. In fact, in this case the trust has been betrayed and therefore the lubricant for the mechanism that turns the economy around has been lost. There is undeniably also a public responsibility for controls that have not been carried out, but I have the impression that the Committee of Inquiry is a way of passing on to Europe the faults and responsibilities that belong, if proven, to the Member State in which this car manufacturer is based. It is not possible for this same country to do the good and the bad, to give reliability licences to the right and to the left, and then, when pinched with their hands in jam, to take issue with the EU instead of being self-critical. That is why I voted against the establishment of this committee of inquiry: yes to transparency, but let us first leave the most stained clothes and then we will gradually define the rest.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. The Volkswagen emissions scandal has once again demonstrated the complicity of the Commission and the Member States with large multinational groups, since leaks in the press have shown that they knew of the manipulation of emission limits long before the American environmental agency uncovers the scandal. These political responsibilities and connections must be urgently clarified, since the Commission intends to re-register transatlantic car regulation through TTE. I think this issue is fundamental: not only because of the serious impact of emissions on the quality of life of Europeans (especially in urban areas), but because the scale of the scandal is such that the future of the car industry and its workers in Europe comes into play. The establishment of a commission of inquiry should clarify responsibilities and lay the groundwork for an environmentally and socially sustainable industrial policy.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ As one of the persons pushing for the setting up of this inquiry committee in the Environment Committee I supported this vote. I believe that we need to look at what mistakes were made in the past and work on strategies and policies that can ensure that such things do not happen again.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. – UKIP voted in favour of setting up a European Parliament committee of enquiry on this issue. The committee intends to investigate the Commission’s role in the scandal. UKIP fully support anything which will hold accountable the unelected EU Commission. However the committee also intends to investigate Member States and national authorities. While we do not support the legitimacy of EU bodies investigating Member States, it may shine a light on wrongdoing by our own government. UKIP will oppose any recommendations made by the committee which call for more EU powers, legislation or harmonisation.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. I voted against this proposed decision on the constitution, the numerical composition and the term of office of the Commission of Inquiry on the Measurement of Emissions in the Automotive Sector.  Indeed, this commission of inquiry, requested by the European left in the wake of the Volkswagen scandal, is not the solution to ensure that such cheating does not happen again. In addition to costing money, it would have no added value compared to existing surveys. This is why we must focus on better monitoring of national licensing authorities with supervision of the European Commission, better monitoring of emissions tests carried out and the implementation of tests in real driving situations as quickly as possible.  It is with these measures that we will avoid a new scandal! It will also reduce emissions in the automotive sector, which is essential for the environment and the health of our citizens.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of clarifying this shameful scandal.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this report because I believe that the least the European Parliament can do is set up a committee of inquiry since so far it has not been able to put an end to the illegalities and arbitrariness of multinational companies, especially car manufacturers.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the decision to set up a Committee of Inquiry to investigate emission measurements in the automotive sector, which will, inter alia, keep under review the test cycles used to measure emissions, investigate the alleged failure of the Commission and the Member States’ authorities to take proper and effective action to oversee the enforcement and to enforce the explicit ban on defeat devices , and investigate the alleged failure of the Commission to introduce tests reflecting real-world driving conditions in a timely manner and to adopt measures addressing the use of defeat mechanisms. The Committee of Inquiry, composed of 45 members, will present an interim report within 6 months of starting its work and will submit its final report within 12 months of starting its work.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Volkswagen scandal has certainly shocked millions of European citizens who need to be answered, but that is not the job of a committee of inquiry. The task of this Parliament, on the other hand, is to work on a new regulation that will make it possible to prevent similar situations from happening again, legislation that will finally make it possible to ascertain emissions realistically, for the benefit of the environment, citizens and, not least, European car companies.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP resolution establishing the Committee of Inquiry into the Measurement of Emissions in the Automotive Sector, promoted by the ENVI Parliamentary Committee, of which I am a member, because I believe it is of fundamental importance that in the face of the recent scandal involving a famous German car manufacturer, the EP, as a representative of European citizens and co-decision-maker together with the Council on the single market and the environment , exercise its right of inquiry. The Committee of Inquiry is called upon to examine complaints of infringement of the extensive European legislation in this field and of maladministration in its application of the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector, without prejudice to national prerogatives. I therefore strongly supported the scope of its mandate and the duration in office, twelve months in total, during which it will have to listen to experts in the sector, car manufacturers and other interested parties and draw up an interim report at the end of the first six months of the investigation.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted today against the decision on the establishment, responsibilities, numerical composition and mandate of the Committee of Inquiry into emissions measurements in the automotive industry, as I believe that such a committee for politically motivated actionism should be set up with the aim of using taxpayers' money unnecessarily and of conducting political bashing at the expense of individual car manufacturers. There is no question that incidents need to be investigated – only that is what the Commission, not Parliament, must do.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. Today, with the votes of the Social Democrats and the Greens and against the votes of the EPP Group, Parliament has decided on a committee of inquiry into the Volkswagen emissions scandal. I consider such a tribunal to be unnecessary and counterproductive.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ In the end, I supported the Committee of Inquiry.  It is important to hold the Commission to account, and for us to have answers to the tough questions about the emissions scandal – not least to find out what, if anything, the Commission knew about it. I do, however, have concerns about any committee set up in this place being used as a mechanism to drive for ‘more Europe’. It seems that just about anything is used as a call for ‘more Europe’ here.  Any success is seen as a green light for further harmonisation, whereas any failure requires harmonisation as the solution.   Furthermore, I do oppose the shockingly short timescale on this issue which has been rushed through in a manner unbefitting a supposedly democratic institution.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome that my Group has successfully led the push for the establishment of a Committee of Inquiry on emission measurements in the automotive sector. It is crucial that fraud is prevented, even more so when it affects our citizens’ health. We now have two lines of action to take: to find out where the compliance regime of the EU Commission and the Member States failed, and to implement the right measures so that in the future all cars will meet the imposed emission limit values also in real world use.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. The fraud committed by Volkswagen in handling its engines to pass the pollutant emission measurement test has revealed a number of failures, if not negligence, on the part of the Commission and the authorities of the Member States in exercising their legal obligations in this regard. We therefore voted in favour of this motion for a Resolution on the establishment of a committee of inquiry to examine allegations of infringement and maladministr administration in the application of EU law with regard to the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. I voted against the constitution of this Commission. The Commission of Inquiry requested by the European Left, which is in addition to the ongoing investigations, is not the solution to ensure that such cheating does not happen again. We know what measures need to be implemented and that is what we need to focus on: better monitoring of national licensing authorities with supervision of the European Commission, better monitoring of emissions tests carried out and the implementation of tests in real driving situations as quickly as possible.  Through these measures, we will avoid a new scandal, reduce emissions in the automotive sector, which is essential for the environment and the health of our citizens, and encourage the industry to make technological progress.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The recent scandal involving the volkswagen car industry has raised concerns about the influence of the major car manufacturers on the Commission. For this reason, the setting up of Parliament's committee of inquiry can only find us in agreement.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this proposal as I am of the belief that setting up a Committee of Inquiry on emission measurements in the automotive sector will be of no benefit to EU Member States and citizens.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a decision to form a special committee to measure emissions in the automotive sector, its powers, composition and duration because I believe that new measures and oversight are needed to prevent consumer fraud again, and to prevent and address environmental damage.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – My UKIP colleagues and I voted in favour of setting up a European Parliament committee of enquiry on this issue. The committee intends to investigate the Commission’s role in the scandal. UKIP fully support anything which will hold accountable the unelected EU Commission. However the committee also intends to investigate Member States and national authorities. While we do not support the legitimacy of EU bodies investigating Member States, it may shine a light on wrongdoing by our own government. UKIP will oppose any recommendations made by the committee which call for more EU powers, legislation or harmonisation.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted against this proposal to create a new commission of inquiry in the wake of the Volkswagen scandal. However, this commission would be in addition to the ongoing investigations, which would not help to ensure that such cheating does not happen again.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I abstained from voting. While such a committee can bring greater transparency and increase the image of the European car industry, it is also to be feared that the result will bring disadvantages for Europe as an industrial location.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported setting up the Committee of Inquiry as it is crucial to investigate alleged contraventions and maladministration in the application of EU law in relation to emission measurements in the automotive sector.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. Following the scandals in the car industry, it was decided to set up a committee of inquiry. The purpose of the latter will be to ascertain any liability with regard to the failure to take appropriate and effective measures to make effective the application of the explicit ban on the use of defeat devices on cars. I believe that this must be clarified as soon as possible, identifying any non-compliance or omission, and I have therefore chosen to vote in favour of the proposal for a decision.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: In writing. The Commission of Inquiry requested by the European Left in the wake of the Volkswagen scandal, which would be in addition to ongoing judicial investigations in several Member States, is not the solution to ensure that such cheating does not happen again. We know what measures need to be implemented and that is what we need to focus on: better monitoring of national licensing authorities with supervision of the European Commission, better monitoring of emissions tests carried out and the implementation of tests in real driving situations as quickly as possible.  Through these measures, we will avoid a new scandal, reduce emissions in the automotive sector, which is essential for the environment and the health of our citizens, and encourage the industry to make technological progress.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. A commission of inquiry into the measurement of polluting emissions in the automotive sector, following the "Volkswagen affair", could damage the image and valuation of European car manufacturers in a context of increasing global competition and economic war. While transparency is a fundamental issue, defending the economic interests of states remains essential to a viable economic and industrial environment in Europe. That's why I abstained.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I abstained on this resolution. Of course, it has the merit of calling for the creation of a commission of inquiry into the Volkswagen case and it is necessary to take the measure of polluting emissions in the automotive sector. I am afraid, however, that, as drafted, this resolution will undermine the defence of the European car industry in a context of fierce global competition.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 At the end of October this year, the European Parliament adopted a resolution on emission measurements in the automotive sector calling for a thorough investigation into the role and responsibility of the European Commission and the national authorities in the context of this scandal that erupted a few months ago.
