Today, a vote was held aimed at setting up a special committee of inquiry to investigate the alleged infringement of Union law and the existence of malademed malad you. One of the main problems is that not only has there been a possible breach of the law, but also a great deal of ecological damage and, crucially, consumers actually lied about the environmental impact of the cars they buy. Moreover, not only producers or sellers could play a small role here, but also responsible national and supranational institutions. This scandal is by no means limited to EU territory, so scrutiny, transparency and objective scrutiny is of international importance. I hope that the members of the committee set up will investigate this problem within the deadlines set and present conclusions that will be actively used for further and general analysis of the causes and consequences of this scandal.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution on the establishment of a committee of inquiry into emissions measurements in the automotive industry, its powers, the number of members and the length of its term of office, because I believe it is complete and documented.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the setting up of an inquiry committee to investigate breaches of EU rules on car emission tests and alleged failures by EU Member States and the Commission to enforce EU standards. We must get to the bottom of ‘dieselgate’.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: In writing. The Volkswagen scandal, which has exposed the German car champion's cheating on its systems for measuring nitrogen oxide and CO2 emissions, is a reminder of the necessary vigilance against major industrial groups. From 2009 to 2015, software was installed on more than 11 million vehicles (sold worldwide) to deceive vehicle testing authorities. The subject is eminently European, with the maximum emission levels set by the European Union.  This week, the European Parliament sent a doubly ambitious response in this regard, first to the Council, and therefore to the States, which had lost their guard in the face of the interests of the car lobby, by taking the decision to raise the permitted levels of nitrogen oxide emissions - The ENVI Committee of Parliament rejected this proposal - but, above all, by drafting a resolution proposing the establishment of a committee of inquiry , therefore having special powers over this cheating and the attitude of the European Commission during the period 2009-2015.  Aware of the difficulty of rallying sufficient votes for Parliament to have the means of investigation (this had failed after the Luxleaks scandal), I voted without hesitation in favour of the establishment of the Commission of Inquiry into the Volkswagen scandal.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The report is, in principle, reasonable and an appropriate investigation. However, I believe that such an investigation should be reserved for the nation states. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: Writing. The FDP abstained from the vote. We very much welcome the fact that the Commission's conduct in the VW affair and, before that, in the implementation of EU legislation, is to be fully exposed. However, the mandate of the Committee of Inquiry is not sufficiently defined and can lead to a general suspicion against the car industry. Diesel should not be demonised now either – because in order to achieve our climate targets in Europe, the lower-carbon diesel is also necessary in the medium term.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. With 283 MEPs, I have called for the creation of a commission of inquiry into the Volkswagen scandal - this resolution defines its powers. The 45-member commission will be tasked with investigating violations of EU law in the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector.  I regret that in this resolution the specific role of Volkswagen is not even mentioned. Nevertheless, I am voting in the hope that this committee will be able to carry out its work with great scepticism.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. I voted against the European Parliament's decision to set up a committee of inquiry into the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector. The scandal must be investigated thoroughly and the rules must be strengthened, not forgetting that the automotive sector represents a key sector of the European economy. I believe that it is up to the European Commission to ensure compliance with Community rules as guardian of the Treaties.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: Written. – In September, it became known that certain car manufacturers were manipulating vehicle emissions data and that real emissions data were much higher than the figures measured in laboratory conditions and the figures reported in the sales brochures for the potential customer. Very quickly it became known that European authorities had known that the tests under controlled conditions were not consistent with the data on actual emissions of pollutants. It is therefore necessary to create complete clarity in the numerous twilight zones that surround the file of the cheating software and the emission values of vehicles. Hence my explicit support for the proposal to set up a parliamentary committee of inquiry. The task of a parliamentary committee of inquiry is always as clear. It must identify the possible malpractice, sloppiness, shortcomings and possible violations of European legislation on pollution problems in the automotive sector. All this with the task of formulating recommendations so that the state of the past does not repeat itself in the future, car manufacturers abide by the rules and customers can rely on correct information and fair products.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the European Parliament’s request to set up a Committee of Inquiry to investigate alleged contraventions and maladministration in the application of EU law in relation to emission measurements in the automotive sector. I agree with the aim of the inquiry, which would be to investigate alleged contraventions of Union law and alleged maladministration in the application of Union law which appear to be the act of an institution or body of the European Union and public administrative bodies of Member States.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted against the European left's call for a commission of inquiry into the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector. Indeed, the European Parliament has asked the committee to take action in response to the scandal created by Volkswagen's anti-pollution test fraud and investigations are already under way.  The European Parliament has voted for better monitoring of national probate authorities with supervision of the European Commission and the implementation of real-life driving tests as soon as possible. These recommendations must be followed by effects to restore European confidence in the use of diesel engines, which are cheaper and less polluting than petrol engines.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the proposal to set up a committee of inquiry to investigate alleged breaches of Union law and alleged maladministration in the application of Union legislation in relation to emission measurement in the automotive industry. Unfortunately, the left has pushed for the creation of a committee of inquiry, and I fear that its real motivation is not to correct the mistakes and failures that led to the creation of 'Dieselgate', but to attack the car industry and to transfer the solution to the problem from a professional level to a political one. The Dieselgate case is to be in the hands of responsible authorities such as the European Commission and the administrative and judicial authorities of the Member States to which investigative and decision-making powers belong. I consider it a necessary step to urgently introduce a real-world emissions test (RDE), which will be in line with European legislation and will therefore not allow for more significant deviations from the emission values set.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The Commission's objective is to investigate alleged infringements and maladministration in the application of Union law in relation to the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the establishment of this committee of inquiry and I was among the signatories that allowed it to be put to the votes of Members.  As COP 21 comes to an end, it is a step forward in the fight against the scourge of air pollution and a positive signal to European citizens to ensure and strengthen compliance with emissions standards. It would have been incomprehensible to our fellow citizens if the European Parliament had bowed to pressure from industrialists, who want above all to continue the business as usual, even if it endangered public health.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I consider this Decision of the European Parliament to establish, authorize, numerically and for the duration of the mandate of the automotive emissions committee redundant and unnecessary. In this particular case, this is irresponsible behaviour by one of the European companies, and the overall level of damage caused to the European automotive industry is not yet fully known to us.  Millions of employees and their family members across Europe depend on the industry and the whole sector. Customer and global market confidence is already sufficiently shaken and any further insistence on establishing already well-known facts and circumstances will not contribute to restoring confidence or continuing the desired economic growth in the sector. As I have pointed out several times before, I believe that illicit and irresponsible behaviour should be severely sanctioned and test methods adapted to the needs of today.  I am pleased that the European Commission is preparing a new act on the real-terms testing of passenger vehicle emissions, and I regret that the possibility of fraud was not taken seriously enough and fraud was detected in time. Changing awareness in responsible people in companies and preventing fraud can only be achieved by imposing the severe and dissuasive penalties that fraudsters will have to face.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider the creation of a committee of inquiry from the level of the European Union to be an attempt to politicise the whole problem, which is rather legal in nature. For this reason, I am sceptical of the proposal.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted against the commission of inquiry requested by the European left in the wake of the Volkswagen scandal. For me, it's not elected officials who investigate, it's justice. It is the principle of separation of powers that is the basis of our system in France. We must respect the work of justice in progress. Second, this fact-finding mission is not the solution to ensure that such cheating does not happen again. We know what measures need to be implemented and that is what we need to focus on: better monitoring of national licensing authorities with supervision of the European Commission, better monitoring of emissions tests carried out and the implementation of tests in real driving situations as quickly as possible.  Through these measures, we will avoid a new scandal, we will reduce emissions in the automotive sector, which is essential for the environment and the health of our citizens. It is not the fact-finding mission that will solve these problems. It could even slow down the process.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted in favour of setting up a European Parliament committee of enquiry on this issue. The committee intends to investigate the Commission’s role in the scandal. UKIP fully support anything which will hold accountable the unelected EU Commission. However the committee also intends to investigate Member States and national authorities. While we do not support the legitimacy of EU bodies investigating Member States, it may shine a light on wrongdoing by our own government. UKIP will oppose any recommendations made by the committee which call for more EU powers, legislation or harmonisation.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: In writing. In the aftermath of COP 21, when Europe has shown the extent of its ambition to combat CO2 emissions, we could not stand idly by in the face of emissions of other pollutants (such as nitrogen oxides and fine particulate matter emitted by diesel engines).  The scandal of vehicle emissions test fraud, because it maintains a system harmful to both the environment and public health, by allowing cars to emit far more pollutants than manufacturers announce, cannot go unpunished any longer, and the European Parliament owes it to citizens to shed light on the subject - including whether or not European or national institutions are involved in fraud.  I am pleased that Parliament has voted in favour of the Committee of Inquiry into this fraud, and I hope that this will be only the first step, because, after identifying those responsible, we will have to ensure that fraud cannot happen again. Above all, we will have to seize the opportunity to invest in alternative engines, the best way to reconcile the protection of industrial jobs and our environment.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this decision, which establishes a European Parliament's commission of inquiry into the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector. Comprised of 45 of our Members, this committee, with clear powers, aims to investigate allegations of breaches of EU law and its misapsed, and to make any recommendations it deems necessary. The Commission of Inquiry will present its final report within 12 months and an interim report on the progress of its work within 6 months. Having supported this committee from the outset, I welcome its institution, which is the logical response to the revelations that have taken place in the automotive sector and on which we have already spoken in our resolution of 27 October last. The light must be shed on this case, the responsibilities clearly established. What could be more necessary, then that Parliament, as a chamber directly elected by European citizens, can conduct its own inquiry? Transparency is certainly essential to restore consumer confidence in a major sector of the European economy.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to abstain as I do not wish to see any new EU committees but I do recognise the importance of this matter.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 In accordance with Rule 198 of the Rules of Procedure, the EP has submitted a draft decision on the establishment, scope, number of members and duration of the Committee of Inquiry on emission measurement in the automotive industry. I voted in favour of the proposal and also signed a motion in support of the submission to plenary of the EP. It is important that we properly investigate the CO2 emissions scandal and, above all, that measures are taken in the future to prevent carmakers from cheating. Just a few days ago, very difficult negotiations on climate change in Paris ended and a climate agreement was born, which has yet to be ratified by individual states. The Europe 2020 strategy has also set itself the objective of reducing CO2 emissions, which is why I welcomed the european Parliament's interest in large companies in the automotive industry complying with the declared emission values, so that the consumer is not misled when buying a car and, ultimately, that we protect the environment.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the resolution establishing a committee of inquiry to measure emissions in the automotive industry. I consider the establishment of such a committee of inquiry premature. The European Commission has not yet exhausted all its control tools at its disposal, and we should let it act for the time to come and not investigate it for alleged failure instead. On 27 October 2015, the European Parliament adopted a resolution on measuring emissions in the automotive sector, asking the European Commission for fundamental changes in this area. I believe that the Commission needs to be asked how it carries out Parliament's tasks, but for this there is no need to set up a committee of inquiry.  The automotive industry should be given room for appropriate response and self-regulation, within which it could act constructively and in an environment of legal certainty. Unfortunately, our decision today to set up a committee of inquiry undermines this legal certainty and essentially goes against the resolution adopted by the European Parliament a month ago.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the proposal for a decision establishing, powers, numerical composition and mandate of the Committee of Inquiry for emission measurements in the automotive sector. I voted against the draft decision because I do not see the need to monitor the test targets for emission measurements and to investigate whether the Commission and the Authorities of the Member States have not acted appropriately and effectively to ensure the control and enforcement of the law and have not implemented an explicit ban on defeat devices.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament must set up a committee of inquiry since so far no one else has been able to stop the illegalities and arbitrariness of multinational companies, especially car manufacturers.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal by signing and later voting to set up a special commission in the European Parliament on emissions measurement for the automotive industry. I think it is important that the representative system provides real solutions in this framework, because the size of the case requires it. I am already involved in the work of a similar special committee, which is carrying out exploratory work on the Lux-leaks tax scandal (TAXE). The aim of the new Special Committee is to examine alleged infringements, maladministration on the basis of EU legislation and the role of the EU institutions in it. In my opinion, the future special committee, with the participation of several factions, can effectively analyse the current situation of emission measurement and possible future solutions in the interests of the electorate.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. We voted to investigate allegations that the Commission had breached its obligation under Article 14, paragraph 3, Regulation (EC) 715/2007, to verify the test cycles used to measure emissions and, if they are no longer adequate or reflect the reality of global emissions, to adapt them so that they accurately reflect emissions generated by the reality of road driving, despite reports of serious and persistent overruns of emission limits for normal-use vehicles.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of a Committee of Inquiry into the Volkswagen affair.  The mandate for the Committee of Inquiry will be much broader than that of the special committee and will try to determine how the European Commission acted. With this inquiry the European Parliament will seek to establish whether the institution failed to meet its obligations under Article 14 of Regulation 715/2007 on the responsibilities of the Commission in monitoring the national test cycles used to measure emissions. The mandate of the parliamentary Committee of Inquiry will go even beyond the Commission and will also allow Parliament to carry out investigations into national certification authorities.

name: Michael THEURER
text: Writing. The FDP abstained from the vote. We very much welcome the fact that the Commission's conduct in the VW affair and, before that, in the implementation of EU legislation, is to be fully exposed. However, the mandate of the Committee of Inquiry is not sufficiently defined and can lead to a general suspicion against the car industry. Diesel should not be demonised now either – because in order to achieve our climate targets in Europe, the lower-carbon diesel is also necessary in the medium term.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the proposal for a European Parliament decision on the establishment, powers, numerical composition and mandate of the Committee of Inquiry on Emission Measurements in the automotive sector (2015/3037(RSO)) as I doubt the effectiveness of the establishment of special committees of inquiry.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal calls for the establishment of a committee of inquiry into emissions measurement in the automotive industry to investigate allegations of infringements of EU law and abuses in its application, without prejudice to the judicial powers of national and EU courts. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour  of the decision on setting up a Committee of Inquiry into emission measurements in the automotive sector, its powers, numerical strength and term of office, because I agree it is necessary to investigate the alleged failure of the Commission to comply with the obligation to keep under review the test cycles used to measure emissions and to adapt them , if they are no longer adequate or no longer reflect real world emissions and to investigate the alleged failure of the Commission and the Member States’ authorities to take proper and effective action to oversee the enforcement of, and to enforce, the explicit ban on defeat devices. I believe the committee will have an important role in setting new standards and improve situation in this regard.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. The recent scandal over Volkswagen's testing of nitrogen oxide emissions by diesel engines has revealed a situation as regrettable as it is paradoxical. In fact, recent data point to a gap that can be 500% between nitrogen oxide emissions measured under laboratory conditions and under normal circulation conditions. In other words, a vehicle within the current 80 mg per kilometre standards can actually emit 400 mg per kilometre. Nitrogen oxide is associated with asthma, neonatal malformations as well as the premature death of 500,000 people per year. Instead of forcing the automotive sector to comply with public health standards, the European Commission has taken recent measures which in practice promote the continuation of non-compliance. They allow more than doubling (2.1) the minimum value of 80 mg per kilometre by 2017 for new models and by 2019 for new vehicles. In a second phase, emissions also allow more than 50% of the standard by 2020 for new models and by 2021 for new vehicles. The question that should be put to the European Commission is where public health weighed on this decision and on what studies it was based on.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The report is, in principle, reasonable and an appropriate investigation. However, I believe that such an investigation should be reserved for the nation states. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – I would like to say that in the history of the history of the European Union and its institutional predecessors, it was necessary not only to adapt internal international treaties and documents in order to include the numerical nature of our Communities. This case with Croatia is not an exception at all. As regards, in particular, croatia-Vietnam relations, it would be worth noting that they have existed at official level for more than twenty years, while neither the first nor the second has a close level of embassies. Croatia, for example, has an embassy in Kuala Lumpur, while vietnam has it only in Budapest, but cooperation has been gradually developing for many years. Agreements were signed on double taxation, trade, investment and visa evasion for holders of diplomatic and official passports. Croatia's and Vietnam relations are likely to receive strong momentum, he/she, with the signing of this framework agreement, with the signing of this framework agreement, with support.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I abstained from consenting to the EU-Vietnam Global Framework Agreement on Collaboration and Cooperation, in this case to take account of Croatia's accession to the EU, since, while I respect the right of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam to negotiate agreements with other countries, I cannot support this Agreement which implies the antechamber of the conclusion of a free trade agreement between the EU and Vietnam, which in no case can be favourable to the interests of either the Vietnamese people or the Peoples of Europe, but will result in a worsening of the working conditions of workers in the Vietnamese textile sector, as well as a greater restriction on access to their lands following the entry of multinationals and foreign investment.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this legislative vote on the EU-Vietnam agreement on partnership and cooperation. We are opposed in principle to EU institutions signing international agreements on behalf of the UK. Only elected and accountable national governments should negotiate and conclude international agreements, not the unelected and unaccountable EU Commission.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The agreement with Vietnam strengthens cooperation with the European Union by helping the country on the path to better governance, respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms as well as in the fight against corruption and deals with issues such as progress on social rights issues, environmental protection and respect for the principle of sustainable development. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the Protocol on the accession of Croatia to the European Union.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The issue of this text is minimal, since it is a question of codifying texts. However, I voted against it because I do not recognise the legitimacy of the European Union to negotiate trade contracts.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ As a UKIP MEP, I oppose this agreement in the first place, as it takes something which should be the responsibility of Member States and gives it to the European Union. I believed it therefore to be consistent with these principles to oppose the update which takes account of the accession of Croatia.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. The Protocol to the Framework Agreement on Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, of the other part, shall take into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. I therefore support the conclusion of this Protocol.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. Although this is only codification, I reiterate my opposition to the claim of Brussels bureaucrats to negotiate commercial contracts: it is the Member States that must be at the helm in such negotiations.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I have endorsed this recommendation to approve a protocol to the EU-Vietnam Comprehensive Framework Agreement to take account of Croatia's accession to the EU.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. – We abstained because, although the trade treaty is technically contingent on respect for human rights, it continues to participate in a commercial logic that promotes the free market and has already proved harmful.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This recommendation relates to a comprehensive framework agreement on EU-Vietnam partnership and cooperation (a protocol taking into account Croatia's accession). Even if the legal status of these texts is not essential since it is codification, it is necessary to reiterate our opposition to the fact that Europe negotiates commercial contracts behind our backs. So I voted against it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Following Croatia's accession to the EU, it was necessary to negotiate the amendment of certain agreements with third countries, including Vietnam. I believe that this text does not take due account of the demands of our territories, which have suffered considerable economic damage as a result of the latest agreements between the EU and Vietnam, which is why I did not support this report with my vote.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it endorsed the conclusion of a Council Decision on a Protocol to the Framework Agreement between the European Union and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam on a comprehensive partnership and cooperation which takes account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. It is a purely legal technical document aimed at incorporating Croatia into all international agreements signed by the EU following its accession to the European Union.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 It is right that the Republic of Croatia, as a Member State of the European Union, should also participate in global partnership and cooperation agreements between the EU and foreign states. We consider this to be a due act.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU-Vietnam Global Partnership and Cooperation Framework Agreement aims to establish a partnership based on common interests and principles such as equality, mutual respect, the rule of law and human rights. The Socialist Republic of Vietnam has proved to be a secure, stable partner, which has shown pro-European orientation in recent decades, actively engaging in member states. The objectives of this Agreement are to promote human and social development, promote institutional reforms and sustainable development, promote sustainable management and environmental regeneration, as well as best practices in this area and the conservation of natural resources, prevent and address the consequences of climate change, support policies and instruments aimed at progressive integration into the global economy and trade. The inclusion of Croatia as a Contracting Party to the Agreement reaffirms the major strategic importance of the Republic of Vietnam as a partner of the Union and the positive impact that such an agreement brings economically and socially, but also in areas such as trade, human rights, migration, regional security, energy, science and technology.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 With the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union, it is necessary to negotiate the amendment of certain agreements signed or concluded between the European Union, or the European Union and its Member States, and one or more third countries or international organisations. I am voting against.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this legislative vote on the EU-Vietnam agreement on partnership and cooperation. We are opposed in principle to EU institutions signing international agreements on behalf of the UK. Only elected and accountable national governments should negotiate and conclude international agreements, not the unelected and unaccountable EU Commission.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I agreed to give my consent to the conclusion of the Protocol to the Framework Agreement on Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States and Vietnam to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union and therefore voted in favour.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the protocol to the EU-Vietnam Comprehensive Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement, which takes into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Protocol to the Framework Agreement on Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, of the other part, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted today on the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the signing, on behalf of the Union, of a Framework Agreement on Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, of the other part, in order to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union.  Although the EU's relations with Vietnam have been in a positive state for a long time and this state is one of our main partners in the Southeast Asian region, this framework agreement includes issues of strengthening free trade, neoliberal policies and political balances, which I find contrary and that is why I have decided to abstain.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure. The Protocol incorporates the Republic of Croatia as a contracting party to the Framework Agreement for Global Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Vietnam on the other, signed on 27 June 2012.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation because it is a mere formality to be carried out in view of Croatia's accession to the European Union: the EU's international agreements are intended to be signed by each of its Member States and therefore, with each enlargement, everything must also be accepted by each new entrant.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ The Framework Agreement on Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation (PCA) between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Vietnam, of the other part, was signed on 27 June 2012.  The PCA provides the basis for more effective engagement by the EU and its Member States with Vietnam.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with what was said in the recommendation concerning the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of a protocol to the Comprehensive Framework Agreement for Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, of the other part, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. – The importance attached to the traditional friendship and cooperation between Croatia and Vietnam on the basis of equality and mutual understanding, in line with its foreign policy of independence, diversification and multilateralisation and proactive integration is welcome. Earlier this year both leaders agreed that there is great potential for Vietnam and Croatia to expand their cooperation, and the signing of the economic cooperation agreement expected in this visit will facilitate cooperation in the oil and gas, infrastructure construction, tourism and food industries. It is beneficial for Croatia and also indirectly for other EU Member States to benefit from such friendship and cooperation with this growing economy, which will open up new opportunities for companies on both sides by increasing market access for goods and services.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 This topic is extremely sensitive. We are being asked today to give our opinion on a proposal for a comprehensive framework agreement for partnership and cooperation between the EU and a country that is a single-party regime. This can only – at first sight – give rise to great perplexity. However, we can only welcome the report inso extent that it seeks to use the agreement in order to push Vietnam to raise the level of respect for human rights. On this issue, in fact, the report is very clear and incisive, in various passages. I am therefore voting in favour.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I abstained from consenting to the EU-Vietnam Global Framework Agreement on Collaboration and Cooperation, in this case to take account of Croatia's accession to the EU, since, while I respect the right of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam to negotiate agreements with other countries, I cannot support this Agreement which implies the antechamber of the conclusion of a free trade agreement between the EU and Vietnam, which in no case can be favourable to the interests of either the Vietnamese people or the Peoples of Europe, but will result in a worsening of the working conditions of workers in the Vietnamese textile sector, as well as a greater restriction on access to their lands following the entry of multinationals and foreign investment.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this procedural report aimed at taking account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the EU in the EU-Vietnam Framework Agreement on Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This report proposes the approval by the European Parliament of the protocol taking into account Croatia's accession, as part of the conclusion of the Comprehensive Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation (APC) between the Union and Vietnam. Signed on 27 June 2012, the CPA provides for a number of mutual commitments between the EU and the Member States on the one hand and Vietnam on the other.  Following Croatia's accession to the European Union on 1 July 2013, this protocol aims to include Croatia among the contracting parties to the agreement. As this purely legal decision is not a problem, I voted in favour of the report.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this legislative vote on the EU-Vietnam agreement on partnership and cooperation. We are opposed in principle to EU institutions signing international agreements on behalf of the UK. Only elected and accountable national governments should negotiate and conclude international agreements, not the unelected and unaccountable EU Commission.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. The conclusion of this partnership and cooperation agreement will lead to closer political and economic ties between the European Union and Vietnam. It will enable greater cooperation on many issues of common interest, such as the fight against corruption, innovation, including new technologies, sustainable development, disarmament and the fight against terrorism.   The Vietnamese government has embarked on numerous reforms to modernize its economic model and integrate it into the global economy. In less than 10 years, GDP per capita has doubled and many foreign companies have increased investment. However, there is still work to be done politically. Social and labour standards remain too low, and certain freedoms, such as freedom of association and trade union rights, are not sufficiently guaranteed. This agreement should allow for improvements in these areas. This partnership, which comes at the same time as the conclusion of the EU-Vietnam Free Trade Agreement, will enable the European Union to increase its presence in Asia and its influence within regional groups in the area, such as ASEAN.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation Framework Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, of the other part, because this is the order following the 2010 Partnership and Cooperation Agreement concluded between the EU and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 It is proposed to vote against the report as, it is proven, an increase in the number of contracting parties to the agreements in no way favours the incoming party but the strong partners.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 We are dealing with a purely formal legal procedure, with a view to concluding the partnership and cooperation agreement between the EU and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, to take account of Croatia's accession to the EU. This is a partnership and cooperation agreement. Normally, we do not object to such agreements, where the content of the agreements has an effective correspondence with the words that designate it – partnership and cooperation. However, this agreement is part of the EU's strategy of materialising its foreign policy in its trade policy, and aims in practice to enshrine a free trade agreement, which we reject for a number of reasons, which relate both to the principle of liberalisation and deregulation of international trade, and to the impacts that the agreement may have on national productive sectors already facing serious difficulties today. , as is the case with oriziculture. In our final vote, these considerations weigh both the eminently technical and formal nature of this proposal.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. – Considering the free trade deal among other concerns I abstained.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the EU-Vietnam Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation Framework Agreement, because it is proven that the enlargement of the parties to the agreements in no way favours the incoming party but the strong partners.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome broader and deeper cooperation with Vietnam, drawing it closer to the EU and helping it on the road of reform towards good governance, respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, as well as the fight against corruption; economic, social & environmental progress must take into account the principle of sustainable development. It will be a major pillar for regional stability, progress in implementing international norms, and socio-economic development.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of taking into account that the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union should be taken into account in reference to the proposal for a Protocol to the Comprehensive Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, on the other.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the EU-Vietnam Framework Agreement on Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation (protocol on Croatia's accession) as I support the technical approach of this report.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the protocol to the EU-Vietnam Framework Agreement on Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation, a technical  measure to take account of the accession of Croatia.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We abstained because, although the trade treaty is technically contingent on respect for human rights, it continues to participate in a commercial logic that promotes the free market and has already proved harmful.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the EU-Vietnam Framework Agreement on Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation. This protocol takes into account the accession of Croatia to the EU.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Our attitude towards cooperation agreements remains firm: if the agreement is the product of a common desire of both the EU and the state with which the agreement is made, then it is acceptable. However, we reserve the right to criticise the content if this seeks to impose EU policy on each state. In the specific case of the EU-Vietnam agreement on the inclusion in this Croatia agreement and on the basis of our positions, we consider that the most appropriate attitude is that of abstention.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ As a UKIP MEP, I oppose this agreement in the first place as it takes something which should be the responsibility of Member States and gives it to the European Union. I believed it therefore to be consistent with these principles to oppose the update which takes account of the accession of Croatia.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to support this report, as I agree with what the proposed Protocol says, namely that it incorporates the Republic of Croatia as contracting party to the Agreement and commits the EU to providing the authentic version of the Agreement in the Croatian language.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the draft Decision of the Council on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Protocol to the Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation Framework Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, on the other, in order to take into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union, as this allows croatia to participate fully in the Framework Agreement concerned.  I believe that Croatia can benefit from a more intensive inclusion, within the framework of european union action in Southeast Asia, and thus contribute to the development of its own priorities, but also to the strategic goals foreseen by the agreement.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – I voted against this legislative vote on the EU-Vietnam agreement on partnership and cooperation. UKIP are opposed in principle to EU institutions signing international agreements on behalf of the UK. Only elected and accountable national governments should negotiate and conclude international agreements, not the unelected and unaccountable EU Commission.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted for this recommendation, which was simply to include Croatia, a new entrant to the European Union, at the conclusion of a comprehensive partnership and cooperation agreement between the Union and Vietnam.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. This protocol is purely technical, as Croatia was not yet part of the negotiations at the time of the start of the negotiations. I therefore agree with the Minutes.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome broader and deeper cooperation with Vietnam – drawing it closer to the EU and helping it on the road of reform towards good governance, respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, as well as the fight against corruption.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. The Partnership and Cooperation Agreement, which we are called upon to discuss, represents another step forward in relations between the EU and Vietnam. The Republic of Croatia has been included among the Contracting Parties, since the Act of Accession provides for croatia to accede to international agreements signed or concluded by the European Union. I have chosen to vote in favour because the cooperation of recent years has led to positive results for European companies on Vietnamese territory. I believe that, through this agreement, there will be a further spread of our products, with favourable effects on trade and an increase in the volume of European investment.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the protocol taking Croatia's accession into account in the context of the EU-Vietnam Comprehensive Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation. This vote is not directed against Croatia.  Even if this is only a codification, I would like to reiterate my opposition to the fact that the European Union concludes trade agreements in the place of the Member States.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this text to express my opposition to the fact that the Union negotiates trade contracts instead of the European states.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation Framework Agreement between the European Union and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam is a framework of cooperation in political and economic terms. I supported the recommendation for the signing of the protocol on technical adjustments to the Agreement due to the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I vote against the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and the Member States, of the Protocol to the Framework Agreement on Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, of the other part, in order to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union , because I do not consider it complete or substantiated.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the adjustment of the Framework Agreement on Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, on the one part, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, on the other part, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this framework agreement. Although this is a simple update of the Treaty to include Croatia in the partnership with Vietnam, which therefore has little impact, we oppose the Union's mania for negotiating agreements behind the backs of the States that make up it.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the recommendation on the protocol to the EU-Vietnam Comprehensive Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement (to take into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union). The aim of the agreement is to initiate cooperation in a number of areas, such as the fight against terrorism, sustainable development and human rights, and to develop a broad-based strategic partnership, forms the basis for a more effective engagement of the EU and its Member States towards Vietnam and represents further progress towards greater political and economic involvement of the Union in South-East Asia. On the basis of Article 6(2) of the Act of Accession of Croatia to the EU-Vietnam Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation Agreement, it is stipulates that Croatia may accede to international agreements signed and concluded by the EU and its Member States by protocol annexed to those agreements.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. This is a purely technical coordination, as Croatia was not part of the EU at the start of the negotiations on the PCA. There are no objections to this, so I agree with this report.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This text calls for amending the cooperation agreement with Vietnam to include Croatia, now a member of the European Union. This agreement is linked to the free trade agreement, which is expected to come into force soon.  I am, in principle, opposed to the enlargement of this Union, at the service of the interests of productivity and finance, and not all the citizens who have to deal with it. So I'm voting against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 This agreement translates into a real economic gain for both parties. The EU could be an important partner in the economic and peace development of a country that has made efforts to implement respect for human rights and fight corruption.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this technical measure, as Parliament must give its consent before new Member States can be recognised by signatories of the Agreement on Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation. In this case Parliament had to give its consent to the agreement being amended to take into account the Treaty of Accession of Croatia.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: Written. – It is a good thing that, with the adoption of this report, the EU and its partners are anticipating future developments in the European integration process.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. \u2012 While it is important to build on the fact that Vietnam has made great progress over the last two decades in meeting the Millennium Development Goals, poverty reduction, economic development, social security, employment, education and health care, it is important, within the framework of the EU-Vietnam Partnership and Cooperation Agreement, to insist on respect for press and media freedom, access to information, freedom of assembly and association, as well as freedom of religion , as reported by the UN Special Rapporteur on freedom of religion or belief.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome broader and deeper cooperation with Vietnam – drawing it closer to the EU and helping it on the road of reform towards good governance, respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, as well as the fight against corruption, whilst taking into account economic, social and environmental progress and the principle of sustainable development, therefore I have voted in favour of the Kalniete report on the EU-Vietnam Framework Agreement on Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation (protocol to take account of the accession of Croatia).

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 The Comprehensive Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and Vietnam establishes a key partnership with regard to common interests and policies, providing essential cooperation between the European Union and South-East Asia. As such, the Protocol here in consideration seeks to incorporate the Republic of Croatia as one of the Contracting Parties to the Agreement in order to take account of croatia's accession to the European Union. The European Union is bound to provide its Agreement in an authentic Document in Croatian language. I am voting in favour of this recommendation in order to pass the conclusion of the Protocol referred to herein.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The purpose of this vote is a comprehensive framework agreement on EU-Vietnam partnership and cooperation (a protocol taking into account Croatia's accession). Even if the legal status of these texts is not essential since it is codification, it is necessary to reiterate our opposition to the fact that Europe negotiates commercial contracts behind our backs. So I voted against it.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. This is a well-balanced report which welcomes broader and deeper cooperation with Vietnam, helping it to fight corruption, respect human rights and make sustainable economic, social and environmental progress.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this purely technical report, which aims to take account of Croatia's accession to the European Union, as part of the partnership agreement between the European Union and Vietnam. The European Union is the largest export market and the largest provider of official development assistance to Vietnam.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. Since Croatia was not yet in the EU when the original agreement was signed, this vote is a purely technical formality, which is why I would have voted in favour of the report.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The Protocol is necessary to take account of Croatia's accession to the EU.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒I support the protocol for the EU-Vietnam Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation Framework Agreement, which takes into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union in July 2013. The Framework Agreement on Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and Vietnam, on the other hand, was signed on 27 June 2012. The proposed protocol includes the Republic of Croatia as a contracting party to the Agreement and obliges the EU to provide the original version of the Treaty in Croatian.  In accession negotiations, Croatia has committed to assume all obligations that the European Union has towards third countries, and by membership of the European Union itself assumes the obligation to accept the existing international treaties concluded by the Union. I support Croatia's inclusion in all EU international treaties.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. The purpose of this text is a comprehensive framework agreement on EU-Vietnam partnership and cooperation (a protocol taking into account Croatia's accession). Even if the legal status of these texts is not essential since it is codification, it is necessary to reiterate our opposition to the fact that the EU negotiates commercial contracts behind our backs. So I voted against it.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒2012 Taking into account the draft protocol to the Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation Framework Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, on the other hand, in order to take into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union (13078/2014, the Council's request for consent in accordance with Articles 207 and 209 TB). and Article 218(6) (a) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (C8-0282/2014) as well as the recommendation of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, I agree with the adoption of this agreement in order to take Into account Croatia's membership after more than two years in Vietnam-EU relations.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. – I agree with the recommendation on the draft decision of the Council on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the protocol to the Framework Agreement on Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, on the other, in order to take into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union, Mep Kalniete.  The Republic of Croatia joined the European Union on 1 July 2013. In accordance with its Accession Act, Croatia accedes to international agreements signed or concluded by the European Union and its Member States through protocols to those agreements. The agreement was signed in Brussels on 27 June 2012 and, although not yet ratified by Member States, will encourage cooperation on a number of economic and social issues.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The Framework Agreement for Global Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Vietnam, of the other part, was signed on 27 June 2012. The proposed protocol incorporates the Republic of Croatia as a contracting party to the agreement and commits the EU to provide the authentic version of the Agreement in Croatian. I am voting in favour of the European Parliament approving the protocol.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted for the protocol taking into account Croatia's accession to the EU-Vietnam Comprehensive Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation. This is a minor change that is not a problem.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislative vote on the EU-Vietnam agreement on partnership and cooperation. We are opposed in principle to EU institutions signing international agreements on behalf of the UK. Only elected and accountable national governments should negotiate and conclude international agreements, not the unelected and unaccountable EU Commission.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. The Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and Vietnam, on the other, was signed on 27 June 2012. Under the proposed protocol, the Republic of Croatia is included in the agreement as a contracting party and the EU is committed to providing the authentic version of the agreement in the Croatian language.  The Council can only adopt the act after the favourable opinion of the European Parliament. What Parliament did today by voting in favour of it.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Due to the fact that the Comprehensive Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, of the other part, was signed in 2012 and that Croatia's accession to the European Union took place in 2013, the European Council decided to submit for approval to the European Parliament this Protocol to the Global Framework Agreement in order to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. Because it is practically a purely technical issue, i obviously voted in favour of this recommendation for approval.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. – We abstained because, although the trade treaty is technically contingent on respect for human rights, it continues to participate in a commercial logic that promotes the free market and has already proved harmful.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's recommendation to allow Croatia to accede to the Comprehensive Framework Agreement for Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this as I do not believe the EU should be managing the foreign affairs of Member States.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ This is a technical document which accompanies the European Parliament’s consent on this matter. This small document advances the draft Protocol to the Framework Agreement on Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation between the EU and its Member States, of the one part, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, on the other, to take account of the Republic of Croatia to the EU in 2013. It’s a reasonable addition to the agreement, and I supported it today.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The Framework Agreement on Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Vietnam, of the other part, was signed in Brussels on 27 June 2012. Following the Council's decision to sign the Protocol to the Framework Agreement on comprehensive partnership and cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Vietnam, on the other, it is necessary to take account of Croatia's accession to the European Union. Therefore, the approval of the proposed Protocol includes Croatia as a Contracting Party and obliges the EU to provide an authentic version of the Agreement in the Croatian language.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 It is important that the Framework Agreement take into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia and thus constitute an agreement concluded between the whole of the EU and Vietnam.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ I supported the Framework Agreement on Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, on the other hand, in order to take into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union, taking into account the new situation and the recommendation of the Committee on Foreign Affairs.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ Croatia approaches international agreements signed or concluded by the European Union and its Member States through protocols to those agreements. The Framework Agreement on Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its states, on the one hand, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, on the other, was signed in Brussels on 27 June 2012. The agreement is currently under ratification and has not yet entered into force. The proposed protocol includes the Republic of Croatia as a contracting party to the Agreement, and the EU undertakes to ensure a credible version of the Agreement in Croatian. I support this proposal because I think Vietnam is a vital economy with more than 90 million consumers and a growing workforce. Its market has great potential and offers many opportunities for European exports in the fields of agriculture, industry and services.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Protocol to the Framework Agreement on comprehensive partnership and cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, of the other part. This agreement will provide a modern and comprehensive framework for relations between the European Union and Vietnam, which have been further expanded and deepened in recent years. After 25 years of establishing diplomatic relations between the EU and Vietnam, we have now voted on a comprehensive partnership and cooperation agreement that, together with the trade agreement, will allow us to deepen and upgrade our relations further. Of course, we must not forget that this country still has many challenges, particularly in the area of human rights. Vietnam needs reforms, particularly in the area of respect for minority rights, the fight against corruption and justice.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We abstained in the 3 reports on the framework of an agreement on cooperation between the EU and Vietnam, showing, on the one hand, respect for the will of the State to conclude such agreements and, on the other hand, maintaining our critical attitude towards EU foreign policy, particularly with regard to the content and objectives of such agreements. The HYPOCRITICAL attitude of the EU to apply its principles and values as they see fit, as well as the promotion of neoliberal policies in third countries through trade agreements that create dependency relations and operate to the detriment of the interests of the peoples, find us vertically opposed.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The extension of the agreements with regard to the Contracting Parties in no way favours the incoming Party but the strong partners.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. – International cooperation is one of the objectives that the EU has prioritised in recent years. Cooperation with any third State with which an agreement may be concluded under the conditions of compliance with certain European rules in the areas concerned shall be concerned.  Relations between the EU and Vietnam have seen significant progress in recent years, developing from a predominantly economic framework to a more comprehensive relationship. This has contributed to the lifting of bans on foreign direct investment in several sectors of the Vietnamese economy, progress in poverty reduction, social security, education and healthcare. Vietnam is also one of the world's fastest growing states, both economically and internationally engaged in Southeast Asia and the wider Pacific.  At the same time, in Vietnam, a number of worrying restrictions on freedom of expression, freedom of the press, access to information, freedom of assembly and association and freedom of religion remain. The conclusion of the comprehensive partnership and cooperation agreement with Vietnam confirms its commitment to the general principles of international law and respect for democratic principles and human rights. In these circumstances, the agreement is an important step forward for both parties.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I expressed my support for the Council's draft decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the protocol to the comprehensive framework agreement on partnership and cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, on the other hand, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Protocol to the Framework Agreement on Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, of the other part, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. With this vote, the Parliament gave its consent to the conclusion of the protocol.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. The aim of the proposed Council decision is to adopt the Protocol with the Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation Framework Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, on the other hand, in order to take into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union.  As a Croatian representative, I support this recommendation since the Republic of Croatia has accepted all the rights and obligations provided for in the Treaty with its accession to the Union, and the adoption of the Protocol in this case makes changes related to linguistic adjustment as well as obligations of a technical nature.  The Comprehensive Partnership Agreement between the Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and Vietnam on the other, was signed in Brussels in 2012, and this Protocol also allows the Republic of Croatia, on an equal footing with other Member States, to consider amendments to the Agreement and texts related to the Agreement in Croatian. So I voted positively.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. - Recommendation on a draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Protocol to the Framework Agreement on comprehensive partnership and cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, of the other part, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union, as I believe that this agreement should be renewed as a result of Croatia's accession to the European Union.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. – We abstained because, although the trade treaty is technically contingent on respect for human rights, it continues to participate in a commercial logic that promotes the free market and has already proved harmful.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution hoping that the situation will evolve positively. This text has important reminders referring to the fact that the democratic situation in Cambodia is not acceptable today. Let me remind people that the Human Rights Watch annual report has flagged the violent efforts of Hun Sen and his Cambodian People’s Party (CPP) to suppress the mass protests against the deeply flawed elections of July 2013 and force the opposition Cambodia National Rescue Party (CNRP) to accept the election results. The Cambodian Government violently beats up opposition parliamentarians and will not recognise the legitimate role played by the political opposition in contributing to Cambodia’s overall economic and political development. The Cambodian authorities have issued arrest warrants, charges and sentences against the CNRP leaders Sam Rainsy and Kem Sokha, CNRP members of the National Assembly and the Senate and CNRP activists and organisers.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The rapporteur for the report agreed to the conclusion of the protocol, which I supported, including on the recommendation of the Committee on Foreign Affairs.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. – We abstained because, although the trade treaty is technically contingent on respect for human rights, it continues to participate in a commercial logic that promotes the free market and has already proved harmful.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. This Protocol incorporates the Republic of Croatia as a contracting party to the Agreement and the EU undertakes to incorporate the original version of the Croatian-language Agreement. We are therefore talking about a procedure necessary to incorporate this new Member State into that agreement, so I consider it necessary to vote in favour.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'I logically voted in favour of the Protocol to take account of Croatia's accession. With this vote, the European Parliament authorised the conclusion of this protocol.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 These Global Partnership and Cooperation Agreements should aim to establish a modern, comprehensive and mutually beneficial partnership based on common interests and principles such as equality, mutual respect, the rule of law and human rights. However, the reality and the very tone of the resolutions point in the opposite directions. The question of respect for human rights is only an adornment that is omitted when it comes to trading with Israel, but which soon takes on an imperial tone of clear interference when we talk about countries that have legitimately opted for different paths of development. On the other hand, these agreements are based on the laws of free trade and a supposed sane and fair competition that, in practice, guarantees the dominance of large multinational companies, which end up destroying local economies, from which comes the reserve army that will provide the cheap and docile labor that capital so appreciates.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. This is a purely technical coordination, as Croatia was not part of the EU at the start of the negotiations on the PCA. There are no objections to this, so I agree with this report.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 This is merely a legal procedure to conclude the partnership and cooperation agreement between the EU and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam to take account of Croatia's accession to the EU. As a partnership and cooperation agreement which we generally do not tend to object to, the agreement specifically referred to is part of the European Union's strategy to materialise its foreign policy in its trade policy, and aims to enshrine a free trade agreement, which we reject. For the reasons set out above, we abstained.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I abstained from consenting to the EU-Vietnam Comprehensive Framework Agreement on Collaboration and Cooperation, since, while I respect the right of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam to negotiate agreements with other countries, I cannot support this Agreement which implies the antechamber of the conclusion of a free trade agreement between the EU and Vietnam , which in no case can be favourable to the interests of either the Vietnamese people or the Peoples of Europe, but will result in a worsening of the working conditions of workers in the Vietnamese textile sector, as well as a greater restriction on access to their lands following the entry of multinationals and foreign investment into the country.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this legislative vote on the EU-Vietnam agreement on partnership and cooperation. We are opposed in principle to EU institutions signing international agreements on behalf of the UK. Only elected and accountable national governments should negotiate and conclude international agreements, not the unelected and unaccountable EU Commission.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The agreement with Vietnam strengthens cooperation with the European Union by helping the country on the path to better governance, respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms as well as in the fight against corruption and deals with issues such as progress on social rights issues, environmental protection and respect for the principle of sustainable development. For these reasons I voted in favour of the agreement.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. In the same way that I objected to the conclusion of the protocol taking into account Croatia's accession and on the comprehensive framework agreement on partnership and cooperation between the Union and Vietnam, I do not support the approval of this agreement on the grounds that the European Union should not be allowed to conclude trade agreements.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ As a UKIP MEP, I oppose this agreement in the first place, as it takes something which should be the responsibility of Member States and gives it to the European Union. I believed it therefore to be consistent with these principles to oppose consent to this agreement.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of concluding a Framework Agreement on comprehensive partnership and cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, of the other part.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. Although this is only codification, I reiterate my opposition to the claim of Brussels bureaucrats to negotiate commercial contracts: it is the Member States that must be at the helm in such negotiations.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I supported this report which endorses the comprehensive framework partnership agreement between the EU and Vietnam. In terms of foreign policy, the project covers specific areas, such as cooperation on human rights and the rule of law, war debris and the prevention of natural disasters. It will also enable better development cooperation (the EU is Vietnam's first support for development aid).

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. – We abstained because, although the trade treaty is technically contingent on respect for human rights, it continues to participate in a commercial logic that promotes the free market and has already proved harmful.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This recommendation relates to a comprehensive EU-Vietnam Partnership and Cooperation Framework Agreement (approval). Even if the legal status of these texts is not essential since it is codification, it is necessary to reiterate our opposition to the fact that Europe negotiates commercial contracts behind our backs. So I voted against it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that the demands of our territories, which have suffered considerable economic damage since the last agreements between the EU and Vietnam, have not been taken into account, i.e. sectors such as rice production, I did not intend to support this report with my vote.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supports the conclusion of a Council decision on a framework agreement on comprehensive partnership and cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, of the other part. The Agreement covers areas of cooperation such as the development of principles, norms and standards, raw materials, migration, the fight against organised crime and corruption, industrial policy, SME, tourism, energy, education and culture, environment, climate change and natural resources, agriculture, health, civil society, state and public administration modernisation.

name: Renata BRIANO
