text: in writing. 2012 The anticipation of the successful closure of the Comprehensive Framework Agreement for Partnership and Cooperation between the EU and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam is a sign of vietnam's willingness to move forward on the path of opening up, modernising and normalising relations that it has begun with its role in ASEAN in recent years. Although there are still many steps to be taken, this process must be encouraged and the framework agreement must be approved as it is consistent with the cultural, economic and political interests of both parties.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU-Vietnam Global Partnership and Cooperation Framework Agreement aims to establish a partnership based on common interests and principles such as equality, mutual respect, the rule of law and human rights. Relations between the Union and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam are based on close historical, political and economic ties, but not least based on the idea of cooperation and mutual aid. The objectives of this agreement are to promote human and social development, promote institutional reforms and sustainable development, promote sustainable management and environmental regeneration, as well as best practices in this area and the conservation of natural resources, prevent and address the consequences of climate change, and support policies and instruments aimed at progressive integration into the global economy and trade. I agree with the objectives of this agreement and believe that it is the prerequisite for the formation of a comprehensive and coherent economic and political framework, and also a tool that will provide answers to a number of problems that we are currently facing, which is why I have expressed myself in favour of this report.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against. On the contrary, the Italian production sector must strengthen duties and barriers to an unfair competitor without the regulations to which European companies are subject. We must protect our farmers and entrepreneurs.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this legislative vote on the EU-Vietnam agreement on partnership and cooperation. We are opposed in principle to EU institutions signing international agreements on behalf of the UK. Only elected and accountable national governments should negotiate and conclude international agreements, not the unelected and unaccountable EU Commission.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I agree to give my consent to the conclusion of the Framework Agreement on Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States and Vietnam and therefore voted in favour.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of approving the EU-Vietnam Comprehensive Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We are voting in favour of the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Framework Agreement on Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, of the other part.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted today on the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the signing, on behalf of the Union, of a framework agreement on comprehensive partnership and cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, on the other. Although the EU's relations with Vietnam have been in a positive state for a long time and this state is one of our main partners in the Southeast Asian region, this framework agreement includes issues of strengthening free trade, neoliberal policies and political balances which I find contrary and that is why I have decided to abstain.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure. The recommendation concerns the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Comprehensive Framework Agreement for Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, of the other part. The agreement strengthens sectoral cooperation in a wide range of areas. In particular, the agreement covers eu standard political clauses on human rights, the International Criminal Court, weapons of mass destruction, small arms and light weapons, as well as counter-terrorism.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation because I consider cooperation with third countries to the European Union to be fundamental. It is important to maintain and manage relations with non-EU states in the best possible way, not least in order to elevate Europe's image as a set of states with an important value in solidarity and cooperation at world level. For these reasons, I am voting in favour of approving the agreement.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with what was said in the recommendation concerning the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Comprehensive Framework Agreement for Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, of the other part.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. – For me it is positive having the EU finally reaching an agreement on trade with one of Asia’s most dynamic economies which establishes a good standard for the trade relationship between the EU and South East Asia as a whole. For this reason I see no reason for not voting in favour to further deepen our partnership and cooperation with Vietnam. There is EU interest in a growing economy and this agreement will provide significant new opportunities for companies on both sides, by increasing market access for goods and services – noting that over 31 million jobs in Europe depend on exports – so having easier access to a growing and fast developing market like Vietnam, with its 90 million consumers, is great news.  Until 2014, the EU was the second trading partner for Vietnam after China (not including trade within ASEAN), representing 10% of total Vietnamese trade. The EU was Vietnam’s second export destination (after the US), with the EU purchasing as much as 18% of Vietnam’s global exports. EU-Vietnam trade in goods was worth over EUR 28.2 billion, with EUR 22.1 billion of imports from Vietnam into the EU and EUR 6.2 billion of exports from the EU to Vietnam.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 This topic is extremely sensitive. We are being asked today to give our opinion on a proposal for a comprehensive framework agreement for partnership and cooperation between the EU and a country that is a single-party regime. This can only – at first sight – give rise to great perplexity. However, we can only welcome the report inso extent that it seeks to use the agreement in order to push Vietnam to raise the level of respect for human rights. On this issue, in fact, the report is very clear and incisive, in various passages. I am therefore voting in favour.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I abstained from consenting to the EU-Vietnam Comprehensive Framework Agreement on Collaboration and Cooperation, since, while I respect the right of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam to negotiate agreements with other countries, I cannot support this Agreement which implies the antechamber of the conclusion of a free trade agreement between the EU and Vietnam , which in no case can be favourable to the interests of either the Vietnamese people or the Peoples of Europe, but will result in a worsening of the working conditions of workers in the Vietnamese textile sector, as well as a greater restriction on access to their lands following the entry of multinationals and foreign investment into the country.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ This is a procedural vote on the EU-Vietnam Framework Agreement on Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. Its aim is to update the framework agreement in order for it to apply also for Croatia. The vote gives consent to the conclusion of the agreement. Hence I have voted in favour of this procedural report.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This report proposes the European Parliament's approval of the European Union's decision on the Comprehensive Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation (APC) between the EU and Vietnam. Signed on 27 June 2012, the CPA provides for a number of mutual commitments between the EU and the Member States on the one hand and Vietnam on the other. It covers traditional European prerogatives on human rights, the International Criminal Court, weapons of mass destruction, small arms and counter-terrorism. In particular, it aims to strengthen cooperation between the two sides on a range of policy areas, such as taxation, migration, health, the environment, social affairs and technology. Supporting these objectives, I voted in favour of the report.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this legislative vote on the EU-Vietnam agreement on partnership and cooperation. We are opposed in principle to EU institutions signing international agreements on behalf of the UK. Only elected and accountable national governments should negotiate and conclude international agreements, not the unelected and unaccountable EU Commission.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. With this vote, we approved the conclusion of a Comprehensive Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation (APC) between the European Union and Vietnam. In addition to Vietnam, this CPA will enable the European Union to increase its political and economic engagement in Southeast Asia.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. The conclusion of this partnership and cooperation agreement will lead to closer political and economic ties between the European Union and Vietnam. It will enable greater cooperation on many issues of common interest, such as the fight against corruption, innovation, including new technologies, sustainable development, disarmament and the fight against terrorism.   The Vietnamese government has embarked on numerous reforms to modernize its economic model and integrate it into the global economy. In less than a decade, GDP per capita has doubled and many foreign companies have increased investment. However, there is still work to be done politically. Social and labour standards remain too low, and certain freedoms, such as freedom of association and trade union rights, are not sufficiently guaranteed. This agreement should allow for improvements in these areas. This partnership, which comes at the same time as the conclusion of the EU-Vietnam Free Trade Agreement, will enable the European Union to increase its presence in Asia and its influence within regional groups in the area, such as ASEAN.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution giving the Approval of the European Parliament to the Council's conclusion on behalf of the Union of the Comprehensive Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam. I think it is appropriate to strengthen existing relations between the parties and to establish cooperation in all areas of common interest. I am thinking in particular of tourism, financial services, the information society, the environment and natural resources, cooperation in maritime and fisheries and, last but not least, human rights.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation Framework Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, of the other part, in order to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the EU, as I consider this to be a way of responsible foreign policy of the Union.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 It is proposed to vote against the report as, it is proven, enlargement to the parties to the agreements in no way favours the incoming party but the strong partners.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 This agreement follows the previous cooperation agreements already concluded between the EU and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam. It is part of the EU's foreign policy and guidelines to engage both economically and economically with countries and regional blocs in South-East Asia. The terms under which this agreement is concluded lay in its text the way for the conclusion of a free trade agreement between the two parties, which will condition the bilateral relations of the Member States, and which we reject. Preceding this agreement, which is also being prepared, this Agreement refers to the facilitation of trade in plants and animals and their products, a situation which concerns us, particularly with regard to the impacts on the national rice paddy market, when we know that Vietnam is among the three main rice producers in the world. There are many areas where the agreement provides for collaboration. We look closely and foremost at the introduction of clauses aimed at promoting the alignment of Vietnam's economic policies with those of the EU through economic reforms and economic integration. In view of the scope and objectives of this Agreement, we voted against it.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the broader and deeper cooperation with Vietnam, which will bring it closer together and bring it closer to the European Union in the future and help it on the path of reforms towards good governance, respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, as well as in the fight against corruption, and will steer the country towards economic, social and environmental progress in the light of the principle of sustainable development.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the adoption of the EU-Vietnam Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation Framework Agreement, because it is proven that the enlargement of the Parties to the Agreements in no way favours the incoming Party but the strong partners.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome broader and deeper cooperation with Vietnam, drawing it closer to the EU and helping it on the road of reform towards good governance, respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, as well as the fight against corruption; economic, social and environmental progress must take into account the principle of sustainable development. It will be a major pillar for regional stability, progress in implementing international norms, and socio-economic development.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this important agreement, convinced that greater cooperation and cooperation between the EU and Vietnam can bring significant benefits for both sides.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. Closer cooperation between European states and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam is beneficial for both sides. I therefore welcome the fact that current relations are being strengthened.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the  report on the EU-Vietnam Framework Agreement on Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation given I welcome broader and deeper cooperation with Vietnam – drawing it closer to the EU and helping it on the road of reform towards good governance, respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, as well as the fight against corruption; economic, social and environmental progress taking into account the principle of sustainable development.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We abstained because, although the trade treaty is technically contingent on respect for human rights, it continues to participate in a commercial logic that promotes the free market and has already proved harmful.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the Recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Framework Agreement on Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, of the other part showing my consent to the conclusion of the agreement.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Our attitude towards cooperation agreements remains firm: if the agreement is the product of a common desire of both the EU and the state with which the agreement is made, then we agree. However, we reserve the right to criticise the content if it seeks to impose EU policy on each state. In the specific case of the EU-Vietnam agreement and on the basis of our positions we consider that the most appropriate attitude is that of abstention.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ As a UKIP MEP, I oppose this agreement in the first place as it takes something which should be the responsibility of Member States and gives it to the European Union. I believed it therefore to be consistent with these principles to oppose consent to this agreement.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to support this report as the PCA provides the basis for more effective engagement by the EU and its Member States with Vietnam. The agreement covers the EU’s standard political clauses on human rights, the International Criminal Court, weapons of mass destruction, small arms and lights weapons, and counter terrorism. Lastly the PCA strengthens the sectoral cooperation across a wide range of policy fields, such as taxation, migration, health, environment, climate change, energy, education and culture, labour, employment and social affairs, science and technology, and transport.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation Framework Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, on the other, as this gives consent for the conclusion of the agreement.  The implementation of this agreement contributes to mutual benefits and strategic cooperation in various fields and in international economic for a. In addition, EU-ASEAN cooperation is strengthened, which can further strengthen the Role of the European Union in the region. It is clear that in order to achieve concrete results and take serious action, a regular communication mechanism should be put in place to ensure effective synergic action.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – I voted against this legislative vote on the EU-Vietnam agreement on partnership and cooperation. UKIP are opposed in principle to EU institutions signing international agreements on behalf of the UK. Only elected and accountable national governments should negotiate and conclude international agreements, not the unelected and unaccountable EU Commission.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this recommendation from the European Parliament, which approves the conclusion of a comprehensive partnership and cooperation agreement between the Union and Vietnam, which will allow for an intensification of trade with this important country while subjecting this cooperation to respect for human rights.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I agree with this report. The agreement with Vietnam will bring many new opportunities for Europe's industry, particularly in the area of goods and freight transport. Vietnam is one of the most dynamic and fastest growing economies in Asia and offers many benefits for Europe's economy and politics.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome broader and deeper cooperation with Vietnam – drawing it closer to the EU and helping it on the road of reform towards good governance, respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, as well as the fight against corruption.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. The Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement (PCA) with Vietnam is a major step towards greater EU political and economic involvement in South-East Asia. Cooperation with Vietnam is part of the wider framework of cooperation with the member countries of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN). I have decided to vote in favour, not only for economic reasons, but also because the PCA with Vietnam contains the EU's standard political clauses on human rights, the International Criminal Court, weapons of mass destruction, small arms and light weapons, as well as the fight against terrorism.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. National Front MEPs voted against the comprehensive framework agreement on partnership and cooperation between the European Union and Vietnam. This vote is not directed against Vietnam. I would like to reiterate my opposition to the fact that the European Union is concluding partnership and cooperation agreements on behalf of the Member States. Moreover, free trade is in no way a cure for France's problems and will not necessarily help Vietnam to develop in a balanced way.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this text to express my opposition to the fact that the Union negotiates trade contracts instead of the European states.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported the recommendation of Mep Barbara Lochbihler, who gives my consent to the EU-Vietnam Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation Framework Agreement signed on 27 June 2012, as the Agreement opens the door to better political and economic relations between Member States and Vietnam and the EU's involvement in South East Asia.  The agreement defines a partnership on economic and trade cooperation with the ultimate goal of signing the Free Trade Agreement, but also cooperation in the areas of human rights, climate change and the fight against terrorism and organised crime.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of a framework agreement on comprehensive partnership and cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, on the other, because it is not complete or substantiated and I refer further to the reasons I set out in detail in my speech of 16/12/2015 to the plenary of the European Parliament.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to give my assent to the PCA between Vietnam and the EU. This should lead to a further deepening of our partnership.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. Dominique Martin voted against this framework agreement. As with the previous vote, we oppose in principle the Union's mania to negotiate agreements behind the backs of the States that make up it, in particular trade agreements which will greatly impact our producers.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EU-Vietnam Comprehensive Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement (resolution). The aim of the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement is to create a modern partnership on the basis of shared interests and principles, such as equality, mutual respect, the rule of law and human rights. Vietnam is a valuable partner for the European Union, especially in the area of climate change. A partnership agreement with Vietnam can define future relations and strengthen cooperation in the face of global challenges, such as the fight against terrorism. In addition, a comprehensive partnership and cooperation agreement can have positive effects on job creation and consequently reduce poverty, which will have positive effects in the field of tourism, economic and social affairs, and in the field of human rights.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The agreement has been negotiated for a very long time, and Europe's economy has had a particularly strong interest in it. Most recently, it was mainly about the implementation of copyright protection, corruption and human rights. The compromise reached is not really satisfactory. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This text validates the forthesty cooperation agreement and free trade agreement with Vietnam. He extols the supposed benefits of "coordination of macroeconomic policies" on the Union's utterly flawed model in this area. I am voting against, as with all the other free trade agreements in the Union, which are motivated only by the mercantile interests of multinational firms, when solidarity protectionism and ecological planning in trade should be promoted.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 This agreement translates into a real economic gain for both parties. The EU could be an important partner in the economic and peace development of a country that has made efforts to implement respect for human rights and fight corruption.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the conclusion of the Framework Agreement on Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation between the EU and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: Written. – The adoption of this report confirms the objective that the EU and Vietnam can benefit economically from the ratification of the Agreement on a Broad Partnership and Cooperation. This agreement contains the seeds for more employment and the fight against poverty. On the basis of this agreement, vietnam's further integration into the world economy can be encouraged.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. \u2012 Although, in the context of the approval of the Framework Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, on the other, it should be appreciated that Vietnam has systematically taken a highly pro-European stance in recent decades, we are obliged to strongly demand respect for human rights and religious freedoms. It is essential to insist on an end to discrimination and repression of ethnic and religious minorities, including harassment, surveillance, intimidation, detention, house arrest, physical assaults and travel bans, as well as christians, Buddhists or followers of other religions. At the same time, I join in the sharp condemnation of the fact that there are an estimated 500 prisoners sentenced to death in Vietnam and the call for the Vietnamese Government to introduce an immediate moratorium on executions and to adopt appropriate legislation to abolish the death penalty.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome broader and deeper cooperation with Vietnam – drawing it closer to the EU and helping it on the road of reform towards good governance, respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, as well as the fight against corruption, whilst taking into account economic, social and environmental progress and the principle of sustainable development, therefore I have voted in favour of the Lochbihler report on EU-Vietnam Framework Agreement on Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation (consent).

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 The Recommendation at issue here on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Protocol on the Agreement—The Global Framework for Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and the Member States, of the one part, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, on the other, intends to approve the conclusion of its Framework Agreement by the consent given by the European Parliament. A number of issues are addressed in this Framework Agreement, including European Union policies on human rights, the International Criminal Court, weapons of mass destruction, small arms and small arms and the fight against terrorism, thereby strengthening bilateral cooperation in important sectors such as health, the environment, energy or education. I am voting in favour of this act, as the Framework Agreement in question seeks to provide a more effective link between the European Union and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam in the field of various policies of common interests.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This recommendation relates to a comprehensive EU-Vietnam Partnership and Cooperation Framework Agreement (approval). Even if the legal status of these texts is not essential since it is codification, it is necessary to reiterate our opposition to the fact that Europe negotiates commercial contracts behind our backs. So I voted against it.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the relationship between the European Union and Vietnam. The aim was to approve the Council's decision to conclude a framework agreement for partnership and cooperation with that country. The European Union is the largest export market and the largest provider of official development assistance to Vietnam.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. Although the content of the agreement has some good indications, which would primarily benefit the European economy and should safeguard human rights, unfortunately some compromises have been made that are not really satisfactory. I would have abstained from voting.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The agreement strengthens economic and political relations between the EU and Vietnam, addressing, inter alia, concerns such as respect for human rights and the fight against terrorism.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I support the agreement for the EU-Vietnam Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation Framework Agreement as it contains two fundamental determinants. First, it establishes stronger economic ties between the European Union and Vietnam and opens up new markets in the East to the European Union. On the other hand, it allows the European Union to financially assist Vietnam under the Development Assistance Programme.  It is essential that the European Union continues to insist on the literal implementation of international treaties and conventions ensuring respect for human rights and freedoms. The fight against other aspects of endangering the functioning of the state, and therefore its citizens, such as terrorism, corruption, crime, natural disasters, etc., remains a top priority.  Aid to Vietnam should be provided in a number of areas, in particular in taxation, labour, employment and social transfer policies, health, the environment, climate change adaptation and science and technology. Quality sectoral cooperation is key to Vietnam's development.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This recommendation relates to a comprehensive EU-Vietnam Partnership and Cooperation Framework Agreement (approval). Even if the legal status of these texts is not essential since it is codification, it is necessary to reiterate our opposition to the fact that Europe negotiates commercial contracts behind our backs. So I voted against it.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒2012 Taking into account the draft Framework Agreement on Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, on the other (18204/2010), the Council's request for consent in accordance with Articles 207 and 208 TSR And Article 218(6) (a) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (C8-0062/2015) and the Recommendation of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, I agree and support the decision to conclude the Framework Agreement on Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation between the EU and Vietnam.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. – I agree with the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion of the Framework Agreement on Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, on the other, Ms Lochbihler. Over the past 30 years, the European Union and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam have signed a number of agreements to edit their relationship.  This agreement will replace the existing legal framework governed by the 1995 agreement between the EU and Vietnam and from 1980 on cooperation between the European Economic Community and the Member States of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN),which also became Vietnam in 1999. I believe that this agreement will contribute to greater economic and political participation of the European Union in Southeast Asia.  The agreement will increase cooperation with Vietnam on many political issues, such as taxation, migration, health, the environment, climate change, energy, education and culture, labour, employment and social policy, science and technology, and transport. I believe this is the next step in increasing european union activities in Southeast Asia and intensifying cooperation with ASEAN countries.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement (PCA) with Vietnam, was initialled by the parties on 4 October 2010, in Brussels, and signed on 27 June 2012. The PCA with Vietnam is a major step towards greater EU political and economic involvement in South-East Asia, strengthens sectoral cooperation in a wide range of policy areas and facilitates the conclusion of a free trade agreement with the country. For all this, I am voting in favour of the European Parliament approving the conclusion of this agreement.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I supported the approval for the EU-Vietnam Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation Framework Agreement. This is a necessary and important step for the European Parliament in concluding the agreement.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislative vote on the EU-Vietnam agreement on partnership and cooperation. We are opposed in principle to EU institutions signing international agreements on behalf of the UK. Only elected and accountable national governments should negotiate and conclude international agreements, not the unelected and unaccountable EU Commission.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. The Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and Vietnam, on the other, was signed on 27 June 2012. Under the proposed protocol, the Republic of Croatia is included in the agreement as a contracting party and the EU is committed to providing the authentic version of the agreement in the Croatian language.  The Council can only adopt the act after the favourable opinion of the European Parliament. What Parliament did today by voting in favour of it.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 As 2015 marks the 25th anniversary of diplomatic relations between the EU and Vietnam, the partnership agreement established is of enormous significance for both signatories. The EU is currently Vietnam's largest export market, so ratification of the partnership agreement should also take into account economic and financial reforms that help boost Vietnam's entry into the global economic framework.  It has already assured that it is willing to draw up a plan that is capable of implementing the recommendations of the Universal Periodic Review of the United Nations Human Rights Council, also pledging to continue its efforts to implement the Judicial Reform by 2020.  The EU should therefore continue to support Vietnam in its economic development and promote good governance, the rule of law and the application of democratic principles. It therefore seems to me essential to support this Agreement, which not only seeks to strengthen the strategic partnership between the EU and Vietnam, following the 1995 Framework Agreement for Cooperation, but also to contribute to the development of a country that is on its own merits on the path of sustainability.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. – We abstained because, although the trade treaty is technically contingent on respect for human rights, it continues to participate in a commercial logic that promotes the free market and has already proved harmful.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament recommendation authorising the Council to conclude the Comprehensive Framework Agreement for Partnership and Cooperation with the Socialist Republic of Vietnam on behalf of the EU. This agreement provides the basis for strengthening mutual cooperation in many areas of strategic importance such as trade and investment, the fight against climate change, science and technology, energy, migration and work. Finally, I would like to point out that this new form of partnership represents a further step towards more effective and effective EU political and economic involvement in South-East Asia.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against, as I do not believe the EU should be managing the foreign affairs of Member States.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Overwhelmingly supported in the committee, I have voted in favour of this AFET Resolution on the Framework Agreement in plenary to give my consent to it. I welcome broader and deeper cooperation in Vietnam, which will help it on the road to reform and towards good governance, respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms in addition to the fight against corruption, economic, social and environmental progress, while taking into account the principle of sustainable development.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Vietnamese economy showed several positive signs of performance improvement in 2014. In the World Bank's Doing Business 2014 ranking, Vietnam ranked 78th in the 189 economies of the world compared to the business environment, which I consider to be a very good result from the point of view of a developing country. As the EU is the second largest trading partner for Vietnam after China, I consider it a success that there is a framework agreement on comprehensive partnership and cooperation between the EU and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, on the other. This is good news and I believe that the framework agreement will create a good standard for trade relations between the EU and South-East Asia as a whole. I expect Vietnam to continue successfully stabilising the macroeconomic situation, accelerating the process of restructuring SOEs through privatisation, improving the conditions for doing business in the country, increasing efficiency and modernising the agricultural sector, improving the development of science, combating corruption and edging administrative and judicial reform.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider it important for the EU to seek to continue and strategically develop its trade relations outside the EU. I support the agreement with Vietnam.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. I support this report taking into account the draft Council decision and the recommendation of the Foreign Affairs Committee. I join the rapporteur's appeal that the national parliaments of the Member States of the European Union ratify the agreement with the Socialist Republic of Vietnam as soon as possible.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ This is a well-balanced report which welcomes broader and deeper cooperation with Vietnam, helping the country to fight corruption, respect human rights and make sustainable economic, social and environmental progress.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ On October 5, 2015, the Trans-Pacific Partnership Agreement (TPP) of twelve Pacific Ring countries, including Vietnam, was finalised, creating a new trading bloc that accounts for 36% of global GDP and could have far-reaching effects on world trade. 2015 marks the 25th anniversary of relations between the EU and Vietnam. These relationships quickly expanded from the area of trade and aid and became more comprehensive.  The agreement sets out a wide range of future relations to further enhance cooperation in addressing global and regional challenges, such as good governance and anti-corruption and economic and social progress, taking into account the principle of sustainable development, disarmament and weapons of mass destruction and the fight against terrorism. The EU is Vietnam's largest export market and, together with its Member States, is the largest provider of official development assistance to Vietnam. I support the European Parliament's legislative resolution on the Council's decision to conclude on behalf of the Union, the Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation Framework Agreement between the European Union and its Member States and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, for the great strategic importance of Vietnam as a key partner of the EU in South East Asia and in ASEAN, and for the comprehensiveness of the Agreement and the cooperation it envisages.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We abstained in the 3 reports on the framework of an agreement on cooperation between the EU and Vietnam, showing, on the one hand, respect for the will of the State to conclude such agreements and, on the other hand, maintaining our critical attitude towards EU foreign policy, particularly with regard to the content and objectives of such agreements. The HYPOCRITICAL attitude of the EU to apply its principles and values as they see fit, as well as the promotion of neoliberal policies in third countries through trade agreements that create dependency relations and operate to the detriment of the interests of the peoples, find us vertically opposed.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Increasing the number of Contracting Parties to the Agreements in no way favours the incoming Party but strong partners.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I spoke in favour of the comprehensive framework agreement on partnership and cooperation between the European Union and its Member States on the one hand and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam on the other.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of a legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Framework Agreement on Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, of the other part. With this vote, the Parliament gave its consent to the conclusion of the protocol.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I have given my consent to the Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation Framework Agreement between the European Union and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, as I consider this partnership to be based on interests for both sides. Indeed, both sides can benefit greatly from this agreement in the areas of trade, investment in job creation and poverty reduction, development and the economy.  On the other hand, we cannot ignore the state of fundamental human rights in Vietnam and the fact that more than 500 prisoners are awaiting the death penalty. That is why I consider it an extremely important part of this ratification to call on Vietnam to consistently respect human rights and abolish the death penalty.  As Vietnam has made significant progress in meeting the Millennium Development Goals, poverty reduction, economic development, social security, employment, education and health over the past two decades, I believe that for the European Union this agreement will mean a long-term benefit, so I voted for it.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. - I supported the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Framework Agreement on comprehensive partnership and cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, on behalf of the European Union, because I believe that eu-Socialist Republic of Vietnam's cooperation is particularly important in the area of trade policy, as the EU is the largest exporter to Vietnam.  The EU must establish, with Vietnam, proper cooperation and a useful partnership that will strengthen common interests and have positive effects on the economy, trade, investment, new technologies, job creation and poverty reduction.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. – We abstained because, although the trade treaty is technically contingent on respect for human rights, it continues to participate in a commercial logic that promotes the free market and has already proved harmful.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution hoping that the situation will evolve positively. This text has important reminders referring to the fact that the Democratic situation in Cambodia is not acceptable today. Let me remind people that the Human Rights Watch annual report has flagged the violent efforts of Hun Sen and his Cambodian People’s Party (CPP) to suppress the mass protests against the deeply flawed elections of July 2013 and force the opposition Cambodia National Rescue Party (CNRP) to accept the election results. The Cambodian Government violently beats up opposition parliamentarians and will not recognise the legitimate role played by the political opposition in contributing to Cambodia’s overall economic and political development. The Cambodian authorities have issued arrest warrants, charges and sentences against the CNRP leaders Sam Rainsy and Kem Sokha, CNRP members of the National Assembly and the Senate and CNRP activists and organisers.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The rapporteur for the report agreed to the conclusion of the protocol, which I supported, including on the recommendation of the Committee on Foreign Affairs.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. – We abstained because, although the trade treaty is technically contingent on respect for human rights, it continues to participate in a commercial logic that promotes the free market and has already proved harmful.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. We are talking about an agreement which was signed on 27 June 2012 and can only be adopted if the European Parliament consents. The Agreement lays the groundwork for greater commitment on the part of the EU and its Member States to Vietnam, and covers European clauses on human rights, the International Criminal Court, weapons of mass destruction, small arms and light weapons and the fight against terrorism. The Agreement strengthens sectoral cooperation in areas such as taxation, migration, health, the environment, climate change, energy, education and culture, work, employment and social affairs, science and technology and transport. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. I voted in favour of this framework agreement on a broad partnership and cooperation between the European Union and Vietnam. I think it is appropriate to strengthen the existing trade relations between Vietnam and the European Union in the sectors that are of common interest to us.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 These Global Partnership and Cooperation Agreements should aim to establish a modern, comprehensive and mutually beneficial partnership based on common interests and principles such as equality, mutual respect, the rule of law and human rights. However, the reality and the very tone of the resolutions point to contrary meanings. The question of respect for human rights is only an adornment that is omitted when it comes to trading with Israel, but which soon takes on an imperial tone of clear interference when we talk about countries that have legitimately opted for different paths of development. On the other hand, these agreements are based on the laws of free trade and a supposed sane and fair competition that, in practice, guarantees the dominance of large multinational companies, which end up destroying local economies, from which comes the reserve army that will provide the cheap and docile labor that capital so appreciates.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The agreement has been negotiated for a very long time, and Europe's economy has had a particularly strong interest in it. Most recently, it was mainly about the implementation of copyright protection, corruption and human rights. The compromise reached is not really satisfactory. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained in the vote on the Lochbihler report on the conclusion of the Framework Agreement on Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation with Vietnam. While I agree that partnership and cooperation with Vietnam, which is one of the fastest growing economies, should be strengthened, on the other hand, I do not agree with some of the parts that have been included in the report. Among the most important were articles that talked about same-sex marriage or the still legal death penalty in Vietnam. However, although I abstained in the final vote, I believe that Vietnam is on track to try to improve the human rights situation and cooperation with the European Union, which has been going on for 25 years, should be encouraged.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 This agreement follows the previous cooperation agreements already concluded between the EU and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam and is part of EU policy to influence South-East Asia in policy and economically.  The current terms in which the text is celebrated lays out in its text the way for the conclusion of a free trade agreement between the two parties, which will condition the bilateral relations of the Member States, and which we reject. Preceding this agreement, which is also already being prepared, this refers to the facilitation of trade in plants and animals and their products, a situation which concerns us, in particular for that of the national rice paddy, when we know that Vietnam is among the top three rice producers in the world. There are many areas where the agreement provides for collaboration. We look closely and foremost at the introduction of clauses aimed at promoting the alignment of Vietnam's economic policies with those of the EU through economic reforms and economic integration.  By the scope and objectives of this Agreement, we voted against.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur I would like to say that the main objective of the Framework Agreement between the European Union and Vietnam on comprehensive partnership and cooperation is to promote the development of further development of bilateral relations in a wide range of areas. Stimulating economic and trade contacts, promoting investment and more active reciprocal tourism, mutual respect for each other's values and traditions, as well as human rights , these and a number of other aspects form both the fundament of this framework agreement and the fundament for our future relations. Vietnam is one of the fastest-growing countries in both the Southeast Asia region and the Pacific. Consequently, the promotion of cooperation is based on taking into account each other's interests, it is perfectly logical and quite fruitful in perspective. Thank you, support!

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Mr President, in this Chamber we have got to stop lecturing third countries on how they should or should not behave. I refer in particular to the original text of paragraph 33 in this report, which was talking to Vietnam about its visa arrangements and where signs should be displayed in embassies. This sort of thing is absolute nonsense. We need to recognise that third countries actually have their own democratic rights and their own sovereignty. I am making this as a general point, not just on that specific issue. This is something that happens far too often in this place, and we need to stop imposing our mindset upon other peoples across the world.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I took part in the debate on Vietnam yesterday, and I must confess that I did not know in full the articles 33 to 35 in question. I've studied them, and I really don't see any reason not to support the deal.  I think the demands we have made have been reasonable, and I do not consider Articles 33 to 35 in that incriminating framework agreement to be too far- wrong. For this reason, I supported this agreement, and at the same time I am committed to the European Union continuing to support the growth of strategic relations with the countries of South-East Asia. This is very important for our security, for the further development of trade relations.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote on this Resolution on the EU-Vietnam Comprehensive Framework Agreement on Collaboration and Cooperation, since, while I respect the right of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam to negotiate agreements with other countries, I cannot support this Agreement which implies the antechamber of the conclusion of a free trade agreement between the EU and Vietnam , which in no case can be favourable to the interests of either the Vietnamese people or the Peoples of Europe, but will result in a worsening of the working conditions of workers in the Vietnamese textile sector, as well as a greater restriction on access to their lands following the entry of multinationals and foreign investment into the country. In addition, Parliament's text makes interference considerations on Vietnamese domestic policy, such as calling on the country to continue the reform process towards establishing a market economy. For these reasons I did not vote for it.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report on the EU-Vietnam agreement on partnership and cooperation. We are opposed in principle to EU institutions signing international agreements on behalf of the UK. Only elected and accountable national governments should negotiate and conclude international agreements, not the unelected and unaccountable EU Commission. The EU has no right to interfere in the domestic affairs of non-EU countries.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The agreement with Vietnam strengthens cooperation with the European Union by helping the country on the path to better governance, respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms as well as in the fight against corruption and deals with issues such as progress on social rights issues, environmental protection and respect for the principle of sustainable development. For these reasons I voted in favour of the resolution accompanying the Agreement.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This agreement is once again based on the dogma of free trade promoted by the European Union. Several aspects of this text constitute interference in the internal affairs of a sovereign state. We believe in the National Front that free trade is not necessarily a panacea. It will not solve French ills, nor will it help Vietnam to develop in a balanced way. That is why I voted against this text.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for a Framework Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, of the other part. The partnership and cooperation agreement concluded with Vietnam underlines the high strategic importance that vietnam attaches to as a crucial EU partner in Southeast Asia. The agreement defines future broad-based relations with a view to strengthening further cooperation and overcoming global and regional challenges, such as good governance and the fight against corruption, economic and social progress in accordance with the principle of sustainable development, disarmament and weapons of mass destruction, as well as the fight against terrorism. I support calls on the governments and parliaments of the Member States to speed up the ratification process in order to ensure that the agreement enters into force.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. Contrary to what the Eurocrats seem to think, free trade is in no way a remedy for France's problems and will not help Vietnam to develop in a balanced way. That is why I voted against this motion for a resolution.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I supported this resolution in which Parliament welcomes the comprehensive framework agreement on partnership with Vietnam. While there is no doubt about the economic boom with the implementation of the agreement, Parliament also hopes that it will have a positive impact on respect for democratic principles and human rights. In this regard, MEPs are urging the Vietnamese government to impose an immediate moratorium on executions at a time when more than 500 people are currently on death row. They also call on the EU and Vietnam to work towards the creation of an instrument to monitor human rights developments in subsequent negotiations on the free trade agreement. In the defence of workers, the resolution calls on the Vietnamese authorities to ratify ILO conventions on freedom of association and the protection of trade union rights and on the right to organize and bargain collectively.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. – We abstained because the language used in the paragraphs on respect for human rights is too weak to justify a vote in favour of the report.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the conclusion of the Comprehensive Framework Agreement on Collaboration and Cooperation with Vietnam, which highlights the country's great strategic importance as the Union's key partner in Southeast Asia and ASEAN. This Agreement also defines future relations over a broad spectrum to further strengthen cooperation in the face of regional and global challenges, such as good governance and the fight against corruption, economic and social progress taking into account the principle of sustainable development, disarmament and weapons of mass destruction or the fight against terrorism.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report concerns a comprehensive eu-Vietnam Partnership and Cooperation Framework Agreement (resolution). I voted against it because I remain convinced that free trade is in no way a cure for France's problems and will not necessarily help Vietnam to develop in a balanced way.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I have always been opposed to this partnership and cooperation agreement with the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, in which the demands of our territories and our production realities, which have been severely affected by previous agreements with that country, especially in the textile sector and in the production of rice and cereals in general, have not been taken into account at all. The EU should do the interests of our citizens and entrepreneurs first, not the exact opposite, which is why I did not support this text with my vote.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. I've abstained. It is positive about the wording on human rights, including a moratorium on the death penalty and control mechanisms in the agreement on MRIssues. As well as the emphasis on ILO conventions, women's rights and LGBT issues. In that part, the agreement can set an example for many other future EU trade agreements. But the ideological keynote of the agreement is neoliberal market economy, without any real consideration of issues of social justice and sustainable development. That's why I'm abstaining.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted for this resolution because it has been a speech by Parliament on the development of relations between the EU, its Member States and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam. The EU is Vietnam's largest export market, and the EU, together with its Member States, is the largest provider of official development assistance to Vietnam. Parliament welcomed the conclusion of a comprehensive partnership and cooperation agreement with Vietnam and stressed the high strategic importance of Vietnam as a crucial EU partner in Southeast Asia and ASEAN. This agreement defines future broad-based relations with a view to strengthening further cooperation and overcoming global and regional challenges, such as good governance and the fight against corruption, economic and social progress, in line with the principle of sustainable development, disarmament and weapons of mass destruction, as well as the fight against terrorism. Parliament therefore calls on the governments and parliaments of the Member States to speed up the ratification process in order to ensure that the agreement enters into force.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Vietnam is making progress towards normalizing regional relations and recognizing certain civil rights. These improvements must be encouraged and promoted in order to ensure that civil rights are recognised in their entirety and that respect for human rights is guaranteed. In this respect, we cannot ignore the still serious situation of widespread poverty and poor sanitation in which a large proportion of the population still lives (with a large number of women and children): Vietnam must be supported in its process of modernisation and the fight against poverty. Global partnership and cooperation agreements in EU-ASEAN relations are also important in this area. EU-ASEAN cooperation could be further strengthened in the development of the financial sector, in the transparency and coordination of macroeconomic policies and in the path of interregional détente recommended by the United Nations for South-West Asia.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU-Vietnam Global Partnership and Cooperation Framework Agreement aims to establish a partnership based on common interests and principles such as equality, mutual respect, the rule of law and human rights. The Socialist Republic of Vietnam has proved to be a secure, stable partner, which has shown pro-European orientation in recent decades, actively engaging in supporting Member States. The Union is the most important export market for Vietnam, with both the Union and Vietnam benefiting economically from the ratification of the agreement. The Socialist Republic of Vietnam has adopted a series of economic and social reforms to stimulate Vietnam's integration into the world economy, an effort i can only welcome, I encourage the continuation of these reforms. I have expressed myself in favour of this resolution, because I strongly believe in the major strategic importance of the Republic of Vietnam, as a partner of the Union. I believe that strengthening this partnership can be a valuable tool through which we can respond to global and regional challenges, through which we can make progress on an economic and social level, but also in areas such as trade, human rights, migration, regional security, energy, science and technology.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against. Let us protect the Italian production sectors against an unfair competitor who lacks the bureaucracy to which our companies are forced.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report containing a non-legislative motion for a resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Comprehensive Framework Agreement for Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, of the other part. The agreement forms the basis of a more effective EU commitment to Vietnam, given that Vietnam has systematically taken a markedly pro-European approach in recent decades. The agreement aims to establish a modern partnership on the basis of shared interests and principles such as equality, mutual respect and the rule of law. Let us not forget that Vietnam has achieved a great achievement in achieving the Millennium Development Goals over the last two decades. It is therefore important to deepen and expand political dialogue and cooperation with the Socialist Republic of Vietnam and to continue to support the development of Vietnam's capacity to promote respect for good governance.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report on the EU-Vietnam agreement on partnership and cooperation. We are opposed in principle to EU institutions signing international agreements on behalf of the UK. Only elected and accountable national governments should negotiate and conclude international agreements, not the unelected and unaccountable EU Commission. The EU has no right to interfere in the domestic affairs of non-EU countries.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Resolution which sets out the elements in the EU’s relationship with Vietnam and the concerns that still remain. The EU Partnership and Cooperation Agreement (PCA) with Vietnam has moved rapidly from trade and aid to a more comprehensive relationship based on shared interests and principles such as equality, mutual respect, the rule of law and human rights. It should be noted that over the past decades Vietnam has consistently adopted a markedly pro-European approach and has been actively engaged with the EU. On the other hand, a number of concerns still remain like restrictions in Vietnam on freedom of expression both online and offline, freedom of the press and media, access to information, freedom of assembly and association as well as freedom of religion. Vietnam is also one of the major source countries for victims of human trafficking.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. The Lochbihler report points out that respect for human rights, democracy and the rule of law is of paramount importance and calls on the Vietnamese Government to implement the RECOMMENDATIONS of the UNHCR, to promote greater political participation in the country, to guarantee standards of protection for workers, to apply a moratorium on the death penalty to 500 prisoners awaiting execution and to safeguard the environment. , stimulating initiatives such as investment in solar energy and rethinking the choice to invest in nuclear power. However, we must not forget that Vietnam is a one-party regime and that the Vietnamese State is firmly and centrally held in the hands of the Communist Party. The merit of the report is that, despite this, there is no renunciation of the attempt at dialogue with the country, but rather an attempt is being made to use the PCA agreement to keep the Vietnamese Government involved, without it being possible to derive it even further from the right path. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support this resolution and at the same time share the Vietnamese government's concerns about the increase in corruption which is one of the country's main problems. The resolution calls for closer consideration to cases where citizens reporting corruption are targeted by the authorities and calls on the Vietnamese authorities to thoroughly investigate arbitrary prosecutions against journalists, blog editors and complainants. It also deplores the Vietnamese government's misuse of Article 258 of the Penal Code on the "abuse of democratic freedoms" – which brings a prison sentence of up to seven years. It notes that only a few cases have been successfully brought to justice despite the anti-corruption law and calls on the government to improve its implementation. The resolution rightly calls on the Vietnamese authorities to make greater efforts against corruption in order to send a positive signal to foreign investors, and rightly also points out that incomplete legal infrastructure and the system of corruption lead to financial uncertainty and pose a serious obstacle to investment and business activities.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted today on the report on the draft Council decision on the signing, on behalf of the Union, of a framework agreement on comprehensive partnership and cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, on the other. Although the EU's relations with Vietnam have been in a positive state for a long time and this state is one of our main partners in the Southeast Asian region, this framework agreement includes issues of strengthening free trade, neoliberal policies and political balances which I find contrary and that is why I have decided to abstain.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to vote in favour, as in the measure Parliament welcomes the conclusion of the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement with Vietnam, stressing the strategic importance of Vietnam as a key partner of the European Union in South-East Asia and ASEAN. The agreement defines future relations in a wide range of areas, in order to further strengthen cooperation in the face of global and regional challenges such as good governance and the fight against corruption, economic and social progress that takes into account the principle of sustainable development, disarmament and weapons of mass destruction, and the fight against terrorism. Parliament highlights the impact that a future trade and investment agreement could have on job creation and poverty reduction. It also expressed the hope that the mutual agreement on respect for democratic principles and human rights would further promote the long-established dialogue with the Vietnamese Government on the promotion of freedom of expression, assembly, association and religion enshrined in the Vietnamese Constitution itself and in the European Convention on Human Rights. The increase in the EU ODA budget for Vietnam of EUR 400 million over the period 2014-2020 is welcomed.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report and I am pleased to note the coincidence of the 25th anniversary of the launch of EU-Vietnam relations. This country has proved to be an important reality and over the last two decades has contributed strongly to achieving the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs): poverty reduction, economic development, social security, employment, education and health. For these reasons, I believe that it is important to implement and improve, with new projects and agreements, the relations between the two forces in question, in order to continue along the path of development at world level that has been fought on so far.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of concluding the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement with Vietnam as vietnam is a key EU partner in South-East Asia and ASEAN. This agreement will help to further strengthen EU-Vietnam cooperation in order to promote economic and social progress that takes account of the principle of sustainable development, as well as to address important global challenges such as the fight against corruption and terrorism, disarmament and the abolition of weapons of mass destruction. I also believe that both sides will benefit economically from the ratification of the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement, as the economic and financial reforms initiated by the Vietnamese authorities will further contribute to Vietnam's integration into the world economy.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. – The Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation Agreement aims to establish a modern, broad-based and mutually beneficial partnership, based on shared interests and principles such as equality, mutual respect, the rule of law and human rights. From a trade point of view, the EU is Vietnam’s biggest export market; whereas the EU together with its Member States is the largest ODA provider to Vietnam and there will be an EU budget increase for this purpose of 30 % to EUR 400 million in 2014-2020.  I also underline the concern about Vietnam being one of the major source countries for victims of human trafficking, and about reports of large numbers of children, especially boys who are not protected by the law against sexual abuse, falling victim to child prostitution, trafficking or maltreatment, urging Vietnam to develop strong and effective child protection laws that protect all children regardless of their gender.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 This topic is extremely sensitive. We are being asked today to give our opinion on a proposal for a comprehensive framework agreement for partnership and cooperation between the EU and a country that is a single-party regime. This can only – at first sight – give rise to great perplexity. However, we can only welcome the report inso extent that it seeks to use the agreement in order to push Vietnam to raise the level of respect for human rights. On this issue, in fact, the report is very clear and incisive, in various passages. I am therefore voting in favour.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote on this Resolution on the EU-Vietnam Comprehensive Framework Agreement on Collaboration and Cooperation, since, while I respect the right of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam to negotiate agreements with other countries, I cannot support this Agreement which implies the antechamber of the conclusion of a free trade agreement between the EU and Vietnam , which in no case can be favourable to the interests of either the Vietnamese people or the Peoples of Europe, but will result in a worsening of the working conditions of workers in the Vietnamese textile sector, as well as a greater restriction on access to their lands following the entry of multinationals and foreign investment into the country. In addition, Parliament's text makes interference considerations on Vietnamese domestic policy, such as calling on the country to continue the reform process towards establishing a market economy. For these reasons I did not vote for it.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ This Resolution forms part of a number of votes that need to be taken in conjunction on the EU-Vietnam Framework Agreement on Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. Its aim is to update the framework agreement in order for it to apply also for Croatia, and hence I supported it.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This resolution echoes the conclusion of the Comprehensive Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation (APC) between the EU and Vietnam. MEPs welcome the government's reforms to integrate Vietnam into the global market economy, as well as the commitments it has made to implement the UN Council's recommendations on human rights and reform the judicial system by 2020. Finally, the European Parliament calls on Vietnam to step up efforts to improve the socio-economic conditions of religious and ethnic minorities. Considering the strategic importance of this agreement, given that Vietnam is a key partner of the Union in the South-East Asia area and in ASEAN, I voted in favour of this report.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report on the EU-Vietnam agreement on partnership and cooperation. We are opposed in principle to EU institutions signing international agreements on behalf of the UK. Only elected and accountable national governments should negotiate and conclude international agreements, not the unelected and unaccountable EU Commission. The EU has no right to interfere in the domestic affairs of non-EU countries.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution. The EU-Vietnam Comprehensive Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation will enable the EU to increase its political and economic engagement in South-East Asia, notably through the creation of an instrument to monitor human rights developments.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. The conclusion of this partnership and cooperation agreement will lead to closer political and economic ties between the European Union and Vietnam. It will enable greater cooperation on many issues of common interest, such as the fight against corruption, innovation, including new technologies, sustainable development, disarmament and the fight against terrorism. The Vietnamese government has embarked on numerous reforms to modernize its economic model and integrate it into the global economy. In less than 10 years, GDP per capita has doubled and many foreign companies have increased investment. However, there is still work to be done politically. Social and labour standards remain too low, and certain freedoms, such as freedom of association and trade union rights, are not sufficiently guaranteed. This agreement should allow for improvements in these areas. This partnership, which comes at the same time as the conclusion of the EU-Vietnam Free Trade Agreement, will enable the European Union to increase its presence in Asia and its influence within regional groups in the area, such as ASEAN.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on a Framework Agreement on comprehensive partnership and cooperation between the EU and Vietnam. The reason for this is the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement concluded in 2010 and between the EU and Vietnam.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 It is proposed to vote against the report as, among other things, it welcomes the recognition of gay marriage.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 Addressing the partnership and cooperation agreement to be concluded between the EU and Vietnam, in a framework that anticipates the conclusion of a free trade agreement, this resolution unsubstantiates a set of recommendations and demands in a posture of shameless interference in the country's internal affairs. We are faced with the well-known neocolonial facet of this project of European capitalist integration, of which traditional criticism stemming from human rights, freedom and democracy is a hypocritical expression. In practice, the report supports the EU's vision of materialising its foreign policy in its trade policy, supporting the position of actually imposing existing cooperation policies to impose fundamental changes in political regimes, which serve, first of all, the interests of the EU and the powers, as well as its economic and financial groups. A spirit that goes against the principle, recognised in the report itself and in the agreement, of basing the relationship on common interests and principles, such as equality and mutual respect. We voted against it.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the broader and deeper cooperation with Vietnam, which will bring it closer together and bring it closer to the European Union in the future and help it on the path of reforms towards good governance, respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, as well as in the fight against corruption, and will steer the country towards economic, social and environmental progress, taking into account the principle of sustainable development.
