However, we must call for respect for freedom of religion to see to it an end to discrimination and oppression of ethnic and religious minorities, including harassment, surveillance, intimidation, detention, house arrest, physical assaults and travel bans on Christians and Buddhists. The competent authorities must refrain from suppressing the peaceful exercise of the right to freedom of expression, assembly and association.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report containing a proposal for a non-legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the signing, on behalf of the Union, of a framework agreement on comprehensive partnership and cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, on the other, because it welcomes the recognition of gay marriage.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this well-balanced report that takes into account our opinion and underlines important considerations across a broad range of norms and rights, such as human rights, democracy, social, political, labour, the situation of women and children, environment and fair trade. Vietnam has made a great achievement in attaining the MDGs, poverty reduction, economic development, social security, employment, education, and healthcare in the last two decades. I believe we need a  broader and deeper cooperation with Vietnam, drawing it closer to the EU and helping it on the road of reform towards good governance, respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, as well as the fight against corruption; I support economic, social and environmental progress taking into account the principle of sustainable development. Cooperation with Vietnam is a major pillar for regional stability, progress in implementing international norms, and socio-economic development.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Resolution after analysing it and verifying that it can mean a significant improvement in cooperation between the EU and Vietnam, as well as an improvement in the living conditions of the citizens of Vietnam and a commitment to the general principles of international law and respect for democratic principles and human rights, as an essential element of the Agreement. I am sure that both the EU and Vietnam will benefit economically from the ratification of the Global Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement, which will have a positive impact on trade, investment, job creation and poverty reduction.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP's non-legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Comprehensive Framework Agreement for Partnership and Cooperation between the EU and its Member States, of the one part, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, of the other part. I supported the agreement, despite the fact that Vietnam still adopts the death penalty today, is one of the main countries of origin of victims of trafficking in human beings and does not respect all freedoms of expression, religion and non-discrimination. Nevertheless, I felt that the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement will not only foster the strongly pro-European approach that the Vietnamese Government is committed to developing, but the EU will also benefit indirectly through the promotion of decent working conditions and poverty reduction in Vietnam. Indeed, the agreement with Vietnam will, on the one hand, allow the implementation of new legislation for human protection and freedom, on the other hand, will provide a great opportunity for the EU, because it will be able to strengthen its position in Asia and play a greater role in the region; finally, the partnership agreement can be the instrument for promoting the basic objectives of peace, democracy and supranational sharing.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. Closer cooperation between European states and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam is beneficial for both sides. I therefore welcome the fact that current relations are being strengthened.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ President, I voted in favour of the  report on the EU-Vietnam Framework Agreement on Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation given I welcome broader and deeper cooperation with Vietnam – drawing it closer to the EU and helping it on the road of reform towards good governance, respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, as well as the fight against corruption; economic, social and environmental progress taking into account the principle of sustainable development.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We abstained because the language used in the paragraphs on respect for human rights is too weak to justify a vote in favour of the report.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the EU-Vietnam Framework Agreement on Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation (resolution). I welcome the conclusion of the Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation Agreement with Vietnam underlining the major strategic importance held by Vietnam as a crucial partner of the EU in South East Asia and ASEAN. The Agreement defines the future relations in a broad spectrum, to further enhance the cooperation on global and regional challenges: good governance, the fight against corruption, economic and social progress taking into account the principle of sustainable development, disarmament and weapons of mass destruction.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report concerns the EU-Vietnam Cooperation Agreement. To the extent that this is the product of a common desire of both the EU and Vietnam, then I agree. However, I reserve the right to criticise the content if this seeks to impose EU policy on each state with which it concludes such agreements. Unfortunately, in this particular case, I do not think that this report is balanced and that is why I choose abstention as my most appropriate position.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ As a UKIP MEP, I oppose this agreement in the first place as it takes something which should be the responsibility of Member States and gives it to the European Union. I believed it therefore to be consistent with these principles to oppose this resolution. Paragraph 33 took to the ultimate degree an EU desire to micromanage the affairs of third nations, to the extent of mentioning signage at embassies and fees for visas and passports. I naturally opposed this, and was glad to see that the original text – on this part at least – fell.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to support this report, as Vietnam over the past decades has consistently adopted a markedly pro-European approach and has been actively engaged with the EU. Vietnam has made great achievements in attaining the MDGs, poverty reduction, economic development, social security, employment, education and healthcare in the last two decades. Vietnam is a valued partner for the EU in the climate change negotiations and has pledged to reduce emissions by 8 to 10 per cent, compared with 2010, and to reduce energy consumption per GDP by 1 to 1.5 per cent per year in the run-up to the UN Climate Change Conference in Paris in November 2015. I welcome the fact that that Vietnam has taken specific measures to develop knowledge and research on science and technology, to address the weaknesses in higher education, to attract overseas Vietnamese and to cooperate with European and US academic institutions to help in this process.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: in writing. ‒ The Framework Agreement on Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation which the EU signed with Vietnam in 2010 is based on principles such as equality and human rights, as well as on shared interests. The Resolution highlights the positive progress made in the country. However, it also points to the changes that still need to be made in areas such as freedom of religion and of expression, and calls for a moratorium on capital punishment, as well as for ratification of the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court. My group and I strongly believe in cooperation as a vehicle of human rights, which is why I have voted in favour of this report. By the way, I believe that the Euro must be abolished. It leads to dissension and discord in Europe.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a non-legislative resolution by the European Parliament on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation Framework Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, on the other, as this further strengthens the EU's cooperation with Vietnam.  Vietnam has strategic importance for the European Union as it is its main partner in South East Asia and ASEAN, and further strengthens this Agreement by working together in the areas of human rights protection, visa regime, vietnam's capacity development in promoting the rule of law and others. However, it is still necessary to increase citizens' participation in the democratic functioning of the state, to allow full freedom of expression, to reduce all forms of discrimination, to put an end to corruption, and to reform the judiciary.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – My UKIP colleagues and I voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report on the EU-Vietnam agreement on partnership and cooperation. We are opposed in principle to EU institutions signing international agreements on behalf of the UK. Only elected and accountable national governments should negotiate and conclude international agreements, not the unelected and unaccountable EU Commission. The EU has no right to interfere in the domestic affairs of non-EU countries.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because it welcomes the future conclusion of a comprehensive partnership and cooperation agreement between the Union and Vietnam, while encouraging the Union to support the establishment of good governance rules and the promotion of human rights in that country.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. The resolution clearly shows what progress Vietnam has made and where there is still room for improvement. The critical paragraph on visa and consular fees, which lacks any diplomatic flair, has fallen. That is why I agree with the resolution.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposal. It is a well-balanced report which welcomes broader and deeper cooperation with Vietnam, helping it to fight corruption, respect human rights and make sustainable economic, social and environmental progress.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ The Comprehensive Partnership Cooperation Agreement (PCA) with Vietnam concerns science, migration, tourism and culture topics. Vietnam has undertaken some reforms in order to reach a socialist-oriented market economy status. At the same time, Vietnam and the European Union have reached a Trade Agreement in 2015, the Free Trade Agreement (FTA). Both agreements, FTA and PCA, have some positive impact regarding the justice system and fight against corruption. However, Vietnam should ratify the ILO Convention and implement gender equality and reforms in public administration. This is why I voted abstention.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote in favour, as the Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement (PCA) with Vietnam is consistent with the EU's objective of creating a stable and cohesive economic and political framework in relations between the EU and the ASEAN countries. I believe that the PCA will strengthen trade cooperation in a wide range of strategic areas, such as taxation, migration, health, environment, climate change, energy, education and culture, work, employment and social affairs, science and technology, transport.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the Lochbihler report on the EU-Vietnam Comprehensive Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation. The Commission does not have to replace member states by entering into partnership and cooperation agreements. This text is once again an interference in the internal affairs of sovereign states. Moreover, free trade is in no way a cure for France's problems and will not necessarily help Vietnam to develop in a balanced way.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this report because free trade is in no way a cure for France's problems and will not necessarily help Vietnam to develop in a balanced way.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I am in support of cooperation with Vietnam, but the EU should not put challenges in agreements that interfere with the internal policies of the states concerned. For example, to call on Vietnam to consider opening its nuclear power plant.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported the recommendation of Mep Barbara Lochbihler, who gives my consent to the EU-Vietnam Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation Framework Agreement signed on 27 June 2012, as the Agreement opens the door to better political and economic relations between Member States and Vietnam and the EU's involvement in South East Asia.  The agreement defines a partnership on economic and trade cooperation with the ultimate goal of signing the Free Trade Agreement, but also cooperation in the areas of human rights, climate change and the fight against terrorism and organised crime.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report containing the proposal for a non-legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of a framework agreement on comprehensive partnership and cooperation between the European Union and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, because I do not consider it complete or substantiated and I refer further to the reasons I set out in detail in my speech of 16 December 2015 to the plenary of the European Parliament.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this proposal, which stresses the importance of Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation Agreements in EU-ASEAN relations and believes that EU-ASEAN cooperation could be strengthened in various areas such as financial sector development, transparency and the coordination of macro-economic policies.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. Dominique Martin voted against this resolution. As with the two previous votes, we oppose in principle the Union's mania to negotiate agreements behind the backs of the States that make up it. However, free trade is not a cure for France's problems, and will not necessarily help Vietnam develop in a balanced way.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. Balanced motion for a resolution praising progress but also outing the problems that still need to be addressed. I therefore agree with this report.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this recommendation as it involves a more effective basis for engagement between the EU and Vietnam.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The European Union is in the process of initiating a free trade agreement with Vietnam. The rapporteur has done everything possible to link this agreement to the one containing a "human rights clause" in order to be able to activate it to suspend the neoliberal agreement. In other agreements with third countries, this clause remains systematically a dead letter, such as Saudi Arabia, which plans to lash the 2015 Sakharov Prize. There is no reason why it should be any different in this case. Above all, in the context of the Union's competition with the United States of America to create the largest free trade area possible in Southeast Asia. Not to mention the systematic lesson-giver and interference in the affairs of other countries. I'm voting against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the EU-Vietnam Comprehensive Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation. The EU-Vietnam Framework Cooperation Agreement entered into force on 1 June 1986 and is of fundamental importance. The EU is Vietnam's largest export market, as well as the largest donor of Public Development Assistance to vietnam. The EU must remain vigilant in order to improve the situation of human rights, freedom of expression, freedom of the press and the media, access to information and freedom of religion.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution on the Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the EU and Vietnam as the Union can provide additional support to increasing good governance and the rule of law in Vietnam. The agreement also means that the EU can offer its expertise in the realms of protecting workers’ rights, freedom of expression and combating corruption.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: Written. – The EU is Vietnam's largest export market. And with EUR 400 million in aid for the period 2014 – 2020, Europe is also the largest donor of official development aid to this country. In order to help Vietnam move towards further integration into the world economy, it is recommended to implement a number of important reforms. The lifting of a ban by Vietnam on foreign direct investment will ensure a positive investment climate. It is also recommended that Vietnam make efforts to close the country's poverty gap. His intention to develop and accelerate scientific research and technology education together with European knowledge institutions will have a positive impact on the necessary diversification of vietnam's economic fabric, product development and export opportunities. This report also contains clear recommendations to the Vietnamese authorities to maintain a moratorium on the death penalty, to allow greater democratic participation of its citizens, to allow opposition parties, to guarantee freedom of the press for journalists and to ensure free access to information for all citizens. The adoption of strict legislation on child protection can be an important step in the fight against trafficking in human beings.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider the resolutions on the EU-Vietnam Framework Agreement on comprehensive partnership and cooperation to be another opportunity to call on the Vietnamese authorities to refrain from suppressing the peaceful exercise of the right to freedom of expression, assembly and association, while insisting on the release of prisoners of conscience convicted in mass trials of various kinds for offences relating in particular to freedom of expression and crimes against the state.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome broader and deeper cooperation with Vietnam – drawing it closer to the EU and helping it on the road of reform towards good governance, respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, as well as the fight against corruption, whilst taking into account economic, social and environmental progress and the principle of sustainable development, therefore I have voted in favour of the Lochbihler report on the EU-Vietnam Framework Agreement on Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation (resolution).

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 The report in question here contains a non-legislative motion for a resolution on the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Comprehensive Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and Vietnam, assuming itself as a crucial partnership with regard to economic and financial benefits, common principles of equality, mutual respect, rule of law , promotion of human rights, migration and regional security, among other important matters. We are looking at essential strategic cooperation here, as Vietnam is a key EU partner in Southeast Asia and ASEAN. Further integration of Vietnam into the world and European economy will be possible through ratification of its Partnership Agreement, as the setting of strictly defined objectives with the European Union will allow for further development of the country in all areas. I am in favour of this report, stressing the importance of the European Union encouraging and supporting Vietnam's ability to evolve in different areas, as well as with regard to good government practice and important social issues.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This report concerns a comprehensive eu-Vietnam Partnership and Cooperation Framework Agreement (resolution). I voted against it because I remain convinced that free trade is in no way a cure for France's problems and will not necessarily help Vietnam to develop in a balanced way.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. This text welcomes the conclusion of the comprehensive partnership and cooperation agreement between Vietnam and the European Union. Vietnam is a major partner of the Union, providing 400 million euros in official development assistance over the period 2014-2020. The resolution highlights Vietnam's progress in the fight against poverty and in the development of human rights. It focuses on the actions that remain to be taken to consolidate the rule of law. However, certain provisions of the text, which make strong judgments on Vietnamese domestic policy, going so far as to call for the modification of certain articles of the penal code or to abandon the construction of a nuclear power plant, are a matter of genuine interference and do not live up to the bonds of friendship between the Union and Vietnam. That's why I abstained.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. The report strikes a good balance by pointing out the positive sands and developments, but it is not afraid to point out and raise problems, which would have led me to vote in favour of this report.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The agreement strengthens economic and political relations between the EU and Vietnam, addressing, inter alia, concerns such as respect for human rights and the fight against terrorism.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I supported this report, which contains a proposal for a non-legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation Framework Agreement between the European Union and Vietnam. The trade and strategic importance of Vietnam is beyond question. Nevertheless, I express concern about Vietnam's massive casnation to protect human rights and freedoms. This must not be overlooked or ignored simply to bring economic benefits to both sides.  Vietnam must undergo profound reforms of the system to become sufficiently functional and establish permanent mechanisms to protect human rights and ensure their application. This means that the ruling structures will have to take into account recommendations that minority rights must not be violated, that fundamental human rights defenders are not imprisoned, that opposition activities are allowed and a basis for a plural society be created. The Union must demonstrate external consistency in policy implementation and ensure compliance with principles with its partners, and in particular the values it nurtures internally.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This report concerns a comprehensive eu-Vietnam Partnership and Cooperation Framework Agreement (resolution). I voted against it because I remain convinced that free trade is in no way a cure for France's problems and will not help Vietnam to develop in a balanced way.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ The objective of the Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation Agreement is to establish a modern, broad and mutually beneficial partnership based on common interests and principles such as equality, mutual respect, the rule of law and human rights. 2015 marks the 25th anniversary of EU-Vietnam relations that have expanded rapidly from trade and aid and become more comprehensive. The agreement sets out a wide range of future relations to further enhance cooperation in addressing global and regional challenges, such as good governance and anti-corruption and economic and social progress, taking into account the principle of sustainable development, disarmament and weapons of mass destruction and the fight against terrorism.  It is a commendable fact that the future FTA includes the following elements: the trade and sustainable development chapter, the obligations to adhere to core labour standards and IOC conventions, the mutual obligations to respect workers' fundamental rights, commitments to support the conservation of natural resources and their sustainable governance, with a particular focus on corporate social responsibility and fair and ethical trading systems , confirming its value and scope. For all this, I support the recommendation to conclude a Framework Agreement on Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation between the EU and Vietnam.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. – I agree with the report containing the proposal for a non-legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation Framework Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, on the other. The European Union is Vietnam's largest export market, having pursued a highly pro-European policy over the past 20 years and has actively cooperated with the EU on a number of policy topics.  For this reason, I underline the great strategic importance of Vietnam as a key partner of the European Union in South East Asia and in ASEAN. The agreement sets out a large number of future relations to further enhance co-operation on a number of issues, such as good governance and the fight against corruption and economic and social progress. Also, this agreement will intensify dialogue on key topics, such as the protection of human rights and the environment.  I believe that ratifying this agreement would benefit both the European Union and Vietnam economicly, for example in trade and investment in job creation and poverty reduction. For these reasons, I call on the governments and parliaments of the Member States to accelerate the ratification of this agreement in order to enter into force as soon as possible.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2015 marks the 25th anniversary of the start of EU-Vietnam relations. These relations quickly expanded from trade and development aid towards a more global bilateral relationship. The EU is Vietnam's largest export market which, in recent decades, has systematically taken a markedly pro-European approach and has been actively engaged with the EU as a member of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) in a wide range of areas including trade and investment, development, the economy and political affairs, and climate change. For the above reasons, Parliament welcomes the conclusion of the Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation Agreement with Vietnam, stressing its great strategic importance as an essential partner of the EU in South-East Asia and ASEAN. I therefore hope that the EU and Vietnam will both benefit most from the ratification of this agreement, which I wanted to support through my vote in favour.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Writing. \u2012 As a Member of the Czech Republic, I am a politician who represents a country with one of the largest Vietnamese communities in the EU. In view of this fact, as well as the historical ties between the Czech Republic and Vietnam, I consider the deepening of cooperation between the EU and this country to be very beneficial. On the other hand, I would like to remind you that there are human rights violations in Vietnam and this problem must be part of the EU-Vietnam dialogue.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I supported the resolution accompanying the EU-Vietnam Comprehensive Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation. We have entered the 25th anniversary of our relationship with Vietnam and are on track to conclude an exemplary trade agreement. Our companies will be able to invest more easily in a country with strong growth potential. It is a whole middle class that has emerged and whose needs can be met by our businesses, whether in terms of infrastructure, goods or services. I saw all the benefits of this agreement during my trip to Vietnam in April 2015.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report on the EU-Vietnam agreement on partnership and cooperation. We are opposed in principle to EU institutions signing international agreements on behalf of the UK. Only elected and accountable national governments should negotiate and conclude international agreements, not the unelected and unaccountable EU Commission. The EU has no right to interfere in the domestic affairs of non-EU countries.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 This is an agreement of relevant strategic importance. Vietnam is a crucial EU partner in Southeast Asia and ASEAN. The Agreement sets out future relations in a broad scope with a view to further strengthening cooperation on global and regional challenges such as good governance and the fight against corruption, economic and social progress, sustainable development, disarmament, weapons of mass destruction and the fight against terrorism. It is an agreement that highlights the potential impact on job creation and poverty reduction, welcoming the economic and financial reforms undertaken by the Vietnamese authorities to foster further integration of Vietnam into the world economy.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. In this report, Parliament welcomes the conclusion of the comprehensive partnership and cooperation agreement with Vietnam and underlines the major strategic importance of Vietnam, the EU's key partner in South-East Asia and ASEAN. Governments and parliaments of Member States are urged to speed up the ratification process to ensure that the agreement can enter into force.  Parliament also welcomed the Prime Minister's master plan for implementing the recommendations of the UN Human Rights Council's Universal Periodic Review, as well as the strategy on judicial reforms that is expected to be completed by 2020.  The Union, for its part, is encouraged to continue its support for strengthening Vietnam's capacity to promote respect for good governance and the rule of law, while Vietnam is called upon to implement reforms to improve the socio-economic conditions of ethnic and religious minorities.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 In June 2012, the Comprehensive Framework Agreement for Partnership and Cooperation between the EU and its Member States was signed, on the one hand, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, on the other. This agreement, to which the European Parliament has given its consent today, provides the necessary tools for a greater and deeper relationship between the EU and Vietnam. With this non-legislative resolution on this Comprehensive Partnership Framework Agreement and which has voted in favour of this resolution, the European Parliament wishes to stress that it will be very vigilant in evolving the situation in a number of areas considered fundamental by us: in addition to the basic political clauses of the EU, in the context of the protection of human rights and the International Criminal Court , weapons of mass destruction and the fight against terrorism, for example, but also in sectoral cooperation in a wide range of policy areas, such as migration, environmental preservation or education.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. – We abstained because the language used in the paragraphs on respect for human rights is too weak to justify a vote in favour of the report.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against, as I do not believe the EU should be managing the foreign affairs of Member States.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution from the AFET Committee on this Framework Agreement that we have also given our consent to today. This agreement represents a major pillar for regional stability, progress in implementing international norms and social and economic development in the region.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution because the EU-Vietnam Framework Agreement on Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation after its entry into force can provide many new opportunities for companies on both sides by increasing market access to goods and services, creating new jobs and reducing poverty. Although Vietnam, with its population of 90 million, has made great progress in recent decades in meeting the Millennium Development Goals, reducing poverty, economic development, social security, employment, education and health care, the framework agreement can, in my view, become an important tool for improving other objectives, which undoubtedly include peace, the rule of law, democracy and human rights, maritime security and resource sharing. I expect Vietnam to use all the possibilities offered from the ratification of the Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation Agreement and to continue the reforms that have been put in place in order to further integrate into the world economy. In particular, I am paying attention to the area of human rights as a key instrument that should be used in a more efficient and pragmatic way.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. In 2015, we celebrate the 25th anniversary of EU-Vietnam relations, which have rapidly spread from trade and aid to a more comprehensive relationship. Vietnam has consistently adopted a highly pro-European approach in recent decades and is actively working with the EU.  It is also the country responsible for ASEAN (Association of Southeast Asian Nations) for coordinating relations in the ASEAN-EU dialogue for the period 2012-2015. Over the past two decades, Vietnam has made significant progress in achieving development goals, poverty reduction, economic development, social security, employment, education and health.  The report welcomes the conclusion of an agreement on a comprehensive partnership and cooperation with Vietnam aimed at establishing a modern and mutual partnership on a broad basis. The agreement regulates EU-Vietnam cooperation in a number of areas, but in my opinion the most important are joint commitments in the area of human rights.  These will intensify the long-existing dialogue with the Vietnamese Government on the specific promotion of freedom of expression, assembly, association and religious freedom. I agree that Vietnam has great strategic importance as a key partner of the EU in South-East Asia and ASEAN.  As the Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation Agreement defines future relations in a broad area, such as further strengthening cooperation on global and regional challenges, I voted in plenary to adopt the resolution.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. I support this report taking into account the draft Council decision and the recommendation of the Foreign Affairs Committee. I join the rapporteur's appeal that the national parliaments of the Member States of the European Union ratify the agreement with the Socialist Republic of Vietnam as soon as possible.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ On 5 October 2015, the Trans-Pacific Partnership Agreement (TPP) of twelve Pacific Ring countries, including Vietnam, was finalised, creating a new trading bloc that accounts for 36% of global GDP and could have far-reaching effects on world trade. 2015 marks the 25th anniversary of EU-Vietnam relations; these relations quickly expanded from the area of trade and assistance and became more comprehensive.  The agreement sets out a wide range of future relations to further enhance cooperation in addressing global and regional challenges, such as good governance and anti-corruption and economic and social progress, taking into account the principle of sustainable development, disarmament and weapons of mass destruction and the fight against terrorism. The EU is Vietnam's largest export market and, together with its Member States, is the largest provider of official development assistance to Vietnam. I support the proposal for a non-legislative resolution by the European Parliament on the Council's decision to conclude on behalf of the Union, the Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation Framework Agreement between the European Union and its Member States and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam for the great strategic importance of Vietnam as a key partner of the EU in South East Asia and in ASEAN, and for the comprehensiveness of the Agreement and the cooperation it envisages.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We have chosen to abstain in the 3 reports on the framework of an agreement on cooperation between the EU and Vietnam, showing respect for the state's willingness to attach such agreements but at the same time maintaining a critical attitude towards EU foreign policy, particularly with regard to the content and objectives of such agreements. The HYPOCRITICAL attitude of the EU to apply its principles and values as they see fit, as well as the promotion of neoliberal policies in third countries through trade agreements that create relations of dependency and operate to the detriment of the interests of the peoples, find us vertically opposed.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The report welcomes the recognition of gay marriage.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted for this text, in which Parliament hopes that the ratification of the comprehensive partnership and cooperation agreement will bring economic benefits to both the Union and Vietnam. In addition, Parliament underlines the potential effects of a future trade and investment agreement on job creation and poverty reduction, welcomes the economic and financial reforms undertaken by the Vietnamese authorities to boost Vietnam's integration into the global economy and calls on Vietnam to continue these reforms. It also calls on the Vietnamese government and the European Union to continue their economic, trade and new technology cooperation in international for a.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Framework Agreement on Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Vietnam, of the other part. Indeed, the Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation Agreement aims to establish a modern, broad-based and mutually beneficial partnership, based on shared interests and principles such as equality, mutual respect, the rule of law and human rights. The EU is Vietnam’s biggest export market and is the largest ODA provider to Vietnam and there will be an EU budget increase for this purpose of 30% to EUR 400 million in 2014-2020.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. I voted for a report containing a proposal for a non-legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation Framework Agreement between the European Union, and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, on the other.  The draft EU-Vietnam Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation Agreement was signed in 2010 and the European Parliament's request for consent as well as the ratification of the agreement is based on a mutual and useful partnership reflected in a commitment to common principles and interests such as the protection of human rights, mutual respect and the rule of law. Ratification of this agreement can have direct economic benefits as the European Union is Vietnam's largest export market.  I also hold positive provisions urging the Government of Vietnam to consistently respect human rights, including the abolition of the death penalty, which is directly contrary to all the values represented by the Union, with estimates of more than 500 prisoners awaiting its execution in Vietnam. I therefore support this report in order to accelerate the adoption of the agreement and to further enhance both diplomatic and economic cooperation.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. - I supported the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Framework Agreement on comprehensive partnership and cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, on behalf of the European Union, because I believe that eu-Socialist Republic of Vietnam's cooperation is particularly important in the area of trade policy, as the EU is the largest exporter to Vietnam.  The EU must establish, with Vietnam, proper cooperation and a useful partnership that will strengthen common interests and have positive effects on the economy, trade, investment, new technologies, job creation and poverty reduction.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. – We abstained because the language used in the paragraphs on respect for human rights is too weak to justify a vote in favour of the report.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The aim of the Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation Agreement is to establish a modern, broad-based and mutually advantaged partnership based on common interests and principles such as equality, mutual respect, the rule of law and respect for human rights. The EU is Vietnam's largest export market and has consistently taken a particularly pro-European approach in recent decades and has been actively involved in the ASEAN-EU dialogue as coordinator of the ASEAN country. I supported the proposal.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. – We abstained because the language used in the paragraphs on respect for human rights is too weak to justify a vote in favour of the report.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe it is necessary to recognise the partnership and cooperation between the EU and Vietnam as an important step in diplomatic, political and economic relations. 2015 marks the 25th anniversary of EU-Vietnam relations; these relations have broadened rapidly from trade and aid to a more comprehensive relationship and I hope that the EU and Vietnam will both benefit economically from the ratification of this Agreement and that it will pave the way for a future agreement on trade and investment on job creation and poverty reduction.  I also welcome the economic and financial reforms undertaken by the Vietnamese authorities to boost Vietnam’s further integration into the world economy and I hope Vietnam will continue such reforms. I also strongly agree with the call on the Vietnamese Government to make concrete progress on the implementation of the UNHRC UPR recommendations, starting with the creation of an independent national human rights institution.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. In the report, Parliament welcomes the conclusion of this Agreement by being Vietnam an important partner for the European Union in Southeast Asia and within ASEAN. The report highlights that the Agreement can improve economic relations with the country while making it easier for Vietnam to make remarkable progress through economic and financial reforms, reforms in its judicial system to promote respect for good governance and the rule of law, as well as the implementation of improvements in science and technology and respect for human rights. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. I voted in favour of this resolution on the Framework Agreement on a Broad Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and Vietnam. I think it is appropriate to strengthen the existing trade relations between Vietnam and the European Union in the sectors that are of common interest to us.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. This resolution deals with the comprehensive partnership and cooperation agreement reached in 2012 between the EU and Vietnam. This agreement broadens the scope of cooperation in science, migration, tourism and culture, which is to be welcomed, but also includes the bilateral free trade agreement concluded on 4 August 2015.  The resolution stresses important points, such as the need for an immediate moratorium on capital punishment and the ratification of International Labour Organization conventions, including on freedom of association and the right to collective bargaining. She also welcomes Vietnamese law allowing same-sex marriage. It also expresses concerns about environmental degradation and land grabbing, a real scourge in Vietnam. But a free trade agreement is a free trade agreement, so the resolution calls for compliance with WTO rules and "coordination of macroeconomic policies" between Vietnam and the EU. While we know the devastation all over the world.   I regret that a country like Vietnam is forced to negotiate such an agreement with the Union. So I chose to abstain.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 These Global Partnership and Cooperation Agreements should aim to establish a modern, comprehensive and mutually beneficial partnership based on common interests and principles such as equality, mutual respect, the rule of law and human rights. However, the reality and the very tone of the resolutions point to contrary meanings. The question of respect for human rights is only an adornment that is omitted when it comes to trading with Israel, but which soon takes on an imperial tone of clear interference when we talk about countries that have legitimately opted for different paths of development. On the other hand, these agreements are based on the laws of free trade and a supposed sane and fair competition that, in practice, guarantees the dominance of large multinational companies, which end up destroying local economies, from which comes the reserve army that will provide the cheap and docile labor that capital so appreciates.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. Balanced motion for a resolution praising progress but also outing the problems that still need to be addressed. I therefore agree with this report.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 Addressing the partnership and cooperation agreement to be concluded between the EU and Vietnam, in a framework that anticipates the conclusion of a free trade agreement, this resolution unacceptably advances a set of recommendations, requests and demands, with shameless interference in the internal affairs of that country. This is the usual neocolonial line of this project of European capitalist integration, which focuses its offensive on traditional criticism stemming from human rights, freedom and democracy. In practice, the report supports the European Union's vision of materialising its foreign policy in its trade policy by supporting the position of actually imposing policy of cooperation and imposing fundamental changes in political regimes, which serve, in the first place, the interests of the EU and its major powers. A spirit that goes against the principle, recognised in the report itself and in the Agreement, of basing the relationship on common interests and principles, such as equality and mutual respect. We voted against it.

name: Marek JUREK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Currency unification has triggered a very serious economic crisis in Europe. It has hit some countries dramatically, but it has also led to a political disintegration of our cooperation. Political reason would have to withdraw from such a policy, but the European Union authorities only want to use this crisis to push even more, even harder, for the confiscation of the sovereign powers of nation states. This, after all, will cause an even greater political crisis, as evidenced by the British position. Such a position not only undermines the well-being of our peoples, but unfortunately is evidence of serious political iliability. Well, in the end it's your choice. We choose sovereignty.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – The so-called European Semester system has been in operation for about five years. Within it, the European Union and its economic policies are coordinated directly and regularly between national and supranational levels, with the concrete installation of the duration of each action involved and the verification of its implementation. While the commission and the Council play a primary role at the transnational level, it would be unequivocally necessary for Parliament's role in this process, as well as overall for the functioning of European monetary union, to be increased, first of all, in terms of transparency and the realisation of verification. In this case, this also concerns in particular the need for parliament to be consulted in good time by the Commission in the context of the preparation of the White Paper on the transition between the first and second phases of the European Monetary Union, which have already been implemented, and the third and final phase, which started in 1999, is now on the way. Overall, I support this move.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Mr President, let me take you back to 1990 when the then British Chancellor, John Major, proposed a European single currency, which was quite a novel concept at the time to many people back in the United Kingdom. We then joined the exchange rate mechanism, which, in one sense, could have been seen as the euro, though without the notes and coins. We fixed our exchange rates and certain aspects of monetary policy. Well, of course, unemployment soared and more businesses went bust than in any other two-year period in British history. We had to crash out of the ERM and it took our economy years to recover. Thank goodness we did not join the euro, because we might have suffered the same consequences that many of the countries which did join the euro have themselves suffered. Mr Major was wrong then. He recommends that Britain should stay in the European Union. Let me tell you that he is wrong now too.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. The EU is stagnant with a slow and fragile recovery, with still-un declining poverty rates and still excessively high unemployment rates. The recovery cannot depend solely on monetary policy and the European Central Bank. There is a need for a change in economic policy, as well as more ambition of the European project to avoid future crises, so that the recovery is fair and balanced and reaches all European citizens. It is therefore necessary to complete economic and monetary union (EMU). There is a need to improve domestic demand and encourage investment. In addition, EMU must be equipped with its own fiscal capacity for the euro area, a strengthened budget and the achievement of the Banking Union. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution. Because I believe that the legislative package presented by the European Commission on 21 October is not sufficient to achieve these objectives, especially as regards democratic legitimacy. It is necessary to improve parliamentary control and debate at European and national level, in order to ensure democratic accountability and, therefore, to improve citizens' perception of euro area governance.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. The five presidents' proposal for the reform of economic and monetary union is a mixture of vague and contradictory promises regarding a social pillar for economic governance alongside real neoliberal proposals that legitimize and deepen the current European technocratic interventionism. This is the case with the tax or competition authorities, which are set up to give a varnish of independence to the inevitable European recommendations for further reductions in public spending or the elimination of labour rights. I voted against this resolution because it not only implies acceptance of this proposal, but it even represents a setback to the Commission's proposals, supporting only its most regressive aspects. The only seemingly positive aspect — the demands for greater parliamentary scrtrolling — is only another exercise in legitimization (without democratic deepening) of European economic policies.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – Economic and Monetary Union is a fundamentally bad idea because it places distinctive and different national economies in one straightjacket of economic policies. Completing economic and monetary union (as the title of this Motion for Resolution wishes) would therefore merely preserve the problems to be fixed by the inevitable break-up of the currency zone – better to make that break-up occur at a time of the zone’s own choosing rather than have it forced upon them by events.  Accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 This resolution follows on from the report of the 5 Presidents (European Commission, European Council, European Central Bank, Eurogroup and European Parliament) on the completion of EMU and the package presented by the European Commission on 21 October with the first implementing measures of the report. The resolution expresses Parliament's dissatisfaction with the absence of democratic dialogue. The presence of the President of the Eurogroup for the first time at a plenary session was a positive step, but there must be substantial continuity.  The years of crisis have shown that the European Union, and in particular EMU, suffers from a democratic deficit. Parliament's role must be further strengthened by essentially participating in decision-making and gaining selective powers.  It is good that measures such as the creation of a European Deposit Guarantee Facility are being promoted, which will strengthen the European Banking System and contribute to the completion of the Banking Union. Nevertheless, it should be noted that there are no measures that would really strengthen the governance of EMU, making it a genuine Economic and Monetary Union with social characteristics.  For all the above reasons I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. I welcome the resolution on the completion of Europe's economic and monetary union, which, while taking note of the Commission's previous proposals to strengthen EMU, also makes it clear once again that the initiatives do not provide sufficient scope for parliamentary scrutiny and discussion at European level, although this would be necessary to ensure democratic accountability for the decisions taken in the context of EMU and, consequently, the influence of citizens on the governance of the euro area.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This report notes the failure of the euro area. The single currency has not kept its promises. Profitable to some countries, it was for others a blow to their economy. The euro was a utopia. Unfortunately, in the face of this situation, the answer provided by this report is: more Europe is needed. However, the opposite is true. Less Europe and more national sovereignty are needed to adjust the currency according to the economies of the countries. Together with my colleagues, I therefore voted against this report, which is strongly tinged with European federalism.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on the completion of a European Economic and Monetary Union contains proposals for the completion of a European Economic and Monetary Union. I support the Commission's proposals to strengthen EMU and to step up efforts to address the current shortcomings of the euro area institutional framework. It is essential to implement the provisions of the six-document and the two-pack as a matter of urgency. I agree that greater parliamentary scrutiny should be envisaged and that discussions at European level are necessary to ensure democratic accountability for decisions taken on the EMU.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the completion of The Economic and Monetary Union of Europe, because I believe that it is a clear and precise text capable of accurately outlining Parliament's recommendations to the European Commission on the future of the single currency. Certainly, the report by the five presidents entitled 'Completing The Economic and Monetary Union of Europe' demonstrates the European Executive's willingness to move forward with regard to the integration of the euro area, which will, however, need to have a single fiscal policy in order to govern the euro. The macroeconomic imbalances that are occurring in the EU today are due precisely to this: the lack of European economic policy instruments capable of operating in the real economy. You cannot live only as a 'European Semester'.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. – We voted against this resolution, which is the European Parliament's response to the report of the five presidents, in which it intends to move forward in the integration of european monetary union, through a centralisation of economic and fiscal powers which would consolidate the model of neoliberal and austeritarian governance. Parliament's report accepts this perspective, calling only for itself for more powers and control over the other institutions. For our part, we believe that monetary union as it exists today is a source of imbalances and doomed to failure if it remains contingent on the interests of large Central European banks. A democratisation of monetary union is only possible through a deep democratization of European society and economy that prepends the interests of peoples to those of the powerful.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Resolution on the realization of economic and monetary union in Europe by taking note of the European Commission's proposal to strengthen EMU and recognising that correct management measures have been taken. However, in the same way, I voted in favour of one of the amendments tabled by the GUE/NGL Group recommending that urgent action be taken on the productive sectors vital to the different economies, which play an essential role in the potential development of each country. It refers more specifically to support for micro-enterprises, SMEs, cooperatives and local administrations.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This resolution entitled "Completing the Economic and Monetary Union of Europe" is a very federalist text which I cannot support despite the intention of giving more power and control to Parliament.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution being voted on is completely ideological, partisan and fully in defence of the EU's monetary policy that generated the current crisis and brought our country to its knees. My vote was clearly against this text.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The EU is stagnant with a slow and fragile recovery, with still-un declining poverty rates and still excessively high unemployment rates. The recovery cannot depend solely on monetary policy and the European Central Bank. There is a need for a change in economic policy, as well as more ambition of the European project to avoid future crises, so that the recovery is fair and balanced and reaches all European citizens. It is therefore necessary to complete economic and monetary union (EMU). There is a need to improve domestic demand and encourage investment. In addition, EMU must be equipped with its own fiscal capacity for the euro area, a strengthened budget and the achievement of the Banking Union. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution. Because I believe that the legislative package presented by the European Commission on 21 October is not sufficient to achieve these objectives, especially as regards democratic legitimacy. It is necessary to improve parliamentary control and debate at European and national level, in order to ensure democratic accountability and, therefore, to improve citizens' perception of euro area governance.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this resolution because it expresses Parliament's position on 21 October. The Commission's published package, which sets out the next steps in building Economic and Monetary Union (EMU). Parliament welcomed the Commission's proposals to strengthen EMU, recognising that some steps were taking the right direction, but noted that further efforts would be needed to address the current shortcomings of the euro area institutional framework. Parliament expressed its regret that the package published by the Commission does not provide sufficient parliamentary scrutiny and debate at European level, which is necessary to ensure democratic accountability for decisions taken on EMU and thus to ensure citizens' responsibility for the governance of the euro area. Parliament called on the Commission, as foreseen in the five Presidents' report, to open negotiations with Parliament, the Council and the Eurogroup on an interinstitutional agreement on European economic governance, including the European Semester and the review of the macroeconomic adjustment programme. stresses that this interinstitutional agreement, in accordance with the Treaties, should ensure that the structure of the European Semester is such that parliamentary scrutiny of the process, in particular the recommendations addressed to the euro area, can be carried out in a meaningful and regular manner.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Completing Europe's economic and monetary union is urgently needed. We must be proud to have the euro, the common currency of 330 million European citizens and 19 States. However, that is not enough: we need an economic government of the Union, to complete monetary and budgetary union, as well as to establish a common treasury of the eurozone together with the legal parameters for the convergence of the different legal and financial systems of the Member States. This cannot be done unless democratic legitimacy and citizens' control over the institutions involved are strengthened. The social aspect of the process must be prominent, implying a redistributive logic of the weight of financial shocks and greater resilience of the EMU system to global macroeconomic imbalances. In supporting the development of EMU, we must make it very clear that its implementation is not the end of a path but one of the key steps in the completion of the European Union in order to achieve the common project of a European federal state.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 Europe's Economic and Monetary Union is a concern in all the structures of the European Union. Even if some progress has been made, further efforts are needed to address the current weaknesses of the institutional framework for the euro area. In view of the significant number of unemployed and people at risk of social exclusion, concrete measures, ambitious and prompt plans are needed to ensure a Union based on sustainable development, equity, ensuring the creation of more jobs, increased economic growth and a high level of prosperity for citizens. There is therefore a need to strengthen an economic union to ensure that each economy has the structural characteristics necessary to prosper within the monetary union. It is also necessary to strengthen the financial union to ensure the integrity of our currency by limiting risks to financial stability. Moreover, the guarantee of bank deposits must be ensured so that we can speak of a stability of the banking system as a guarantee of macroeconomic stability. I was in favour of this report because prompt measures to strengthen economic and banking governance and the completion of the Union's economic and monetary union need to be adapted.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Absolutely against. Ideological resolution and totally in defence of THE EU's monetary policy.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The European Commission published in October the necessary steps to complete the Economic and Monetary Union (EMU) which echo the report of the five presidents published earlier this year. In this resolution, the European Parliament welcomes this desire to complement the European Union but questions the means to achieve it. The resolution reiterates the need to work together between the various institutions in order to achieve an optimal result in European economic governance. Many hurdles remain to be overcome in order to achieve a more effective economic and monetary union that is better adapted to current economic challenges. I would remind you that the improvement of EMU requires the implementation of the "six-pack" and the "two-pack" rules. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of this resolution to complete The Economic and Monetary Union of Europe. I would like to focus on two points. The first concerns investments which, as you know, are held back in the euro area by at least three factors: weak demand dynamics, debt accumulation and fragile private sector confidence. The eurozone needs to not only support demand, but also address the issue of debt and fragile confidence. The European Central Bank must put in place monetary policy measures that can help support the eurozone's economic recovery. The second point concerns a proposal recently adopted by the College of European Commissioners to improve the economic governance of the eurozone. Eurozone Member States should have unified representation in international financial institutions, in particular in the International Monetary Fund. If every eurozone member state speaks for itself, or worse if they contradict each other, the eurozone will never have the weight it should be given. In order to complete economic and monetary union, much depends on how it is implemented and whether the coordination mechanism will be created to prepare the unified positions that the President of the Eurogroup could and should present to the International Monetary Fund on behalf of all eurozone Member States.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. – I voted against this report which I have a number of serious concerns with. In my capacity as a member of the Economic and Monetary Affairs Committee, I have positively and proactively worked on this report. I have tabled a number of amendments to this report in order to improve the text. What is particularly disconcerting is that the pillar of economic governance has been seriously strengthened over the past years to the detriment of Member States. The EU now has a multitude of instruments at its disposal, ranging from the Fiscal Compact on controlling the draft budgetary plans to the macroeconomic excessive imbalances procedure. And this report is not only seeking to consolidate such powers but also to strengthen and enhance them. At the same time, the social pillar is languishing. This is why it is crucial that Member States retain ownership and that the principle of subsidiarity is not undermined.  As a small county, Ireland needs to remain cautious given the inevitable reduction in autonomy and control and I will continue to use my mandate that the Irish people provided me with to ensure that Irish economic and social interests are protected in Europe.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. – Economic and Monetary Union is a fundamentally bad idea because it places distinctive and different national economies in one straightjacket of economic policies. Completing economic and monetary union (as the title of this Motion for Resolution wishes) would therefore merely preserve the problems to be fixed by the inevitable break-up of the currency zone – better to make that break-up occur at a time of the zone’s own choosing rather than have it forced upon them by events.  Accordingly, as a UKIP MEP, I voted against.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Resolution which calls for more European parliamentary oversight and debate at European level, which are necessary to ensure the democratic accountability of the decisions taken in the context of the European Monetary Union (EMU) and for Parliament to be consulted in due time in the context of the preparation of the White Paper on the transition between phase 1 and phase 2 of the reforms of the EMU.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 This is a resolution with an oral question on the future of economic union which, despite the breadth of the issue, forcibly limits the focus on the democratic aspects relating to the marginal role played by the European Parliament in emu governance issues, deliberately omitting all substantive and most controversial issues, and thus giving up the opportunity to express Parliament's position on the process of implementing the report of the 5 Presidents. This is a renunciation of any serious debate on this matter within Parliament, and I have therefore voted against it.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the motion for a resolution and agree, in relation to the Commission's proposals to strengthen EMU, that, despite the measures taken in the right direction, further efforts will be needed to address the current weaknesses in the euro area institutional framework. We also regret that the package published by the Commission does not leave enough room for parliamentary oversight and the development of dialogue at European level, which is necessary in order to ensure democratic accountability for decisions taken in the context of EMU and therefore also a sense of 'familiarity' of citizens with regard to the governance of the euro area. Finally, we call on the Commission, as also provided for in the report of the five Presidents, to consult Parliament in good time in preparation for the White Paper on the transitional period between phase 1 and phase 2 of the EMU reforms.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution on the completion of Europe's Economic and Monetary Union relates to Parliament's reaction to the COM proposal. That is why I decided to vote against the resolution. More generally, democratisation and transparency, including the role of the EP, can help to improve the current framework, which is not reflected in this resolution.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution tabled to make progress in European Monetary and Economic Union. The Commission was right to encourage this step, which has not yet been achieved by presenting a package containing the stages towards the completion of economic and monetary union (EMU), consisting of two communications, a recommendation on a Council recommendation and a proposal for a Council decision and a Commission decision. With these measures, while acknowledging that some steps have been taken in the right direction, I believe that further efforts will be needed to address the current shortcomings in achieving this objective. I therefore agree with this report and I am voting in favour of it.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission, as part of phase 1 of the roadmap included in the Five Presidents' Report, published on 21 October 2015 a package containing measures to complete economic and monetary union (EMU), consisting of two communications, a Council recommendation, a proposal for a Council decision and a Commission decision. I share the European Parliament's position that, while some steps have been taken in the right direction, additional efforts are needed to address gaps in the institutional framework of the euro area, and I support the need for an Interinstitutional Agreement on European economic governance, including the European Semester, with regular control by the European Parliament.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on economic and monetary union because I believe that it is a priority to achieve a Union capable of achieving greater growth, employment and prosperity for all citizens, but at the same time based on solid foundations, in order to meet the challenges not only internally, but also globally, and capable of absorbing shocks by equipping themselves with sufficiently resilient economies. I am well aware that employment and social developments have been examined in detail in country reports this year, but I would like to stress the urgency and the need to improve the labour market and social performance, especially in order to restore confidence to all young unemployed people.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. – I believe that despite difficulties, the EMU helped Eurozone countries to combat the global crises which took place until a couple of years ago. Yet completing the Union as we want it will need to factor in difficulties like the large scale fiscal transfers which are still absent and labour mobility which is relatively low. To this effect, Member States need to put in place policies that ensure fiscal stability, prevent the emergence of large macroeconomic imbalances and facilitate adjustment in case of shocks. For this reason I agree with a steady, yet slow movement because EMU is not exactly ready for the next crisis, but what has already been achieved will help overcome fiscal turbulence in its journey to rebuild trust. Although I agree and voted in favour I am still sceptical about the preparedness of the Eurozone for fundamental changes over the next year, as we still do not have enough intellectual convergence on what is needed.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution on which we are to vote today is yet another missed opportunity for Parliament to address issues of the utmost importance! Despite the breadth of the issue, it focuses artificially only on the democratic aspects of the marginal role played by the European Parliament in EMU governance issues, deliberately neglecting all substantive and most controversial issues. Parliament is thus throwing away the opportunity to express its position on the process of implementing the report of the five Presidents. Once again, the form has been preferred to the substance: this text is the unsatisfactory result of a compromise reached in a few hours between the main political groups and adopted at the cost of the mass withdrawal of the amendments that were on the substance. This resolution ( which therefore in no way reflects the position of the ECON Committee, which is clearly divided on governance issues) has the effect of repressing any possibility of political debate and silencing the voice of the smaller groups. The text which has resulted from this and which we are being asked to vote on today is, it is reiterated, a text that says absolutely nothing. This can only be a vote against.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. The five presidents' proposal for the reform of economic and monetary union is a mixture of vague and contradictory promises regarding a social pillar for economic governance alongside real neoliberal proposals that legitimize and deepen the current European technocratic interventionism. This is the case with the tax or competition authorities, which are set up to give a varnish of independence to the inevitable European recommendations for further reductions in public spending or the elimination of labour rights. I voted against this resolution because it not only implies acceptance of this proposal, but it even represents a setback to the Commission's proposals, supporting only its most regressive aspects. The only seemingly positive aspect — the demands for greater parliamentary scrtrolling — is only another exercise in legitimization (without democratic deepening) of European economic policies.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution, which focuses on the package adopted by the Commission on 21 October 2015. It states that while some elements of the package can be welcomed (for instance the aggregate analysis and the stance on the completion of the banking union), it is regrettable that it moves the EMU more into intergovernmental mode. I agree with strengthening the existing frameworks as long as they are within the parameters of the Treaties. Furthermore, it is also important to recall the role of national parliaments, which are the democratically elected institutions closest to where the impact of decisions and reforms are felt.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. Reacting to the Commission's communication of 26 November on the EU's economic and social priorities for 2016, this resolution sets out the recommendations of the European Parliament to complement the Economic and Monetary Union (EMU). In particular, it proposes specific measures to deal with rising unemployment and to improve the employment of young people, as well as the social condition of European citizens. Supporting these objectives, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. – Economic and Monetary Union is a fundamentally bad idea because it places distinctive and different national economies in one straitjacket of economic policies. Completing economic and monetary union (as the title of this Motion for Resolution wishes) would therefore merely preserve the problems to be fixed by the inevitable break-up of the currency zone – better to make that break-up occur at a time of the zone’s own choosing rather than have it forced upon them by events. Accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. I regret that the European Commission's measures do not leave enough room for parliamentary control and debate at European level. However, they are essential in order to make the decision-making taken in the context of the European Economic and Monetary Union (EMU) a democratic seed and to ensure that citizens take ownership of the governance of the euro area. That is why I voted in favour of the resolution entitled 'Complete Economic and Monetary Union'. Through this vote, we call for the opening of negotiations for an inter-institutional agreement with Parliament, the Council and the Eurogroup on European economic governance.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because I feel it is absolutely necessary to make more progress in strengthening the euro area. For example, I think it is essential to implement the provisions of the "six-pack" and the "two-pack". I also regret that the measures that the Commission has made public do not leave sufficient room for parliamentary control and debate at European level, which are nevertheless necessary to put democratic seing on decisions taken in the context of EMU and to ensure the ownership of the governance of the euro area by citizens. I support the Commission's request to consult Parliament in the preparation of the white paper on the transition from the first to the second phase of EMU reforms and I encourage the Commission to open negotiations for an inter-institutional agreement with Parliament, the Council and the Eurogroup on European economic governance, including the European Semester and monitoring the implementation of the economic adjustment programme.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
