text: in writing. \u2012 I did not support this motion for a resolution because I do not agree with the main message that the package proposed by the European Commission to strengthen economic and monetary union does not leave enough room for parliamentary scrutiny and debate at European level.  This is not a matter of democratic scrutiny, as proposed by the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, but it is a question of who should oversee national budgets. There are already more than enough mechanisms to ensure democratic control.  Furthermore, I also do not support the suggestion that the European Fiscal Board should be responsible for the EP's political credibility. This board has a purely advisory function and does not have a broader mandate than that. Transferring this prerogative sovereignty at European level would not only politicise the issue, but would also be wrong and illegal.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The adoption of the euro has led to significant divergences between Member States, which have made structural imbalances between them greater and caused a distortion of recession in the countries of the European Union. A new credit policy must be put in place to tackle the problem of over-indebtedness and bankruptcy affecting thousands of families in the Member States. Stability and convergence programmes must also be abolished in order to address the continuing recession in weak economies.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 At the time of its creation, economic and monetary union (EMU) was far from an optimal monetary zone. Built without any economic support, on the backs of the people, this political project of the right and social democracy imposed on workers and peoples neoliberalism as law, forcing the deepening of federalism. From the outset, we opposed the creation of EMU. We said that it would bring divergence, increased exploitation, loss of income and economic policy instruments, especially for countries such as Portugal, with the adoption of a currency that is not suitable for the productive structure. Today, the consequences jump in sight: high unemployment levels, stagnant and near-negative inflation rates, high levels of indebtedness, loss of external competitiveness, very low growth rates. Although it has been proven that EMU was a wrong option, they insist on its conclusion, once again without economic arguments and once again on the backs of peoples. We do not accept makeup or "social" washes from an intrinsically antisocial project. You want more democracy? So let them consult the people and respect their will. Are you really concerned about unemployment and rising poverty? So put aside a project that institutionalizes neoliberal principles.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 In order to complete economic and monetary union, necessary and responsible steps will need to be taken in the future to remake the European Semester, including a new timeframe and a new regime for annual growth analyses, the establishment of a European Fiscal Board to contribute in an advisory capacity to multilateral surveillance in the euro area, to ensure the external representation of the euro area within the IMF and many other measures.  It is possible to see some positive elements in the European Commission's package on completing economic and monetary union, such as the completion of the Banking Union, but it is regrettable that the package essentially responds to claims and concerns that are not ours, just as economic and monetary union moves more into intergovernmental waters, especially when it comes to external representation. The exclusion of the European Parliament from any decision-making on Stage 1 elements is totally against the spirit of strengthening democratic accountability.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 The worst never ends. Despite the damage and deaths caused by this crazy economic policy, we insist.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The adoption of the euro has led to significant imbalances between Member States, which have made structural imbalances between them greater and caused a distortion of recession in the countries of the European Union. A new credit policy must be put in place to tackle the problem of over-indebtedness and bankruptcy affecting thousands of families in the Member States and stability and convergence programmes must be abolished in order to tackle the continuing recession in weak economies.

name: Ashley FOX
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this oral question as it is an outrageous attempt by the EU to monitor national budgets. Furthermore, calls for a greater role for the European Parliament when setting up agencies politicises a process that is supposedly advisory and therefore neutral. Whilst I support democratic oversight, this oral question does not respect subsidiarity and infringes the rights of Member States.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in full favour of the need to strengthen EMU in order to end the shortcomings of the institutional framework of the euro area which have been highlighted during the economic crisis. We must take decisive steps in European integration in order to avoid the mistakes of the past in the future. In the face of the problems facing the EU, there is only one possible solution: more Europe.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. The EU is stagnant with a slow and fragile recovery, with still-un declining poverty rates and still excessively high unemployment rates. The recovery cannot depend solely on monetary policy and the European Central Bank. There is a need for a change in economic policy, as well as more ambition of the European project to avoid future crises, so that the recovery is fair and balanced and reaches all European citizens. It is therefore necessary to complete economic and monetary union (EMU). There is a need to improve domestic demand and encourage investment. In addition, EMU must be equipped with its own fiscal capacity for the euro area, a strengthened budget and the achievement of the Banking Union. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution. Because I believe that the legislative package presented by the European Commission on 21 October is not sufficient to achieve these objectives, especially as regards democratic legitimacy. It is necessary to improve parliamentary control and debate at European and national level, in order to ensure democratic accountability and, therefore, to improve citizens' perception of euro area governance.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I strongly voted for the EP resolution on the completion of EMU, because I believe that we must move forward vigorously in the implementation of the report of the 5 Presidents, building on the latest communications adopted by the Commission, which fall within the so-called phase 1 of the roadmap, aimed at strengthening EMU. At present, therefore, further efforts are needed within the institutional framework of the euro area. It is a question of political will, because the Treaties already make it possible to make progress towards the completion of EMU, but this will have to be done with greater democratic control by the EP, in order to guarantee the ownership of European citizens with regard to the governance of the euro area. I therefore supported the EP's call to open negotiations for an interinstitutional agreement (IAI) on European economic governance, including the European Semester and monitoring the implementation of the macroeconomic adjustment programme with the EP, the Council and the Eurogroup, as provided for in the 5 Presidents' own report. To this end, I believe that democratic control of the EP is particularly important, particularly with regard to the recommendations concerning the eurozone. The strengthening of the euro area will also depend on the completion of the banking union, through the European deposit insurance system.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the resolution on the completion of the European Economic and Monetary Union, as I support the approach, particularly with regard to the European Semester.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. If we want to continue to benefit from the benefits of a common economic and monetary union, corrective measures are needed. Only in this way can the social benefits continue to be enhanced by creating jobs, maintaining financial stability and reducing social inequalities.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ The euro area recommendations proposed are balanced instruments. The euro area needs to get back on track economically, that means not just focusing on some deficiencies of some smaller southern Member States, but also on larger ones where the domestic demand needs to be stimulated.  I recognise that labour markets need reform, but it has to be the right kind. It should be easier to hire people, not to fire. The priority has to be to reduce unemployment, and provide people with proper contracts and social protection instead of zero hour contracts. Another critical point to address is the amount of non-performing loans, in the Eurozone (but also beyond). More than EUR 826 billion of non-performing loans are  hanging as a sword of Damocles over our banking sector. This needs to be tackled urgently.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted against this Resolution, which is the European Parliament's response to the five-president report, which aims to advance the integration of the European monetary union through a centralisation of economic and fiscal powers that would consolidate the neoliberal and austeritarian governance model. Parliament's report accepts this perspective, calling only for itself for more powers and control over the other institutions. For our part, we believe that monetary union as it exists today is a source of imbalances and doomed to failure if it remains contingent on the interests of large Central European banks. A democratisation of monetary union is only possible through a deep democratization of European society and economy that prepends the interests of peoples to those of the powerful.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: in writing. The EU is stagnant with a slow and fragile recovery, with still-un declining poverty rates and still excessively high unemployment rates. The recovery cannot depend solely on monetary policy and the European Central Bank. There is a need for a change in economic policy, as well as more ambition of the European project to avoid future crises, so that the recovery is fair and balanced and reaches all European citizens. It is therefore necessary to complete economic and monetary union (EMU). There is a need to improve domestic demand and encourage investment. In addition, EMU must be equipped with its own fiscal capacity for the euro area, a strengthened budget and the achievement of the Banking Union. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution. Because I believe that the legislative package presented by the European Commission on 21 October is not sufficient to achieve these objectives, especially as regards democratic legitimacy. It is necessary to improve parliamentary control and debate at European and national level, in order to ensure democratic accountability and, therefore, to improve citizens' perception of euro area governance.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ My vote on Completing Europe's Economic and Monetary Union was decided by the fact that the European Parliament takes note of the Commission’s proposals to strengthen the EMU and, while recognising that some steps have been taken in the right direction, notes that further efforts will be necessary to address the current shortcomings of the institutional framework of the euro area.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ Economic and Monetary Union has been a disaster.  It is a political project with no economic basis in reality.  I therefore voted against this report. For some reason, failure (no matter how huge) is no reason for the EU to drop an idea! I note that the (then) British Chancellor John Major proposed such a scheme in 1990, and he has been proven wrong about this matter on every occasion since then. He is now entering the debate on British membership of the European Union, proposing that we remain in the EU.  I submit that he is wrong about that too.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. – The EU is stagnant with a slow and fragile recovery, with still-un declining poverty rates and still excessively high unemployment rates. The recovery cannot depend solely on monetary policy and the European Central Bank. There is a need for a change in economic policy, as well as more ambition of the European project to avoid future crises, so that the recovery is fair and balanced and reaches all European citizens. It is therefore necessary to complete economic and monetary union (EMU). There is a need to improve domestic demand and encourage investment. In addition, EMU must be equipped with its own fiscal capacity for the euro area, a strengthened budget and the achievement of the Banking Union. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution. Because I believe that the legislative package presented by the European Commission on 21 October is not sufficient to achieve these objectives, especially as regards democratic legitimacy. It is necessary to improve parliamentary control and debate at European and national level, in order to ensure democratic accountability and, therefore, to improve citizens' perception of euro area governance.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to support this resolution, as the initiative report on ‘the review of the economic governance framework: stocktaking and challenges’ underlined the need for ambitious and rapid progress in strengthening the euro area. In reference to the Commission’s proposals to strengthen the EMU, while recognising that some steps have been taken in the right direction, further efforts will be necessary to address the current shortcomings of the institutional framework of the euro area. The package published by the Commission does not leave enough room for parliamentary oversight and debate at European level, which are necessary to ensure the democratic accountability of the decisions taken in the context of the EMU and consequently for ensuring citizens’ ownership of euro area governance.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. I voted against the Gualtieri motion for a resolution, as the report calls for a broad amount of increased centralisation, which goes in the direction of a European central state. It praises the measures proposed in the Five Presidents' Report and also calls for more rights for the European Parliament and further transfer of national sovereignty to the European Commission. The ALFA advocates subsidiarity and strongly rejects the European central government. We believe that the economic recovery of the eurozone can only begin if the exchange rate distortions caused by the euro are resolved. A number of amendments from various groups to raise the report's failed eurozone bailout policy were rejected by the major parties. I cannot agree to a one-sided and ideologically strong motion for a resolution. That is why I rejected the report. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the proposal for an EP resolution on the completion of Europe's Economic and Monetary Union, as I believe that activities on this, in particular, political project that will bring economic benefits to EU members in the long term need to intensify and make all institutional and legislative assumptions so that a single monetary and economic union is truly functional, operational, purposeful and economically justified.  I support the completion of Europe's Economic and Monetary Union and the Statement of the Five Presidents and the need for ambitious and swift progress in strengthening the euro area. In this regard, I support the fact of a greater role and involvement of parliament.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – Economic and Monetary Union is a fundamentally bad idea because it places distinctive and different national economies in one straitjacket of economic policies. Completing economic and monetary union (as the title of this Motion for Resolution wishes) would therefore merely preserve the problems to be fixed by the inevitable break-up of the currency zone – better to make that break-up occur at a time of the zone’s own choosing rather than have it forced upon them by events.  Accordingly my UKIP colleagues and I voted against.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am abstaining from voting on this report. The proposed measures go beyond what countries can cope with under the current framework. In part, proposals are aimed at creating a transfer union, which I reject.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. I voted against the Gualtieri resolution because the report calls for much more centralisation, which goes in the direction of a European central state. It praises the measures proposed in the Five Presidents' Report and also calls for more rights for the European Parliament and further transfer of national sovereignty to the European Commission. The ALFA advocates subsidiarity and strongly rejects the European central government. We believe that the economic recovery of the eurozone can only begin if the exchange rate distortions caused by the euro are resolved. A number of amendments from various groups to raise the report's failed eurozone bailout policy were rejected by the major parties. I cannot agree to a one-sided and ideologically strong motion for a resolution. That is why I rejected the report.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution is based on the Five Presidents’ Report. It is the first resolution of the European Parliament after the latest EMU proposal. Moreover, Parliament does not have time to comment before the Council on any recommendation of the Commission. Another negative aspect of the resolution is that it legitimises the European economic framework as such. I voted against since this resolution does not give parliamentary control to the EMU and does not improve the EMU.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution. I believe that the European Semester is the most efficient form of coordination of European economic policies. I support, however, the demands of this Parliament which, with this measure, is calling on the Commission to involve the Treaties as much as possible in the decision-making procedures during the European Semester. I believe in a Europe of the peoples, economically and politically integrated, and this is not possible without the ever-increasing participation of the European Parliament, the only institution directly representing the citizens.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution to "complete the Economic and Monetary Union of Europe". This text is very federalist in which it is inspired, and refuses to accept the obvious, namely that the single currency will never be able to ensure real convergence and cohesion within the euro area. The euro is a straitjacket for the Member States. It has also amplified the economic imbalances between them. This resolution will not change that.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution on economic and monetary union because it is openly federalist in nature. The amendments supported by the FN MPs, who were trying to defend national sovereignty, were rejected by an overwhelming majority RPS!

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. The EU is stagnant with a slow and fragile recovery, with still-un declining poverty rates and still excessively high unemployment rates. The recovery cannot depend solely on monetary policy and the European Central Bank. There is a need for a change in economic policy, as well as more ambition of the European project to avoid future crises, so that the recovery is fair and balanced and reaches all European citizens. It is therefore necessary to complete economic and monetary union (EMU). There is a need to improve domestic demand and encourage investment. In addition, EMU must be equipped with its own fiscal capacity for the euro area, a strengthened budget and the achievement of the Banking Union. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution. Because I believe that the legislative package presented by the European Commission on 21 October is not sufficient to achieve these objectives, especially as regards democratic legitimacy. It is necessary to improve parliamentary control and debate at European and national level, in order to ensure democratic accountability and, therefore, to improve citizens' perception of euro area governance.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. I voted against the Gualtieri motion for a resolution, as the report calls for a broad amount of increased centralisation, which goes in the direction of a European central state. It praises the measures proposed in the Five Presidents' Report and also calls for more rights for the European Parliament and further transfer of national sovereignty to the European Commission. The ALFA advocates subsidiarity and strongly rejects the European central government. We believe that the economic recovery of the eurozone can only begin if the exchange rate distortions caused by the euro are resolved. A number of amendments from various groups to raise the report's failed eurozone bailout policy were rejected by the major parties. I cannot agree to a one-sided and ideologically strong motion for a resolution. That is why I rejected the report.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I do not agree with monetary union as an overall dysfunctional project, I am particularly concerned about the point on the Interinstitutional Agreement (IIA) on European Economic Governance.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Strengthening and creating a genuine EMU is necessary, but it is equally important to extend these measures to other Member States, as we do not aim to divide them into eurozone Member States and other Member States. It is for this reason that the objectives of the Economic Union are essential, which are convergence, social cohesion and prosperity.  We need to put all instruments into the function of meeting these objectives, which includes strengthening the single market, expanding the scope of structural reforms and increasing investment. However, when talking about convergence and social cohesion, we need to extend the debate to other areas and instruments that can make a significant contribution.  We need to answer the key question of how we see the contribution of cohesion policy, i.e. how to strengthen it and connect it more strongly with the objectives of the Economic Union. Equally important issues for achieving these objectives are how we see the future of the EU budget and the Multiannual Financial Framework and how to better coordinate different European policies in areas such as the financial system, transport, digital society, energy, innovation, rural development.  I supported the European Parliament's resolution on the completion of Europe's Economic and Monetary Union, which requires partnership, unity and determination by Member States to implement joint initiatives and changes, as without it there is neither convergence nor sustainable economic growth.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the motion for a resolution on the completion of Europe's Economic and Monetary Union because, in my view, it is neither complete nor substantiated, and I refer further to the reasons I set out in detail in my speech of 15/12/2015 to the plenary of the European Parliament.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I agree with the sentiments of this resolution that the Commission’s recent proposals for completing European Monetary Union (EMU) are insufficient to address the current shortcomings in the institutional framework of the euro area.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: In writing. The European Commission published its proposals on 21 October on the completion of the Economic and Monetary Union. Both on the method and in substance, they show an unfortunate leak forward of the euro area. No proposal is legislative, so the European Parliament will not have a voice. The proposals validate the liberal and technocratic orientation of the euro area, with an obsession with the same "structural reforms" that have not produced the effects expected so far and which evade the structural differences of the European economies. In response, the European Parliament responded with a resolution, led by Roberto Gualtieri, Chairman of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. This text is one of a missed opportunity. Not only has Parliament been circumvented, but above all its different view of the euro area and the reforms to be brought to it does not appear in the resolution.  Illustration of a logic of compromise by subtraction, it is reduced to the skin of sorrow. Because it denounces the non-legislative nature of these proposals and calls for a deepening of the democracy that systematically involves Parliament, I voted in favour of this text, but regretting that it is limited to an institutional message.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. This report leads to more coordination, more control on the part of the institutions, more powers. I am opposed to further centralisation and, therefore, to this report.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This Parliament's report builds on the Commission's proposal for the completion of Economic and Monetary Union. The report focuses on the institutional and critical aspects, in this context, the lack of democratic control of the European Parliament in the implementation of EMU.  But not a word about national parliaments, flouted referendums or other recurring violations of the sovereignty of peoples by the Union ... Above all, this report validates the neoliberal line applied by the EU. It stresses that "progress has been made in the right direction" in the implementation of EMU, thus ignoring the imbalances between states created by the euro and the coup de force carried out by the ECB and the Eurogroup against legitimate governments. Finally, it calls for the implementation of the 'six-pack' and 'two-pack' provisions, which allow the Union to control and sanction the state budget. The permanent financial coup system is thus legitimized. I'm voting against

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the completion of European Economic and Monetary Union. The Commission's proposals to strengthen economic and monetary union were very important, but further efforts are still needed to address the current shortcomings in the euro institutional framework.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I supported for this motion for a resolution as it calls for more parliamentary oversight and debate at European level, as the current Commission proposal does not allow for democratic accountability of the decisions taken in regard to the Economic and Monetary Union.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. Economic and monetary union must be reformed and strengthened. Today, we clearly lack real governance, a single pilot setting the course for EMU. We have a single currency, but our economic and fiscal policies are too often disparate. We need to put in place common, effective measures that will effectively ensure the convergence of our economies.  I regret that the European Parliament has still not been given the powers of control due to it. The European Commission's proposal to create national competitiveness authorities through an ordinary legislative procedure is another example. We must ensure that all the proposals made are subject to debate and parliamentary scrutiny at European level. This is the only way to ensure that EMU's principle of democratic legitimacy is respected.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of Parliament’s Resolution on Completing Europe’s Economic and Monetary Union, which is a response to the Commission package adopted on 21 October to complete the EMU within the first phase of the Five Presidents’ Report. I agree with the European Parliament resolution, which notably regrets that the package proposed by the Commission does not leave enough room for parliamentary oversight and debate at the European level.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 On 21 October 2015, the Commission published a package containing steps to achieve Economic and Monetary Union (EMU). In its report, the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs recommends that Parliament take note of the Commission's proposal to strengthen EMU, acknowledge that this has succeeded in taking several steps in the right direction, while making it clear that further efforts will be needed to address the current shortcomings in the euro area institutional system. It urges the Commission to open negotiations with Parliament, the Council and the Eurogroup on an interinstitutional agreement on European economic governance. Finally, it proposes that Parliament express its reservations about the lack of parliamentary scrutiny and debate at European level necessary to ensure democratic accountability for decisions taken under EMU. I supported the report.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This resolution entitled 'Completing the Economic and Monetary Union of Europe' is a very federalist text which I cannot support despite the intention of giving more power and control to Parliament.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the Economic and Monetary Union of Europe. The text calls on the Commission to address the shortcomings of the current institutional framework in the euro area by complementing EMU. It stresses that the existing treaties and instruments must enable some of the necessary additional phases to be achieved and calls for greater control and debate by the European Parliament in this area.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. Since the report calls for further centralisation of competences and seeks to add power to the European institutions, I would have opposed this report in order not to further curtail the competences of the Member States.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The right measures have been taken to strengthen economic and monetary union, but further efforts are needed to address the current shortcomings of the institutional framework for the euro area.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒The euro area recommendation explained by this declaration is part of the process of finally establishing a European Economic and Monetary Union. Parliament, the Commission and national parliaments have a lot of work to do on the road to achieving this goal. The new approach to the European Semester, the introduction of national competitiveness committees and the advisory European Fiscal Board, and the more unified representation of the euro area in international financial institutions, in particular the IMF, are just some of the package of measures to strengthen EMU and I believe that they need to be implemented in particular to make the Union economy more resilient to future financial and economic shocks and crises.  I join my colleagues from the Economic and Monetary Policy Committee and ask that the Commission clarify its steps towards completing the EMU, in relation to the Commission Communication of 21 October 2015. I therefore also support the motion for a resolution submitted following a question for oral response. We are currently at the very beginning of the first phase of emu completion and I hope that the set deadlines will be respected. In particular, I urge national parliaments to make it appropriate to implement responsible fiscal policies at national level through their conduct and compliance with the Commission's recommendations.  Taking into account the Commission Communication on steps towards the completion of the EMU, the 'Five Presidents' Report', package six and two measures and the question ed to the Commission, I will support this recommendation as the Commission's efforts to achieve emu are evident.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This resolution entitled 'Completing the Economic and Monetary Union of Europe' is a very federalist text which I cannot support. In any case, I do not wish to complete economic and monetary union but to restrict or even eliminate it, because the euro is one of the main sources of the economic problems of the majority of countries which have the misfortune of having it as their currency. I obviously voted against this text.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite the many steps forward, further efforts are needed to complete economic and monetary union (EMU) and to address the current shortcomings of the euro area institutional framework. For the President of the Eurogroup, Jeroen Dijsselbloem, it is necessary to complete the monetary union through the creation of a real banking union with a deposit guarantee and by increasing the European Fund for Strategic Investments. The President of the Eurogroup also stressed that debt continues to hamper growth and that fiscal policies should continue. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution, but I hope that the package published by the European Commission, containing the stages for the completion of economic and monetary union (EMU), will leave more room for parliamentary control and debate at European level that are necessary to ensure democratic accountability for decisions taken within the framework of EMU and, consequently, to ensure citizens' ownership of the governance of the euro area.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report, although I have a different opinion on some issues relating to the euro. On this occasion, I would like to reiterate my view that the Czech Republic is to join the euro area after this step has been approved by the citizens of my country in a popular vote, a referendum. When this moment comes, it will be such an important change that this decision should remain directly up to the citizens. If this procedure is followed, there is no need to speculate on possible automatic exemptions from the euro, as the Communist faction proposes here today. For this reason, I did not support this amendment.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the Economic and Monetary Union of Europe. Much progress has been made, but there are still some necessary adjustments for a functioning under democratic control, with the ambition and better involvement of the Member States.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ Economic and Monetary Union is a fundamentally bad idea because it places distinctive and different national economies in one straightjacket of economic policies. Completing economic and monetary union (as the title of this Motion for Resolution wishes) would therefore merely preserve the problems to be fixed by the inevitable break-up of the currency zone – better to make that break-up occur at a time of the zone’s own choosing rather than have it forced upon them by events.  Accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which I believe provides relevant guidelines to complement economic and monetary union. The report of the five presidents and the proposals put forward by the Commission are a new step in this direction. However, as this House points out, this is not enough, and more efforts are needed, in particular, to address the shortcomings of the euro area's institutional framework. On the other hand, parliamentary control and debate in the context of economic and monetary union must be strengthened, which is not fundamentally the case with the measures proposed by the Commission. How can we overcome this pitfall? Our resolution sets out a number of avenues. The Commission will have to consult with this House in the preparation of the white paper on the transition from the first to the second phase of the reforms of the Economic and Monetary Union, as envisaged by the report of the five presidents. The inter-institutional agreement on European economic governance must ensure that the structure of the European Semester allows for regular and effective parliamentary oversight. The Commission must ensure that the international representation of the euro area is subject to the democratic control of this House.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution on the completion of the European Economic and Monetary Union, in order to encourage the continuation of ambitious efforts to strengthen the euro area, and in view of the persistent shortcomings currently affecting the institutional framework of the euro area. The "six-pack" and the "two-pack" provisions must be implemented without delay, and EMU must be completed, while ensuring that decisions taken under EMU are accompanied by democratic control.  The Commission is invited to open negotiations with the other institutions with a view to concluding an inter-institutional agreement on European economic governance as soon as possible, with an emphasis on the proper implementation of the economic adjustment programme, in full transparency and with regular parliamentary scrutiny, particularly with regard to the recommendations concerning the euro area.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. – We voted against this resolution, which is the European Parliament's response to the report of the five presidents, in which it intends to move forward in the integration of european monetary union, through a centralisation of economic and fiscal powers which would consolidate the model of neoliberal and austeritarian governance. Parliament's report accepts this perspective, calling only for itself for more powers and control over the other institutions. For our part, we believe that monetary union as it exists today is a source of imbalances and doomed to failure if it remains contingent on the interests of large Central European banks. A democratisation of monetary union is only possible through a deep democratization of European society and economy that prepends the interests of peoples to those of the powerful.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ European Economic and Monetary Union is not something I would support and therefore I voted against.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because I would like to see the EMU be more democratically accountable, especially as the eurozone embarks on further integration. Despite being a part of the exclusive competence of the European Union, there has been a move towards intergovernmentalism of the Euro-area, especially with regards to external representation. The fact that the Parliament has been excluded from any decision-making elements of ‘stage 1’ is totally against the spirit of strengthening the democratic accountability of the EMU. While there is further integration of eurozone members, it is important, however, that non-eurozone members continue to be heard.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the motion for a resolution on completing Economic and Monetary Union in Europe. The proposal concludes that, as part of the first phase of the roadmap contained in the Five Presidents' Report, the Commission published on 21 October 2015 a package containing steps towards completing economic and monetary union, consisting of two communications, one recommendation on a Council recommendation, a draft council decision and a Commission decision. Parliament continues to insist on the implementation of the provisions of the six-pack and the package of two legislative acts, while stressing that the existing treaties and instruments would allow the necessary additional steps to be taken to complete Economic and Monetary Union in Europe. The resolution regrets that the package published by the Commission does not leave sufficient scope for parliamentary oversight and debate at Pan-European level, which are essential to ensure democratic accountability over the decisions taken in relation to economic and monetary union and thus to guarantee citizens' share of the governance of the euro area.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Writing. I voted against the Gualtieri motion for a resolution, as the report calls for a broad amount of increased centralisation, which goes in the direction of a European central state. It praises the measures proposed in the Five Presidents' Report and also calls for more rights for the European Parliament and further transfer of national sovereignty to the European Commission. The ALFA advocates subsidiarity and strongly rejects the European central government. We believe that the economic recovery of the eurozone can only begin if the exchange rate distortions caused by the euro are resolved. A number of amendments from various groups to raise the report's failed eurozone bailout policy were rejected by the major parties. I cannot agree to a one-sided and ideologically strong motion for a resolution. That is why I rejected the report.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 Completing Economic and Monetary Union in Europe is an important step towards an efficient community. These must be based on democratic principles and take account of the situation in the Member States.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. On 21 October 2015, as part of the first phase of the programme contained in the Five Presidents' Report, the Commission published a package containing measures to progress towards the completion of the Economic and Monetary Union. The package of measures adopted by the College of Commissioners contains a new approach to the European Semester, which is achieved, inter alia by strengthening democratic dialogue and further improving economic governance, for example through the introduction of national competitiveness committees and the advisory European Fiscal Board, and a more unified representation of the euro area in international financial institutions, in particular the IMF.  Measures to complete the Banking Union, in particular through the European Deposit Insurance Scheme and measures to further reduce risks in the banking system, are also listed. I support the proposal for a resolution on the completion of Europe's Economic and Monetary Union. I believe this is a step forward, towards a genuine Economic Union where all economies will have the necessary structural characteristics for progress within the monetary union.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the resolution on completing Europe's Economic and Monetary Union. I welcome the Commission communication on the completion of the European Economic and Monetary Union, which sets out a very ambitious agenda for the future. The resolution proposes a set of measures focusing on four strategic areas: building an economic union, a financial union, a fiscal union and a political union. The key question here, however, is how much political will to carry out this project by the national governments of the Member States and by the European Commission and the European Parliament. I firmly believe in the future of the euro and the future of economic and monetary union.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The adoption of the euro has led to significant divergences between Member States, which have made structural imbalances between them even greater and caused a distortion of recession in the countries of the European Union. A new credit policy must be put in place to tackle the problem of over-indebtedness and bankruptcy affecting thousands of families in the Member States and stability and convergence programmes must also be abolished in order to tackle the continuing recession affecting weak economies.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the decision to complete the European Economic and Monetary Union. I welcome the efforts of the five Presidents and the Commission to strengthen economic and monetary union. The plan is ambitious but also pragmatic, which no longer only means crisis management, but also aims at consolidating and fulfilling the Union. Democratic accountability and legitimacy have and will play a major role in this process, which is why it is important that the European Parliament is given enough space to review macroeconomic adjustment programmes. As a result, greater involvement of the European Parliament in the European Semester process is crucial, since without it full legitimacy has not been given.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The package of proposals adopted by the European Commission on 21 October launches the first phase of a series of actions to complete economic and monetary union. Undoubtedly, the Commission should be commended for its efforts to develop the EU economy and to improve public finances. The document contains many important demands, such as a change of approach to the European Semester, the creation of a Banking Union or a more coherent representation of the euro area in international institutions. Unfortunately, in addition to important solutions, the document contains many proposals that may raise doubts. One such issue is an unjustified belief in the miraculous power of institutional solutions. Indeed, existing bodies at European and national level are proposing to add more, such as national competitiveness councils. The European Parliament resolution appropriately emphasises the Commission's positive efforts to strengthen economic and monetary union, while highlighting problems with the implementation at national level of certain budgetary and fiscal reforms and the lack of proper coordination between the Commission and Parliament. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour of this resolution.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. – Achieving economic and monetary union is key to the European project. It therefore only gives greater coherence and solidity to the Union.  The Commission has now launched a draft for the completion of EMU, based on the Five Presidents' Report, which includes an up-to-date European Semester and a new scheme for assessing annual growth, the establishment of national competitiveness councils to assess performance and policies in this area, the organisation of the European Budget Council for the supervision of the euro area and the provision of representation of the euro area at international level , especially within the IMF. New steps towards the achievement of the banking union are also foreseen, in particular through the establishment of a European Deposit Guarantee Scheme.  Unfortunately, the package proposed by the Commission does not provide for greater scrutiny of EMU by the European Parliament, which would have strengthened the democratic dimension of this policy. Provisions should also be included to encourage economic and social convergence, as well as an increase in decision-making transparency in this area. However, I believe that the current resolution is a first step towards strengthening EMU, which can be followed by other improvements that will bring the Union closer to the needs of citizens.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. Like the rapporteur, I regret that the measures that the Commission has made public do not leave sufficient room for parliamentary control and debate at European level, which are nevertheless necessary to put democratic seing on decisions taken in the context of EMU and thus to ensure the ownership of the governance of the euro area by citizens.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which insists on further efforts to address the current shortcomings of the institutional framework of the euro area. It also insists on the implementation of the provisions of the six-pack and the two-pack, while stressing that existing Treaties and instruments would allow some of the necessary additional steps to be taken towards completing the EMU.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: in writing. \u2012 The economic recovery of our continent is unfortunately still very fragile and in order to revive growth we must make the best use of the instruments at our disposal, so it is necessary to strengthen economic governance and fully achieve the economic and monetary union of our continent. We have created emergency mechanisms, new institutions to strengthen economic cooperation, but it is not enough, we need first of all to complete the banking union, to give solidity to our banks, but also and above all to savers. New instruments, such as the European Fund for Strategic Investments, are also needed. This is a first step in the right direction, but it needs to be strengthened in order to allow more credit flows for businesses and we need stronger action to strengthen domestic demand.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Through its supervisory mechanisms, the European Parliament gives real legitimacy to the European Semester and can ensure that it is not a mere wish list, but a comprehensive economic and financial plan tailored to the needs of the Member States.  If the control of this house over the European Semester is not fully established, the question of its democratic legitimacy may indeed be raised, just as the very meaning of its existence can be questioned, as its recommendations in several Member States are not implemented at all or attempts to be maximally circumvented by national authorities. I hope that Parliament will fully consume its supervisory role in the future, ensuring that the European Semester recommendations are applied consistently to create a sustainable economic picture for Member States, based on private investment, structural reforms, market freedom and balanced fiscal policy.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the completion of The European Economic and Monetary Union because I believe that the Five Presidents' report is well prepared and we need an ambitious plan to strengthen the euro area, and an independent committee on the supervision of the euro area needs to be drawn up.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. – We voted against this resolution, which is the European Parliament's response to the report of the five presidents, in which it intends to move forward in the integration of european monetary union, through a centralisation of economic and fiscal powers which would consolidate the model of neoliberal and austeritarian governance. Parliament's report accepts this perspective, calling only for itself for more powers and control over the other institutions. For our part, we believe that monetary union as it exists today is a source of imbalances and doomed to failure if it remains contingent on the interests of large Central European banks. A democratisation of monetary union is only possible through a deep democratization of European society and economy that prepends the interests of peoples to those of the powerful.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Writing. I voted against the Gualtieri resolution because the report calls for much more centralisation, which goes in the direction of a European central state. It praises the measures proposed in the Five Presidents' Report and also calls for more rights for the European Parliament and further transfer of national sovereignty to the European Commission. The ALFA advocates subsidiarity and strongly rejects the European central government. We believe that the economic recovery of the eurozone can only begin if the exchange rate distortions caused by the euro are resolved. A number of amendments from various groups to raise the report's failed eurozone bailout policy were rejected by the major parties. I cannot agree to a one-sided and ideologically strong motion for a resolution. That is why I rejected the report.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ The reform of our monetary zone is as urgent as it was six months ago.  Completing the Banking Union is as urgent as before. Ensuring that private creditors pay first, and that the European supervision is accompanied by a European fiscal backstop prevents the failure of the banking system in a Member State from forcing its government to cut its public services. It is also important to build a eurozone fiscal capacity that enables Europe to react to asymmetric shocks, particularly to help those Member States that have a sudden hike in unemployment. The European Union loses more and more credibility every time that a Member State decides not to comply with a European directive. It is happening with the two-pack and it happened with the six-pack. 1. A stronger political legitimacy for the European Commission. The disrespect of national governments for European rules shows that only with a strong Commission, with a President elected and accountable directly to the European people will be able to enforce the rules. 2. More regulations, less directives. The goodwill of national governments cannot be taken for granted. Their application of European directives is at least ambiguous.  If we want a strong and more integrated Eurozone, we need first to comply with our own rules.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Significant and rapid progress is needed in strengthening the euro area. On 21 October 2015, as a first step in the agenda outlined in the five Presidents' reports, the European Commission published a package of steps to achieve Economic and Monetary Union (EMU). The Commission's proposal has succeeded in taking several steps in the right direction, but further efforts will be needed to close the current gaps in the euro area institutional system. I supported the final text.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. – We voted against this resolution, which is the European Parliament's response to the report of the five presidents, in which it intends to move forward in the integration of european monetary union, through a centralisation of economic and fiscal powers which would consolidate the model of neoliberal and austeritarian governance. Parliament's report accepts this perspective, calling only for itself for more powers and control over the other institutions. For our part, we believe that monetary union as it exists today is a source of imbalances and doomed to failure if it remains contingent on the interests of large Central European banks. A democratisation of monetary union is only possible through a deep democratization of European society and economy that prepends the interests of peoples to those of the powerful.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because I agree with the text on ‘the review of the economic governance framework: stocktaking and challenges’ that has underlined the need for ambitious and rapid progress in strengthening the euro area. In this resolution we recognise that some steps have been taken in the right direction, but we also stress that further efforts will be necessary to address the current shortcomings of the institutional framework of the euro area. This topic is very important also as regards the stability and trust of the Monetary Union and I regret that the package published by the Commission does not leave enough room for parliamentary oversight and debate at European level, which are necessary to ensure the democratic accountability of the decisions taken in the context of the EMU and consequently to ensure citizens’ ownership of euro area governance.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. I voted against this report on the future of economic and monetary union, as it is an empty and inconclusive text that in no way calls into question the current proposals to complete and further strengthen the construction of the eurozone, despite the failed experience of the euro, made clear by the crisis of recent years, suggesting that we go in the opposite direction. The report essentially confines itself to seeking fake solutions to the very serious and intolerable problem of the total lack of democratic control over fundamental economic policy decisions inherent in the current framework of economic governance. The report also fails to address a fundamental reflection on the sustainability of the single currency and the need to radically rethink the current governance framework, putting national sovereignty at the heart of democratic monetary and fiscal policy choices and defining a plan for a controlled and orderly dissolution of the eurozone. For these reasons, I voted against this report.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'This report calls for further efforts to address the current shortcomings in the institutional framework of the euro area. Although some steps have already been taken in the right direction, further efforts still need to be made. This issue is extremely important in order to restore stability and confidence in EMU.

name: Paavo VÄYRYNEN
text: Written. \u2012 Today, Thursday, a European Parliament resolution on the finalisation of Economic and Monetary Union was voted on. The resolution itself is partly technical and calls for Parliament to be consulted on the final process of economic and monetary union. Parliament wants 'democratic control' to 'hear the voice of the citizens'. This refers to Parliament itself. I do not think it is an exaggeration to interpret the fact that, by adopting this report, it will at the same time approve the five presidents' plan for the development of the euro area. This would mean greater financial solidarity between member states and centralisation of decision-making at supranational level. The five Presidents' plan aims, among other things, at a bank union of solidarity, a common euro area budget with permanent transfer systems and a common Ministry of Finance.  These are objectives that I cannot accept.  The problems in the euro area are due to the fact that there are too many different economies involved in the single currency. It is not the optimal currency range. The five presidents' plan further exacerbates the economic and political problems caused by the single currency.   Deeper integration of the euro area will take decision-making power away from the governments of the euro area countries to a supranational level, far away from the Member States and their citizens. This is a development that I cannot accept. That is why I voted against the report.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 In EMU and its economic governance, so-called austerity policies are permanent and not temporary, as they are shaped by rules that constitute a vest-of-forces to the sovereign decision of the Member States and their peoples. From the outset, we opposed the creation of EMU. Today, the consequences jump in sight: high levels of unemployment, high levels of indebtedness, loss of external competitiveness, very low growth rates. Although it has been established that EMU was the wrong option, they insist on its conclusion, once again without economic arguments and once again without listening and without consulting the people of each Member State. As in the past, they impose more neoliberalism and more federalism, but now with the package of the social dimension and greater democracy. We don't accept makeup. You want more democracy? So consult the people and respect their will. Are you, in fact, concerned about unemployment and rising poverty? So put aside this project that institutionalizes neoliberal principles.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. This report leads to more coordination, more control on the part of the institutions, more powers. I am opposed to further centralisation and, therefore, to this report.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the completion of Europe's Economic and Monetary Union, because the proposal of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs rightly highlights the weaknesses of the institutional framework of the euro area and the lack of reliable and regular parliamentary control.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite the breadth of the issue, this resolution, which I rejected, forcibly limits the focus on the aspects of democracy relating to the marginal role played by Parliament in emu governance issues, deliberately omitting all substantive and most controversial issues, and thus giving up the opportunity to express Parliament's position on the process of implementing the 5 Presidents' report. The final text is the unsatisfactory result of a compromise reached within a few hours between the main political groups, which also led to the mass withdrawal of amendments that went too far into the substance. It is a resolution that has suppressed any possibility of political debate and the voice of smaller groups and in no way reflects the position of the ECON Committee, which is clearly divided on governance issues. In the ECON Committee, we tabled a number of amendments highlighting central issues relating to the failure of the euro, the inadequacy of the governance framework and the instruments available, and which reiterated that the lack of democracy can only be resolved by giving Member States democratic sovereignty over monetary and fiscal policies. These amendments, like most of those tabled by all the political groups, have simply been ignored or rejected.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 With EMU, the divergence between Member States has deepened for the benefit of the most robust economies and tax avoidance and profit transfer have intensified. The concrete proposals for the establishment of a European Budgetary Council and national competitiveness councils – which we reject – composed of experts and aimed at monitoring the performance of budgetary implementations and labour policies, only emphasises the undemocratic nature of economic governance. We have put forward a number of proposals, which aim, on the one hand, at the repeal of the economic governance structure, namely the European Semester, the Stability and Growth Pact, the Fiscal Treaty and, on the other hand, the renegotiation of debt, the creation of an emergency plan to support the economies intervened by the Troika, the recovery of economic and monetary sovereignty, the strengthening of the role of the financial public sector and the subordination of economic power to democratic political power , ideologically and politically, contrary to the proposals to deepen neoliberal policies that underpin the process of capitalist integration that is the European Union. Unfortunately, they weren't approved.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: – The European Union has a great responsibility to ensure that human rights are respected in the world. It is a question of human dignity, but also a practical way of preventing waves of migration from countries that suppress human fundamental rights. It is good that the proposed text of this report was balanced and included a call for the abolition of the death penalty, including a ban on surrogacy as an inhumane practice that leads women to sell and rent their bodies. On the other hand, a series of amendments that go beyond Parliament's competence have been added to the text. It is sad that human rights are being abused as a pretext for promoting abortion and same-sex marriage, while completely ignoring the principle of subsidiarity. That is why I had to vote 'no' in the final vote.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur Supporting human rights and democracy on a global scale is one of the cornerstones of the European Union's existence. While several countries develop contacts with each other on the basis of interests and the principles of pragmatism, it is of paramount importance to strengthen this vector for the European Union's foreign policy. At the same time, colleagues, it is clear that we must not forget that different parts of the world have evolved in each of their specific contexts and each culture has its own specific characteristics, and while there is clearly such a thing as universal human rights, it must always be remembered that everywhere their understanding is peculiar and that is what we have to take into account. This is precisely the basis for any rational diplomacy: to proponiate your views, interests and values, taking into account other values in parallel. But in general, I regard this document as extremely important, I voted in favour and I believe that it will give further impetus to the protection of human rights by the European Union.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – I welcome the fact that the report calls for consistency between the Union's internal and external policies and for the avoidance of double standards, specifically drawing the attention of the UNION and its Member States to effectively addressing internal human rights challenges. Only such a consistent approach, both domestically and externally, can enable the Union to maintain its credibility and effectiveness in its external human rights policy. I would like to cite the issue of indigenous national minorities as an example, since the Union often criticises third countries for violations against national minorities in its foreign policy activities, but these minorities do not benefit the UNION institutions, despite being almost 10% of the TOTAL POPULATION of the EU.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Mr President, we all support human rights, but this report states that the EU and Member States must speak with a consistent, single voice on such matters. A consistent, single voice interferes with sovereign national rights to set our own foreign policy. I refer in particular to three points in this report and the amendments approved today.  Firstly, regarding the talk of a definition of a new type of refugee – a climate refugee – we have not thought through the consequences of doing this, and yet the Parliament approved it by a large majority today. Secondly, quota systems for women in politics and democracy, how on earth – even if you believe that such demeaning quotas are a good thing – can you impose that on countries outside Europe? That is nonsense. Finally, regarding the death penalty, I personally am weakly opposed to the death penalty, but it is not for us to lecture others on that matter. It is a sovereign decision for nation-states to take for themselves.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The annual report on human rights and democracy in the world makes it possible not only to carry out an assessment of the interventions carried out in the year ended, but also to ensure that European citizens have a better knowledge and information on European policies in this field. The work presented by the rapporteur, Mr Preda, calls on European bodies to make more effective and effective use of the instruments provided for respect for human rights and democracy in third countries. The European Union should first and foremost support and encourage the process of democratisation and the construction of democracies on the ground. In addition, it should make a further effort to protect specific axes of action, such as freedom of conscience, freedom of faith and respect for the rights of women and children. I voted in favour because the report not only showed a positive account of the instruments used in 2014, but also proposed further forms of action to ensure better achievement of European human rights objectives.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted against this report because, while there are positive parts, such as those we find on the rights of women and LGBTI groups, the report calls for a strengthening of the instruments of interference foreign policy, in particular with funding for specific organisations on the ground with which we do not agree at all. In addition, Annex 1 calls for a list of 'prisoners of conscience' which, in addition to endangering the security of certain human rights defenders, would be a strongly sesathed list by relying on European Parliament resolutions on cases of violations of human rights, democracy and the rule of law, in which certain countries are always appointed while other countries are always appointed , for various reasons relating to the interests of EU Member States, are never mentioned. That is why I have not supported this report.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP abstained on this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP of course shares many of the concerns highlighted in the report regarding the violation of human rights, discrimination against LGBTI people, sexual violence as a weapon of war and many other cruel and inhumane acts. However we cannot support calls for more EU action on the international stage. These issues should be handled between national governments and at the appropriate and legitimate international level, namely the United Nations. The unelected and unaccountable EU institutions have no right to interfere in the foreign policy of Member States or the domestic affairs of non-EU countries.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The European Union must be at the centre of its external action to promote human rights. This report, which I voted in favour of, stresses the need for better coordination between the various Commission services and between the various tools at its disposal. Specific reference is made to the need to respect the rights of women and children, including the right to abortion, LGBT rights, social rights, the refugee crisis, and the need to create humanitarian corridors.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. The 2014 Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World and the European Union's policy in this area calls on the Commission and the European External Action Service (EEAS) to take full follow-up to the issues raised in the Annual Report to address these issues. Indeed, I share the view that the EU and its Member States should tackle the international human rights challenges effectively in order to maintain the credibility and consistency of their external human rights policy. The situation of the Roma, the treatment of refugees and migrants, discrimination against LGBTI people, racism, violence against women, conditions of detention and freedom of the media are important challenges that we must face up to. In addition, human rights and democracy-enhancing measures should be an integral part of EU policies with an external dimension. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report by the European Parliament.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. Like the United States, the European Union likes to teach the whole world about democracy and impose its ideologies. It should be noted, however, that his indignations are selective and variable geometry. This is quite a case in this text: Russia is constantly targeted and denounced as an aggressive country that does not respect human rights. Not a word, however, about Turkey and the Gulf countries, much less about the Western interference that led to the chaos in Iraq and Libya, in the name of human rights. Of course, this report gives pride of place to immigrants, LGBTI minorities and Roma. As always, all these populations would be the victims of odious discrimination. From there, the policies of mass immigration, libertarian laws (marriage and adoption for homosexual persons, dissemination of gender theory in the school environment), evictions from illegal and unsanitary camps are presented as unbearable violations of human rights. Together with my colleagues on the National Front, I naturally voted against this relationship to the destructive ideology of the nation and the family.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The Committee on Foreign Affairs adopted this initiative report, which first points out that half of the world's population still lives under undemocratic and repressive regimes and that global freedom has declined overall. The report therefore rightly stresses that human rights and the policy of supporting democracy should be integrated into all EU policies with an external dimension such as development, migration, security, the fight against terrorism, enlargement and trade policy. Among the priorities to be defended by the Union and the Member States, the report highlights the universal abolition of the death penalty, the promotion of freedom of thought, conscience and religion or belief, the defence of the rights of women and girls, respect for the rights of LGBTi and support for civil society and human rights defenders. I approved this report.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. – We abstained in this vote by considering that this is a report which does not add any added value to the annual reports developed by non-governmental organizations with more experience, expertise and human and material resources in the field. Moreover, they may be more objective than the report commissioned by a political group. Although the report introduces relevant aspects such as the human rights consequences of the crisis and implemented policies, homophobia, climate refugees and the search for lasting solutions to address the refugee crisis, it contains intolerable biases for a report presented as neutral, such as the absence of concrete criticism of human rights violations within the EU , or the commitment to sanctions on trading partners who are systematically violating rights.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I would like to thank the rapporteur for his work on this annual report on human rights and democracy 2014 and the EU's policy on human rights and democracy. I welcome the vote cast on opposition to the annexation, occupation and colonization of territories and the insistence on this Resolution on the inalienable right of peoples to self-determination. Similarly, I voted in favour of the amendment of the GUE/NGL Group on Western Sahara and the request for the release of political prisoners and for MINURSO to be given a mandate on human rights, and the express mention of the self-determination of Western Sahara.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I voted against the core of pure ideology that is the Preda report on human rights. Once again, the European institutions are more concerned about the discrimination against minorities such as Roma, migrants, etc., than about the increasingly precariousness of European peoples who are victims of mass unemployment and Brussels austerity that is taking them by surprise. Moreover, Mr Preda's text is a new nugget in terms of hypocrisy, since, while it recalls the inalienable right of peoples to self-determination, it once again hammers the imperialist role of the Union which, through total interference, is supposed to bring human rights and democracy to the rest of the world; a shame when we also see the treatment of European leaders who dare to listen to the will of their people. Finally, this report is a new cover-up addressed to the sovereignty of the Member States summoned to bow to the Commission, which would gradually become the only authority for diplomacy on the international stage.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Respect for human rights is the basis of EU principles and I am convinced that it needs to be included in all agreements with third countries, but this is an already established practice that the EU often and willingly does not enforce, preferring to make the economic interests at stake prevail or failing to assert its political weight adequately. The solutions proposed in this report are too weak and I believe ineffective in the pursuit of the ultimate goal, for these reasons I did not support this text with my vote.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. I have abstained from voting on the report on the annual report. The report highlights good things, including on surrogacy, women's and LGBTQ rights, and the importance of binding human rights clauses in trade policy. On the other hand, the report attaches far too much importance to a common foreign and security policy and supports the Khartoum process. Furthermore, with regard to refugee policy, the report emphasises, among other things, the importance of the EU's external borders and talks about refugees as burdens. At a time when the EU does not respect the right to asylum, where the EU is deporting thousands of people to deadly situations, where the EU is defending borders instead of people, I would need to see stronger wording in support of human rights and an emphasis on solidarity rather than borders, in order to support the report.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it has been the subject of an annual report by Parliament on human rights and democracy in the world in 2014 and the European Union's policy in this area. The EU is committed to developing a common foreign and security policy, in accordance with the principles of democracy, the rule of law, the universality and indivisibility of human rights and fundamental freedoms, respect for human dignity, equality and solidarity, in accordance with the principles set out in the UN Charter, the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and international law. Parliament has therefore expressed deep concern in this report that freedom of assembly and association is increasingly under threat in many parts of the world, including countries of authoritarian regimes, human rights and democratic values such as freedom of expression, thought, conscience and religion, as well as freedom of assembly and association, and the public space of civil society is shrinking and human rights defenders are increasingly being attacked. Parliament therefore called on the EU and its Member States to step up their efforts to make human rights and democratic values a key aspect of their relations with the wider world, and advocated that the EU should take appropriate measures, including measures in the area of trade, energy or security relations, in the event of serious violations of human rights in third countries, especially if that country is governed by authoritarian regimes.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 In its report on the state of human rights and democracy in the world in 2014, the European Parliament examines the situation of fundamental rights and freedoms and democracy in so-called third countries. The document emphasises that human rights and democratic values, such as freedom of expression and freedom of thought, have been put at an even worse disadvantage in many parts of the world. Furthermore, although freedom of conscience, religion or belief is a fundamental human right recognised in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, they are also grossly violated in many UN Member States. The report calls on the EU and its Member States to make better use of the policy instruments at their disposal and calls for their efforts to be stepped up so that human rights are effectively at the heart of their international relations.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. I voted against violations of human rights, democracy and the rule of law and in accordance with the rights of children and families. I have also advocated protecting our traditional values on which Europe is built.
