The ideological themes in that report divide us, and on top of that, they still have the competences of the EU Member States. And it saddens me, because the most important democratic institution is turning into a place of in-erience political and ideological reckoning.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU's annual report on human rights and democracy in the world is an extremely important instrument for the Union's external action, which, in accordance with Article 21 of the Treaty on European Union, must develop around the principles of democracy, the rule of law and the universality of human rights, enabling them to be promoted on a global scale. On the assumption that respect for fundamental rights and freedoms must therefore be the guiding principles of the Union's action on the international stage, we must ensure consistency between our external action and our internal policies. If Europe wishes to continue to act as guarantor of human rights in the world, it must first of all serve as an example of respect for human rights within its borders. In this regard, I welcome the fact that human rights are increasingly at the heart of the dialogue of the European institutions, particularly within Parliament, and I consider it highly desirable that any instrument intended to protect them should actually be deployed. Not only that: the promotion and defence of fundamental rights must be integrated into every Union policy with regard to the external dimension, with a particular focus on neighbourhood policy and development cooperation.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ I am pleased to support elements of this report relating to the right to choose, surrogacy and other progressive values of my political option.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 It is worrying that the human rights and democratic values of freedom of thought, speech, religion and association are now so threatened in many parts of the world, particularly under authoritarian regimes. In view of the shrinking public and democratic space in the world and given that an increasing number of human rights defenders are suffering physical and psychological attacks, it is clear that, in order to deliver on their commitment to promoting human rights and democracy in the world, the EU and its Member States must speak with a single and coherent voice in order for their message to be heard. Enhanced cooperation between the Commission, the Council, the EEAS, Parliament and EU delegations is needed in order to improve the overall coherence of EU human rights and democracy policy and its centrality with regard to all UNION policies with an external dimension, in particular in the areas of development, security, employment, migration, trade and technology. Human rights and democracy in the world will not be able to take solid root unless democratic countries act in a manner consistent with their values in all possible circumstances, including economic and financial bargaining.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 Respect for and promotion of the indivisibility and universality of human rights and their defence is one of the union's concerns, committed to the development of a common foreign and security policy guided by the principles of democracy, the rule of law, the universality and indivisibility of human rights and fundamental freedoms, respect for human dignity, and the principle of equality and solidarity. There are a number of large-scale threatened rights, such as freedom of thought, conscience, religious freedom and belief. The number of infringements increases considerably, especially in third countries. The Union must take prompt and responsible action when serious human rights violations are reported in third countries, in particular those governed by authoritarian regimes.  It is also important to adopt measures internally, given the cases of discrimination and violation of the rights that arise in the situation of Roma, in the situation of migrants and refugees. Immediate responses are needed in such cases in order for the Union to maintain its credibility and consistency in its foreign human rights policy. I have expressed myself in favour of this report, because I believe that it is imperative to guarantee human rights and democratic values, as well as the existence of internal and external policies through which these principles are transposed.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Unbalanced and instrumental text. As usual, the EU points the finger at some countries but forgets about others with whom it does business. I am voting against.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the annual report on human rights and democracy in the world in 2014 and on the European Union's policy in this area, which has been a dramatic situation. In many countries there have been restrictions on non-governmental organisations, serious human rights violations against activists and attacks on journalists and bloggers. A situation that seems even worse in this 2015. Much more must therefore be done to guarantee fundamental freedoms, respect for human dignity, the principles of equality and solidarity. Respect for human rights in Europe must be high on the agenda of the EU institutions and the Member States. The report has highlighted all these elements and I have therefore voted in favour of it.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. – While this report contained some positive elements such as such as maintenance of a universal moratorium against the death penalty, there were a number of negative aspects. Specifically, the report called for the strengthening and expansion of the role of the EEAS and the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy / Vice-President of the Commission at the unilateral expense of Member States. Such interference does not benefit human rights or democracy, conversely it undermines such.  Therefore, I was unable to support this report and I abstained on the final vote.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. – UKIP abstained on this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP of course shares many of the concerns highlighted in the report regarding the violation of human rights, discrimination against LGBTI people, sexual violence as a weapon of war and many other cruel and inhumane acts. However we cannot support calls for more EU action on the international stage. These issues should be handled between national governments and at the appropriate and legitimate international level, namely the United Nations. The unelected and unaccountable EU institutions have no right to interfere in the foreign policy of Member States or the domestic affairs of non-EU countries.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that human rights and democratic values should remain at the core of the EU’s relations with third countries and of the EU’s actions in general. I agree on the importance of the EU stepping up its efforts to make full use of all policy tools at its disposal in order to promote respect for human rights and democratic principles worldwide, as has been set out in this report, including gender equality and identity. I also agreed with the text concerning the abolition of the death penalty and the prohibition of surrogate motherhood. On the other hand, I was unable to vote in favour of this report as it contained references to abortion and sexual and reproductive rights.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which expresses the will to act in an incisive and coherent manner in order to consolidate respect for human rights and democracy in third countries. Together with the rapporteur, Mr Preda, and the other shadow rapporteurs, we have focused our attention in particular on human rights defenders, the rights of indigenous peoples, the rights of migrants and refugees, sport and human rights, freedom of thought, conscience and religion, the fight against torture and discrimination, LGBTI rights, the rights of people with disabilities , women's and girls' rights and children's rights.

name: Nessa CHILDERS
text: in writing. ‒ Through this Annual Report, we show recognition of all that needs to be done, in the years to come, to fight for human rights and democracy inside and outside the EU Since the economic crisis, political decisions have been made which clearly undermine citizens’ rights in the EU. And today we are faced with an unprecedented humanitarian crisis within our borders. And that is why it is vital that, today, we work harder in the EU to defend human rights and to promote them.  When austerity measures are put in place, we see the that the fulfilment of civil rights, labour rights, health and education rights is compromised.  I am pleased to hear that the Commission’s main priorities, within external action, will continue to include the protection of human rights, so that this element will continue to shape policies in the near future. At a time of rising populism, this report rightly reiterates the importance of abolishing the death penalty, promoting freedom of speech, promoting LGBTI, women’s and children’s rights and continuing support for human rights defenders’ groups in other parts of the world where they are undermined by oppressive governments.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the report and underline the EU's efforts to respect and promote respect for human rights and democratic values in its relations with the rest of the world. The report rightly points out in our view that democratic regimes are not only characterised by free and fair electoral procedures but also guarantee freedom of speech, the press and association, the rule of law and accountability, the independence of the judiciary and impartial administration, among others. It also stresses that democracy and human rights are inextricably linked and mutually reinforced, as is also recalled in the Council conclusions of 18 November 2009 on support for democracy in the context of the EU's external relations. Finally, we welcome the fact that the new action plan on human rights and democracy pays particular attention to activities to support democracy.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report on the 2014 annual report on human rights and democracy in the world and the European Union's policy in this area concerns a particularly important area in which we must focus our attention in order to promote democratic ideals and socially correct perceptions. Despite the problems, which are not negligible, such as foreign policy issues, cases of intervention in third countries, dialogue on religious issues and the issue of 'prisoners of conscience', the resolution nevertheless contains positive elements since, for example, the urgent need to address the root causes of migration flows is stressed and the need for an integrated approach to migration on the basis of human rights is underlined and these positive elements have prompted me to vote in favour of the report.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure. Parliament welcomes the adoption of the EU annual report on human rights and democracy in the world in 2014; considers that the annual report is an indispensable tool for monitoring, communicating and discussing the EU's policy on human rights, democracy and the rule of law in the world. Expresses its deep concern that human rights and democratic values, such as freedom of expression, thought, conscience and religion, and freedom of assembly and association, are increasingly under threat in many parts of the world, particularly under authoritarian regimes; it is also deeply concerned that public space for civil society is shrinking and that an increasing number of human rights defenders are being attacked around the world. It called on the EU and its Member States to step up their efforts to effectively put democratic values and human rights at the heart of their relations with the rest of the world, while respecting the commitment made in the TEU.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because the European Union has always fought for the protection of what it considers to be the basic human rights of a society that guarantees the well-being of its citizens. In particular, international covenants on civil and political rights, the Pact on Economic Rights, freedom of religion and expression, the protection of minors and women and the promotion of fundamental human rights are of great consideration at European level. Now and then I think that in too many states these rights and these attentions to society are not guaranteed, the example of freedom of the press and freedom of speech comes to mind, which in some countries of Africa and in some Eastern countries are not fully granted. I believe that the EU must take the lead in the fight for the protection of these principles, and act as a global driving force for obtaining the rights that have largely been achieved in our Union. To this end, I welcome and agree with the description guidelines and policies set out in the aforementioned report.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ The report drafted by Cristian Dan Preda (EPP) highlights the importance of the EU making full use of all policy tools at its disposal in order to promote respect for human rights and democratic principles worldwide. The text calls in particular for an effective implementation of the new EU Action Plan on Human Rights and Democracy 2015 - 2019. The report suggests avenues of action for making human rights dialogues, human rights country strategies and human rights guidelines more meaningful in addressing related shortcomings in third countries. It equally praises the role of the EU Special Representative for Human Rights whose visibility and own-initiative powers should be enhanced.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 Annually, the European Parliament assesses the situation of the world with regard to human rights and the rule of law. This report makes this diagnosis once again, correctly identifying the most worrying situations around the world.  On the other hand, human rights are called for a cross-cutting policy, across all foreign policy, and for the implementation of the 2015-2019 action plan for human rights. Furthermore, the report also supports the European Union's leading participation in relevant international for a, such as the United Nations, notably by encouraging the implementation of existing international instruments. Unfortunately, there are still many regions of the world where human rights are disrespected every year and their populations live in unacceptable conditions. I therefore think it is essential that the European Parliament continues to make its defence, in Europe and in the world, a priority issue.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 This report underlines the importance for the European Union of enhancing the political instruments at its disposal in order to promote respect for human rights and democratic principles around the world, reaffirming the need to implement a new EU action plan on human rights and democracy 2015 - 2019. I chosen to vote in favour of approving the Eu ropean Union's annual report on human rights and democracy in the world in 2014, as it is an indispensable instrument for monitoring, communicating and discussing the EU's policy on human rights, democracy and the rule of law in the world. I also hope that the EEAS and the Commission will ensure that the issues raised in the annual report are addressed in practice and that multilateral organisations, in particular the UN, the OECD and the OSCE, commit themselves to improving international cooperation in the field of human rights and democracy.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. – Once again we are denouncing the dramatic number of deaths at sea in the Mediterranean making this sea the deadliest region in the world for irregular migration, wasting ink to reaffirm this year on year without registering any significant progress. I am extremely concerned about reports of human rights abuses against migrants and asylum seekers on their way to the EU and I call for the Union and its Member States to cooperate with the UN, regional mechanisms, governments and NGOs to tackle these issues in an urgent manner through integrated policies that are more closely rooted in the principle of solidarity at Union level. But such needs to lead to action, boosting cooperation with these countries to the highest level in order to dismantle the illegal networks used to traffic migrants and fight illegal mafias profiting from human trafficking and human smuggling. Unless I see this happening in a decisive manner I feel I should not applaud Member States’ efforts in living up to what should be their expectations.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted against this report because, while there are positive parts, such as those we find on the rights of women and LGBTI groups, the report calls for a strengthening of the instruments of interference foreign policy, in particular with funding for specific organisations on the ground with which we do not agree at all. In addition, Annex 1 calls for a list of 'prisoners of conscience' which, in addition to endangering the security of certain human rights defenders, would be a strongly sesathed list by relying on European Parliament resolutions on cases of violations of human rights, democracy and the rule of law, in which certain countries are always appointed while other countries are always appointed , for various reasons relating to the interests of EU Member States, are never mentioned. That is why I have not supported this report.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament (EP) prepares an annual report entitled "The state of human rights and democracy in the world". The report adopted at the December plenary gives an picture of the state of human rights in 2014. The EP is deeply concerned that human rights and democratic principles and values in many parts of the world cannot prevail or are under threat. The European Union works to promote human rights and democracy around the world through its means and through international cooperation. This active role is underlined in the report itself. Traditionally, among vulnerable groups, the report mentions "people belonging to minorities". I supported Parliament's decision, but I would like to draw attention once again to the fact that the rights of indigenous national minorities require greater, more comprehensive protection not only outside the EU but also within the European Union.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which focuses on the situation of human rights and democracy in the world in 2014 and EU policy on the matter. It deals with a number of issues: mainly refugee policy and development policy and the link between the two. It also focuses on LGBTI rights, business in third countries – especially EU business and the need to include human rights in our trade policies and industries in third countries. The report also focuses on the situation of women’s rights in the world, touching upon inequality and violence against women It reiterates the EP’s call against the death penalty and speaks about freedom of expression and religion. Whilst I am in favour of the general position and the calls made in this report, I voted against sexual and reproductive health rights since they include abortion and also the termination of pregnancy through abortion.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This initiative report reiterates the importance of the Union using all the political instruments at its disposal to promote respect for human rights and democratic principles around the world. In particular, the rapporteur calls for improving the implementation of European measures, such as the 2015-2019 action plan for human rights and democracy, and for strengthening the power of initiative of the EU Special Representative for Human Rights. Better integration of actions to support human rights and democracy within the framework of the Union's external policies (development policy, migration, neighbourhood) is also considered necessary. The text also refers to indigenous rights, the death penalty, the rights of women and children and torture, and recalls the importance of supporting electoral processes to promote democratization. Supporting these objectives, I voted in favour of the report.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. – UKIP abstained on this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP of course shares many of the concerns highlighted in the report regarding the violation of human rights, discrimination against LGBTI people, sexual violence as a weapon of war and many other cruel and inhumane acts. However we cannot support calls for more EU action on the international stage. These issues should be handled between national governments and at the appropriate and legitimate international level, namely the United Nations. The unelected and unaccountable EU institutions have no right to interfere in the foreign policy of Member States or the domestic affairs of non-EU countries.

name: Luis de GRANDES PASCUAL
text: in writing. In my own name and right and representing the Spanish delegation of the PPE Group as Secretary-General, we would like to say, in relation to the Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World (2014) and the European Union's policy on this issue, that, while we supported this report today in the final vote — because it is of great importance , among other issues, on key issues such as seeking a greater impact of EU policies on the promotion of human rights in the world, support for dissidents and human rights defenders, the protection of the rights of children and women, in particular in conflict zones, as well as immigrants— , we do not agree, and we have therefore voted against it, with the reference in paragraph 111 to sexual and reproductive rights. These are very sensitive issues related to the right to life, a priority for our political formation, and on which we have been speaking unequivocally. Moreover, the European Union has no competence in this area.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. I am very concerned about the growing threat in many parts of the world, particularly in authoritarian regimes, to human rights and democratic values such as freedom of expression, freedom of thought, conscience and religion, or freedom of assembly and association. That is why I voted for the 2014 annual report. Through this vote, I also believe that there is an urgent need to address the root causes of migration flows by addressing the external dimension of the refugee crisis. But I am opposed to the country quota system, which is not a long-term answer. Finally, I welcome the conclusions of the European Council on the promotion and protection of children's rights, adopted in December 2014, and that is why I call on the European Union to continue to help partner countries to combat all forms of violence against children. However, I abstained on the issue of LGBTI rights and same-sex marriage because, in my opinion, this is not within the competence of a mandate as an MEP but of the competence of Member States.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 In its report on the state of human rights and democracy in the world in 2014, the European Parliament examines the situation of fundamental rights and freedoms and democracy in so-called third countries. The document emphasises that human rights and democratic values, such as freedom of expression and freedom of thought, have been put at an even more disadvantageous disadvantage in many parts of the world. Furthermore, although freedom of conscience, religion or belief is a fundamental human right recognised in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, they are also grossly violated in many UN Member States.  The report calls on the EU and its Member States to make more effective use of the additional policy instruments at its disposal and calls for their efforts to be stepped up so that human rights are effectively at the heart of their relations with the wider world. In this spirit, I voted in favour of the Preda report, because human rights cannot play a secondary role in EU foreign policy.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Written. \u2012 The N-VA delegation approved the 2014 annual report. Democracy and human rights deserve a prominent place in the external action of the Union and its Member States. Nevertheless, the N-VA has questions about the following three things: First, the report often risks losing itself by shifting too much emphasis to economic, cultural and social rights in certain paragraphs. Secondly, the request to the EU to take an active part in the debate on the term 'climate refugee', including a possible legal definition of it in international law, is unrealistic. Finally, we believe that stricter recommendations to respond to the business world on human rights are more realistic than an international legally binding instrument.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is necessary to dwell at least once a year on the European Union's human rights and democracy policy in the world. I am pleased to see that this year the rapporteur has managed to prevent the report from becoming a Christmas tree containing only a list of countries and specific cases of human rights violations. I am also delighted to see the contribution of my group by adding the following: the need to continue thinking to strengthen the effectiveness of the European Parliament's resolutions on human rights violations; the need to continue to promote women's political and economic empowerment for foreign policy by integrating gender equality into all external EU policies and programmes and providing sufficient resources for this purpose; and finally, the need to consider as a war crime, but also as a crime against humanity, the deliberate and systematic destruction of archaeological sites,...

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained from Mr. Prea's report "Annual Report 2014 on Human Rights and Democracy in the World and EU Policy in This Area", as the focus of the report shifts from fundamental human rights to secondary rights such as the right to abortion, LGBTI rights (lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and intersex/intersex).  What would people who have been in prison for years think and are not given a fair trial, and this is a fundamental human right, that in the European Parliament's annual report on human rights we discuss social rights, the right to financial transactions and labour rights.  Of course, these rights are also extremely important, but they are still secondary under international law, and the right to abortion and LGBTI rights are even a third generation of rights that shift our attention away from extremely serious cases of persecution, detention by force, ill-treatment, torture, unfair processes and all such serious violations of fundamental human rights.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I find the resolution negative in its entirety because the meaning of true democracy has nothing to do with what today's 'democrats' are promoting. Their respect for human rights is selective and their perceptions of freedom create their own society from which patriots and anyone who loves their country are excluded. The world they want to build goes through the destruction of tradition and peoples.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 In its report on the state of human rights and democracy in the world in 2014, the European Parliament examines the situation of fundamental rights and freedoms and democracy in so-called third countries. The document emphasises that human rights and democratic values, such as freedom of expression and freedom of thought, have been put at an even more disadvantageous disadvantage in many parts of the world. Furthermore, although freedom of conscience, religion or belief is a fundamental human right recognised in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, they are also grossly violated in many UN Member States. The report calls on the EU and its Member States to continue to use the policy instruments at their disposal more effectively and urges them to step up their efforts to ensure that human rights are effectively at the heart of their relations with the wider world. In this spirit, I voted in favour of the Preda report, because human rights cannot play a secondary role in EU foreign policy.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because the European Parliament's report on human rights is the important instrument for monitoring, communicating and debating the EU's policy on human rights, democracy and the rule of law in the world. Human rights are of decisive importance in the EU's relations with other countries and regions of the world. Human rights work can help prevent and resolve conflicts and ultimately alleviate poverty. The report emphasised the EU's commitment to supporting and promoting respect for human rights and democratic values in its relations with the rest of the world. emphasis has been made on the fact that democratic regimes are characterised not only by free and fair electoral processes, but also by freedom of speech, the press and association, the rule of law and accountability, the independence of the judiciary and impartial administration. In its annual report, Parliament focused its attention on very important issues such as human rights and trade, human rights and development, the rights of indigenous peoples, the rights of people with disabilities, LGBTI rights, etc., strongly condemning the death penalty and torture.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Written. An important report on the role of the EU in influencing human rights issues. I have voted against generally condemning surrogacy and I have voted to recognise Western Sahara as a sovereign state and voted in favour of the whole report.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. \u2012 The action of undemocratic and repressive regimes, armed conflicts and aberrant business, speculative and power logics, determine in much of the world the systematic violation of human rights. Inequalities, abuses, crime, poverty, the exploitation of resources, precarious working conditions, poor quality of services and restrictions on their access undermine the basic social and economic rights and deteriorate the living conditions of entire populations. Respect for the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights are essential for the full realisation of human potential and shared well-being. The European Union and the actors in international cooperation must continue to strengthen all measures to monitor, prevent and suppress human rights violations and to step up actions aimed at the global democratisation and transparency of political, institutional and economic decision-making processes.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. The usual procession of arguments and evaluations on the condition of human rights in more than 130 countries, in the light of the European Union's own vision – instrumental and restrictive – on human rights and democracy, as if a paladin were both, points to third parties what it neglects within doors. This is the usual prescription, which, aligned with the EU's foreign policy overview and the use of its tools, serves no more than to promote interference in third countries, in areas such as the rule of law, justice, governance and democracy, always pointing the accusatory finger at some – those who are not subservient and do not serve the interests of the EU and its powers – and forgetting others , promoters of gross and repeated human rights violations, such as Israel or the US. Despite some observations, considerations and concerns that are mirroring throughout the text and which we follow, overall, we consider unacceptable the instrumentalisation of human rights and democracy, at the service of the eu's hegemonic interests. We are faced with a monument to hypocrisy. We voted against it.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 This is an important topic with a direct impact on the quality of life and democracy in individual Member States as well as throughout the European Union. Such documents are necessary for discussions on how to ensure the protection of human rights. In terms of practical performance, however, they do not help much. They would be more useful if they included a concrete evaluation and analysis of the impact of existing policies on respect for human rights, whether within or outside the Borders of the European Union. Unfortunately, there are no such parties, despite the description of many parties. It is precisely the effectiveness of the current regulation and its existing instruments that is important to know. Whether we look at the situation in the area of women's rights, minorities, including people with different sexual orientations, hate speech is increasingly occurring against them. At the same time, they are not penalised in any way. Aggressors get a sense of impunity, and discrimination within society just flourishes. Woefully little is being done against this trend. The topic is also important in terms of setting up foreign policy and trade relations in the European Union. When establishing trade relations, for example in the field of energy, but especially in security, the Member States and their representatives are completely not looking at what approach their third-country trading partners have to protect human rights.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the 2014 annual report on human rights and democracy in the world and the European Union's policy in this area, because the meaning of democracy really has nothing to do with what today's 'democrats' are promoting. The way in which they respect human rights is selective and with their choices of freedom they create their own society - with the exception of the patriots and everyone who loves their country. The world they want to build means the destruction of tradition and peoples.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the final agreement reached on the opinion on Annual Report on human rights and democracy in the world 2014. Negotiations have been positive and enriching, and I believe the opinion will support the work of our colleagues in the AFET Committee. We made a strong connection between insisting on human rights, gender equality, good governance, peace and security and the goal of eradicating poverty and inequalities as well as achieving the SDGs. Moreover, we recalled that cultural diversity cannot be invoked to infringe human rights guaranteed by international law. Human rights must be at the core of our development agenda: we therefore stressed the need to ensure that the 2030 agenda for sustainable development is underpinned by a human rights based approach. We mentioned the importance of the Addis Ababa agenda and we decided to strongly condemn, in the opinion, the use of harmful practices on women and of the use of rape as a weapon of war. Last but not least, we reminded the Commission and Member States that the agreements concluded with developing countries must include binding clauses on human rights and that the Commission must conduct systematic human rights impact assessments of trade and investment agreements.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 In its report on the state of human rights and democracy in the world in 2014, the European Parliament examines the situation of fundamental rights and freedoms and democracy in so-called third countries. The document emphasises that human rights and democratic values, such as freedom of expression and freedom of thought, have been put at an even more disadvantageous disadvantage in many parts of the world. Furthermore, although freedom of conscience, religion or belief is a fundamental human right recognised in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, they are also grossly violated in many UN Member States.  The report calls on the EU and its Member States to make more effective use of the additional policy instruments at its disposal and calls for their efforts to be stepped up so that human rights are effectively at the heart of their relations with the wider world. In this spirit, I voted in favour of the Preda report, because human rights cannot play a secondary role in EU foreign policy.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the view that Article 21 of the EIP commits the EU to developing a common foreign and security policy (CFSP) guided by the principles of democracy, the rule of law, the universality and indivisibility of human rights and fundamental freedoms and respect for human dignity. The EU must therefore direct its policies to improving human rights and democracy by intensifying its efforts to effectively place human rights and democratic values at the heart of its relations with the rest of the world.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the annual report on human rights and democracy in the world in 2014 and on the European Union's human rights policy, because I believe that respect for and freedom of human beings is a milestone in Europe's external action. Current geopolitical developments are a worrying situation, with the spread of authoritarian regimes and terrorist groups that sow terror among civilians and are guilty of deplorable actions against opponents. I am deeply concerned that freedom of expression, thought, religion, association and all other democratic values are increasingly under threat in the world. It is no coincidence that yesterday the European Parliament awarded the 2015 Sakharov Prize to Raif Badawi, a Saudi activist sentenced for apostasy to ten years in prison and a thousand lashes, for criticising some religious figures. Finally, I would like to stress the importance of closer cooperation between the Member States and the international community in order to contribute to the elimination of all forms of violence and discrimination and to promote the recognition of universal values of democracy, and in particular the rights of LGBTI, women, the disabled, minorities and all vulnerable groups.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted today against the report on the 2014 annual report on human rights and democracy in the world and the European Union's policy in this area, as the report, in the form amended by the committee responsible, contains many points that have nothing to do with respect for human rights – sometimes even the opposite. On the other hand, I very much welcome the European Parliament's first clear vote against inhumansuria.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. Europe must make use of all political means to represent our common understanding of human rights and the principles of democracy internationally. It is important that we develop an effective action plan for the period 2015-2019, working with international organisations.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the annual human rights report for 2014, which sets out the state of play of EU policy instruments for advancing human rights worldwide and proposes ways to ensure the promotion of human rights and democracy through EU external policies and instruments, notably in the framework of the New Action Plan. It is crucial that we step up efforts on achieving internal and external cohesion, women’s and children’s rights including the right to abortion and the right for raped women/girls in conflict situations to be aborted, the role of women including in post-conflict situations, LGBTI rights,  ILO standards, the ICC, shrinking space for civil society, human rights defenders, and refugee crises, including amendments for the setting up of humanitarian corridors.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We abstained in this vote on the grounds that this is a report which adds no added value to the annual reports developed by non-governmental organizations with more experience, expertise and human and material resources in the field. Moreover, they may be more objective than the report commissioned by a political group. Although the report introduces relevant aspects such as the human rights consequences of the crisis and implemented policies, homophobia, climate refugees and the search for lasting solutions to address the refugee crisis, it contains intolerable biases for a report presented as neutral, such as the absence of concrete criticism of human rights violations within the EU , or the commitment to sanctions on trading partners who are systematically violating rights.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the annual report on human rights and democracy in the world 2014 and the EU policy on the matter because the European Parliament expresses deep concern that human rights and democratic values, such as freedom of expression, freedom of thought, conscience and religion, and freedom of assembly and association, are increasingly under threat in many parts of the world , including under authoritarian regimes. The European Parliament calls for the EU and its Member States to enhance their efforts to effectively regard human rights and democratic values.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 In its report on the state of human rights and democracy in the world in 2014, the European Parliament examines the situation of fundamental rights and freedoms and democracy in so-called third countries. The document emphasises that human rights and democratic values such as freedom of expression and freedom of thought have been put at an even worse disadvantage in many parts of the world than ever before. Freedom of conscience, religion or belief is a fundamental human right recognised in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and is grossly violated in many UN Member States.  The report calls on the EU and its Member States to make better use of the policy instruments at their disposal and urges them to step up their efforts to ensure that human rights are effectively at the heart of their relations with the wider world. In this spirit, I voted in favour of the Preda report, because human rights cannot play a secondary role in EU foreign policy.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The issue of human rights and democracy is extremely sensitive. Unfortunately in the EU, as this report and other analyses show, declarations cannot be left out of the geopolitical game and above economic interests. The report attempts to exclusively target certain countries with which the West is at fault. There is no mention of the violations within the Union itself or of the countries with which the Union has close economic and not only relations.  It is not possible to vote in favour of the report with such glaring shortcomings. It is not possible not to be criticised for visiting different countries and not highlighting human rights issues. We want a Europe different from the other powers and not a Europe under the control of economic and geostrate strategic interests.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the annual report on human rights and democracy in the world for 2014 which gives an overview of the global situation regarding human rights and had some very positive provisions such as support for the systematic introduction of human rights clauses in all international agreements between the EU and third countries, the need for a comprehensive human rights-based approach to migration , and the need to tackle the root causes of migration by addressing the external dimension of the refugee crisis, opposition to the death penalty, support for LGBTI people and the mainstreaming of gender equality. Regarding one area on the rights of women and girls, the issue of surrogacy is grey rather than black and white with varying situations and degrees of protection around the world.  Therefore while I did not vote to condemn the practice or prohibit it as a matter of human rights as many couples with fertility issues benefit from the practice with consenting women, there is an issue concerning the exploitation of vulnerable women in developing countries which needs to be examined further, hence my differing votes on these sections.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I note three problems with this report, aside from the obvious point that the desire for the EU to speak with a ‘single, consistent voice’ is tantamount to removing national sovereignty over foreign policy: 1.  It proposes quota systems for women in democracy.  Even if you believe in quotas, it is not for the EU to impose this on third countries. 2.  It proposes the abolition of the death penalty worldwide.  Even if you oppose the death penalty, it is not for the EU to impose this on third countries. 3.  It proposes a new kind of refugee, a ‘climate refugee’.  I suspect the consequences of such a proposal have not been properly thought through, and could in fact lead to EVERY person on the planet claiming to be a refugee in Europe.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒  I decided to support this report because having respect for, along with the promotion and safeguarding of, human rights must be cornerstones of the EU’s external action. The increased coherence between EU internal and external policies, as well as between the EU’s external policies stands as an indispensable requirement for a successful and effective EU human rights policy. Improved consistency should enable the EU to respond more rapidly in the early stages of human rights violations. Respect for human rights is being challenged and is under threat worldwide and the universality of human rights is being seriously challenged by a number of authoritarian regimes. Finally, more than half the world’s population is still living under non—democratic and repressive regimes and global freedom has continuously declined over the past few years, and this non—respect of human rights has a cost for society and for the individual.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. Parliament is one of the most effective advocates of human rights, but it always commits the same mistake: it is constantly expanding the definition of human rights. What would the Raif Badawis think in the world's prisons when they hear that Parliament's 2014 human rights report deals extensively with financial transactions and corporate taxation, among other things? We will soon be able to close down all the other committees and deal with all human rights issues in the Committee on Human Rights. We are diverting attention from those who really need our help. That is why I voted against this report. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 In its report on the state of human rights and democracy in the world in 2014, the European Parliament examines the situation of fundamental rights and freedoms and democracy in so-called third countries. The document emphasises that human rights and democratic values, such as freedom of expression and freedom of thought, have been put at an even more disadvantageous disadvantage in many parts of the world. Furthermore, although freedom of conscience, religion or belief is recognised in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, they are grossly violated in many UN Member States.  The report calls on the EU and its Member States to make more effective use of the policy instruments at its disposal. It urges them to step up their efforts to make human rights more prominent in their foreign policy. In this spirit, I voted in favour of the Preda report, because human rights cannot play a secondary role in EU foreign policy.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the 2014 Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World. european union policy in this area (2015/2229 (INI)) which expresses deep concern that human rights and democratic values, such as freedom of expression, freedom of thought, conscience and religion, and freedom of assembly and association in many parts of the world are increasingly at risk, including countries under authoritarian regimes.  Furthermore, concerns are raised about the narrowing of public space for civil society and the attacks on an increasing number of human rights defenders worldwide. Respect, promotion, indivisibility and the protection of the universality of human rights must continue to be the foundations of the EU's external action. This report calls, inter alia, on the EU and the Member States to step up their efforts to base their relations with other parts of the world on human rights and democratic values.  Coherence between the EU's foreign and internal policies on respect for human rights and democratic values is needed. The annual report on human rights and democracy in the world is an indispensable tool for monitoring, informing and discussing EU policy on these topics, as well as the basis for planning future action. It is a positive fact that in July 2015 the Council adopted a new human rights and democracy action plan for the period 2015-2019.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – I abstained with the rest of my UKIP colleagues on this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP of course shares many of the concerns highlighted in the report regarding the violation of human rights, discrimination against LGBTI people, sexual violence as a weapon of war and many other cruel and inhumane acts. However we cannot support calls for more EU action on the international stage. These issues should be handled between national governments and at the appropriate and legitimate international level, namely the United Nations. The unelected and unaccountable EU institutions have no right to interfere in the foreign policy of Member States or the domestic affairs of non-EU countries.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted, in its entirety, for this report. Indeed, the text urges the Union to use all available instruments to promote respect for human rights and democratic principles in the world. However, I abstained on paragraph 104 of the report because, while it enshrines the necessary gender equality, this paragraph also contains ambiguity in its text when it calls for a "public approach to gender issues". Not knowing what's behind (but assuming!) I prefer to abstain given the ambiguous writing. On the other hand, I voted for paragraph 105, which encourages quotas on the representation of women in political/public life. This is already the case in France. Finally, I voted for paragraph 114 because it condemns surrogacy.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. Human rights and democracy are of great concern to me, but the proposals put forward in this opinion go too far and present the EU as a moralising power.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. Parliament is one of the most effective advocates of human rights, which I very much welcome in principle. However, the definition of human rights must not be permanently extended. What do people like Raif Badawi and others in the world's prisons think when they hear that Parliament's human rights report deals extensively with financial transactions and corporate taxation, among other things? This is an unacceptable extension of the concept of human rights. This distracts attention from those who really need our help. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 In its report on the state of human rights and democracy in the world in 2014, the European Parliament examines the situation of fundamental rights and freedoms and democracy in so-called third countries. The document emphasises that human rights and democratic values, such as freedom of expression and freedom of thought, have been put at an even more disadvantageous disadvantage in many parts of the world. Furthermore, although freedom of conscience, religion or belief is a fundamental human right recognised in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, they are also grossly violated in many UN Member States. The report calls on the EU and its Member States to continue to use the policy instruments at their disposal more effectively and urges them to step up their efforts to ensure that human rights are effectively at the heart of their relations with the wider world. In this spirit, I voted in favour of the Preda report, because human rights cannot play a secondary role in EU foreign policy.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. – The report does not come close to balance and as such is unsustainable to me. Our old adage is that everyone sweeps in front of their own door. The indigenous peoples of Europe, domaned to a minority fate, would rightly expect and expect that their retraction and vulnerability be lifted first by the European Union, the leader of democracy and human rights. The Catalans, Basques, Szeklers and trianon peace dictums have also pushed our nations abroad. I have not seen any effort to do so, nor have the Benes decrees been repealed by the EU. Two years ago, the protection of traditional European national communities and the creation of standards guaranteeing their collective rights at EU level were a requirement in the report at the time. Why hasn't this been born since?

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I fully support the arguments made in Cristian Prey's report on human rights and democracy in the world in 2014 and EU policy in this area. I agree that fundamental freedoms and human rights, such as freedom of expression, freedom of assembly, freedom of association and association, the principle of non-discrimination, are constantly threatened and violated, and human rights defenders often pay a high price for their activity, in extreme cases the cost of living. I particularly strongly support the comments made in the femm opinion annexed to the report, which recalls women's rights as an important area of human rights and the need to mainstream women's rights into politics and the economy. I agree with the report's assertion that respect for human rights is an attribute of mature democracies and that fundamental freedoms and democratic values are at the core of identity and the basis of all European Union policies. These values are not given once and for all, they are constantly being undermined and broken, which is why it is so important to take appropriate steps and create a legal framework for them, such as through the strategic framework and the new European Agenda for Human Rights and Democracy, launched in 2012, which talks about integrating human rights issues into the EU's external policy and its relations with the whole outside world.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. – As we can see from the 2014 human rights and democracy report the world is going backwards. The dark memories of times when human rights were constantly abused are reflected in today’s world news.  In this inhuman and intolerant international environment the EU should step up as a champion of human rights. We should seek a better human rights record from our trading partners, political allies and prospective members. Most importantly we should not stop our continuing effort to improve the human rights record within our borders, in particular in our Member States. Because if we manage to fully deal with lack of freedom of expression, racism, exploitation and gender crimes within our borders then there is no reason why we cannot do so outside of them. I hope that the 2016 human rights and democracy report will show a better human rights record worldwide; if not, then we should bear in mind that we have failed.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. Human rights and democratic values are the very basis of the European Union. That is why the Member States have a duty to step up their efforts to defend and promote these rights, placing them at the centre of their relations with the rest of the world. This report concerns the EU's external policies to promote human rights through greater coherence between the EU's internal and external policies. Finally, I would like to point out that only joint action by the Member States will make it possible to address the difficult internal challenges in the field of human rights.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the 2014 annual report on human rights and democracy in the world and on the European Union's human rights and democracy policy in this area. As every year, this report testifies to the worst of federalist ideology. The text recognises a diplomatic role for the European Union. It uses human rights as a pretext to justify a substitution of Member States by the European Union on the international stage. It imposes the EU's vision on 'climate refugees', etc.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this catch-all text on human rights because it seeks both to deny the sovereignty of the Member States of the Union, and to interfere in the internal affairs of third states, especially Morocco, when it is a reliable partner that the Union should rather support. The only consolation: the votes of the FN MPs have made it possible to condemn the use of GPA (gestation for others)!

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. Parliament is one of the most effective advocates of human rights, but it always commits the same mistake: it is constantly expanding the definition of human rights. What would the Raif Badawis think in the prisons of the world when they hear that Parliament's human rights report deals in detail with financial transactions and corporate taxation, among other things? We will soon be able to close down all the other committees and deal with all human rights issues in the Committee on Human Rights. We are diverting attention from those who really need our help. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. – The protection and respect of human rights, freedom, democracy, the principles and values of the rule of law have recently become less and less respected in the world. Many declarations and agreements remain a formality on paper, lacking verifiable control and the possibility of sanctions and sanctions. This ultimately makes it impossible to evaluate them unambiguously, clearly and comprehensiblely. The EU should be a leader in promoting human rights and democracy. To do this, however, the work done so far in all the EU policies concerned needs to be reconsidered. Consequently, a series of measures must be taken to give a state of stronger interest in respect for and respect for human rights, not only in developing countries but also in developed countries.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I abstain from voting on the 2014 Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World and the European Union's policy in this area because it is not complete or documented. I also refer to the speeches I gave in detail in my speech of 16 December 2015 before the plenary of the European Parliament.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report and particularly welcome its recognition of the importance of additional measures against individuals (targeted sanctions such as freezing of assets or travel bans) in dealing with authoritarian regimes should dialogues persistently fail.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this report. This report, which is totally ideological, is concerned about the discrimination that minorities such as Roma, migrants, etc., would suffer at a time when European citizens are victims of mass unemployment and Brussels austerity that are pushing them to ruin. In a text full of counter-sense and paradoxes, Mr Preda recalls, on the one hand, the inalienable right of peoples to self-determination, while placing a heavy emphasis on the imperialist role of the Union which, through total interference, is supposed to bring human rights and democracy to the rest of the world. This vision is all the more grotesque when we know the fate and treatment of European leaders who dare to listen to the will of their people: just look at what is happening in Hungary or Poland.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on the report on human rights and democracy in the world in 2014 and the EU's policy in this area. I do not want to downplay the importance of this issue, of course I subscribe to the principles of protection of fundamental human rights, the rule of law and democracy. However, I am concerned about its imbalance in the report, with criticism targeting only some already chronically well-known offenders, such as China, Belarus or Russia and Moldova. I cannot accept the double standard policy as applied by the EU in a long and hypocritical way, which is why I abstained in the final vote on the report.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The report is purely ideological. It advocates quotas, LGBTI rights, strengthening EU human rights institutions and their influence on Member States' legislation. I therefore reject this report.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the overall report to help the EU make use of its full toolbox to promote human rights and democratic principles throughout the world.  On paragraph 114 I voted to condemn the practice of surrogacy when it involves reproductive exploitation.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. As every year, the European Parliament reports on the state of human rights in the world. Despite good evidence, on freedom of conscience, children's rights or development aid, the report is mainly aimed at strengthening the Union's foreign policy. In this regard, he calls on the Union to "speak with one voice" at the United Nations. And as usual, it is always the same countries that are singled out. Of course, the most cited are China and Russia on a 140-paragraph report. But not a word about the United States, while the report claims to defend the moratorium on capital punishment. Nor is there a word about Saudi Arabia, which is stoned and blithely beheaded. I am voting against this hypocritical report of denunciations with varying geometries which serves as an excuse to justify the Union's policy of interference.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote on the annual report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World and the Union's policy on this matter. The reasons for my abstention in this important report are the disagreement in the way in which this same subject was developed and described in the report.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: Written. – It is part of the European Parliament's tradition of reporting annually on the human rights situation in the world and the way in which the European Union is making efforts to improve human rights. As shadow rapporteur, I have insisted that Europe should anticipate human rights violations more quickly and decide for clear political conclusions and actions when countries manifestly refuse to safeguard fundamental human rights. In terms of content, I have advocated the human rights criterion in the selection of a host country for the organisation of international sporting events and requested to ensure medical care and education in conflict zones and refugee camps. I have also called for the promotion of international standards for business. I have also called for the destruction of valuable cultural heritage by terror groups to be classified as a crime against humanity. The award of the Sakharov Prize to Dr. Mukwege in 2014 was highlighted in this report. I have also included in the report that no form of violence or discrimination can ever be justified on the basis of cultural or religious beliefs. I did not approve the amendment on Western Sahara that was tabled in plenary.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. \u2012 The practice of carrying a child by a second mother for money is becoming more common and spreading very quickly worldwide. Today, we are witnessing an undignified global market for women's body and motherhood, victims of which are women in difficult living and financial situations, as well as children who are literally looked at as goods. Surrogacy has become a commercial practice that is not in line with human rights and, above all, not with human dignity. I therefore consider it an urgent need to address the impacts of human rights on mother and child at international level. In the legislation of a civilised society, they have nothing to look for laws that stand on the money side against the most basic human rights.  I therefore ask in my proposal that the EP officially reject the practice of gestational surrogacy, which involves the reproductive exploitation and use of the human body for financial purposes or other gain, especially for vulnerable women in developing countries.  I believe that the EP should regard the solution to the issue of surrogacy as a matter of urgency with regard to human rights instruments and to push for a ban on such a practice.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the annual human rights report 2014, which in my opinion gives a good account of the state of play on the EU policy instruments for advancing human rights worldwide and proposes ways to ensure the promotion of human rights and democracy through EU external policies. The report covers important issues such as promoting social, economic, civil and cultural rights, and especially the rights of women and children who are the first victims of economic hardship. I fully support the measures agreed in the report on LGBTI rights, ILO standards, promoting civil society, protecting human rights defenders, among others.  At times when people around the world are more vulnerable than ever due to economic crisis, war conflicts and terrorism, I think it is important that Europe steps up its commitment to promote and defend the concept of the universality of human rights. Having said that, however, I would like to note that I voted against certain elements in the report on abortion and sexual and reproductive health rights. In my opinion the use or introduction of abortion is the wrong way to address health or social problems and to promote human rights worldwide.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Council adopted in June 2015 a document entitled "THE EU's 2014 Annual Report on the State of Human Rights and Democracy in the World". In its motion for a resolution on this issue, the Committee on Foreign Affairs recommends that Parliament express its deep concern at the increasing threat to human rights and democratic values and the shrinking of civil society's margins and the increasing number of human rights defenders worldwide. It calls it crucial to avoid double standards and to ensure increased consistency between the Union's internal and external policies in respect of human rights and democratic values, recalling that parliament's annual report on the state of fundamental rights in the EU has not found everything right. In this context, it proposes to call on the EU and its Member States to address internal human rights challenges, such as the situation of the Roma, the treatment of refugees and migrants, discrimination against LGBTI people, racism, violence against women, detention conditions and freedom of the media, in order to maintain its credibility and consistency in the Union's external human rights policy. It emphasises that the EU must speak with a consistent, unified voice and ensure that its message is heard. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. The protection of human rights and democracy are the basic principles of the European project. I therefore believe that the Union and the Member States should redouble their efforts to put human rights and democratic values at the heart of their external policies. Democratic values such as freedom of expression, thought, conscience, religion and association and the rule of law are constantly threatened and called into question.  As mentioned in this document, the Union should swiftly implement the Action Plan on Human Rights and Democracy 2015—2019 and ensure greater coherence between internal and external policies.  The Union, at multilateral level, must strengthen actions against the death penalty and ill-treatment, torture, discrimination, gender-based violence, for the right of children and women. I cannot fail to refer to the most vulnerable groups, such as migrants and refugees, who show us the need for a real agenda.  I vote in favour of this report because I believe that the efforts have been achieved. However, I would like to note that, in my opinion, there is still a long way to go, in particular to improve processes and procedures.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the annual human rights report of 2014 which summarises the state of play of EU policy instruments for advancing human rights worldwide and proposes ways to improve human rights and democracy through EU external policies. This is a comprehensive and detailed report, containing clear calls for improved external policy in areas such as gender, LGBTI rights and the implementation of the UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I abstained on this report, which annually provides an overview of human rights and democracy around the world. Beyond several anti-Russian provisions which bring nothing, apart from the deterioration of relations between the Union and Russia, at a time when our producers and consumers continue to suffer from the sterile escalation of reciprocal sanctions, the report validates the concept of the distribution of migrants by quotas within the Member States. As a result, it was impossible for me to vote for it. It should be noted that, in paragraph 63, the text refers to "respect for racial diversity." However, it was adopted by a large majority, from the extreme left to the Socialists, from the centre to the right, without causing any particular controversy.

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Surrogacy must be prohibited. This practice undermines the human dignity of women because their body and reproductive functions are used as a commodity and because it involves the exploitation of the human body and the use of the human body for economic or other return, particularly in the case of vulnerable women in developing countries. With these words, by adopting the annual report on human rights and democracy in the world in 2014, the European Parliament affirmed a fundamental principle of civilisation, protecting the dignity not only of women, but also of newborns, reduced to mere 'products' of this hideous market. Welcoming Pope Francis' universal message, this report also strongly called for the abolition of the death penalty and strongly condemned trafficking in human beings. Contradictoryly, since some paragraphs in this same text violate the principle of subsidiarity, treating in an unacceptable way certain fundamental values in the field of the protection of marriage and human life, I had to abstain on the final vote but, overall, the assessment remains positive. Surrogacy, the last frontier of human exploitation on man, must be categorically prohibited.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this text as it outlines some of the most important developments in the world and in the EU on human rights. Unfortunately, I do not believe the overall situation is improving – in fact, there is a clear deterioration in the universal protection of human rights in many parts of the world. More than ever, the EU needs to be cohesive and coherent in its external dialogue, and this means a lot more coherence between the Member States and the EEAS and Council. At the same time, I expect that we have learned much from past mistakes, being capable of investing in smarter policies and having more lasting dialogues with actors who can influence the balance on these issues.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report adopted annually by the EP to draw attention to the problems of human rights violations in the world. The need for this year's report is all the more urgent because threats to human rights such as freedom of expression, freedom of thought, conscience and religion, and freedom of assembly and association are on the rise in many parts of the world, including authoritarian regimes, and attacks on human rights defenders are increasing worldwide. I did not support the point condemning the use of surrogacy and abstained in this case. I would not dare to say that surrogacy as such disparages a woman's human dignity, as her body and reproductive functions are being used as a commodity and that this is reproductive exploitation. I can imagine situations where surrogacy is justified and morally defensible, and I do not believe that such a categorical position should be taken on this complex issue.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. The report is purely ideological and calls, in addition to quotas, for the strengthening of LGBTI rights and the development of EU human rights institutions. This would only mean further curtailment of national institutions. I would have voted against this report and voted against it.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The EU must defend its human rights campaigners more strongly. Human rights must play an important role in the EU's global strategy, and what is recorded in the EU's strategic framework for human rights and democracy must be actually implemented.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The JRC voted against the report because its main concern is the propaganda of the non-existent values embraced by the EU. The EU is even exploiting this area, citing the 'human rights clause' in its relations, and in particular trade with third countries, in order to be able to implement its unpopular policy, promote its monopolies in order to dominate these new markets and put forward pretexts for its imperialist interventions that blood the people. Moreover, he presents himself as an unsolicited judge of everything by methodizing the imposition of "restrictive measures" on anyone who does not comply. It in itself 'pioneers' the EEAS, this EU tool to promote its unpopular strategy and imperialist aggression. The report defiantly states that "trade and human rights can go hand in hand" and that "the business community has an important role to play in promoting human rights and democracy", when the main aim of business groups and the condition of their profitability is the violation of labour and popular rights. Their rights will be conquered and safeguarded, meeting all their needs, only when they take power and become owners of the wealth they produce, only after they have achieved their release from the EU and other imperialist alliances.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which proposes guidelines for the Union's human rights policy. The issue of climate refugees is very relevant because it is the next massive migration phenomenon that we will face if we do nothing.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ "The 2014 Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World and european union policy in this area" has taken a major step in condemning surrogacy, which is a form of human trafficking, and undermines the dignity of women it transforms into childbearing machines and children that it transforms into buy-and-sell facilities. I assess positively that the report opposes the death penalty and expresses a clear position on its abolition globally.  I think it is important that the report expresses concern about the rise of religious persecution in the world, especially the persecution of Christians who have reached worrying levels. However, I do not consider the report as a whole to be good and I find a lot of contentious elements in it. His main goal has been undermined by the introduction of various quasi rights that are not and whose imposition I deeply oppose. Some problematic articles have been adopted which I believe undermine the principle of subsidiarity.  The abolition of gender disparities by forcibly imposing gender ideology undermines the foundations of our society, and the denial of the right to life manifested through the constant commitment to access to abortion as part of women's sexual and reproductive rights and the humanitarian aid instrument is not acceptable to me.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒Human rights and democratic values form the basis of Europe's political integration. The European Union has the power and strength to act globally to promote its core values, but at the same time we must act so that we do not allow violations of those same rights and freedoms on the territory of the Union itself. Every time we talk about violations of minority rights in different parts of the world, we have to think about often equally scandalous injustices in individual members of the Union.  Human rights should not be subject to ideological bickering, since the fundamental, material living conditions of many often depend on their preservation. Of particular importance is why I consider the parts of this report to focus on marginalised groups, i.e. provisions on the rights of women and children, including sexual and reproductive freedoms in conflict situations, LGBTI rights, refugees and the rights of members of the Roma national minority.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The 2014 Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World and the European Union's human rights policy illustrates the EU's ongoing efforts to promote the universality of human rights everywhere. During 2014, the EU initiated formal human rights dialogues and consultations with 37 partner countries. In June 2014, on the occasion of the 10th anniversary of the adoption of the EU Guidelines on Human Rights Defenders, the particularly significant role of women defending human rights and defenders from vulnerable and marginalised groups was highlighted. While in December 2014, at the annual EU NGO Forum on Human Rights, the EU guidelines on freedom of expression were adopted. However, despite the many efforts made, human rights and democratic values, such as freedom of expression, thought, conscience and religion, and freedom of assembly and association, are still increasingly at risk in many parts of the world, particularly under authoritarian regimes. There are some references in the text to sensitive ethical issues which, in my opinion, deserve to be dealt with elsewhere. I have therefore chosen to abstain.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted for the 2014 annual report on human rights and democracy in the world and on the European Union's human rights and democracy policy in this area. It is a reference report every year on this issue. Many proposals will make it possible to make a contribution to the edifice of democracy in the world.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non-legislative and non-binding report.
