Peacekeeping, conflict prevention, the strengthening of global security, as well as the economic, social and political stability of geographical areas, necessarily involves clear and shared rules to avoid the risk that arms exports could be used to commit or facilitate serious acts of violence, for the compromise of security and the environment, for internal repression or for support for terrorist organisations.  Transparency and public control must be the basis of any procedure aimed at combating the ambiguities and limitations of this trade.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 This report addresses the issue of arms exports from Member States to third countries. In general, the report assumes concerns and positions that, being correct, contribute little to a change in the current reality. We could say that this report is in line with the interests of the European arms industry, an industry that exports annually the equivalent of several tens of billions of euros, ensuring more than a third of the global arms exports, which has obvious implications for the situation of instability currently in regions such as the Middle East and North Africa , feeding authoritarian regimes and armed groups. These are the consequences of the European Union's foreign policy, which the report conveys and promotes, aligning arms export policy with the Common Security and Defence Policy, a position we reject. More than enough reasons for our vote against.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Unfortunately, we are currently witnessing the spread of armed conflicts, particularly in Ukraine, Syria, Iraq, Libya and Yemen, as well as international conflicts, which threaten global stability and security in an increasingly globalised world and result in a less stable and less secure Neighbourhood for the European Union. It must also be said very clearly and loudly that transfers of arms to conflict-affected states may have contributed to these conflicts. I therefore welcome the entry into force of the Arms Trade Treaty and the information activities that the European Union has taken to promote the universal ratification and implementation of the Arms Trade Treaty. It is essential that Member States that have not yet ratified this Treaty ratify it at the earliest opportunity. Governments have political responsibility for whether military or dual-use goods are exported or not, and therefore Member States must provide detailed information on each licence issued in order to carry out checks at European Union level to ensure that countries do not violate the common position criteria for reasons of economic, political or personal interest.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 On the one hand, the report wants to ban arms exports to war zones and, on the other hand, does not recognise the fact that the eu's major powers and the driving force of its foreign policy, namely the US, have supplied half of the world's terrorist organisations with weapons. I am voting against the report on arms exports because I find it out of reality that the EU should require Member States to tell it the details of defence exports, which, for reasons of national security (buyer and seller) in particular, should not be disclosed. The report also calls Russia an enemy of the EU. I believe that Member States should cooperate and make agreements with third countries when they serve their interests. Just because the US or Germany sees Russia competitively does not mean that it cannot be a partner for many other states.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The unprecedented spread of armed conflicts is a huge threat to world stability and security and has determined a less stable and less secure neighbourhood for the EU area; arms transfers to states in conflict are significantly contributing to these conflicts and situations.  I therefore strongly support the report, which will allow better regulation for arms exports. We have a key role in preventing irresponsible exports of arms to countries that violate human rights and fundamental freedoms, and regulating the international arms trade must be a global ambition. It is fundamental to support transparency, and to promote adherence to the highest regional and international standards, such as the Arms Trade Treaty and the EU Common Position on arms export control. This legally binding framework demonstrates the determination of EU Member States to prevent the export of military technology and equipment that might be used for undesirable purposes such as internal repression or international aggression, or contribute to regional instability; we therefore have to fully support its implementation.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. U2012 I abstained. I believe that it is necessary to respect the Common Position for compliance with EU principles and values, as well as the EU's responsibility for regional and global security. EU Member States are among the world's leading arms exporters, so the potential implications for EU security and defence of the transfer of sensitive knowledge and technology to third parties are worrying. A deeper assessment of specific risks related to recipient countries and EU security interests is needed before licensing.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it proposes measures to move towards effective control of arms exports. In adopting the Common Position, Member States were equipped with criteria to be able to refuse export licences if necessary, but the absence of control and sanction mechanisms and the lack of transparency of some governments have unfortunately made it easier for weapons from Europe to end up in the hands of criminals and/or terrorists.  The approved report proposes independent verification modalities (the PP's refusal has prevented progress towards the creation of a European supervisory authority), as well as sanction mechanisms for those States that fail to comply with the Common Position and the strengthening of surveillance and control systems to prevent the diversion of exports. I believe that the report provides an excellent basis for further progress towards global security, the credibility of EU foreign policy and European commitment to human rights. I regret, however, that the PP, Podemos and the United Left have abstained in the final vote on a text which represents remarkable progress in discipeding the arms trade in the EU.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the EP resolution on arms exports: implementation of Common Position 2008/944/CFSP, because I believe that their uncontrolled distribution poses a risk to the security of citizens, as well as a strong threat to international peace and stability.  Given that every minute in the world a person dies from causes of gun violence, it is not difficult to understand the need for better regulation of the international arms trade and greater accountability on the part of states at global level, especially those that make this sector one of the main economic activities.  The recent terrorist attacks in Paris, the ongoing wars in Syria, Iraq, Yemen and Libya and all other conflicts around the world have shown that weapons very often end up in the hands of terrorists, used against the civilian population and to train child soldiers.  I believe that the common position on the arms trade is the right legal approach to bind the Member States to closer coordination of national policies on this issue.  Finally, I would like to see the creation of an independent arms control authority under the aegis of the EU High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. We are seeing a significant increase in armed conflict. That is why it is important for Europe to continue to take responsibility. What we need are sensible and long-term solutions.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. Current events including a conflict on the EU’s borders in the Ukraine, the rise of ISIS in the Middle East and the terror threat from returning jihadis mean a tight, well-regulated EU arms export policy has never been more important.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We abstain in the vote on this text because, while it introduces considerations on the desirability of increased controls on the export of military weapons and technology to third countries that we think are necessary, it legitimizes the arms industry as a fundamental pillar of both EU industrial development and EU foreign policy. We can advocate the generation of mechanisms for cooperation and dialogue between countries that do not support or participate in global arms escalation, and for a productive model for the EU and its Member States that depends only utilitarianly or residually on the development of an activity that is first and for all based on aggression , the death of people and the destruction of life environments.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ Alongside my fellow Labour MEPs, I voted in favour of the report. The current climate in the Middle East, on the EU’s doorstep in Ukraine, and indeed across the world has given rise to concerns about the availability of arms. This report promotes public transparency in Member States’ arms exports. It asks for a legally binding EU export-control instrument and for a harmonised EU arms control policy that would reinforce other dimensions of the EU’s external action.  We have seen European arms in the hands of repressive regimes, terrorists and criminals, fuelling conflict in many countries. If we are concerned about security, human rights and international peace we cannot afford to be soft on arms exports. A well-regulated EU arms export policy has never been more important.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the report on  Arms export: implementation of the Common Position 2008/944/CFSP because the European Parliament expressed concern about the spread of armed conflicts, notably those in Ukraine, Syria, Iraq, Libya and Yemen as well as all international conflicts, which, in an increasingly globalised world, are a threat to world stability and security and have determined a less stable and less secure neighbourhood for the EU. The European Parliament also stresses that arms export controls are an integral part of EU foreign and security policy and must be guided by the principles enshrined in Article 21 TEU, notably the promotion of democracy and the rule of law and the preservation of peace, prevention of conflicts and strengthening of international security.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I have certain concerns with regard to the export of arms, not least to repressive regimes with poor human rights records. However, once again this is a matter which should not be an EU competence.   Therefore, whilst there are some aspects of the report which I might agree with on a national level, I could not support it as a resolution at a pan-EU level. Let Westminster decide this issue.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report because it proposes measures to move towards effective control of arms exports. In adopting the Common Position, Member States were equipped with criteria to be able to refuse export licences if necessary, but the absence of control and sanction mechanisms and the lack of transparency of some governments have unfortunately made it easier for weapons from Europe to end up in the hands of criminals and/or terrorists.  The approved report proposes independent verification modalities (the PP's refusal has prevented progress towards the creation of a European supervisory authority), as well as sanction mechanisms for those States that fail to comply with the Common Position and the strengthening of surveillance and control systems to prevent the diversion of exports. I believe that the report provides an excellent basis for further progress towards global security, the credibility of EU foreign policy and European commitment to human rights. I regret, however, that the PP, Podemos and the United Left have abstained in the final vote on a text which represents remarkable progress in discipeding the arms trade in the EU.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒  I decided to abstain on this vote as Ireland is a neutral country.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on arms exports: the implementation of common position 2008/944/CFSP, as this issue is very important nowadays, when the EU environment is extremely politically and security-unstable. Weapons in the hands of irresponsible individuals become a terrorist threat.  Uncontrolled proliferation poses a serious risk to peace, security, human rights and sustainable development in the world. Action in this regard should be coordinated and coordinated. More transparency and control is needed. Arms export control is an integral part of the EU's foreign and security policy and must be in line with the principles of promoting democracy and the rule of law and preserving peace, preventing conflicts and strengthening international security.  I support the entry into force of the Arms Trade Treaty. Member States should interpret and apply the criteria of the Common Position in a single way without allowing economic reasons to take precedence in decision-making. It is necessary to create an independent European arms control body and pay more attention to dual-use technologies.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – I voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is opposed in principle to unaccountable EU institutions being able to decide who we export to and the terms of such export. The only people that should decide UK trade policy are our elected and accountable national government.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I do not agree with this report. It contains unjustified accusations against the European arms industry and undermines the competitiveness of this sector in Europe.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: in writing. – As shadow rapporteur of the EPP group, I decided to abstain in the final vote of this report.  We had achieved good results in balancing the report.  This includes mentioning the right to self-defence according to Article 51 of the UN Charter. Every state should be able to defend itself from aggression: thus delivering arms to Ukraine and to the Kurdish Peshmerga is highly important.  The report also highlights the positive role of the defence industry. The latter is needed to bolster European security, but also for development of the European technological and industrial base. The EU Common Position on arms exports has worked well.  The implementation of the eight criteria needs to be even more improved, especially concerning the timely and efficient exchange of information between the Member States when denying or revoking licences.  The main reason for abstaining in the final vote lies in the paragraphs that go beyond the competences of the Common Position – demanding sanctions when Member States do not apply the CP, or demands to create a new oversight authority. Although a binding agreement, the final decision lies still in the hands of the Member States and such European mechanisms are beyond the competences of the EP and the EU.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report. Despite having common EU rules on arms exports, we still see European arms ending up in the hands of repressive regimes, terrorists and criminals, fuelling conflict. It is time to stop these double standards. Human rights and humanitarian law, not profit, must be at the heart of our policy decisions on arms sales. In today’s new global security environment, we need to reinforce our principles. We need a truly progressive and transparent European arms export policy with stricter risk assessments for granting export deals.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. – Due to endless conflicts, the worldwide arms trade is on the rise. The arms industry is a major industry for many EU Member States. However, what is disturbing is the basic fact that arms indeed are fuelling conflicts and causing sufferings and human rights violations. In this sense, the EU should take steps to limit the trade, or at least to force Member States to provide real data and information about their arms trade. If we possess good information about development of the arms market and trade then we can avoid not only human rights violations but also mass killing, ethnic cleansing and terrorist attacks.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on arms exports. This is a delicate subject, but one on which it must be inflexible: the defence and armaments industries should be a matter of state sovereignty. I do not accept that The defence policies of the Member States should be subject to the interests of the European Union. This one, and through it, some of our competitors (Germany in particular) and many other countries that no longer have any defence industries, no army, or even memories of having one day had one, do not have to influence our trade policy.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this report because I believe that the defence and arms industries do not have to go under the control of the Union, but must continue to be a matter of state sovereignty. It is a report that is actually hostile to France, which is one of the best arms manufacturers in the world. In the face of terrorism, this is really not the time to give up free use of this know-how!

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it proposes measures to move towards effective control of arms exports. In adopting the Common Position, Member States were equipped with criteria to be able to refuse export licences if necessary, but the absence of control and sanction mechanisms and the lack of transparency of some governments have unfortunately made it easier for weapons from Europe to end up in the hands of criminals and/or terrorists.  The approved report proposes independent verification modalities (the PP's refusal has prevented progress towards the creation of a European supervisory authority), as well as sanction mechanisms for those States that fail to comply with the Common Position and the strengthening of surveillance and control systems to prevent the diversion of exports. I believe that the report provides an excellent basis for further progress towards global security, the credibility of EU foreign policy and European commitment to human rights. I regret, however, that the PP, Podemos and the United Left have abstained in the final vote on a text which represents remarkable progress in discipeding the arms trade in the EU.

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: in writing. ‒ The Sweden Democrats support the European Code of Conduct on Arms Exports and recognise the special responsibility of arms exporting states (the 8 EU criteria for arms export). Sweden as a country has also signed the Wassenaar Arrangement on export of dual-use goods and technologies (based on consensus). We also have a rigorous national export control system. According to Article 346 in TEU, we also maintain the right to protect the national military industry. The SD opinion on further strengthening of the EU control mechanisms on Member States’ arms- and dual-use goods export is that this control is mainly up to the Common Position, for Member States to implement nationally.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I am against the EU dealing with embargoes instead of nation states.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. – The political and security situation in the world, local and regional conflicts, together with the increasing threats of terrorism, are enforcing new rules on arms exports. In order to protect and keep its people safe, Europe must adapt to this situation and revise its existing rules in this area, including public procurement and export control and arms possession. Finding a balance between the economic, economic and financial interests of exporters and arms manufacturers and preserving the freedoms of the population, on the one hand, and ensuring the protection and security of the population, on the other, will not be easy. However, the Union will have to reach a compromise that takes the utmost account of all security risks.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I support the report on arms exports: implementation of Common Position 2008/944 CFSP because it is complete and documented, and for the reasons I detailed in my speech of 16/12/2015 to the plenary of the European Parliament.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ Member States must apply the EU’s eight—point code on arms exports more rigorously, particularly with the changed security environment in the EU’s neighbourhood. These trade flows are not in the EU’s direct security interests, and national political and economic considerations must not override decision—making on export licences.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this text. We are adamant on this subject: the defence and arms industries should be the sovereignty of the Member State, not the Union. We do not accept that our competitors, such as Germany, or the Union, which has never had an army, dictate our conduct. We must be free to do what is necessary to protect our citizens and our territory.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The report contains some sensible approaches. However, anti-Russian sentiment can be seen and an endorsement of EU sanctions against Russia can be seen. I therefore reject this report.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained in the final vote on this report as it is unrealistic in the demands for delivery of information by Member States in terms of licences issued, and in general the arms trade is a national competence.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. In 2008, the EU Code on Arms Trade was replaced by the eu's legally binding common position (2008/944 / PESC). It sets eight criteria for the export of conventional weapons. These totally hypocritical standards reveal the mirage of the Union's common foreign and security policy. Because the Member States are blithely deviating from it. Thus criterion 2 mentions "respect for human rights in the final destination country" but the report does not say a word about arms exports to Saudi Arabia. Criterion 3 states that "arms exports should not be used to aggravate or prolong tensions in the final destination country" while the report "takes note of the decision taken by some Member States to provide defensive armaments to Ukraine" without overly worrying. On the other hand, the rapporteur is "deepest concern about the consequences for the security and defence of the Union as a result of the transfer of knowledge and sensitive technologies to third countries, (...), such as Russia". I am in favour of democratic control over the export of arms, which largely disqualifies the Union for this. I am voting against this text.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. With the threat of terrorism in Europe, there has been a call for stricter controls on arms sales. Common Position 2008/994/CFSP is a legally binding framework setting out criteria for the export of military equipment to be applied by EU Member States in their licensing decisions. I believe, however, that a more in-depth debate should be given to the matter in question, which deserves some caution, which is why I have decided to abstain.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. Following the numerous and dramatic attacks that have taken place in and outside Europe, the security situation of all European citizens implies a stricter application of the European code on arms exports. We need transparency and tools to properly assess the risks of conflict in the world. That is why I voted in favour of the creation of an independent European arms control authority, under the patronage of the Union's High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. The aim is to go beyond the simple exchange of information and to authorise the High Representative to give an opinion that would ensure that Member States comply with the minimum rules in this area.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. \u2012 Since uncontrolled proliferation poses a serious risk to peace and security, I support the motion for a resolution on arms exports in terms of the implementation of the European Union's common position. In fact, in the period 2010-2014 only, EU Member States were responsible for 25.4% of all supplies of large conventional weapons in the world, and it turned out that a not insignificant part of them ended up in the hands of repressive regimes, armed groups or terrorists. I therefore consider it necessary to ensure even greater transparency in these agreements in order to ensure that countries do not violate the common position criteria for reasons of economic, political or personal interest and do not contribute to feeding conflicts in third countries with European weapons. All the more so because the statistics provide the already appalling facts that somewhere in the world every minute a person dies because of armed violence.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on arms export: implementation of Common Position 2008/944/CFSP, which provides for a legally binding framework laying down eight criteria for the export of conventional arms to be applied by EU Member States to their licensing decisions, and helps to impose better regulation for arms exports.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 Council Common Position 2008/944/CFSP laying down common rules for the control of exports of military technology and equipment was adopted on 8 December 2008. Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, Iceland, Canada, Montenegro and Norway have officially joined the criteria and principles set out in the Common Position as third countries. The draft resolution of the Committee on Foreign Affairs points out that armed conflicts are spreading mainly in Ukraine, Syria, Iraq, Libya and Yemen, and that arms trafficking to conflict-affected states may have contributed to these conflicts. It also points out that weapons often fall into the hands of terrorists or repressive regimes in countries where children are recruited or deployed, or by regimes with a questionable relationship with international terrorism and repressive domestic policies and aggressive foreign policies. Finally, it regrets that around half a million people die each year as a result of armed violence, both in armed conflicts and in relation to criminal offences. For these reasons, it proposes that Parliament, in its resolution, call for the implementation, consistent observance and stricter monitoring of the common position. I supported the proposal.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 The Comprehensive Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and Vietnam establishes a key partnership with regard to common interests and policies, providing essential cooperation between the European Union and South-East Asia. As such, the Protocol here in consideration seeks to incorporate the Republic of Croatia as one of the Contracting Parties to the Agreement in order to take account of croatia's accession to the European Union. The European Union is bound to provide its Agreement in an authentic Document in Croatian language. I am voting in favour of this recommendation in order to pass the conclusion of the Protocol referred to herein.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This report concerns the export of arms and in particular its implementation within the framework of the 2008/944/PESC common position. This subject is very delicate, but it is nevertheless necessary to adopt an inflexible attitude. Defence and arms industries must be solely a matter of state sovereignty. The Union and, through it, many competitors (Germany) and other countries which no longer have defence industries or armies have no need to influence our trade policy in this area. So I decided to vote against it.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. Current events including a conflict on the EU’s borders in the Ukraine, the rise of ISIS in the Middle East and the terror threat from returning jihadis mean a tight, well-regulated EU arms export policy has never been more important.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted against this annual report on the quality of Member States' controls on arms exports. In particular, this text calls for the sharing of very detailed information on Member States' exports. However, the application of common provisions in this area is and must remain a national competence. France, for its part, has a regime for arms export controls that goes beyond the eight criteria defined by the common position.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this text as it is vital in the context of greater efforts for world security to step up our efforts in controlling arms trade and proliferation. The near vicinity of the EU has grown more unstable in the past few years, and small and large weapons are a basic source of instability. The Arms Trade Treaty was a welcome development in this context, just like the recent efforts of the Member States in upholding the provisions of the Common Positions. However, the development of new technologies puts even more urgency in the EU's efforts - as the risks for these technologies to fall in the wrong hands through unregulated exports are great.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. – The report, in addition to its perfectly reasonable approaches, has a strong anti-Russian stance and advocates sanctions against Russia. Since the export bans contained therein are severely affecting our farmers, especially dairy farmers, and the EU is providing scant assistance, I would have opposed this report.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. In a situation where EU weapons are increasingly in the hands of terrorists outside the EU, greater control over the movement of weapons, both at Member State and EU level, is needed. Control must be more efficient, the rules are more comprehensible and must not forget that the purpose of the production and sale of weapons in Europe is to increase security and self-defence.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒I do not support the proposal for an EP resolution on arms exports and the implementation of common position 2008/944/CFSP. I do not think that it underlines the necessary steps that Member States should take in the future in order to put this Common Position into practice and to keep European policy credible in highlighting the main values, namely the protection of human lives, prevention of conflicts, fostering internal stability and avoiding war as a way of solving internal problems between conflicting parties within or between states.  I hope that Member States will take seriously the problem of arms exports and trade and control of official and unofficial sales channels, especially smuggling. On the other hand, I hope that the problem of numerous regional conflicts in the European neighbourhood will encourage the competent within the Union to approach the institutionalisation of the problem of arms transfers among the Members of the European Union, but also towards third countries, more studiously.  Accordingly, a clear requirement must be made for candidate countries not to be a platform for manipulating arms sales routes and should be required to strictly implement the existing legislative framework.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This report concerns the export of arms and in particular its implementation within the framework of the 2008/944/PESC common position. This is a very sensitive subject, but we must nevertheless adopt an inflexible attitude. Defence and arms industries must be solely a matter of state sovereignty. The Union and, through it, many competitors (Germany) and other countries which no longer have defence industries or armies have no need to influence our trade policy in this area. So I decided to vote against it.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ Despite the EU's efforts to promote the ratification of att and the fact that the Union has a single legally binding arms export control framework, the level of control is insufficient given the data on the amount of weapons ending up in the wrong hands and the fact that some EU members are among the world's leading arms exporters and that exports are growing due to decreasing revenues in Europe.  It is particularly problematic that there is insufficient public scrutiny or transparency in reporting and export data, precisely in those Union countries that are the largest exporters. I support the call for a more thorough assessment of the risks associated with the countries to which it is exported and a demand for stricter adherence to the Common Position in order to prevent the dangerous and devastating possibility of the Union directly equipping terrorists and repressive regimes with indirect weapons.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. - I support the proposal for a European Parliament resolution on arms exports: implementation of the Common Position 2008/944/CFSP proposed by Bodil Valero. Bearing in mind that Article 51 The Charter of the United Nations recognises the inaliething right to individual or collective self-defence, and it is in the interest of international stability to provide the means to establish peace, it is of significant importance to have well-established and strict models of coordination of the export of such weapons.  Given that uncontrolled proliferation poses a major danger to EU countries and the international community, and creates a serious threat in maintaining peace and security, I believe that regulating international trade really needs to be a global goal. In this context, we should take particular account of the significantly changing EU environment, especially south and east, and we should also take into account the fact that third countries: Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Macedonia, Iceland, Canada, Montenegro and Norway have formally committed to respecting the criteria and principles of the Common Position.  I give only legitimacy to exports that strictly adhere to the criteria of Common Position 2008/944/CFSP and which take place in the framework of the EU response to the request regarding the right to self-defence. We must not forget that illegal, illegal and unregulated arms transfers threaten political stability and hamper democratic, social and economic development.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The terrorist threat in Europe and the recent attacks in Paris have prompted the European Commission to strengthen controls on firearms and to revise Common Position 2008/944/CFSP laying down common rules for the control of exports of military technology and equipment. In 2013, EU Member States alone, among the world's leading arms exporters, exported the equivalent of €26 billion in arms to countries outside the EU.  The global security environment around the EU has changed dramatically in recent years. We certainly need to be very careful on this issue, but at the same time we must prevent security and foreign policy motivations from being mesaded with the production and trade in small firearms. The latter are also used for activities such as sports shooting or hunting.  I therefore hope that the Eu ropean Union will take proper account of arms export issues but will not do unjustified damage to the firearms production sector, which plays an important role in the economy of Itala and Europe. That is why I have decided to abstain

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. Although this subject is sensitive, especially in a context of remilitarization of many regions of the world, I have taken a position on this vote which does not go into the caricatures that can be heard here and there. The tone of the report is rather accusatory and does not take into account the specifics of the French arms export regime. Indeed, the French regime for arms export control goes beyond the eight criteria defined by the common position and our arms export policy already takes into account the strategic situation and the regional environment of the destination state. So let's be vigilant but let's not mix all situations on a subject that doesn't need passions, but reason.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. We are opposed in principle to unaccountable EU institutions being able to decide who we export to and the terms of such export. The only people that should decide UK trade policy are our elected and accountable national government.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 Effective arms export control regimes need to be adopted, condemning the use of weapons in order to fuel insecurity and armed conflict, both internally and externally, and to support internal repression, regional conflicts or serious violations of human rights and fundamental freedoms. It is regrettable that the illicit arms trade remains a lucrative and large-sized business. EU Member States are the world's largest exporters of arms, with exports worth €36.7 billion in 2013, of which €10.735 billion was traded between Member States and €25.976 billion to third countries. I am seriously concerned about the consequences for EU security and defence caused by the transfer to third countries of sensitive knowledge and technologies, which also poses an increased risk of dependence on third countries with divergent strategic interests, such as Russia.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report and in particular the provision which calls on Member States to support the creation of an independent European Arms Control Authority (AECA) under the patronage of the Eu High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. Such an authority should be empowered to give notice to Member States planning to grant authorisation refused by at least one other Member State. This opinion should consist of an independent assessment of the applicability of the eight common criteria (including compliance by the recipient with international commitments, respect for human rights, the internal situation in the final destination country, the preservation of regional peace, security and stability, the national security of Member States and Allied or friendly states. etc.) and could also be requested by States to assess the applicability of the eight criteria common to any European export authorisation.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Greater cooperation at European level with regard to world arms trade requires a strengthening of the Common Position, as referenced in the report, which, although quite important, should not forget the principle of subsidiarity, i.e. "harmonisation at EU level should not be used as a pretext for dissolving stricter national rules." I therefore stress in this report the calls for greater transparency and increased scrutiny on arms exports to third countries, the call for a truly effective implementation of embargo policies, the importance of combating illicit trade and the need for greater coordination between Member States, Eurojust and Europol with third countries. I also welcome the European Commission's work to modernise legislation on export controls for dual-use goods. Unfortunately, I cannot agree with the report's proposals on the frequency of member states' reporting obligations, which I consider, like my political group, unnecessary administrative burden and unnecessary excessive bureaucracy that does not serve the best interests in combating illicit arms trafficking. For these reasons I abstained in the vote on this report.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. – We abstain in the vote on this text because, while it introduces considerations on the desirability of increased controls on the export of military weapons and technology to third countries that we think are necessary, it legitimizes the arms industry as a fundamental pillar of both EU industrial development and EU foreign policy. We can advocate the generation of mechanisms for cooperation and dialogue between countries that do not support or participate in global arms escalation, and for a productive model for the EU and its Member States that depends only utilitarianly or residually on the development of an activity that is first and for all based on aggression , the death of people and the destruction of life environments.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this as it seeks to control the activities of member states.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The security situation in the EU's southern and eastern neighbourhoods has deteriorated dramatically, while at the same time we are still witnessing uncontrolled proliferation. EU Member States have been responsible for up to a quarter of all supply of large conventional weapons in the world in recent years. It is regrettable that the EU cannot unite on the fact that trade relations are not always in the security interest of individual Member States. Arms exports, in which EU states also participate, are one of the main causes of the constant spread of conflicts. Moreover, it turns out that weapons also end up in the hands of terrorists, repressive regimes or countries that support international terrorism and behave aggressively on the international stage. Although it is not possible to prevent arms exports, as this is an important part of the economy for many countries, it is absolutely essential that the EU develops effective and consistent ways of controlling arms sales. Such control is enshrined in the EU's basic treaties and forms an integral part of its foreign and security policy. Governments have political responsibility for where the exported military goods will be used, yet they interpret the export control rules to their liking. I therefore believe that, in order to be credible with its foreign partners, the Union must arrive at a coherent and coordinated position on arms trade.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The global security environment around the EU has changed dramatically recently. The uncontrolled proliferation of arms poses a serious risk to peace, security, human rights and sustainable development. The data shows that around the world, every minute someone dies from armed violence. The same statistics also apply to the production of 15 new weapons.  The report refers to arms exports from the EU and notes that EU Member States were responsible for 25.4% of the actual supply of major conventional weapons worldwide in 2010-2014. In 2013 alone, EU Member States exported weapons totalling EUR 36.7 billion.  I believe that the defence industry should be an instrument for the implementation of the defence and security of the Member States. Arms export controls are an integral part of the EU's foreign and security policy. I agree that the EU must ensure consistency of external action as a whole in the context of external relations. This would promote democracy and the rule of law, prevent conflict, eradicate poverty, promote intercultural dialogue and maintain international stability and security.  I believe that unjustified, illegal and deregulated arms transfers undermine political stability and threaten democratic, social and economic development. As I agree that it is necessary to ensure coherence between arms exports and the credibility of the EU as a global defender of human rights, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Bart STAES
text: Written. After years of silence, a progress report on the implementation of the common position on arms exports is finally on the table. Not a day too soon, given that Belgium has been identified as a source of used weapons in many recent attacks. The reputation of our country and everyone's security benefits from more targeted efforts in the fight against illegal weapons. And that is exactly what this report by my Green colleague calls for. For example, there is a need for more rigorous but coordinated action at European level, whereby Member States can implement their own, even more stringent, programmes, but where it is also necessary to use the collection, analysis and exchange of data with an anti-abuse clause in end-user certificates and on-the-spot research of end-users. Moreover, commercial, economic and industrial interests should not affect the 8 criteria set out in the common position for arms exports.  The EU accounts for 25.4% of the arms market, member states exported €36.7 billion in 2013, of which €26.7 billion outside the Union.  The report further focuses on private security firms, the possession of weapons by individuals, the growing importance of dual-use technology, with a clear need to better regulate drones and spying technology. More transparency, cooperation with civil society and more parliamentary involvement are crucial.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: Writing. \u2012 In its report, the European Parliament assesses the state of implementation of the Council Common Position laying down common rules for the control of exports of military technology and equipment. Thanks to the shadow rapporteur, Mr Kelam, the report has managed to assess the security risks in which Europe is located. This summer, the European Union lifted the embargo on arms exports to Ukraine, opening the way for Ukraine to self-defense. In a situation where the Minsk agreements are dead, it is the weapons that open the way to peace. No treaty with Russia will guarantee peace. Ukraine will be brought peace by the defeat of the aggressor. You don't win wars without guns. Another example is Syria. The report refers to the decision by some member countries to supply arms to Iraqi Kurds who are fighting in self-defence against Da'ish. My country, the Czech Republic, has already delivered 500 tons of ammunition to Erbil. Defending against violence is the right of every free man, every free state. In times of war, you have to defend yourself by force. Peace is an important commodity today. We must constantly ask how much one kilogram of peace costs in Ukraine or Syria. Although the original draft report managed to be improved by a number of amendments, I was not identified with the content of several articles of the original text that could not be removed from the report, nor with the overall toss of this report. I therefore voted against its adoption.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ I supported this report, as arms export control is an integral part of EU foreign and security policy and should be guided by the principles woven into Article 21 of the UEU, in part through the principles of promoting democracy and the rule of law and preserving peace, preventing conflicts and strengthening international security. I express concern about the possible playing of EU export controls through licensed production in third countries or through overseas branches of companies established in the EU.  In my view, there is a need for tighter control of intermediation services and related arms trade activities at EU level, which could be scrutiny due to the fact that these practices vary from country to country. Therefore, I call for the establishment and introduction of a registration system that will oblige intermediaries to report in detail on their activities.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. Current events including a conflict on the EU’s borders in Ukraine, the rise of ISIS in the Middle East and the terror threat from returning jihadis mean a tight, well-regulated EU arms export policy has never been more important.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ The global security environment around the EU has changed dramatically, so uncontrolled proliferation poses a serious risk to peace, security, human rights and sustainable development. Therefore, EU countries signed the Common Position on preserving regional peace, security and stability in 2008/944/CFSP, which sets out eight benchmarks for conventional arms exports that EU Member States must apply when making licensing decisions.  Eu member states' arms exports totalled €36.7 billion in 2013, of which €26.7 billion (or 36% of total arms exports) were exported to third countries, and few can claim that these trade flows are of immediate security interest to the EU. I accept the Council's position at first reading on arms exports, as I believe that a consistent interpretation and successful implementation of the Measures of the Common Position 2008/944/CFSP would make a crucial contribution to the achievement of the EU's objectives on the coherence of development policies, peacemaking, security and human rights. However, bearing in mind that the report also covers some aspects that I would not fully agree with, I voted "abstaining".

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. - I abstained in voting on the report on arms exports: the implementation of the Common Position. In the security situation we are facing recently, this report is necessary, because we need a uniform and common policy in the area of arms exports. A major problem is arms smuggling and the illegal arms trade, which poses a serious threat to peace, security and human rights. I abstained in the vote because the report is in some area of interference with the areas of the Member States, as national defence remains the responsibility of the Member States.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We chose abstention. The problem with the report is that, while it agrees that huge exports of war equipment to third countries (worth EUR 26.7 billion) are taking place and that these exports are linked to the escalation of conflicts - since much of the equipment ends up in the hands of terrorists and repressive regimes, it nevertheless contains particularly negative reports from which one can conclude that the sale of arms to areas such as Ukraine and Iraq poses no problem. In addition, the report avoids proposing effective measures to combat the illegal arms trade and to combat corruption. The dominant circles of the EU do not in any way wish to be held responsible for the conflicts in Ukraine or the Middle East, but at the same time unfortunately protect, unfortunately in every way, the interests of the war industries and add reports that there is provision for the uninterrupted continuation of the production and sale of war equipment where there is 'demand'.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 On the one hand, the report wants to ban arms exports to war zones and on the other hand does not recognise that the major EU powers, but also the driving force of its foreign policy, namely the US, have supplied half the world's terrorist organisations with weapons. We consider it out of reality that the EU should require Member States to tell it the details of defence exports because often they, for reasons of national security of buyer and seller, should not be disclosed. In addition, the report calls Russia an enemy of the EU. We believe that Member States should cooperate and make agreements with third countries when this is in their interests. The fact that the US or Germany sees Russia competitively does not mean that it cannot be a partner for many other states.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union and the Member States have a significant arms industry, which carries out total exports of EUR 36.7 billion, thus contributing a significant share to the Union economy. At the same time, however, the global security environment has seen a worrying proliferation of armed conflicts resulting in a large number of civilian casualties, many of which are located near the Union's borders and adversely affect Member States.  On the other hand, the use of armaments exported by EU countries for self-defence purposes is considered legitimate, especially in the case of conflicts in Ukraine and Iraqi Kurdistan. From this point of view, rigorous regulation of arms exports to third countries is necessary on the basis of the Arms Trade Treaty.  The adoption of Common Position 2008/944/CFSP, which also joined a number of Western Balkan states, THE EFTA and Canada, represents an obvious step forward in this area, by making exports conditional on respect for certain European values and freedoms and human rights in third countries, but also on the imperatives of European security. More transparency is recommended in the publication of annual reports on arms exports, as well as public control over dual-use military products, in particular new technologies.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. We voted in favour of the text. The Group reaffirms that adherence to the common position is essential to the application of the Union's principles and values, particularly in the area of international human rights and international humanitarian law, as well as to the exercise of its responsibilities for regional and global security.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the implementation of the common position on arms export. The EU’s common position sets out the rules on monitoring the export of military technology and equipment. The Member States undertook to comply with an eight-point code when selling arms. These relate, for example, to human rights in the country of final destination, the internal situation in the country of final destination, preserving regional peace, security and stability, and the potential effect on the economic and development prospects of the country of final destination.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ This report, on the initiative of Rapporteur Valero of the Parliamentary Group of the Greens, attempts to push through the strict implementation of the Union's common foreign and security policy in the arms export segment by the Member States of the European Union to third countries. That proposal constitutes another attempt at gross breach of the principle of subsidiarity, since it requires exclusive competences to be handed over to the European Commission at the expense of the individual Member States of the Union. I cannot support certain calls directed towards Member States, such as for example a call for support in the creation of an independent European Arms Control Agency under the auspices of the High Commissioner for Foreign and Security Policy of the Union, who would be empowered to issue an opinion to those Member States planning to issue an export licence on their territory; because I have a strong belief that security policy has always been, and should remain, in the hands of individual Member States of the Union.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I abstained in the vote on the report on arms exports: I abstained from the implementation of Common Position 2008/944/CFSP, as I do not agree with the proposals in the report that were not in line with the EES proposals.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. – We abstain in the vote on this text because, while it introduces considerations on the desirability of increased controls on the export of military weapons and technology to third countries that we think are necessary, it legitimizes the arms industry as a fundamental pillar of both EU industrial development and EU foreign policy. We can advocate the generation of mechanisms for cooperation and dialogue between countries that do not support or participate in global arms escalation, and for a productive model for the EU and its Member States that depends only utilitarianly or residually on the development of an activity that is first and for all based on aggression , the death of people and the destruction of life environments.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Arms Export Report, as the uncontrolled spread of weapons poses a serious threat to peace and security, human rights and sustainable development. Worldwide, every minute, one person dies from armed violence and, in the same time, 15 new weapons are manufactured. Furthermore, arms transfers to unstable regions can contribute to the emergence of new conflicts, and the EU must be extremely careful in this regard, as in 2010-2014 EU Member States were responsible for 25.4% of the amount of weapons delivered worldwide. Arms export control is part of the EU's foreign and security policy and must be carried out in accordance with the principles enshrined in the founding treaties, such as promoting democracy and the rule of law, preventing conflicts and strengthening international security. The EU must ensure consistency between arms exports and its credibility as a global human rights promoter. A common position on arms exports is therefore needed, and relations between Member States in this area are needed, which falls within the exclusive competence of the States.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 It is deeply worrying that armed conflicts are spreading primarily in Ukraine, Syria, Iraq, Libya and Yemen, and all the international conflicts that pose a threat to the stability and security of the world in an increasingly globalised world and which have reduced stability and security in the EU's neighbourhood. Arms trafficking in conflict-affected states may have contributed to these conflicts. And you have to be able to take action against that. I voted in favour of the common position.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. – We abstain in the vote on this text because, while it introduces considerations on the desirability of increased controls on the export of military weapons and technology to third countries that we think are necessary, it legitimizes the arms industry as a fundamental pillar of both EU industrial development and EU foreign policy. We can advocate the generation of mechanisms for cooperation and dialogue between countries that do not support or participate in global arms escalation, and for a productive model for the EU and its Member States that depends only utilitarianly or residually on the development of an activity that is first and for all based on aggression , the death of people and the destruction of life environments.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this text because I am deeply concerned about the spread of armed conflicts, notably those in Ukraine, Syria, Iraq, Libya and Yemen as well as all international conflicts, which, in an increasingly globalised world, are a threat to world stability and security and have determined a less stable and less secure neighbourhood for the EU; in relation to the protraction of such conflicts, I agree that arms transfers to states in conflict have been a major contributing factor. I am against the use of weapons, the international trade of weapons, individuals bearing weapons and I believe stricter measures and legislation should be applied when it comes to weapons. Developments in the last two years have shown that weapons sometimes end up in the hands of terrorists or repressive regimes or of countries where children might be recruited or used in hostilities.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. We must at all times prevent our European weapons from falling into the hands of terrorists. Because of the recent terrorist threat, a well-controlled European arms export policy is more necessary than ever. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. The European Union is one of the world's leading arms exporters. The value of these exports in 2013 amounted to 36.7 billion euros, of which 26.7 billion to third countries. These arms exports will directly feed repressive regimes, including terrorist networks. The European Union's responsibility for the many conflicts in the southern and eastern regions of the Union, notably Ukraine, Syria, Iraq and Libya, is therefore committed because of this deadly trade. The report denounces this, as well as the total lack of transparency of this trade. Only 21 countries provide information in this area. The details of the arms trade of the three largest exporters, France, Britain and Germany, remain completely opaque. Despite criticism of the devastating effects of the arms trade, the report maintains a positive assessment of European foreign policy. Such a contradiction, despite the findings and recommendations of this report, is not acceptable to me as a guarantee of stability and world peace. This can be seriously doubted when one sees the destructive and deadly effects of these policies of interference in third countries. I therefore preferred to abstain on this report.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. The uncontrolled spread of weaponry poses a serious risk to peace and security in the world. Every minute, one person dies in the world who are victims of armed violence and, in the same time interval, 15 new weapons are manufactured. In the period 2010-2014, EU Member States accounted for 25.4% of the world's main conventional weapons. It is regrettable that developments over the past two years have shown that weapons sometimes end up in the hands of terrorists or repressive regimes, or countries where children can be recruited or used in conflicts, or regimes that have dubious relations with international terrorism or have an aggressive internal and external policy. So instead of crying crocodile tears, it is necessary to adopt effective arms export control regimes and stop using weapons to fuel insecurity and armed conflict in countries such as Libya, Syria, Iraq or Afghanistan, among others.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The report contains some sensible approaches. However, anti-Russian sentiment can be seen and an endorsement of EU sanctions against Russia can be seen. I therefore reject this report.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ A tough EU arms export policy has never been more vital. I back efforts to prevent arms getting into the wrong hands. I demand EU Member States do more to prevent arms being exported to repressive regimes, terrorists and criminals.  Transparency in the EUR 20 billion European arms industry is long overdue. The Arms Trade Treaty requires an assessment of all exports to stop weapons ending up in conflicts fuelling genocide and human rights abuses. The unregulated trade in arms has had a devastating effect on peace and stability around the world. Proper implementation of the UN agreement starts with a coordinated EU approach to regulate the arms industry. As a human rights and children’s rights champion I demand that the EU do whatever it takes to prevent European arms contributing to death and suffering in the world.

name: Kristina WINBERG
text: in writing. ‒ The Sweden Democrats support the European Code of Conduct on Arms Exports and recognise the special responsibility of arms exporting states (the 8 EU criteria for arms export). Sweden as a country has also signed the Wassenaar Arrangement on export of dual-use goods and technologies (based on consensus). We also have a rigorous national export control system. According to Article 346 in TEU, we also maintain the right to protect the national military industry. The SD opinion on further strengthening of the EU control mechanisms on Member States’ arms- and dual-use goods export is that this control is mainly up to the Common Position, for Member States to implement nationally.

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I welcome the report presented. Its importance is attested by the fact that EU countries export EUR 40 billion worth of arms per year, including EUR 28 billion to third countries. If you look at the global arms trade, 36% of the value of this trade is on EU countries. It is therefore fully appropriate to assess each year whether the countries that make up the European Union apply strict criteria for arms trafficking. Unfortunately, as the report points out, this is not the case and weapons exported from the EU also go to the wrong recipients. This requires not only stricter criteria for arms exports, but above all careful monitoring of who is the ultimate weapon user. Original buyers buy weapons in principle in accordance with the law. The problem is that later, often this weapon resells and it goes to the wrong users. This is the weakest point in the implementation of the EU's arms export policy.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not give my vote to the resolution on arms exports. In particular, the report encouraged the strict implementation of the Common Position by Member States and criticised arms exports by some large Member States to third countries. I believe that, especially in the current deteriorating security situation, care must be taken of arms exports and situations where exported weapons could encourage armed conflicts in third countries. On the other hand, however, I am of the opinion that defence policy must remain a matter of national sovereignty and cannot therefore be restricted by the European Union. Unfortunately, the report, as proposed by the implementation of the common position and thus the granting of greater powers to the Commission, was not acceptable to me because of the violation of sovereignty.

name: Damiano ZOFFOLI
text: in writing. \u2012 An important vote this; An important support for a report which has the noble objective of regulating and making the arms market more transparent. Weapons which, unfortunately, have all too often come into the hands of terrorists and violent people lately and which therefore need clear traceability and, above all, transparency in the context of exports. We need to know for sure and clearly who owns a weapon and what use it intends to make of it.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 The report addresses the issue of arms exports from Member States to third countries. In general, it assumes concerns and positions that, being correct, do not depart from reality. It aligns with the European arms industry, an industry that exports several tens of billions of euros annually, making up 36% of arms exports to third countries – a situation that has obvious implications for the instability currently in the Middle East and North Africa, fuelling authoritarian regimes and extremist movements. These are the consequences of the European Union's foreign policy, which the report conveys and promotes, aligning arms export policy with the Common Security and Defence Policy, a position we reject. In other words, if on the one hand it says that it wants to limit the export of arms, on the other it corroborates the EU's foreign policy that fuels militaristic escalation. We voted against it.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur For about seventeen years, the directive has clearly stated that products such as fruit, vegetables, others cultivated thanks only to purely biological processes, such as through breeding or crossover, cannot be patented. The principle of intellectual property is undeniably important and is applied in a number of other cases, but not in these cases. However, in its judgment of 25 March 2015, the Board of Appeal of the European Patent Office decided in Cases G2/12 and G2/13 that the issue of patents for tomatoes and broccoli respectively is possible and in no way conflicts with the abovementioned European Commission Directive. Patenting plant-specific characteristics obtained by biological cultivation technology is at least partly possible. Consequently, we must also further develop this direction and this vector politically. Thank you!

name: Marian HARKIN
text: – Mr President, I was very happy to support this resolution because it is essential that we maintain what is known as the breeders’ exemption. Essentially, this means that access to all breeding materials is available to all breeders. This means that all modern varieties, as well as landraces and wild species are available. We have to ensure that varieties are kept freely available, without patents, for all who wish to breed. It does not matter if they are subsistence farmers, if they are gardeners, or if they are small businesses in the plant breeding industry. That is why I fully support the call on the Commission to clarify the scope and the interpretation of Directive 98/44/EC. We have to ensure legal clarity in regard to the prohibition of the patentability of products obtained from essentially biological processes. I did support Amendment 5, which asked for a comprehensive breeders’ exemption. That means free commercialisation of new traits. I was disappointed that it was not carried because I think it would certainly have added to what is otherwise a good resolution.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. This Resolution was adopted on the basis of an oral question with the same title. I supported the oral question because I consider it necessary to ask the Commission for explanations on the recent decision of the European Patent Office which provides for the possibility of patenting plant characteristics also when these traits were developed on the basis of essentially biological reproduction techniques or could be obtained through such techniques, which expands the possibility of granting patents. However, I voted against this Resolution because, since the amendments proposed jointly by the Verts/ALE Groups have not been adopted, EFDD and GUE/NGL, this is a much less ambitious resolution than the existing one (European Parliament Resolution 2012/2623(RSP) of 10 May 2012) defending the rights of farmers and farmers and a total exemption from patentability of conventional crop products and farming methods. This new Resolution does not provide for this complete exceptionality (which would ensure that, for example, farmers are not sued for accidental pollen contamination of patented varieties).

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – We abstained on this important, highly complex issue because such verbose EU legal resolutions – whether approved or rejected – are simply not the best way to deliver progress and prosperity on the issue.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. – I supported this resolution which concerns a decision by the European Patent Office on 25 March 2015, which effectively makes it possible to patent plant traits even if they are the result of classical breeding – effectively making it possible to commercialise the natural world. The resolution calls for the protection of native genes and asks that they not become a commodity for sole use by multinationals. This line of precedent is particularly worrisome and could have a fundamental impact on food production and food security, as the holder of such a patent could block innovation in plant breeding, leaving hundreds of varieties threatened. I supported the text as it asks for an urgent clarification of the legislation in place, to ensure that biological processes such as plants, seeds, native traits and genes are excluded from patentability, and criticises the EPO for following a line clearly not in line with the legislator’s intention.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The European Patent Office has agreed to patent plant characteristics. This is not the approach of the Union and France, which believe that the plant characteristics and the "material" used by breeders should remain accessible to all. In order for the work of breeders to be a minimum protected, France and the Union have set up a Certificate of Plant Breeding. This mechanism allows farmers to reseed their crops with a contribution to the selection bodies. Compared to US patent law, the European approach is a lesser evil. Considering that this motion for a resolution expresses the need to distance myself from the American patent law that encompasses the living, I voted in favour of it.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This highly-technical non-legislative resolution has some positives and some negatives. The overall impact is somewhat unclear, and I felt it appropriate to abstain on the report as a whole.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 Access to biological material is essential to stimulate innovation and bring new varieties to ensure global food security and to combat climate change. Intellectual property rights are important to maintain economic incentives for the withdrawal of new plant products and for competitiveness. In cases G2/12 (on tomatoes) and G2/13 (on broccoli), the EPO may introduce more patents relating to the natural characteristics of new varieties resulting from essentially biological processes such as cross-breeding or selection. I support the calls on the Commission to clarify the scope of Directive 98/44/EC, in particular Articles 4, 12(3)(b) and 13(3)(b) thereof, and how to interpret these provisions in order to ensure legal certainty as regards the prohibition of patentability of products essentially derived from biological methods.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. The European Patent Office has agreed to patent plant characteristics, which is contrary to the EU and French approach, which believes that the plant characteristics and "material" used by breeders must remain accessible to all. The solution chosen by the Union (2012) and by France is the introduction of plant breeding certificates (VOCs), which are a form of protection of the work of breeders without preventing their use for other work. For farmers, it is also a guarantee that they will be able to harvest their crops, whatever they may be, for a contribution. Despite this last questionable point, the CVOos are a lesser evil compared to the American patent law which, in turn, encompasses the living and therefore benefits only a minority of multinationals like Monsanto, which does not hesitate to send its "seed militia" to verify that farmers do not reseed varieties that "belong to" it... This resolution calls for the Union not to align itself with US law, once again in the context of the TTIP negotiations. That is why I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution and the amendments tabled wisely by the Greens.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. – We voted against this resolution since the oral question submitted to the Commission is sufficiently clear in itself. In addition, Parliament has already ruled on this with a satisfactory resolution on the exemption of patents on certain products in 2012, and therefore we do not think it is necessary to reopen this matter with a new resolution which delves into this issue.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The European Patent Office has agreed to patent plant characteristics, which is contrary to the EU and France's approach that they and the equipment used by breeders should remain accessible to all.  The solution chosen is the establishment of plant breeding certificates which are a form of protection of the work of breeders without preventing the use for other work. For farmers, this allows the crops to be reseeded. CVOs are therefore a lesser evil compared to U.S. patent law that only benefits multinationals.  The resolution calls for the EU not to align itself with US TTIP law. I therefore voted in favour of the joint resolution.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report we are voting on is acceptable and without any critical issues, so I wanted to support it with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. This Resolution stems from a question to the Commission on the implications of the decision of the High Chamber of Resources of the European Patent Office (EPO) that it is possible to patent plant characteristics, including those developed or obtained through essentially biological plant variety techniques.  This decision has implications for the innovation capacity of the plant variety sector in developing new varieties and on the risk of monopolies appearing in the food market by reducing the diversity of products offered to consumers. In the U.S., legislation allows genes to be patented and new varieties recorded (the set of genes an individual has, not every gene separately) is recorded. That is why we are asking the Commission for clarification on existing rules to avoid the conflict between European plant variety regulation and the possibility of extending the US gene patent to Europe, in order to avoid the possibility of patenting genes in the European Union.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this resolution because it advocates the protection of patents and the rights of breeders. Access to biological material, including plant characteristics, is essential to stimulate innovation and bring new varieties to ensure global food security, combat climate change and prevent monopolies in the plant breeding sector, while at the same time creating more opportunities for SMEs. Intellectual property rights are important to maintain economic incentives for the withdrawal of new plant products and for competitiveness.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the proposed resolution on patents in the field of agriculture. I, too, personally condemn the decision of the European Patent Office, which in March this year allowed the patentability of certain varieties of broccoli and tomato obtained by the breeding technique.  The prohibition on patenting products obtained by biological processes, such as crucifixion, is crucial for innovation and food security, which is why the Office's decision is all the more surprising. The breeding of plant varieties is an innovative process that growers have traditionally been doing since ancient times.  Therefore, unrestricted access to biological material is necessary in order to promote innovation and ensure global food security. In addition, this method is useful in the fight against climate change. Plant varieties and properties developed from biological breeding techniques should therefore be exempted from patentability. I hope that the Commission will understand this.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ Recent decisions by the extended Appeals Chamber of the European Patent Office have allowed plant features to be patented, even when they are achieved intrinsically through biological farming and crossing techniques. At issue is that the European Patent Office has decided that it has jurisdiction to issue patents on plant features obtained by natural crossing. Someone in that institution imagined himself to be a divine being and had copyright to nature!  Such a decision can have far-reaching and catastrophic consequences on European agriculture, and in particular on small farmers and farmers. That is why I supported a resolution asking the Commission to examine the legal basis for the Decisions of the European Patent Office.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Access to plant biological material by researchers must be unlimited. Closing the sector as per the recent decision (G2/12 and G2/13) of the Enlarged Board of Appeal of the European Patent Office (EPO) allowing plant characteristics to be patented even when they are developed, or could be obtained, with essentially organic plant selection techniques is wrong and dangerous.
