Without unrestricted access to plant biological material, it is impossible to innovate and strengthen the plant selection sector: there is a risk of blocking innovation in the sector and thus threatening the important role that European countries have for world food production and food safety.  The impact on European competitiveness will be negative, with risks of chain repercussions in terms of plurality of food supply, quality of production available to consumers and reduction of internal competitiveness in the market.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 Food security has always been a concern at the level of the European institutions, also taking into account the fact that 2050 will bring an increase in the global population by 25% and 9.7 billion respectively, according to UN estimates.  Cheap, quality food, easily accessible to consumers, requires a balance between all the actors involved in this process. Undoubtedly, stimulating innovation and developing new plant varieties can be answers to these challenges, and plant breeders play a key role in diversifying species and increasing productivity. Plant improvement is absolutely necessary for food security, and the effective protection of those working in research guarantees the development of this sector. At the same time, we must ensure that all legal uncertainties regarding the rights of patent owners and the exceptions to breeders are fully clarified, so as to avoid anything that could affect the development of the plant breeding sector and, therefore, the possibility for farmers to benefit from productive and accessible varieties. The European Patent Office must be extremely careful in its work, so as not to end up patenting something that has existed for hundreds of years and which will certainly endanger food safety.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour. The international plant variety rights regime based on the Upov Convention, as well as Community legislation, enshrine as a fundamental principle the fact that the holder of a plant found plant cannot prevent others from using the protected plant in order to promote the use of protected varieties in other production activities. Already in that resolution, the EP, particularly in the field of reproduction, noted that the granting of excessively broad protection by means of patents could stifle innovation and progress and harm small and medium-sized producers by blocking access to animal and plant genetic resources; plant selection is an essential prerequisite for the security of food supply and, to some extent, energy supply. The text we are voting on today reaffirms this concept, even admitting that this objective has not been fully achieved and stressing that products obtained by conventional reproduction techniques (some of which, in spite of everything, have been the subject of a great many applications for registration at the European Patent Office in recent years) should not be allowed to be patented.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the motion for a resolution 'Patents and plant variety rights'. With this resolution, Parliament has stressed that the ban on the patentability of products obtained by conventional selection techniques is essential to stimulate innovation, particularly for small businesses. Plant selection is an innovative process practised by farmers and farming communities for a long time and access to biological material is essential to stimulate innovation and the development of new varieties, in order to ensure global food security, cope with climate change and essentially prevent biological, such as plants, seeds, native characteristics and genes, should be excluded from patentability. The Commission then clarifies existing EU rules, in particular the Directive on the legal protection of biotechnological inventions, and transmits these clarifications to the European Patent Office (EPO), in order to ensure that products obtained from conventional reproduction techniques cannot be patentable.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. – I abstained on this important, highly complex issue because such verbose EU legal resolutions – whether approved or rejected – are simply not the best way to deliver progress and prosperity on the issue.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as I am concerned that the recent decision of the Enlarged Board of Appeal of the European Patent Office (EPO) on Cases G2/12 (tomatoes) and G2/13 (broccoli) could lead to more patents being granted by the EPO in respect of natural traits introduced into new varieties by means of essentially biological processes such as crossing and selection. I urge the Commission to report on the development and implications of patent law in the field of biotechnology and genetic engineering, as required in Article 16(c) of Directive 98/44/EC and as requested by Parliament in its resolution of 10 May 2012 on the patenting of essential biological processes.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the joint resolution as I am convinced that patent law should be duly implemented in the area of plant breeding, mainly in relation with the innovations in biotechnology.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the resolution because it is moving in a positive direction. We consider that the fundamental principle of the international plant variety rights system based on the UPOV Convention and the EU system based on Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003 should be amended accordingly. The right holder of a plant variety right may not deprive third parties of the possibility of using the protected variety for further improvement activities. It is right to be concerned that the recent decision of the enlarged Board of Appeal of the European Patent Office in Cases G2/12 (concerning tomatoes) and G2/13 (concerning broccoli) may lead to an increase in the number of patents granted by the EIA with regard to the physical characteristics introduced into new varieties through mainly biological methods such as cross-breeding and selection.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on patents and plant variety rights. Continuous research into plant products and access to plant biological material is important to stimulate innovation and the development of new varieties in order to: ensure global food security, cope with climate change and prevent monopolies in the field of plant selection, while providing greater opportunities for SMEs.  On these points, from food safety to standards for meeting small and medium-sized enterprises, I believe that Europe must make a great deal of effort. It is right to point out that essentially organic processes should be excluded from patentability and I agree with the proposal to call on the Commission to clarify as a matter of urgency the scope and interpretation of Directive 98/44/EC in order to ensure legal certainty with regard to the prohibition of patentability of products obtained by essentially biological processes. In general, therefore, I agree with the proposal and therefore intend to support it.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that products obtained by essentially organic processes should be excluded from patentability and should be used to stimulate innovation and the development of new varieties.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. – Since the motion for resolution calls upon the Commission to report on the development and implications of patent law in the field of biotechnology and genetic engineering, as required in Article 16(c) of Directive 98/44/EC, it is contradictory to vote in favour of biological processes, such as plants, seeds, native traits and genes, to be arbitrarily excluded from patentability. The fundamental principle of the international system of plant variety rights is based on the International Convention for the Protection of New Varieties of Plants (the UPOV Convention), and of the EU system based on Council Regulation (EC) No 2100/94, that the holder of a plant variety right cannot prevent others from using the protected plant for further breeding activities.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 Patents on products derived from conventional reproduction methods or on genetic material necessary for conventional reproduction undermine the exclusion laid down in Article 53(b) of the European Patent Convention and 4 of Directive 98/44/EC, which states that "plant varieties and animal breeds and essentially biological processes for the production of plants or animals are not patentable". This is a principle of the utmost importance!  Allowing such patents threatens the sector's innovative capacity to develop new varieties and poses a threat to global food production and food security. It will have a negative impact on European competitiveness and can result in monopolies on the food market, reducing the variety of products offered to consumers.  We must therefore condemn the recent decision of the Enlarged Board of Appeal of the European Patent Office (EPO), which allows plant characteristics to be patented even when they are developed, or could be obtained, with essentially biological plant selection techniques.  For this reason, we are voting in favour of the joint resolution that arises on the request by the AGRI and JURI Committees for an oral question on the subject of 'plant variety patents', even though it could have been better structured and provided for greater protection.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. This Resolution was adopted on the basis of an oral question with the same title. I supported the oral question because I consider it necessary to ask the Commission for explanations on the recent decision of the European Patent Office which provides for the possibility of patenting plant characteristics also when these traits were developed on the basis of essentially biological reproduction techniques or could be obtained through such techniques, which expands the possibility of granting patents. However, I voted against this Resolution because, since the amendments proposed jointly by the Verts/ALE Groups have not been adopted, EFDD and GUE/NGL, this is a much less ambitious resolution than the existing one (European Parliament Resolution 2012/2623(RSP) of 10 May 2012) defending the rights of farmers and farmers and a total exemption from patentability of conventional crop products and farming methods. This new Resolution does not provide for this complete exceptionality (which would ensure that, for example, farmers are not sued for accidental pollen contamination of patented varieties).

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution as I believe that access to biological material is necessary in order to stimulate the innovative strength of the plant breeding sector. Undermining the innovative ability of the plant breeding sector to develop new varieties poses a threat to global food production and food security and will have a negative impact on European competitiveness and may lead to monopolies on the food market. I want to make sure that we protect ourselves against these possibilities.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This resolution calls on the European Commission to clarify EU patent rules to ensure the unlimited use of organic material by seed breeders and to promote innovation effectively while ensuring a level playing field for small breeders. The recent decision of the Court of the European Patent Office (EPO) to authorise patents even on plant traits obtained using conventional breeding techniques, such as cross-breeding, raises the question of the consequences in terms of hindering innovation and threatening global food security. Taking on a narrow interpretation of Article 53, point b) of the European Patent Convention and Article 4 of the Biotechnology Inventions Directive, this decision calls for urgent clarification in order to avoid negative consequences on the competitiveness of the European Union. In support of this resolution, I voted in favour.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. – We abstained on this important, highly complex issue because such verbose EU legal resolutions – whether approved or rejected – are simply not the best way to deliver progress and prosperity on the issue.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution which states that products obtained from biological processes, such as plants, seeds, indigenous characteristics and genes, must be excluded from patentability. Plant selection is an innovative process practiced by farmers and farming communities since the birth of agriculture, access to biological material is essential to stimulate innovation, food safety and small businesses.  For these reasons, the European Commission urgently needs to clarify existing European rules on the legal protection of biotechnological inventions so that these clarifications can be transmitted to the European Patent Office (EPO) and thus ensure that products obtained by conventional reproduction techniques cannot be patented.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. In 1998, the European Commission published a directive that excludes mainly biological processes (plant varieties, animal breeds) from the scope of patentability. However, on 25 March 2015, the European Patent Office (EPO) issued two opinions allowing the granting of a patent for a plant derived from a mainly biological process. This principle would not only force the work of farmers, but above all to reserve access to patents only to those with sufficient resources while slowing down innovation in this sector. In voting in favour of this resolution, we call on the European Commission to reject the EPO's opinions by again taking a stand against the patentability of essentially biological processes.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: In writing. I call on both the Commission and the Member States to clarify and enforce international law and the Patent Directive 98/44, which explicitly prohibits the patentability of plant varieties, "essentially biological processes" of animal breeds and native traits, including when obtained by natural processes. However, in its decision last March, the Grand Chamber of the European Patent Office took a dangerous step in favour of patenting plants derived from "essentially organic processes". This is unacceptable. An abuse of patents would neon the legislation on plant breeding, which allows any breeder to access and use existing varieties to create new varieties, but also for any farmer to draw his own seeds from his crops. It would also create another danger: only a few powerful groups capable of obtaining patents would build a monopoly on life for a single commercial and financial purpose rather than working for innovation and shared progress. As such, I call for extreme vigilance in the negotiations of trade agreements and partnerships with third countries.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. In order to avoid appropriation of nature, two texts frame the protection of biotech inventions in Europe (a 1998 directive and the 1973 patent convention). These texts exclude from the scope of patents "essentially biological processes for obtaining plants". Without abandoning this principle, the European Patent Office has decided that plants derived from these methods can be protected, provided they meet three criteria: novelty, innovation and industrial application. I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that products obtained by essentially biological processes such as plants, seeds, traits and native genes should not be patentable. Plant breeding is an innovative process that has been practiced by farmers and farming communities since the birth of agriculture. This process is important for genetic diversity; it is essential to have non-patented varieties and breeding methods. I therefore call on the Commission to urgently clarify the scope and interpretation of Directive 98/44/EC in order to establish legal certainty regarding the prohibition of patentability of products obtained by essentially biological processes.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted "scratched" on the resolution on patents and the rights of plant breeders, as I think it is important that we take a balanced approach to the case with the precedent set by the EPO. We must be able to promote development and innovation, but we must also distinguish between situations where biological characteristics are obtained for research and development purposes, used for personal purposes or commercialised.  When we talk about commercialization of the resulting characteristics, I think we fall into a completely different category of research development. It is important that we be able to distinguish these situations and be able to strike a balance, because the wider the exceptions, the smaller the scope of the rules.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We are voting in favour of the motion for a resolution because it clearly separates free organic farming and seeks to protect it against large multinationals and genetically modified organisms.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. \u2012 The ban on patenting plant varieties and essentially organic plant production processes is of great importance, as well as from an ethical point of view. That is why the recent decision of the Enlarged Board of Appeal of the European Patent Office, which allows plant characteristics to be patented even when they are developed, or could be obtained, by essentially biological plant selection techniques, worries us a great deal because it poses a threat to world food production and to food safety itself.  The decision will have a negative impact on European competitiveness and can result in monopolies on the food market, reducing the variety of products offered to consumers. On the other hand, the threat to farmers is even greater. For these very reasons, this resolution seems to us to be weak and I cannot support it in the first place because there is no adequate reference to the need for the EU to ensure that, in its patent legislation on the selection of plants and animals, there is a general derogation for farmers.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 This oral question relates to the possibility of patenting plant characteristics, including when they are developed, improved or obtained through biological reproduction and breeding techniques. It follows the recent decision of the Grand Board of Appeal of the European Patent Office, which goes directly against the exception to the patent law which safeguards producers with regard to biological improvement techniques and extends the power of patents. While we follow the concerns underlying the question, we do not think it is enough to ask for directive 98/44/EC to be clarified, rather, it is necessary to review and update it, not in order to protect European competitiveness, or unrestricted access to biological material only for the innovation sector, but mainly so that there are no interpretations that go against the rights of producers and peoples to produce and improve plant species with biological and traditional techniques, not limiting some access to food production, which may even jeopardise food security and access to food.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 A recent decision of the Enlarged Board of Appeal of the European Patent Office allows the patent of lynx plants, including cases where these features are developed from or could be obtained by essentially biological breeding method. This Decision entails a narrow interpretation of Article 53(b) of the European Patent Agreement and thus indicates wide possibilities for granting patents covering different plant varieties. This Decision of the European Patent Office undermines the innovative capacity of the plant husbandry sectors for the development of new varieties and poses a threat to world food production and food security. This can have a negative impact on European competitiveness and may lead to a monopoly on the food market by reducing the diversity of products offered to consumers. Unrestricted access to biological material is necessary to stimulate the innovative strength of the breeding sector. Undermining the innovative capacity of the plant husbandry sector to develop new varieties poses a threat to world food production and food security and will have a negative impact on European competitiveness.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the resolution calling for greater transparency and the use of legislation that brings EU citizens closer together and does not hinder them.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Access to biological plant material encompassing plant traits is absolutely necessary for boosting growth and innovation and developing new varieties in order to guarantee global food security, tackle climate change and prevent monopolies within the breeding sector, while at the same time providing more opportunities for SMEs. Unrestricted access to biological material will stimulate the innovative strength of the plant breeding sector. Undermining the innovative ability of the plant breeding sector to develop new varieties poses a threat to global food production and food security and will have a negative impact on European competitiveness and may lead to monopolies on the food market. I therefore would like to express  my concern about the recent decision of the Enlarged Board of Appeal of the EPO in Cases G2/12 (tomatoes) and G2/13 (broccoli), which could lead to an increase in the number of patents, granted by the EPO, for natural traits which are introduced into new varieties by using essentially biological processes such as crossing and selection.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ This highly-technical, non-legislative, resolution has some positives and some negatives.   The overall impact is somewhat unclear, and I felt it appropriate to abstain on the report as a whole.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted against this Resolution since the oral question submitted to the Commission is sufficiently clear. In addition, Parliament has already ruled with a satisfactory resolution on the exemption in 2012, and therefore we do not think it is necessary to reopen this matter with a new resolution which delves into this issue.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ Unrestricted access to biological material is necessary in order to stimulate the innovative strength of the plant breeding sector. Undermining the innovative ability of the plant breeding sector to develop new plant varieties represents a threat to global food production and food security, will have a negative impact on European competitiveness, and will have a negative impact on measures designed to ensure more sustainable farming.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the Resolution on patents and plant breeders’ rights because with it the EP calls on the Commission to clarify the scope and interpretation of Directive 98/44/EC, in particular Article 4 along with Articles 12(3)(b) and 13(3)(b) thereof, in order to ensure legal clarity regarding the prohibition of the patentability of products obtained from essentially biological processes and the fact that breeding with biological material falling within the scope of a patent is permitted.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Although I agree with the substance of this resolution, I do not consider it necessary for two reasons: firstly, the oral question to the Commission is already clear and, secondly, there has already been a resolution since 2012 that fully satisfies us. I fear that a new resolution will perhaps overturn the positive points that we believe the 2012 resolution ensures.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution as access to biological plant material encompassing plant traits is absolutely necessary for boosting innovation and the development of new varieties in order to guarantee global food security, tackle climate change and prevent monopolies within the breeding sector, while at the same time providing more opportunities for SMEs. Intellectual property rights are important in order to safeguard economic incentives for developing new plant products and to deliver competitiveness. Plant breeding is an innovative process that has been practised by farmers and farming communities since the birth of agriculture while unpatented varieties and breeding methods are important for genetic diversity.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's resolution on the patents and rights of plant farmers on the basis that I consider it necessary for the European Commission to speak out regarding the interpretation of Directive 98/44/EC in order to ensure clarity of the law as regards the prohibition of patenting of products obtained through biological processes, and to clarify that the patent allowed cultivation with the help of biological material.  In this context, innovation and the development of new species should be encouraged to ensure food safety, mitigate the effects of climate change and prevent monopolies within the plant growing sector. I also believe that we should be extra vigilant when it comes to biotechology and genetic engineering, and therefore I support this resolution.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – My colleagues and I abstained on this important, highly complex issue because such verbose EU legal resolutions – whether approved or rejected – are simply not the best way to deliver progress and prosperity on the issue.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which calls on the Commission to legally clarify the ban on patentability of products obtained by mainly biological processes, otherwise access to patents would be reserved only for those players with sufficient means.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of this resolution. It strengthens the rights of farmers and users of seeds and clearly defines that patenting DNA from crops must be expressly rejected.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution, as I am worried that the recent decision of the Enlarged Board of Appeal could have a negative impact on EU’s competitiveness and lead to the creation of monopolies on the food market.

name: Elisabeth KÖSTINGER
text: Writing. Patents on conventionally farmed animals and crops, as well as their seeds and offspring, are unethical and turn millennia-old rights of farmers on its head. That is why I support this resolution and i urge once again that the Commission and the relevant ministers in the Member States should urgently clarify the situation and, if necessary, to seek a tightening up of patent laws. Practices that undermine the breeder's privilege must be stopped immediately!

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution. This issue is important from an ethical and scientific point of view, and it deserves our attention to ensure that the rules in force are precisely applied. This measure calls on the Commission to clarify as a matter of urgency the scope and interpretation of Directive 98/44/EC, in particular Article 4 and Article 12, in order to ensure legal certainty with regard to the prohibition of the patentability of products obtained by essentially biological processes and to specify that selection with biological material covered by patents is permitted.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. The European Patent Office has agreed to patent plant characteristics, which is contrary to the EU and French approach, which believes that the plant characteristics and "material" used by breeders must remain accessible to all. The solution chosen by the Union (2012) and by France is the establishment of Plant Breeding Certificates, which are a form of protection of the work of breeders, without preventing their use for other work. For farmers, it is also the guarantee of being able to reseed their crops, for a contribution (a kind of tax paid to the organizations grouping the breeders). Despite this last questionable point, the CVOos are a lesser evil, compared to the American patent law which, in turn, benefits only a minority of multinationals of the type of Monsanto (which does not hesitate to send its "seed militia" to verify that farmers do not reseed varieties that belong to it...). This resolution calls for the Union not to align itself with US law, once again in the context of the TTIP negotiations.  So I voted FOR.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported a Resolution of the European Parliament calling on the Commission to clarify Directive 98/44/EC to ensure legal clarity on the prohibition of patenting of products obtained in biological procedures and to define the use of materials derived from biological plant breeding procedures. Proper definition of plant regulations is necessary for the development of new varieties to ensure global food stock security, combat climate change and prevent monopolies in the farming sector. At the same time, this protects intellectual property and encourages innovation.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I support the joint motion for a resolution on patents and plant variety improvement rights because it is complete and documented and I refer further to the reasons I set out in detail in my speech of 17 December 2015 before the plenary of the European Parliament.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ A ban on the patenting of products obtained by conventional breeding techniques, such as crossing, is essential to sustain innovation, food security and small businesses.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this joint resolution of the Greens, the GUE and EFDD. It is aimed at countering the decision of the European Patent Office which has agreed to patent plant characteristics, which is contrary to the approach of the Union and France. We believe that the plant characteristics and "material" used by breeders should remain accessible to all. The resolution of the Greens, the GUE and EFDD called for the Union not to align itself with US law, once again in the context of the TTIP negotiations. The Greens' amendments improve their scope, including respect for farmers' rights.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal is a response to the recently adopted Decision (G2/12 and G2/13) of the European Patent Office's Grand Complaints Chamber, which allows the patent of plant characteristics, even if these characteristics have been developed or obtained using essentially biological breeding methods. This Decision involves a narrow interpretation and thus opens up wide possibilities for granting patents involving plant varieties. This is in direct contradiction to the exception for breeders explained in Article 15 of the 1991 Act of the International Union Convention for the Protection of New Varieties of Plants (UPOV) and Article 15 of Regulation (EC) No 2100/94. I agree that it is very important to balance EU legislation (in particular Directive 98/44/EC) if international obligations on intellectual property rights are to be fulfilled and to increase innovative competitiveness within the European plant breeding sector. Pursuant to Rule 26 of the Implementing Regulation of the European Patent Office, Directive 98/44/EC shall be used as an additional interpretative tool for European patent applications and patents relating to biotechnological inventions. Clarification of Directive 98/44/EC will have an immediate impact on the work of the European Patent Office. That is why I supported today's resolution.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The RC-B8-1394/2015 resolution convinces with sensible and objective proposals. Natural processes such as cross-breeding, selection, etc. have been established for thousands of years and may not be patented. I therefore agree with this motion for a resolution.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this motion for a resolution as it calls on the Commission to urgently clarify the rules governing the patentability of plants.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The patent and the Plant Breeding Certificate (VOC) are both means of protecting the intellectual property of plants. The resolution aims to clarify the application of European directives on the protection of biotech inventions. Indeed, the report is concerned about "the recent decision of the Large Court of Appeal of the European Patent Office in G2/12 (tomatoes) and G2/13 (broccoli) which could lead to an increase in the number of patents granted for natural traits introduced in new varieties through the use of mainly biological processes such as cross-breeding and selection" while these processes are normally excluded. Therefore, it asks the Commission to argue for the exclusion of patentability from essentially biological processes in the context of multilateral discussions for the harmonization of patent law. If this text takes a small step in the right direction it does not go so far as to propose a ban on the patenting of the living. That's why I'm voting against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on patents and breeder rights of plant varieties. Products obtained from essentially biological processes, such as seeds and plants, should be excluded from patentability. Selective cultivation is an innovative process practiced by farmers and farming communities since the beginning of agriculture, and varieties are not protected by patent and breeding methods are important for genetic diversity.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this resolution as it calls for greater clarification from the Commission regarding the patentability of products obtained from essentially biological processes. This clarification is essential if we are to harbour the spirit of innovation in the field of agriculture, especially in a time of uncertain food security and changing climate conditions.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the joint Motion for a Resolution on patents and plant breeders’ rights because I agree with the assertion in the report that unrestricted access to biological material is necessary in order to stimulate the innovative strength of the plant breeding sector. Undermining the innovative ability of the plant breeding sector to develop new varieties poses a threat to global food production and food security and will have a negative impact on European competitiveness and may lead to monopolies on the food market.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 Draft resolutions on the subject were submitted by the political groups PPE, S&D, ECR and ALDE. The four political groups have managed to reach a common position and draw up a compromise proposal. I supported the compromise proposal.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. We are dealing with a motion for a resolution under intellectual property law and is an essential right to safeguard economic incentives and ensure market competitiveness, and here specifically the patentability of products obtained from essentially biological processes is at stake. A decision taken within the enlarged Board of Appeal of the European Patent Office (EPO) could lead to an increase in the number of patents granted by this institute in relation to the natural characteristics introduced into new varieties, essentially using biological processes such as crossing and selection. In this context, there is a need to clarify the scope of Directive 98/44/EC, which legislates on biotechnological inventions, in particular genetic engineering, and particular attention should be paid to Article 4 in order to ensure legal clarity and to define what types of products may or may not be patented. I am voting in favour of this proposal, as patent law should be harmonised, and its implications for biotechnology and genetic engineering should be considered in the future.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The aim of this resolution is that the Union does not align itself with US law under TTIP. Indeed, the European Patent Office has agreed to patent plant characteristics, which is contrary to the approach of the Union and France, which believe that these and the material used by breeders must remain accessible to all. The solution chosen is the establishment of plant certificates, which are a form of protection of the work of breeders without preventing the use for other work. For farmers, this allows the crops to be reseeded. CVOs are therefore a lesser evil compared to U.S. patent law that only benefits multinationals. So I voted for this text.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this joint resolution which calls on the Commission to clarify the interpretation of Directive 98/44/EC and to guarantee access to plants derived from mainly biological processes. This resolution follows two opinions issued by the European Patent Office (EPO) on 25 March 2015, which allow the granting of a patent for a plant derived from a mainly biological process. However, Directive 98/44/EC on the legal protection of biotech inventions excludes essentially biological processes from the scope of patentability. The EPO's decision is therefore at odds with this directive. It is a matter of clearly affirming to farmers the protection of their access to plants derived from these processes.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. – I would have voted in favour of the RC-B8-1394/2015 resolution, as it is convincing with sensible and objective proposals and believes that natural processes such as cross-breeding, selection, etc., which have been established for thousands of years, should not be patented.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The subject of patentability of products relating to biological plant products needs to be interpreted more closely.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. —Without specifically entering into the procedures and reasons used by the Extended Board of Appeal of the European Patent Office when taking its decision on the case 'on tomatoes and broccoli', it is clear that European legislation speaks of how the patenting of animal and plant varieties and the necessary biological processes in the production of plants and animals must not be carried out.  The European Parliament has already warned that legislation in this regard must be clear, as any ambiguity, in addition to undermining the innovative potential in the plant growing sector for the development of new varieties, also poses a threat to global food production and food security, while also weakening the EU's positions in international trade relations. I also believe that it is necessary to ensure a completely unlimited use of biological material, not only for companies in the plant growing sector, but also for farmers using existing biological material and available techniques to produce new innovative and resilient varieties, as they have been doing so undisturbed for millennia. I would like to recall that European law is based on principles and EUROPEAN Union rules must be interpreted as a whole given their true purpose and objective, as not all fringe circumstances can always be foreseen. For all of the above, I supported this resolution of the European Parliament.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This resolution aims to ensure that the EU does not align itself with US law under TTIP. Indeed, the European Patent Office has agreed to patent plant characteristics, which is contrary to the approach of the Union and France, which believe that these and the equipment used by breeders must remain accessible to all. The solution chosen is the establishment of plant certificates, which are a form of protection of the work of breeders without preventing the use for other work. For farmers, this allows the crops to be reseeded. CVOs are therefore a lesser evil compared to U.S. patent law that only benefits multinationals. So I voted for this text.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ Plant cultivation is an innovative process that farmers and farming communities have been carrying out since the beginning of agriculture, and unpatented varieties and farming methods are important for genetic diversity. Access to plant biological material is needed to stimulate innovation and develop new varieties to ensure global food security, tackle climate change and prevent monopolies.  Therefore, products derived from processes that are essentially biological, such as herbs, seeds, original properties and genes, should be exempted from patentability. The prohibition of patentability of products obtained through processes that are biological, such as crossing, is essential for maintaining innovation, food safety as well as for small farmers. I therefore join calls on the Commission and the Patent Agency to clarify their decision before Parliament as soon as possible.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 Article 29 of Regulation (EC) No 2100/94 on the Community plant variety right is incompatible with Article 12 of Directive 98/44/EC on the legal protection of biotechnological inventions. A plant variety can be protected by a plant variety right, but it may also contain one or more patented biotechnological inventions, such as patented genetic components.  The danger is that the patentability of naturally obtained parts of plants could create a monopoly in the food market, thus having a negative impact on competition. In order to resolve this contradiction, Parliament considered it necessary to amend Regulation (EC) No 2100/94 by aligning the rules laid down in Regulation (EC) No 2100/94 with those laid down in Directive 98/44/EC.  Considering this amendment necessary, I voted in favour and I hope that the Commission will soon be able to clarify the objectives of the existing EU rules in this area.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution echoes two opinions issued by the European Patent Office (EPO) on 25 March 2015 allowing the granting of a patent for a plant derived from a mainly biological process. The principle of patenting plants from mainly organic processes would force farmers' work and reserve access to patents only to actors with sufficient means. However, Directive 98/44/EC on the legal protection of biotech inventions excludes essentially biological processes from the scope of patentability. The EPO's decision is therefore at odds with this directive. I supported the joint epp, S and D, ALDE and ECR resolution expressly asking the Commission to clarify the interpretation of Directive 98/44/EC, and to guarantee access to plants derived from mainly biological processes.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ We abstained on this important, highly complex issue because such verbose EU legal resolutions – whether approved or rejected – are simply not the best way to deliver progress and prosperity on the issue.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. It was by an overwhelming majority of 413 votes in the right and 86 against that MEPs adopted a resolution this afternoon to clarify the EU's rules on patents for plant varieties. This initiative is very important and follows the worrying decision taken in March 2015 by the European Patent Office that the origin traits of plants could now be patentable. Specifically, this decision was for tomatoes and broccoli obtained by conventional breeding techniques. As a direct result, small farmers and gardeners would now have to pay to continue to have free access to plant seeds. I have obviously voted in favour of this resolution, which is based on the strong principles of equity and the fight against monopolies in the food chain. The trend is worrying with 10 companies sharing 60% of the global seed market. It is therefore essential to do everything possible to preserve the right of farmers to use seeds extracted from their own crops. The Commission, which has so far been too silent, must act quickly to defend in Europe an agricultural model that rejects any patents on plants and plant material.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. Yesterday, I objected to the establishment of a European list of 36 priority invasive alien species, because in my opinion this list is incomplete and not based on scientific criteria. In these circumstances, the fight against this scourge will not be effective. For this reason, the European Parliament has objected, by a large majority, to the draft decision establishing this priority list within the framework of the European regulation aimed at preventing and managing the introduction and spread in the Union of this scourge by coordinated action plans. In doing so, Parliament followed the recommendation of the Parliamentary Committee on the Environment as formulated on 2 December.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. – (PT) I voted in favour of this joint resolution, because it reflects in a very balanced way parliament's concerns about the patentability of essentially biological processes with regard to the selective cultivation of plants in cases of varieties not protected by patent. First of all, it is necessary for the Commission to clarify the prohibition of patentability of products obtained from essentially biological processes and to apply the principle of 'excluding the patentability of essentially biological procedures in the context of multilateral discussions on the harmonisation of patent law'. As recalled by paragraph 6 of the adopted Joint Resolution, we also await the submission of the report 'on the development and implications of patent law in the field of biotechnology and genetic engineering, as required in Article 16(c) of Directive 98/44/EC, and as requested by Parliament in its Resolution of 10 May 2012 on the granting of patents on essential biological processes'.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. – We voted against this resolution since the oral question submitted to the Commission is sufficiently clear in itself. In addition, Parliament has already ruled on this with a satisfactory resolution on the exemption of patents on certain products in 2012, and therefore we do not think it is necessary to reopen this matter with a new resolution which delves into this issue.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. \u2012 It is essential to safeguard the right of farmers to use and reproduce plant genetic material. This is a scale sufficient to, without compromising quality, allow the continuity of traditional and ancestral practices, such as the exchange of seeds in horticulture and agriculture, which contribute to preserving the diversity of plant varieties, especially those with little commercial interest. We must ensure a regulatory framework that promotes this diversity, because it is up to it that the resilience of ecosystems and, ultimately, the preservation of the natural landscape as we know it today.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this as the resolution is non-legislative and on a complex technical issue already the subject of existing laws.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Today in the plenary chamber I voted in favour of this resolution. Unrestricted access to biological material is necessary to stimulate innovation in the plant breeding sector. Undermining the ability of plant breeders to innovate and develop new varieties of plants poses a real threat to the future of global food security and will have a serious impact on Europe's competitiveness and very well may lead to monopolies by some companies on the food market.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the motion for a resolution on patents and plant breeders' rights. Intellectual property rights are an important means of protecting the economic incentives for the development of new plant products and ensuring competitiveness. Plant breeding is an innovative process used by farmers and farming communities from the beginning of agriculture, and unassuming species and breeding methods are important for genetic diversity. Directive 98/44/EC regulates biotechnical inventions, in particular genetic engineering, but its inconsistent interpretation is currently causing major problems, Therefore, the Commission should clarify as soon as possible the scope and interpretation of the Directive, in particular Article 4 thereof, Article 12(3.b) and Article 13(3.b) in order to ensure legal clarity as regards the prohibition of patentability of products obtained essentially by biological means and the fact that breeding with biological material covered by the scope of the patent is permitted.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I have decided to support the resolution on patents and plant breeders' rights.  The resolution calls for the prudent application of patent law in the field of plant breeding, the application of which should apply to biotechnological inventions, but not to the results of normal biological processes. I believe that the resolution is the right appeal to limit the patenting of plant characteristics where these characteristics have been developed or obtained using essentially biological breeding methods. I consider such patenting to be an exaggerated way of protecting intellectual property that goes against innovation in the sector. I trust that the European Patent Office will reconsider its decision. The resolution is also completely in line with the position of the Ministry of Agriculture of the Czech Republic. Its wording, which originated from the AGRI and JURI committees, is quite sufficient, and I therefore did not support the additional amendments from the GUE/NGL and Green factions.

name: Bart STAES
text: Written. 'I voted against the resolution because farmers are only partially protected and the industry's greed to patent all seed has not been stopped. Neither the European Commission nor the European Patent Office will use this weak text to give a different interpretation to the March 2015 ruling (under which certain properties from tomatoes and broccoli may be patented as long as it does not include a single variety). The plant variety right in itself offers the possibility - even within the biotechnology directive 98/44 - to grow in the context of research and innovation, even if it is patented. But after active lobbying by Europa Bio (agrochemistry), supported by the Social Democrats and Christian Democrats, the protection of farmers is only partly regulated. Although in practice they are most preoccupied with seed propagation and breeding (through farm-specific or locally adapted varieties), it is the concentration of power in the seed sector that threatens this right of the farmer. At a time when there is great pressure to keep new plant breeding techniques out of GMO legislation, it was even more important to reduce the greed of the industry so that not all seed is patented. The resolution does not go far enough for me.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ I support this proposal because it stimulates innovation and economic growth. I consider it essential to enable products to obtain European Patent confirmation in order to be as competitive as possible on the market, and also to better profile the European Union on the global market. This certificate would facilitate the business and protection of patent law for all nationals of the Member States of the European Union, which is one of the main objectives of investment protection. This proposal shows that the European Union cares for and invests in science and innovation and that efforts in these fields should continue.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. \u2012 Access to biological plant material covering plant properties is a key precondition for providing a strong boost to growth and innovation, and for the development of new varieties. The development of new varieties would ensure global food security, tackle climate change, prevent a monopoly in the farming sector, while creating more opportunities for SMEs. Products obtained by processes that are essentially biological, such as herbs, seeds, original properties and genes, should not be patented. Therefore, the rightholder of the plant variety cannot prohibit others from using the protected plant for further cultivation, which is a fundamental principle of the international system of breeding rights to the plant variety, which is based on the International Convention for the Protection of New Plant Varieties (UPOV Convention), and the EU system based on Council Regulation (EC) No 2013/2013. 2100/94. I fully support that resolution at first reading, as I consider it necessary to define clear plant growers' rights and patent criteria. Intellectual property rights are extremely important for preserving economic incentives for the development of new plant products and ensuring competitiveness.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on patents and plant variety rights. Intellectual property rights are important for preserving economic incentives for the development of new plant products and ensuring competitiveness. I welcome the call on the European Commission to forward its upcoming clarification on the possibility of patenting products obtained through processes which are essentially biological to the European Patent Office so that it can be used as a complementary means of interpretation, and to ensure that the Union, together with the Member States, ensures that the Union will continue to ensure access to material obtained through processes essentially biological , and its use for breeding, so as not to, where appropriate, interfere with the practice of Member States on the exemption of breeders.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The resolution concerns the recent decision of the enlarged Court of Appeal of the European Patent Office to open the legal route for the issue of patents for organic plant varieties. It is essentially a copyright purchase by a company. In this way, that company may request a monetary consideration to allow the commercial exploitation of the patented plant variety (e.g. seed of a particular wheat variety) by third parties, whereas in the past those varieties were for free exploitation by each company and each farmer. An oral question has recently been tabled asking the Commission to propose legislation (through a revision of Directive 98/44/EC) to prohibit the patenting of organic plant varieties. This was followed by this resolution on which we abstained, although we agree on the substance, because we believe that the recent oral question and the 2012 resolution fully cover the positions of our group, as opposed to the resolution which has significant shortcomings.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution clearly separates free organic farming and protects it against large multinationals and genetically modified organisms.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 An important topic of the European Parliament today was the proposal for a resolution on patents and plant breeding, which I also noted as a proposer and supported in the vote. The issue concerns food safety and it is therefore important to regulate it at European level. I believe that innovation and R&D should not be hindered in any way if there is no risk to human or animal health. Therefore, the European Patent Office should assist this process, and the IPR system is also an important market incentive and competitive tool. Let us not forget that as a result of breeding work, we also produce public good. It is important that the plant breeding sector has unrestricted access to biological agents.  In order to ensure food security, biodiversity and adaptation to environmental change, I believe that farmers should even be allowed to produce their own seeds adapted to local conditions (if they meet certain criteria). This may also be important in special cases such as organic cultivation. Regulation of this needs, of course, to be improved: there is currently no coherence in patent systems at EU or national level, plus the unrestricted use of biological agents by plant growers. In my speech, I drew attention to the settlement of the relationship between this subject and TTIP.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. – The European Union's agriculture and food policy focuses on ensuring an adequate quantity and quality of food supply to European consumers. The recent decision of the European Patent Office to patent certain plant characteristics is a restrictive interpretation of the European Patent Convention, which may have a negative effect on European competitiveness and lead to the emergence of monopolies in the food market by decreasing the diversity of consumer products offered. Biological hybridisation processes, however, are essential practices to increase plant resistance to various pests or diseases that may occur and endanger the food security of European citizens. In order to stimulate research and innovation in this area, unrestricted access to biological material is necessary, which is jeopardised by the decision of the European Patent Office. For this reason, I believe that a unified European hybridisation policy is needed, which supports the production of resilient plant varieties that do not affect European and global agricultural production and that continueto offer the widest range of products to European consumers.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I am very concerned that the recent decision of the EPO's Grand Board of Appeal in G2/12 (tomatoes) and G2/13 (broccoli) could lead to an increase in the number of patents granted by the EPO for natural traits introduced in new varieties through the use of mainly biological processes such as cross-breeding and breeding. The Commission urgently needs to clarify the scope and interpretation of Directive 98/44/EC, Article 4, Article 12, paragraph 3, paragraph b), and Article 13, paragraph 3, point b), in order to establish legal certainty regarding the prohibition of patentability of products obtained by essentially biological processes, and to specify that obtaining patented biological material is permitted.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution which calls on the Commission to urgently clarify the scope and interpretation of the 98/44/EC directive on patents, in order to ensure legal clarity regarding the prohibition of the patentability of products obtained from essentially biological processes, and to clarify that breeding with biological material falling under the scope of a patent is permitted. Indeed, the recent decision of the Enlarged Board of Appeal of the European Patents Office (EPO) on Cases G2/12 (tomatoes) and G2/13 (broccoli) could lead to more patents being granted by the EPO in respect of natural traits introduced into new varieties by means of essentially biological processes such as crossing and selection.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I have supported patent and plant variety rights because I believe that unrestricted access to biological material is necessary. This promotes the innovation of breeding and ensures global food security and prevents a monopoly on the market. I also believe that the exclusion of plant varieties and properties developed by predominantly biological breeding techniques from the patentability is crucial.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. – We voted against this resolution since the oral question submitted to the Commission is sufficiently clear in itself. In addition, Parliament has already ruled on this with a satisfactory resolution on the exemption of patents on certain products in 2012, and therefore we do not think it is necessary to reopen this matter with a new resolution which delves into this issue.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 In order to guarantee global food security, address climate change and prevent monopolies in the plant breeding sector, while at the same time ensuring more opportunities for SMEs, access to biological plant material, including plant characteristics, is essential to boost innovation and develop new varieties. I voted in favour of the S&D group's position.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. – We voted against this resolution since the oral question submitted to the Commission is sufficiently clear in itself. In addition, Parliament has already ruled on this with a satisfactory resolution on the exemption of patents on certain products in 2012, and therefore we do not think it is necessary to reopen this matter with a new resolution which delves into this issue.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because I agree that access to biological plant material encompassing plant traits is absolutely necessary for boosting innovation and the development of new varieties in order to guarantee global food security, tackle climate change and prevent monopolies within the breeding sector, while at the same time providing more opportunities for SMEs. Intellectual property rights are equally important in order to safeguard economic incentives for developing new plant products and to deliver competitiveness. I supported this resolution because I think it is necessary to clarify the scope and interpretation of some previous directives in order to ensure legal clarity regarding the prohibition of the patentability of products obtained from essentially biological processes.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this report because I am convinced that it will stimulate the innovation and development of new varieties that can guarantee global food security, further tackle climate change and prevent monopolies within the plant breeders' sector.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution relates to the possibility of patenting plant characteristics, including when they are developed, improved or obtained through breeding techniques of organic plants, and follows the recent decision of the Grand Board of Appeal of the European Patent Office, which goes directly against the exception to the patent law which safeguards producers with regard to biological breeding techniques and extends the power of patents. Although we follow the question, we do not think it is enough to ask for the clarifying of Directive 98/44/EC, but it will need to be reviewed and updated, not in order to protect unrestricted access to biological material, but in order to avoid abusive interpretations that go against the rights of producers and peoples to produce and improve plant species with biological and traditional techniques. Major multinational seed companies, such as Monsanto, Dupont or Syngenta, already have rights on the most important seeds for human food, with all the consequences this has on producers and consumers. Soon, and if there is no break with this model, it will be these companies that determine what should be grown and at what price.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The RC-B8-1394/2015 resolution convinces with sensible and objective proposals. Natural processes such as cross-breeding, selection, etc. have been established for thousands of years and may not be patented. I therefore agree with this motion for a resolution.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this parliament's resolution. I believe that the legal situation at present not only creates legal uncertainty, which is directly harmful to intellectual property rights, but is also directly harmful to innovation and progress. It is inconceivable that materials obtained by biological processes, breeding which humanity has used since time immemorial, should be subject to patents which would not allow their further free use. On the contrary, the derogation that should apply to these cases is beneficial not only for the further development of new species, but also for the overall food security of the population.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 This oral question relates to the possibility of patenting plant characteristics, including when they are developed, improved or obtained through breeding techniques for organic plants, which comes from the recent decision of the Grand Board of Appeal of the European Patent Office, which goes directly against the exception to the patent law which safeguards producers with regard to biological breeding techniques and extends the power of patents. Although we follow the content of the question, we do not think that it is enough to ask for the clarifying of Directive 98/44/EC, but it will need to be reviewed and updated so that there are no interpretations that go against the rights of producers and peoples to produce and improve plant species with biological and traditional techniques.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. The Directive on 'patentable biotechnology' provides that plant varieties, animal breeds and essentially biological processes for the production of plants or animals are excluded from the possibility of being patented. The European Patent Office (EPO) in a recent decision overturned what was established by the directive, allowing plant products developed with organic selection techniques to be patented as well. As a result, the availability of biological material from many plant varieties will become the prerogative of the biotechnology industries, reinforcing the current trend of the seed market being concentrated in the hands of a few industries. This resolution was born with the intention of combating these abuses, but it is weak because it does not fully defend the rights of farmers. If a crop is contaminated with patent-protected plants, the farmer who owns that field could be sued by the patent holder.  We must have the courage to defend the farmers vigorously. Against the excessive power of agrochemical farms, we cannot accept middle ground, so I voted against this resolution. Access to plant genetic heritage must be protected decisively without ifs and buts.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur For a number of reasons, African countries are the ones that, since their independence ten years ago, have had or are still very difficult to build, effectively functioning statehood structures, where the daily lives of society would not be threatened by internal conflicts, human rights violations, poverty, hunger and other causes. Some countries have already solved these problems, others still have these problems. Burundi is unfortunately one such country : although the country's independence was regained more than half a century ago, there is still no real history of peace. Regional instability, ethnic cleansing or even full-scale genocide, two civil wares, one of the world's highest levels of poverty, mass corruption, an extremely weak situation with health care , all caused by the crisis and president Pierre Nkurunziza's desire to remain in office for a third term. All this is not what meets our European criteria. Thank you!

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. While I share the deep concern expressed in the Resolution about the situation in Burundi, aggravated by the killing by security forces of at least eighty-seven people, as well as the rapid deterioration of the humanitarian situation in the country, I have not been able to vote in favour of this text, since it welcomes the sanctions imposed by the EU and calls for it as a measure of pressure on withdrawal of all European funding in the country, except for strictly humanitarian funding, while this consists mainly of headings from the European Development Fund. The Resolution never refers to the responsibility of European multinationals and former colonial powers in exposing resources or promoting conflicts in the country. On the contrary, it calls on the African Union, the EU and the United Nations to increase their presence in the country through a so-called "peacekeeping mission" that the Security Council could even commission from NATO, but which regardless of its command will mean a greater foreign military presence in Burundi, leading to further crisis exacerbation.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP abstained on this non-legislative and non-binding resolution. While of course we share deep concern over the unstable political situation and killings that have taken place, we cannot support calls for more EU interference. These issues should be handled between national governments and at the appropriate and legitimate international level, namely the United Nations. The un-elected and unaccountable EU institutions have no right to interfere in the foreign policy of Member States or the domestic affairs of non-EU countries.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. Burundi is a former German and then Belgian colony. It gained independence in 1962. Between 1972 and the early 2000s, however, the civil war almost never stopped. Since 2000, ethnic conflicts have subsided under the pacifying action of former Tutsi President Pierre Buyoya, until old quarrels were revived by the desire of Pierre Nkurunziza, the current president, to run for a third presidential term. The situation has deteriorated considerably since last May. Despite these tragic events, the complexity of the oppositions would render any European Union intervention unnecessary or even harmful. I therefore voted against this joint motion for a resolution.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I recognise the seriousness of the situation in Burundi, and I welcome the fact that this situation has been highlighted.  I also note that the report is non-legislative in nature.  Therefore, I did not feel it appropriate to oppose this report.   Nevertheless, some aspects of the report are concerning - particularly in respect of the EU's role in foreign affairs which I fundamentally disagree with.  I therefore could not vote in favour of the report either. It made sense, therefore, to abstain on the resolution as a whole.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. The security situation in Burundi has deteriorated dramatically in the last few days following attacks on three military camps in Bujumbura. 29 June 2015 There were parliamentary and local elections in Burundi and the presidential elections on 21 July 2015, but the international community believes that none of these electoral processes were transparent, inclusive, free and credible. According to the Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights and other human rights organisations, human rights violations and violence against opposition figures, human rights defenders and journalists in particular have been committed both in and after the elections in the country for political reasons. Recent violent attacks and human rights violations must be strongly condemned. It is necessary to put an immediate end to violence, human rights violations and political intimidation of opponents, in strict compliance with international law and human rights.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. The situation in Burundi had calmed down in recent years, thanks in part to the efforts of former President Pierre Buyoya, a Tutsi who was able to make peace with the Hutus through the Arusha Accords. But by announcing last April that he would run for a third presidential term, which the constitution forbade, Pierre Nkurunziza revived old oppositions. In May, the Constitutional Court validated the candidacy, triggering very serious riots, with police opening fire on protesters in Bujumbura.  Since April, several hundred people have been killed and more than 200,000 people have been "displaced". At the moment, the situation seems out of control and the whole region is threatening to catch fire. Especially since Rwandan President Paul Kagame has vowed to overthrow burundian president. All the more reason for the European institutions to remain cautious instead of once again playing the lesson-givers!

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I supported this joint resolution which strongly condemns violence and all violations of human rights, including by the army and police in Burundi. Parliament urges all parties to establish the conditions for restoring trust and fostering national unity and calls for the immediate resumption of an open and transparent national dialogue between the government, opposition parties and representatives of civil society. I believe that the international community should spare no effort to end the violence in this country and restore the rule of law and respect for fundamental rights.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I supported the motion for a Resolution on the situation in Burundi. I would like to highlight the section which expresses its particular concern at the serious levels of discrimination and criminalization to which LGBTI people are subjected. In addition, the African Union, the United Nations and the EU are called upon to take into account the regional dimension and prevent further destabilization of the region with the increase in its presence on the ground. It is also noted that Burundi's problems are related to disputes concerning control over fertile farmland, income inequality and discrimination.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I voted against this text. Indeed, while I recognise that the current situation in Burundi is dramatic and that there is a risk of a flare-up for the whole region, the European Parliament is once again proposing unrealistic positions, wanting to make the European Commission the policeman of global problems. While the positions taken by Rwandan President Paul Kagame are worrying, it seems more reasonable to allow the African Union to mediate, especially since this civil war has, in large part, ethnic foundations. The European Union, through its repeated interference, tends to inflame the situation, as was the case in the Middle East or Ukraine, and it would be wiser in this case to rely on the diplomacy of sovereign states to reach a solution.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 While I share the concern about the serious political and security situation in the State of Burundi and the condemnation of human rights violations, I do not fully agree with the solutions proposed in this text, which is why I abstained.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this resolution because it is a statement by Parliament on the situation in Burundi. After the attacks on three military camps in Bujumbura, the security situation in Burundi has deteriorated dramatically in the last few days since 11 and 12 December 2015. Burundi's security forces have killed at least 87 people. 29 June 2015 There were parliamentary and local elections in Burundi, and the presidential elections on 21 July 2015, and the international community believes that none of these electoral processes were transparent, inclusive, free and credible, which led to the EU suspending its election mission in Burundi, and a large part of burundi's opposition decided to boycott the elections. According to the Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights (OHCHR) and other human rights organisations, human rights violations and violations have been committed in the country for political reasons, both in the period leading up to and after the elections, and violent acts against opposition figures, human rights defenders and journalists in particular. Parliament strongly condemned the recent violent attacks and the increase in human rights violations and disregard, including killings, extrajudicial executions, violations of physical integrity of the population, torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment, arbitrary arrests and unlawful detention, including child detention, the fact that schools are occupied by soldiers and police, as well as severely condemning violations of freedom of the press and expression and prevailing impunity.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. In April 2015, President Nkurunziza announced that he would run for president for a third time, despite the country's constitution prohibiting it. Contrary to the recommendation of the international community, President Nkurunziza nevertheless ran for office, which he won in August. This has plunged the country into its deepest political and humanitarian crisis since the civil war. Since then, approximately 200 people have been killed and 200 forced to flee the country. The motion calls for an immediate cessation of violence and calls on the Government of Burundi to respect their obligations and guarantee the fulfilment of fundamental human rights.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ I strongly condemn the killings and human rights violations taking place in Burundi. I call for an end to violence and an end to human rights violations. It is of utmost importance to prevent the situation from deteriorating further, and I call for political dialogue between the authorities and the opposition. We must prevent further escalation of conflicts that can extend to neighbouring countries.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Burundi is one of the least developed countries in the world. Almost half of its 10.6 million inhabitants are 15 years of age or younger (children under 5 make up 19.9% of the population) and are at the top of the global hunger index, with three out of five children suffering from growth delays. Therefore, the political stalemate in Burundi, characterized by a lack of dialogue between the parties involved in the country and the consequent deterioration of the economic and security situation, has serious repercussions on the population and represents a serious risk to the stability of the region, where difficult elections will be held over the next two years (Uganda, Democratic Republic of congo, Rwanda).  The continuation of the mediation efforts supported by the African Union, the EU and the UN, in order to promote dialogue within the country in order to achieve a peaceful solution to the crisis, is undoubtedly positive. Similarly, targeted EU sanctions are to be supported, in line with the African Union decision, including a travel ban and a freeze on assets for Burundians whose actions and statements contribute to the perpetuity of violence and hinder efforts to find a political solution to the crisis.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU's commitment to human rights, the rule of law and democracy and to all the peoples of the world, including the Burundian people, leads to a strong condemnation of the actions taking place in Burundi, such as the use of force against peaceful, unarmed demonstrators, abuses of state human rights officials, extrajudicial executions, arbitrary arrests and imprisonments, torture, attacks on independent media , the harassment and murder of human rights defenders, unjustified limitations of freedom of peaceful assembly and expression, as well as the displacement of more than 200 000 people as a result of violence.
