The EU partnership with Burundi is governed by the Cotonou Agreement, which states that all parties are required to comply with and apply the provisions of this agreement, in particular as regards human rights. The Union supports the establishment by the Prosecutor General of the Republic of Burundi of a commission of inquiry to investigate the API killings of 13 October 2015, in particular since Burundi is also a party to the International Criminal Court and has undertaken the obligation to combat the impunity of the offences falling within its jurisdiction. We are in danger of a regional crisis, highlighted by the permanent exodus of refugees to neighbouring countries, and that is why I gave this proposal my vote in favour.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Abstention vote.  The resolution expresses its concern at the serious political and security situation in Burundi, as well as at the worsening humanitarian situation and the consequences that this could have for the security and stability of the entire sub-region.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The situation in Burundi has plummeted worryingly in recent months. The chronicles speak of a country in which blood has returned. If the fighting does not stop in Burundi, the conflict could spread to Congo, then to Rwanda.  The situation must be given the utmost attention and the international community must act before it is too late. So far, more than 240 people have been killed and another 280,000 displaced, making the country experience the worst crisis in its history since the end of the civil war fought between 1993 and 2006.  In recent weeks, however, it seems that the international community's passivity has come to an end. The UN Security Council has condemned the spiral of violence and there is a clear position of the African Union which has found the full support and support of the European Union.  It is now necessary to strongly call on the government of the country to stop the repressive spiral and to agree to take part in peace talks with the mediation of the international community, the African Union and the European Union.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution and moreover, prior to this resolution, I supported the open letter, prepared by the Parliamentarians for Global Action together with FIDH, to support Human Rights Defenders in Burundi, who have been systematically targeted in the past months by both the government and armed forces. The actions of the Burundian Government are reprehensible. They have responded to public protests  with extremely repressive measures, including extra-judicial killings, arbitrary detentions, and restrictions on freedom of expression.   It is estimated that 230 000 people have fled to neighbouring countries. It is further reported that 87 people were killed following attacks on three military bases in the capital, Bujumbura, only last week.  Some of the victims appear to have been shot in reprisals carried out by the security forces. I and my Sinn Féin colleagues are deeply concerned about the ongoing violence and human rights violations in Burundi, and I will continue to use my role as a Member of Parliament to ensure that this matter is brought to the attention of the international community.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. – UKIP abstained on this non-legislative and non-binding resolution. While of course we share deep concern over the unstable political situation and killings that have taken place, we cannot support calls for more EU interference. These issues should be handled between national governments and at the appropriate and legitimate international level, namely the United Nations. The un-elected and unaccountable EU institutions have no right to interfere in the foreign policy of Member States or the domestic affairs of non-EU countries.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution because we, as the European Union, need to formally protest against the current situation in Burundi. Violence and political intimidation are unacceptable and the international community should do everything possible to ensure that the crisis is resolved and human rights are respected again.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the resolution because it welcomes the targeted sanctions adopted by the EU in accordance with the AU decision. These sanctions include the travel ban and the freezing of assets of those Burundian citizens whose actions and statements contribute to the continuation of violence and the obstruction of efforts to find a political solution to the crisis. Furthermore, the EU is called upon to extend similar sanctions to all persons acting in a way that threatens peace and stability in the region when they incite hatred and violate the Ausa agreement. The resolution urges the EU and its Member States, taking into account the way in which public consultations under Article 96 of the Cotton Agreement have evolved, to consider freezing all non-humanitarian aid to the Government of Burundi until excessive violence and human rights violations by government forces have ceased. , as the OHCHR denounces, and until a political solution is found resulting from a genuine national dialogue in the country.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The joint resolution on the situation in Burundi contains a number of positive elements. It strongly condemns the recent violent attacks and the growing incidents of human rights violations and abuses, urges all parties to create the necessary conditions for restoring trust and strengthening national unity and calls for respect for the African Charter of Human and Peoples' Rights, as well as concrete measures to put an end to violent acts. That's why I decided to vote for it.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to support the measure. Parliament expressed its deep concern at the serious political and security situation in Burundi, as well as at the rapid deterioration of the humanitarian situation and the consequences that this could have for the security and stability of the entire region.  Strongly condemns the recent violent attacks and the increase in the number of cases of human rights violations and abuses, including murder, extrajudicial executions, violations of people's physical integrity, acts of torture and other cruel, inhuman and/or degrading treatment, arbitrary arrests and illegal detentions, including the detention of children and the occupation of schools by the military and police, as well as violations of press and expression freedom and predominantly impunity.  It called for an end to the violence and for a thorough and independent investigation into the killings and abuses to be promoted and for those responsible for these acts to be brought to justice. It called for an immediate end to violence, human rights violations and political intimidation of opponents, and called for the immediate disarmament of all armed groups allied to political parties, in strict accordance with international law and human rights.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution analysing the crisis in Burundi and the consequent concerns and commitments that the Union must make to burundi. Burundi is experiencing a deep social crisis, it is one of the least developed countries in the world and, in my opinion, awareness must be raised in Europe about the serious political and security landscape that is being created. I hope that we will put an end to violence, human rights violations and the political intimidation of opponents. In view of the partnership agreement between the EU and Burundi, I would like our Union to take concrete action and help to ensure that respect for fundamental human rights is maintained in the African state. Europe must be at the forefront of this, so I support the proposal by voting in favour.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ In its resolution, the EPP insists on the need to stop all violence and political intimidation and urges the Government of Burundi to respect its obligations to guarantee fundamental rights under all international and regional human rights instruments.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. – Five days ago we celebrated Human Rights Day against a scenario of 240 people in Burundi killed since President Pierre Nkurunziza launched a controversial bid to prolong his term in office last April and more than 210 000 people fleeing the country since then. Clearly the situation in Burundi has deteriorated dangerously in recent weeks and the security forces continue to disrespect the human rights of Burundians, amid a general climate of impunity; daily reports of serious human rights violations, including extrajudicial killings, arbitrary arrests and detentions, torture, attacks on independent media and harassment and killings of human rights defenders, as well as unjustified limitations on the freedoms of peaceful assembly and expression.  By voting in favour of this motion for a resolution I express agreement with Resolution 2248 (2015) of the UN Security Council to consider additional measures against all Burundian actors whose actions and statements contribute to the perpetuation of violence and impede the search for a peaceful solution.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. While I share the deep concern expressed in the Resolution about the situation in Burundi, aggravated by the killing by security forces of at least eighty-seven people, as well as the rapid deterioration of the humanitarian situation in the country, I have not been able to vote in favour of this text, since it welcomes the sanctions imposed by the EU and calls for it as a measure of pressure on withdrawal of all European funding in the country, except for strictly humanitarian funding, while this consists mainly of headings from the European Development Fund. The Resolution never refers to the responsibility of European multinationals and former colonial powers in exposing resources or promoting conflicts in the country. On the contrary, it calls on the African Union, the EU and the United Nations to increase their presence in the country through a so-called "peacekeeping mission" that the Security Council could even commission from NATO, but which regardless of its command will mean a greater foreign military presence in Burundi, leading to further crisis exacerbation.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 The increasing insecurity and the constant worsening of violence in Burundi (a recent massacre took place the other day that resulted in the killing of some 90 people) have dramatic consequences for the country and the entire region. The Burundian authorities must participate in consultations with a view to finding a solution acceptable to the parties in order to put an end to the violation of human rights, democratic principles and the rule of law. The security and freedom of citizens, human rights defenders, journalists and the press, as well as the restoration of the rule of law, are essential. I strongly support the immediate cessation of violence, human rights violations, political intimidation of opponents and the immediate disarmament of all armed groups allied to political parties, in strict accordance with international law and human rights. The EU must continue to actively support all diplomatic efforts that will lead to a consensual solution to the crisis and be ready to come up with new solutions, depending on developments. The EU must also adopt new restrictive measures aimed at those who, through their actions or speech promoted, have provoked or could cause acts of violence, repression and serious human rights violations.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The resolution deals with the security and democratic situation in Burundi including human rights violations and conflicts between Burundi security forces and civilians resulting in deaths and random executions. It also touches upon serious breaches of democracy in the sense of a possible dictatorship in the making after the current president overstayed his mandate. The resolution also condemns various instances in Burundi where rule of law was not being adhered to, such as the last elections which the international community did not view as transparent and the general deterioration of the security of the country and region. As I believe that the European Parliament should continue acting as one of the strongest international advocates for the protection of human rights and democracy I have voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. In this resolution, MEPs call for an end to violence and political intimidation in Burundi and call on the government of the day to respect its obligations under international human rights law without delay. On 26 August 2015, President Nkurunziza was elected to lead Burundi for a third term, despite the constitutional prohibition of him and despite numerous pressure from the international community.  Since then, the country has been plunged into an unprecedented political, security and humanitarian crisis, according to humanitarian organizations on the ground that bear witness to the escalation of violence, with more than 200 people killed and 200,000 people fleeing Burundi. Together with my colleagues in the EPP Group, we reiterated the importance of establishing dialogue and consensus at the regional level. A viable political solution must include all regional and international actors. I also supported the granting of EU financial aid to this humanitarian crisis, and I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. – UKIP abstained on this non-legislative and non-binding resolution. While of course we share deep concern over the unstable political situation and killings that have taken place, we cannot support calls for more EU interference. These issues should be handled between national governments and at the appropriate and legitimate international level, namely the United Nations. The un-elected and unaccountable EU institutions have no right to interfere in the foreign policy of Member States or the domestic affairs of non-EU countries.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because I am very concerned about the climate of civil war and the seriousness of the political situation, as well as the rapid deterioration of the humanitarian situation in Burundi. I strongly condemn killings, extrajudicial executions, attacks on the physical integrity of persons, torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment, arbitrary arrests and unlawful detentions, including detention of children, and violations of press freedom and freedom of expression.  There is an urgent need to restore security, stability and the restoration of democracy and the rule of law in the interests of Burundian citizens. To this end, it is necessary that a thorough and independent investigation be carried out into the current killings and abuses, that the perpetrators of these acts be brought to justice and that the immediate disarmament of all armed groups allied to political parties be carried out, with strict respect for international law and human rights.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported another resolution on the situation in Burundi, which is threateningly deteriorating by the past month. Just a few weeks ago, the armed forces once again overran the rights of the population, at least 240 people have been killed since current President Nkurunziza decided to extend his term, and more than 200,000 have fled the country. It is essential to re-establish the democratic process and dialogue between political parties and to put an end to the persecution, murder and impunity of the military.  Also disturbing is the case of Richard Spyros Hagabimana, a Police Officer in Burundi of Greek origin who was locked up and tortured because, as a police officer, he refused to shoot into the crowd. The European External Action Service must do its u best to protect its rights and negotiate its release.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. Burundi, like many other African countries, has been a colony in this case of the Germans and the Belgians. After the end of colonial exploitation, the transition to freedom and democracy did not take place smoothly. The Hutu and Tutsi differences in particular continue to ach the country. The current regime is far from being classified as the rule of law. The country's Constitution has been broken, there is no welfare state and there is no respect for human, civil and political rights and fundamental freedoms. It needs an immediate restoration of peace and calm. An optimal and urgent solution is needed in the light of the deteriorating humanitarian situation and, in order to protect the Christian population of more than 60% of the total, a mission under the UNHcran High Commission for the Preservation and Enforcement of Peace is required.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. In April 2015, President Nkurunziza announced that he would run for president for a third time, despite the country's constitution prohibiting it. Contrary to the recommendation of the international community, President Nkurunziza nevertheless ran for office, which he won in August. This has plunged the country into its deepest political and humanitarian crisis since the civil war. Since then, approximately 200 people have been killed and 200 forced to flee the country. The motion calls for an immediate cessation of violence and calls on the Government of Burundi to respect their obligations and guarantee the fulfilment of fundamental human rights.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution is a clear example of how skewed and partially skewed and partially how so many other resolutions are promoted and voted on in the European Parliament, responding to the economic and political interests of the major powers of the European Union, without looking at the means, distorting reality and twisting it to the version that suits it best to fuel the destabilisation of a country. The deplorable text presented does everything to affirm a unilateral vision of a democratically elected regime, with strong popular support, and which has affirmed a vision of development of the country that does not serve the interests of capital. He omits that the "fighters for democracy", which feeds through the mechanisms for EU democracy, are a relevant part of the conflicts that take place there, promoting aggression and murder and spreading fear in the population. It distorts events promoted by these movements, attributing them to government forces – movements associated with terrorism and trafficking, which serve the interests of the EU, which has fertile and desirable soil in the great lakes for the exploitation of ores by European industry. An unacceptable text, imbued with hatred and intentions of interference, over a country and a sovereign government. We voted against it.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The political, humanitarian and security situation in the country is deteriorating and poses risks to neighbouring countries. More than 200,000 people have fled the country and about 250 have been reported killed since last April. In November, the son of prominent human rights activist Pierre Claver Mbonimp was killed. More recently, the government has closed the bank accounts of 10 human rights NGOs. I therefore welcome the european Union's response, which has imposed sanctions against four people close to the President, as well as sending a letter to the Government to open consultations under Article 96 of the Cotonou Agreement. I strongly condemn the ongoing murders and human rights violations, as well as the deteriorating humanitarian situation. we must ensure that further deterioration of the situation is avoided, inter alia, through political dialogue between the government and the opposition, including civil society, and ensuring accountability for violations of the violence committed.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. Burundi, like many other African countries, has served as a colony, in this case German and Belgian. After colonial exploitation, the transition to freedom and democracy did not take place smoothly. The Hutu and Tutsi differences in particular continue to aer the country over time. The current regime is far from being classified as the rule of law. The country's Constitution has been broken, there is no welfare state and there is no respect for human, civil and political rights and fundamental freedoms. For the above reasons, I am voting against the relevant reports in their entirety. It needs an immediate restoration of peace and calm. An optimal and urgent solution is needed, given the deteriorating humanitarian situation and, in order to protect the Christian population of more than 60%, enforcement and peacekeeping forces must be sent to the country, under the auspices of the UN High Commissioner for Peace Enforcement and Peace Keeping.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I would like to express my fear for the escalation of violence in Burundi and my solidarity with all victims of violence, as well as with the people forced to move in an atmosphere of insecurity and uncertainty. I regret the continuing political impasse in the country, marked by the refusal of a real dialogue between the actors. Any speech and incitement to hatred could aggravate the already precarious situation and is therefore totally unacceptable. These developments may have tragic consequences for Burundi and for the entire region. We must by all means cooperate to find a solution to stop the violence in the country. I support the call on all parties, both government and opposition, to show the utmost restraint in language and to avoid triggering a cycle of violence at all costs. I also would like to recall that it is primarily the responsibility of the Burundian Government to protect its population.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. April 2015 - President Nkurunziza announces that he will run for president for a third time, despite the country's constitution prohibiting it. Contrary to the recommendation of the international community, President Nkurunziza nevertheless ran for office, which he won in August. This has plunged the country into its deepest political and humanitarian crisis since the civil war. Since then, approximately 200 people have been killed and 200 forced to flee the country. The motion calls for an immediate cessation of violence and calls on the Government of Burundi to respect their obligations and guarantee the fulfilment of fundamental human rights.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the finding that the security situation in Burundi has deteriorated severely in recent days, and because of the rapid deterioration of the humanitarian situation and the consequences that this may have for the security and stability of the entire subregion. The EU must demand that violence, human rights violations and political intimidation of opponents be immediately put to an immediate end, and that all allied armed groups of political parties be disarmed immediately.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. A political solution involving all regional and international actors is needed. Only in this way can a long-term solution be developed for the affected population. The aim must be to resolve the current humanitarian crisis quickly and effectively.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ Hundreds killed or arrested, thousands internally displaced, 250 000 in refugee camps in the region. This is the consequence of President Nkurunziza putting personal gain over people’s interest, and the opposition doing the same in its response to the crisis. Meanwhile, a lack of disarmament following past conflicts, combined with attempts to manipulate ethnic fault lines, risks leading to another civil war.  What we need is an African solution that will be a sustainable one, but I am concerned about the lack of unity and vision displayed by the African Union and East African community in terms of mediation efforts, especially given the fragile stability of the entire Great Lakes region which is closely interlinked. That is why I support the call made by Burundian human rights activist Pierre-Claver Mbonimpa – himself a victim of repression in the country – for the EU to decisively leverage its financial influence to put pressure on major actors in Burundi and the wider region to convene an inclusive dialogue.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I, along with my fellow Labour MEPs, condemn the ongoing killings and human rights violations and deplore the worsening humanitarian situation in Burundi. We are calling for an end to the violence and human rights abuses. We must work to ensure that there is no further deterioration of the situation through political dialogue between the government and the opposition, working with civil society and ensuring accountability for the violations committed. We urge the Security Council to follow its resolution with specific measures to stop rights abuses. We must work to prevent further escalation of the conflict and further loss of life.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ My vote for the report on the situation in Burundi expressed the concern about the situation in Burundi, that has seriously deteriorated, following the attacks of three military camps in Bujumbura; whereas Burundian security forces killed at least 87 people on 11 and 12 December 2015; whereas many of these killings seem to have been random executions.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. In April 2015, President Nkurunziza announced that he would run for president for a third time, despite the fact that it is prohibited by the country's constitution. Contrary to the recommendation of the international community, President Nkurunziza nevertheless ran for office, which he won in August. This has plunged the country into its deepest political and humanitarian crisis since the civil war. Since then, approximately 200 people have been killed and 200 forced to flee the country. The motion calls for an immediate cessation of violence and calls on the Government of Burundi to respect their obligations and guarantee the fulfilment of fundamental human rights.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted along with ALDE against this joint motion for a resolution on the situation in Burundi. Burundi has reached a stage of absolute chaos where armed forces are arbitrarily killing their own citizens. The unacceptable state of affairs means the international community has to take serious action to avert a civil war, this resolution is simply not enough. First and foremost, peace must be established and international laws respected and applied to be on a first-step basis for violence reduction in the country.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I recognise the seriousness of the situation in Burundi, and I welcome the fact that this situation has been highlighted.  I also note that the report is non-legislative in nature.  Therefore, I did not feel it appropriate to oppose this report.   Nevertheless, some aspects of the report are concerning – particularly in respect of the EU’s role in foreign affairs, which I fundamentally disagree with. I therefore could not vote in favour of the report either. It made sense, therefore, to abstain on the resolution as a whole.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution due to the fact that Burundi is facing an unprecedented political, security and humanitarian crisis, with more than 200 people killed and an estimated number of 200 000 people having fled the country. Human rights organisations have reported on the growing politically motivated violence and impunity in the country, and the countless human rights violations and abuses, mainly caused by the ruling authorities. There is an urgent need to stop all violence and political intimidation, and urgency on the government of Burundi to respect their obligations to guarantee fundamental rights under all international and regional human rights instruments.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. In April 2015, President Nkurunziza announced that he would run for president for a third time, despite the country's constitution prohibiting it. Contrary to the recommendation of the international community, President Nkurunziza nevertheless ran for office, which he won in August. This has plunged the country into its deepest political and humanitarian crisis since the civil war. Since then, approximately 200 people have been killed and 200 forced to flee the country. The motion calls for an immediate cessation of violence and calls on the Government of Burundi to respect their obligations and guarantee the fulfilment of fundamental human rights.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's resolution on the situation in Burundi, as the country is in an even worse political, economic and humanitarian crisis today than previously adopted European Parliament resolutions. Unfortunately, in recent weeks, the situation has deteriorated sharply and security forces have been violating human rights without fear of sanction.  This, on the one hand, supports the dialogue between the government and representatives of the opposition, and on the other hand, calls for consideration of additional sanctions measures towards actors that contribute to the continuation and escalation of violence and constitute an obstacle to finding a peaceful solution. This resolution calls for the suspension, i.e. the diversion of EU development assistance, i.e. member states.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – My fellow colleagues and I abstained on this non-legislative and non-binding resolution. While of course we share deep concern over the unstable political situation and killings that have taken place, we cannot support calls for more EU interference. These issues should be handled between national governments and at the appropriate and legitimate international level, namely the United Nations. The un-elected and unaccountable EU institutions have no right to interfere in the foreign policy of Member States or the domestic affairs of non-EU countries.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which strongly condemns President Pierre Nkurunziza's desire to serve a third term in Burundi, contrary to the country's constitution. This will has already led to major clashes in the country and raised fears of further human rights obstructions and even genocide.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of this resolution. The constructive proposals to improve the situation in Burundi and the clear indications of the dangers that the country faces provide a good guideline for the EU's action in its relations with Burundi.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report, as it expresses concern regarding the grave security and political situation in Burundi and calls on the government to stop the violence against civil society. The EU and the whole international community have to react to the violation of fundamental human rights.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. In April 2015, President Nkurunziza announced that he would run for president for a third time, despite the country's constitution prohibiting it. Contrary to the recommendation of the international community, President Nkurunziza nevertheless ran for office, which he won in August. This has plunged the country into its deepest political and humanitarian crisis since the civil war. Since then, approximately 200 people have been killed and 200 forced to flee the country. The motion calls for an immediate cessation of violence and calls on the Government of Burundi to respect their obligations and guarantee the fulfilment of fundamental human rights.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I have decided to give a favourable opinion to this motion for a resolution on the serious situation in Burundi. Human rights violations have been taking place in that country for far too long, and given that relations between the EU and the country are governed by the Cotonou Agreement, which provides for strict respect for the former, we cannot wait for action. The Secretary-General of the United Nations, Ban Ki Moon, has presented three proposals to the Security Council in which he recommends a revision of the mandate of the UN presence in Burundi, in the light of developments in the situation, which we are all aware of, with this measure to urge the High Representative to coordinate the foreign policy of the Member States in order to re-establish respect for fundamental rights and the rule of law.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because the Union is interfering in the internal affairs of a sovereign state, with moreover whole passages that fall into neocolonialism.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. – Political violence, human rights violations, killings and torture in Burundi can turn into genocide and regional crisis, resulting in a deepening of the refugee crisis in the world.  More than 250 people have died in Burundi this year and 200,000 have already fled to neighbouring countries. The EU must use all diplomatic paths, including economic and economic measures, which will promptly lead to a halt to this inhumane action. At the same time, it is also necessary to look for ways and possibilities for resolving this conflict with the help of the UN.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I support the joint motion for a resolution on the situation in Burundi, both because it is complete and documented and because of the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech of 25/11/2015 to the plenary of the European Parliament.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ Growing insecurity, the lack of political moves towards reconciliation and worsening humanitarian conditions in Burundi – a country that tops the Global Hunger Index – means we should consider under the Cotonou Agreement the suspension of all EU aid to the Burundi Government. Instead, the EU and its Member States should re-direct non-humanitarian EU aid to civil society there.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I preferred to abstain on this text. I recognise that the current situation in Burundi is dramatic and that there is a risk of a flare-up for the whole region, but the proposals made by the European Parliament are unrealistic, even dangerous.  Although the positions taken by Rwandan President Paul Kagame are worrying, it still seems more reasonable to allow the African Union to act as a mediator, rather than imposing the European Commission as a gendarme, especially since this civil war has largely ethnic foundations that escape Brussels. We should not forget that the European Union tends to inflame the situation when it gets involved, as was the case in the Middle East or Ukraine. For Burundi's security, it would be preferable for the Commission to refrain from intervening and let local diplomats do their job.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. An immediate end to violence, human rights violations and political intimidation of opponents is, of course, to be welcomed. I therefore agree with the rc-B8-1348/2015 motion for a resolution.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this Motion for a Resolution which urges the government of Burundi to respect their obligations to guarantee fundamental rights under all international and regional human rights instruments and insists on the need to stop all violence and political intimidation.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. Last July, President Nkurunziza's bid for a third term and his subsequent re-election plunged Burundi into its worst political crisis since the end of the civil war. Paul Kagame's influence in Rwanda was felt. The opposition has been severely repressed, NGOs, journalists locked up or killed... an authoritarian drift in which more than 200 people have died and more than 200,000 people have been displaced.  The European Union triggered Article 96 of the Cotonou Agreement (consultations and possibly sanctions) and felt that the government's responses were not sufficient. The resolution denounces the violence and recalls the need for inter-Burundian dialogue and the Union's financial and humanitarian assistance to move towards a peaceful solution and disarmament.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in Burundi. The political and security situation in Burundi is very worrying, so the EU must do everything in its power to reverse this situation, particularly in terms of financial support and humanitarian aid to neighbouring countries, which have been taking in refugees from Burundi. The Government of Burundi must carry out the immediate disarmament of all armed groups.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this resolution as it calls for an immediate end to the violence in Burundi. I was also proud to sign this cross-party resolution as it also highlights the need for the Burundian constitution to be respected and as it enshrines the protection of human rights, civil and political rights and fundamental freedoms for the Burundian people.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. Burundi is on the brink of civil war following the events of the past few days and the dangerous, ambiguous, ethnic-like rhetoric of power. This political crisis, which is the most serious since 2005, is forcing the international community to position itself. I welcome the african Union Peace and Security Council's proposal to send a 5,000-strong force to Burundi. We are facing crimes against humanity, crimes under international law that cannot go unpunished.  We can no longer tolerate disproportionate violence, arbitrary arrests, extrajudicial abuses, abductions, destroyed media, gagged opposition, dismantled civil society, closed NGOs, etc. It will be up to the East African Rapid Reaction Force to protect the population and, beyond that, to help maintain the stability of the sub-region. For my part, we must move towards a transition that will eventually lead to new elections.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly condemn the ongoing killings and human rights violations as well as deplore the worsening humanitarian situation in Burundi, therefore I voted in favour of the final resolution which is calling for ending the violence and human rights abuses in Burundi. Furthermore, the Resolution agrees that it is of great importance to prevent a further deterioration of the situation, including through political dialogue between the government and the opposition, including civil society and ensuring accountability for the violations committed.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 Draft resolutions were submitted by the political groups ECR, Verts/ALE, PPE, S&D, ALDE, GUE/NGL and EFDD. The seven political groups have managed to reach a common position and draw up a compromise proposal. I supported the compromise proposal.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. Although I recognise that the current situation in Burundi is dramatic and that there is a risk of a flare-up for the whole region, the European Parliament is once again proposing unrealistic positions, wanting to make the European Commission the policeman of global problems. While the positions taken by Rwandan President Paul Kagame are worrying, it seems more reasonable to allow the African Union to mediate, especially since this civil war has, in large part, ethnic foundations. The European Union, through its repeated interference, tends to inflame the situation, as was the case in the Middle East or Ukraine, and it would be wiser in this case to rely on the diplomacy of sovereign states to reach a solution. So I voted against it.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on the situation in Burundi. This text recalls the large number of victims and cases of serious human rights violations that have been reported since the beginning of the crisis caused by President Nkurunziza's third term. It calls on all parties to establish the conditions for restoring trust and fostering national unity, and calls for the immediate resumption of an open and transparent national dialogue between the government, opposition parties and representatives of civil society.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I would have voted in favour of the RC-B8-1348/2015 resolution, as it calls for an immediate end to violence, human rights violations and political intimidation of opposition figures and is, of course, welcome.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Burundi is in a deep crisis, which requires cooperation between the African Union, the UN and the EU. At the same time, we must monitor the worsening humanitarian crisis and be prepared to respond adequately.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I support the proposal for a resolution condemning the current situation in Burundi regarding the president's attempts to win a third term as head of state. This resolution sends clear criticism to burundi's political leadership and calls for resolving the political crisis that has been going on in the state since July 2015. The Great Lakes region is known for its instability resulting from reduced power and the ability of states to contain local warlords with their security and military capabilities in an effort to establish control over local or regional areas.  Burundi's current situation threatens to threaten stability in the region and may utest into a new era of continuing conflicts. Many irregularities related to elections, media freedom, opposition action, respect for human rights and freedoms, and violations of international conventions and treaties and the Burundian constitution are of concern. The regime of current President Nkurunziza impedes the development path of Burundian society and it is necessary to encourage democratic change in this state.  As Burundi is one of the poorest countries in the world, it is necessary to increase the level of humanitarian action and donations to the Burundian population, but with appropriate monitoring mechanisms and guarantees that the aid offered is actually delivered to those in need. This resolution is clear in its formulation and I hope that it will actually result in changes.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. I recognize that the current situation in Burundi is dramatic and that there is a risk of a flare-up for the entire region. The European Parliament is once again proposing unrealistic positions, wanting to make the European Commission the policeman of global problems. While the positions taken by Rwandan President Paul Kagame are worrying, it seems more reasonable to allow the African Union to mediate, especially since this civil war has, in large part, ethnic foundations.  The European Union, through its repeated interference, tends to inflame the situation, as was the case in the Middle East or Ukraine, and it would be wiser in this case to rely on the diplomacy of sovereign states to reach a solution. So I voted against it.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ In the sub-subdignment, I support the opening of Article 96. cotonou agreements and concrete measures to stop existing and prevent further violence and human rights violations in Burundi, given the deteriorating political, humanitarian and security situation in the state, the refugee wave and the state repression of human rights organisations and the opposition.  If the UN and the Union will not act more convincingly and with more concrete moves in terms of sanctions and encouraging consultations and agreements between the authorities, the opposition and civil society, the violence will undoubtedly continue, if not worsen.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. – I support the proposal for a resolution on the situation in Burundi by Charles Tannock, Mark Demesmaeker, Raffaele Fitto and Notis Marias. As the situation in Burundi has deteriorated sharply in recent weeks and human rights have been repeatedly violated, and respect for human rights, democratic principles and the rule of law plays a key role in the EU-Burundi relations governed by the Cotonou Agreement, the EU is obliged to stand up for human rights and urge the establishment of a democratic order and the rule of law.  Failure to respect fundamental human rights, impeding the work of civilian institutions, violating media freedom have led to more than 200,000 people being displaced. As UN Security Council Resolution No 2013 2248. The Government of Burundi strongly urges the Government of Burundi to respect and protect human rights and freedoms and to agree to participate in mediation under the leadership of the African Union East African Community with a view to establishing dialogue within Burundi, I believe that this is the only effective solution to the current crisis.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 The ongoing wave of political and potentially ethnic violence has claimed the lives of 600 people since the beginning of the year, with another 220,000 forced to leave their homes. The EU has allocated an additional EUR 4.5 million to support these people. This resolution strongly calls on the Government of Burundi of Africa and the responsible authorities to immediately end the violence and stabilise the political and security situation. As a Social Democrat, I am glad that the resolution did not neglect to recall the responsibility of the ruling forces for respect for human and civil rights, which, according to all available information, are grossly violated, persecution, torture, even extrajudicial executions take place. The international community must take the situation in Burundi seriously, the escalation of the conflict and the ensuing migration crisis could have huge negative effects on the whole region.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The UN Special Rapporteurs stated on 13 November 2015 that the situation in Burundi continues to deteriorate. There are growing daily complaints about serious human rights violations by security forces, internal divisions, lack of dialogue between the different fighting parties in the country and the risk of a regional crisis. It is important to find a consensual and national solution to the current crisis. The Burundian Government must cooperate fully in mediation efforts in order to find a lasting and credible political solution, based on the principles of the Arusha peace agreement, and to restore a climate of peace and security to encourage the return of refugees. I voted in favour of this proposal, which also provides for the need to provide more rapid funds for aid to Burundian refugees who have fled to neighbouring countries.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Writing. \u2012 Burundi is facing another wave of deadly violence these days. Not only this country, but the entire region requires our strong attention and, of course, concrete support, given recent events. The world community has already failed once to prevent genocide in this region, and therefore Burundi and other states in this troubled region must not be forgotten.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on Burundi. The situation was still confused at the time of the vote on the death toll in Bujumbura. Since then, nearly 100 deaths have been confirmed. There is real concern about the situation in the country following President Pierre Nkurunziza's decision to run for a third term and his re-election after the July 21, 2015 election that plunged the country into its worst political crisis since the end of the civil war.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non-legislative and non-binding resolution. While of course we share deep concern over the unstable political situation and killings that have taken place, we cannot support calls for more EU interference. These issues should be handled between national governments and at the appropriate and legitimate international level, namely the United Nations. The un-elected and unaccountable EU institutions have no right to interfere in the foreign policy of Member States or the domestic affairs of non-EU countries.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. The political and security situation in Burundi has been worsening, and with it we have seen the rapid deterioration of the humanitarian situation and stability of the entire sub-region. We condemn recent violent attacks and the increase in cases of human rights violations and abuses, including killings, extrajudicial executions, attacks on the physical integrity of persons, acts of torture and other cruel, inhuman and degrading treatment or punishment, arbitrary arrests and illegal detentions, and violations of freedom of the press and expression. It is time for the European Union to act in accordance with the values it upholds and to put an end to the prevalence of impunity.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I co-signed this resolution, which was passed today and which expressed the European Parliament's great concern about the high level of insecurity and seriousness of the political situation in Burundi, as well as the rapid deterioration of the humanitarian situation and the consequences that could result for security and stability throughout the sub-region. The adopted text condemns recent violent attacks and increased human rights violations, including killings, extrajudicial executions, attacks on the physical integrity of persons, torture, arbitrary arrests and unlawful detentions, as well as violations of press freedom and freedom of expression, and general impunity.  The resolution also call for an immediate end to acts of violence, human rights violations and intimidation against opponents, as well as the immediate disarmament of all armed groups allied to political parties. The voted text also reminds the Burundian government that it has an obligation to ensure security on its territory and to guarantee fundamental, civil and political rights as well as fundamental freedoms, as stipulated in Burundi's Constitution and the African Charter of Human Rights.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. In April 2015, President Nkurunziza announced his candidacy for a third term, grossly violating Burundi's constitution and plunging the country into a deep political crisis since the end of the civil war.  Against all the recommendations of the international community, President Nkurunziza continued with the electoral process and was re-elected on 26 August 2015. Since then, Burundi has faced an unprecedented serious political, humanitarian and security crisis, the balance of which is tragic: more than 200 people have died and an estimated 200,000 refugees. This motion for a resolution, of which I am one of the signatories, stresses the need to put an end to the wave of political violence and intimidation, urging the Government of Burundi to respect its obligations to guarantee fundamental rights within the framework of all international and regional human rights instruments.  Finally, I leave a word of greeting for the mediation efforts made by the international community, as well as for the financial support provided by the European Union to deal with the current humanitarian crisis.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the situation in Burundi because I support the European Parliament's desire to promote and protect human rights, hindering all kinds of violence and political intimidation. The European Union urges the Government of Burundi to respect the obligation to guarantee fundamental rights to its citizens. In order to achieve these important objectives, the importance of dialogue and the search for consensus at regional level is also stressed.

name: György SCHÖPFLIN
text: Writing. In April 2015, President Nkurunziza announced that he would run for president for a third time, despite the country's constitution prohibiting it. Contrary to the recommendation of the international community, President Nkurunziza nevertheless ran for office, which he won in August. This has plunged the country into its deepest political and humanitarian crisis since the civil war. Since then, approximately 200 people have been killed and 200 forced to flee the country. The motion calls for an immediate cessation of violence and calls on the Government of Burundi to respect their obligations and guarantee the fulfilment of fundamental human rights. In agreement with the content of the motion, I voted in favour of its adoption.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this as it is not for the EU to get involved in foreign affairs.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly condemn the ongoing killings and violations of human rights and absolutely deplore the increasingly worse humanitarian situation in Burundi. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution not only because it calls for an end to the violence and human rights abuses, but it is also greatly important that we seek to prevent a further deterioration of the situation. We need to encourage political and civil dialogue between the government and the opposition; political dialogues that bring in the wider civil society and ensure accountability for the violations that have been committed. I urge, along with my colleagues in this chamber, the Security Council to follow its resolution with concrete steps to stop these abuses to fundamental rights and prevent this conflict from escalating any further.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The security situation in Burundi has deteriorated significantly in recent days following attacks on three military camps. Burundian security forces killed at least 87 people on December 11 and 12, 2015, and many of those killings show signs of accidental killings. Burundi is one of the least developed countries in the world and is at the top of the World Hunger Index, with up to 67% of people living below the poverty line. The political situation in this state is also in crisis, human rights and electoral laws are not respected. This is also why more than 200 000 people are displaced or seeking refuge in neighbouring countries as a result of the worsening political situation in Burundi. The EP resolution on the situation in Burundi calls on the EU and the Member States, in the light of developments, to consider freezing all inhumane aid provided to the Burundian Government until government forces stop the excessive use of force and human rights violations recorded by the Office of the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights and a political solution is found in order to strengthen civil society. The EU should address the fundamental problems of poverty inequality and chronic malnutrition.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. In recent days following attacks on three military camps in the capital Bujumbura, the security situation in Burundi has deteriorated sharply. Burundian security forces killed at least 87 people on 11 and 12 December 2015. Before that, in the summer of 2015, local elections were held first, and then presidential elections.  According to the Office of the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights and other human rights organisations, politically motivated abuses and human rights violations and acts of violence are alleged to have been carried out in the country in the run-up to and after the elections. These actions were pointed at opposition activists, human rights defenders and, in particular, journalists.  More than 200,000 people are displaced as a result of the deteriorating political situation in Burundi. For the displaced population, the EU stepped up humanitarian aid in July 2015 and allocated an additional EUR 4.5 million. The joint motion for a resolution on the situation in Burundi calls for an immediate end to violence, violations of human rights and political intimidation of opponents and for the immediate disarmament of all armed groups linked to political parties, which must be fully in line with international law and human rights.  It is essential that all parties establish the necessary conditions to restore trust and promote national unity. For the sake of the above, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ In recent weeks, the situation in Burundi has deteriorated sharply and security forces in the country continue to violate human rights without fear of punishment.  November 13, 2015 The UN Special Envoy for Burundi said the situation in Burundi is deteriorating and that human rights are being seriously violated on a daily basis, including extrajudgial killings, arbitrary arrests and detentions, torture, attacks on media independence and harassment and killings of human rights defenders, including unfounded restrictions on the right to peaceful assembly and expression, and more than 200,000 people have been displaced as a result of the violence.  I express my deep concern at the growing human rights violations and violence in Burundi, the growing divisions in society and the lack of dialogue among Burundian stakeholders and the risk of a regional crisis breaking out, and I call on all parties in Burundi to stop the spiral of violence.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. Burundi signed the Peace and Reconciliation Agreement signed an agreement hinging that the president could serve only two terms. After President Pierre Nkurunziza served two terms, he announced on April 26, 2015 that he would run for a third term. Based on the results of August 26, 2015, he was declared the winner, leading the country to its biggest political crisis since the end of the civil war.  Due to unrest in the state, police used excessive force to suppress peaceful protests, killing 129 people. On May 28th of the same year, the EU suspended the EOM because the minimum conditions for democratic elections were not met. The international community does not consider the elections valid. The political stalemate in the state and the deteriorating security and economic situation have dire consequences for the population and threaten the stability of the entire region. I support the resolution on the situation in Burundi because I think it is necessary to protect human rights, punish politically motivated violence, summary executions and extrajudial killings, arbitrary arrests and detentions. Burundi, along with Rwanda and Congo, was one of the first countries in the region to start holding elections, and should therefore serve as an example of respect for the international and constitutional order necessary for the sustainability of democratisation, peace and development in the region.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the motion for a joint resolution on the situation in Burundi. The situation in Burundi has deteriorated dramatically in recent days, with Burundian security forces killing at least 87 people. According to the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights and other human rights organisations, politically motivated abuses and human rights violations and acts of violence against opposition activists, human rights defenders and, in particular, journalists have been carried out in the period before and after the elections. I support the call for an immediate end to violence, violations of human rights and political intimidation of opponents and for the immediate disarmament of all armed groups linked to political parties, which must be fully in line with international law and human rights.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. Burundi served, like most other African countries, a colony of the Germans and the Belgians in this regard. After colonial exploitation, the transition to freedom and democracy did not take place smoothly. In particular, the Hutu and Tutsi differences are still aching the country. The current regime is far from being classified as the rule of law. The country's Constitution has been dissolved, there is no welfare state and there is no respect for human, civil and political rights and fundamental freedoms. It needs an immediate restoration of peace and calm. An optimal and urgent solution is needed in view of the deteriorating humanitarian situation and it is necessary, in order to protect the Christian population exceeding 60% of the total, the mission under the UN High Commissioner for Peace Enforcement and Peace Keeping Force.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a resolution because I am convinced that, after the UN, the AU and other international factors, the EU, the European Parliament, must also strongly call on the opposing political actors in Burundi to end the armed violence with serious consequences. On the basis of the facts recalled in the report, I am particularly concerned about the risk of an escalation of internal conflict throughout the Great Lakes, which could increase the already massive wave of refugees to an unmanageable size for neighbouring countries. Moreover, I believe that the European Union, as the largest local donor and one of the leading forces in the international community, cannot stand idly by in the face of the humanitarian catastrophe caused by the violence in Burundi. On the basis of international solidarity, I consider urgent international action necessary, in particular because of the very high proportion of children among the victims and even armed actors of the conflict in Burundi. From this EP resolution, I therefore hope that it will provide the High Representative with a strong political backdrop for a more effective EU contribution in order to prevent further deterioration of the security and humanitarian situation in Burundi in order to end the violence.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is one of the main supporters of human rights and fundamental freedoms worldwide. The Union also places particular emphasis on the development of democratic practices and the rule of law in the various countries of the world.  Burundi is a developing African state, where these values promoted by the EU are threatened by the current regime in power. Specifically, we are talking about an ongoing humanitarian catastrophe, with 200,000 refugees in neighbouring countries and around 250 people killed later this year. Also, opponents of the regime and human rights activists are threatened, punished and even killed, their organisations being disbanded. The situation thus created is likely to threaten the security of the entire East African area and generate a new outbreak of immigration.  The UN Security Council has already adopted a resolution calling on the government in office to remedy the situation quickly, but this has not happened so far. The EU has introduced a series of sanctions against the current Burundian president's close associates under Article 96 of the Cotonou Agreement. However, the measures taken may prove insufficient, and if dialogue is not a solution, sending peacekeepers is the last resort.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. In recent months, we have witnessed escalating violence in Burundi. In musical terms, a crescendo often heralds an apotheosis. The one we are seeing now materializes in your country is far from lyrical. On the contrary, it is a chronicle of an announced chaos. The massacres continue and take on a frightening dimension. Your citizens, by the dozens, were killed last weekend in numerous arbitrary executions. Burundi has taken another step towards its decline. Increasingly violent and increasingly targeted, confrontations with the opposition ended in a real bloodbath on the streets of Bujumbura. Have we learned nothing from Rwanda? Do we not see the same calls for hatred and the same search for a scapegoat? was still indignifying my colleague Arena lately!

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as I am deeply concerned by the grave security and political situation in Burundi, the rapidly worsening humanitarian situation and the consequences that this may have for security and stability in the entire sub-region. By voting for this text I call for an immediate end to violence, human rights violations and political intimidation of opponents, and for the immediate disarmament of all armed groups allied to political parties, in strict accordance with international law and human rights. In this respect I urge all parties to establish the necessary conditions for rebuilding trust and fostering national unity, and call for the immediate resumption of an inclusive and transparent national dialogue.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒This resolution builds on the High Commissioner's statement dated 25/11 this year. The situation in Burundi has deteriorated significantly in recent weeks - security forces are in increasingly crude ways violating the fundamental human rights of Burundian citizens with impunity. At least 240 people have been killed and 210,000 people have moved out of the country since President Nkurunziza made the controversial decision to extend his presidential term. In addition, I support the call in this resolution, which leads to a solution to the crisis being agreed within Burundi and for the same to be based on consensus. Accordingly, all political parties in Burundi are calling for an end to violence and the start of dialogue.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. - I supported the motion for a resolution on the situation in Burundi (2015/2973(RSP)) because, in the current tightening situation in that country, it is necessary to establish an effective policy in order to prevent a regional crisis. I also support the deployment of human rights observers and military experts in Burundi, as serious violations of human rights and fundamental freedoms are taking place in this country.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I express with this vote my deep concern at the rise in human rights abuses and violence in Burundi, the widening divisions and lack of dialogue among Burundian stakeholders, and the threat of a regional crisis; I urge the Burundian Government to fully cooperate with the mediation efforts led by the EAC in order to achieve a lasting political solution through a credible and inclusive inter-Burundian dialogue based on the principles of the Arusha peace agreement, and to restore a peaceful and secure environment to encourage the return of refugees; I welcome the decision by the African Union Peace and Security Council to launch an in-depth investigation into the violations of human rights and other abuses against civilians in Burundi and to deploy additional human rights observers and military experts. Let me remind the authorities that Burundi is a State Party to the International Criminal Court (ICC) and has taken on the obligation to fight impunity for crimes falling within its jurisdiction.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. This resolution follows developments in Burundi's dangerous situation today, but the terms of this resolution are yet another interference in the internal affairs of a sovereign state with whole passages that will be taken as neo-colonialism. I'm voting against it.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. The security situation in Burundi has deteriorated considerably in recent days following the attacks on three military camps in Bujumbura. Burundian security forces killed at least 87 people on December 11 and 12, 2015; there appear to have been many indiscriminate executions among these killings. The Government of Burundi ignored the decisions and recommendations adopted by the AU and the East African Community (EAC) on 13 June 2015 and 6 July 2015, the full implementation of which would have paved the way for credible and society-wide elections. I supported the decision of the S&D group.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution concerning the worsening situation in Burundi, where more than 400 people have been killed since President Pierre Nkurunziza decided to run for a controversial third term, earlier this year. Violence has put in serious danger the peace and stability of the country and of the wider region. This political crisis, the worst since 2005, forces the international community to take action. I also supported the proposal of the Council of Peace and Security of the African Union to send a force of 5 000 men to Burundi. We are dealing with crimes against humanity and we need to react swiftly. I also agree that the EU and its Member States must freeze all assistance to the Burundian Government and in the resolution we also invite all parties concerned to end hostilities through dialogue, which we are ready to fully support.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. We are talking about a resolution calling for an end to violence in Burundi and for the Government to respect its human rights obligations. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: in writing. – The resolution invites all parties concerned to talk, and we are ready to fully support it. But haven’t we gone beyond the moment where talks can be held as if nothing has happened? Blood is in the streets. Armed forces are arbitrarily killing their own fellow citizens. It is clear Burundi has reached a stage of deep chaos, where fundamental rights are of no importance. As a liberal, I cannot accept this. The EU and its Member States must freeze all assistance to the Burundian Government, while continuing to support the civil population in these dire days of political and humanitarian turmoil. We must also stand ready to support an African-led peace-keeping operation, to bring stability again. Otherwise Burundi, because of the unreasonable power struggle by its President Nkurunziza, will sink away into violent trouble and risk infecting the entire Central African region.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. Between 2013 and 2014, Burundi dropped from 178th to 180th place in the UNDP ranking in terms of the human development index. Currently, four out of five people in Burundi live on less than $1.25 a day and 66.9% of the population lives below the poverty line. The situation in Burundi is worrying and could have disastrous consequences for the whole region. The current crisis can only be resolved through political dialogue at national and regional level, and should under no circumstances serve as a pretext for further military intervention in the region. In this sense, we expect the EU to maintain development aid and refrain from any imperial conditionality, which will only help to reignite conflicts rather than resolve them.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. An immediate end to violence, human rights violations and political intimidation of opponents is, of course, to be welcomed. I therefore agree with the rc-B8-1348/2015 motion for a resolution.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution is a clear example of how skewed and partially skewed and partially how so many other resolutions are promoted and voted on in the European Parliament, responding to the economic and political interests of the major powers of the European Union, without looking at the means, distorting reality and twisting it to the version that suits it best to fuel the destabilisation of a country. The deplorable text presented does everything to affirm a unilateral vision of a democratically elected regime, with strong popular support, and which has affirmed a vision of development of the country that does not serve the interests of capital. Omit that the "fighters for democracy", which feeds through the mechanisms for EU democracy, are a relevant part of the conflicts that take place there, promoting aggression and murder, spreading fear in the population. It distorts events promoted by these movements, attributing them to government forces – movements associated with terrorism and trafficking, which serve the interests of the EU, which has fertile and desirable soil in the great lakes for the exploitation of ores by European industry. An unacceptable text, imbued with hatred and intentions of interference, over a country and a sovereign government. We voted against it.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur Virunga National Park is the oldest on the African continent and the richest species there. Unfortunately, although it has been on the UNESCO World Heritage List since 1979, this park is under constant threat. In 2007, the local government granted concessions for exploration of oil stocks in 85% of the park area. In the neighbouring central African region, there have been bloody conflicts for many years, while edge hunting against species living in the park has been going on for decades. In addition, over the last ten years, more than 140 supervisors were killed in the park, performing their duties. I am delighted by the fact that we MEPs are in favour of preserving a unique natural heritage and, of course, I voted in favour with both hands.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Virunga Mountains National Park has been considered a World Heritage Site by UNESCO since 1994. A WWF report has shown that the biodiversity of the Park is at risk due to illegal activities carried out by poachers and foreign multinationals interested in significant mineral resources. The protection of the oldest and richest park in the Republic of Congo is a fundamental tool not only for the preservation of an invaluable environmental heritage, but also for the protection of a substantial source of livelihood for the local and indigenous population. I voted in favour of the report on the protection of the Virunga National Park because I believe it is essential not only necessary to intervene in the protection of such an environmental heritage against reckless human actions.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. Virunga is the oldest national park in Africa, but despite its status as a protected natural space, it has suffered for decades from the threat of armed groups engaged in poaching, illegal logging and other forms of illegal exploitation of resources, leading to its inclusion in the World Heritage List in danger. This report stresses that irreversible damage could be caused as a result of oil exploration and exploitation; considering it unacceptable that concessions in the park were granted in 2007 to the French oil company TOTAL and the British SOCO International, thus transgressing the Paris Convention, the 1992 Convention on Biological Diversity, the Ramsar Convention and Congolese law itself. Since this Resolution calls for legally binding measures to bring to justice companies that have circumvented national laws and international treaties, and calls for the development as much as possible of a comprehensive protection strategy for this park, including the fight against corruption and the investigation of acts of violence committed against active human rights defenders in the DRC , I voted in favour.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP abstained on this non-legislative and non—binding resolution. While of course UKIP shares great concern over the exploration for oil in this national park with the possible serious ramifications for protected animals and the environment, and while we would urge the DRC to comply with international law on protected sites, we cannot support the EU being involved. This issue should be handled through negotiations between national governments and at the appropriate and legitimate international level, namely the United Nations. The un-elected and unaccountable EU institutions have no right to interfere in the foreign policy of Member States or the domestic affairs of non-EU countries.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. The Virunga National Park, located in the Democratic Republic of Congo, has been a UNESCO-listed park since 1979 and is a true "ecological sanctuary". Today, the park is strongly threatened by more than twenty armed groups (fighting, deforestation, poaching) but also by the exploration of large oil companies and especially by that of the international company SOCO. I have spoken in favour of this motion for a resolution which aims to stop SOCO international's activities in the park, restore security in the area through the disarmament of the rebels and call on the Commission to take measures to counter companies that do not comply with existing laws and treaties.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. – The Virunga National Park is a UNESCO World Heritage Site in the east of the Democratic Republic of Congo, and is Africa’s most biodiverse park. Sadly, the region the Park lies in is ravaged by civil war, lawlessness, poaching and corruption. Irreversible damage could also be done to the park as a result of exploration and exploitation of oil in and near the Park, particularly by British oil company SOCO International. This resolution calls for a diplomatic response to the challenges facing the park, including the economic and social factors that place the park under extra strain. It aims to protect and support both the integrity of the park and the endangered species in it, as well as the livelihoods and human rights of people living beside it and the rangers who work in it. The resolution also calls for greater pressure to be placed on companies that breach international laws and human rights while seeking to illegally exploit the resources of the park. I therefore voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. Virunga Park is the oldest natural park on the African continent. Its surface area is 790,000 hectares. Listed as a Unesco World Heritage Site, the park is now threatened by the presence of armed groups that not only fight against the regular Congolese army but also take advantage of it to poach. It is also threatened by the presence of the oil company SOCO International, which obtained the concession of 85% of the park at the decision of the DRC government.  In the last ten years, nearly 140 guards have died and the Prince of Merode, linked to the Belgian royal family, has been seriously injured. The motion for a resolution referred to here calls for an end to surveys in the park and the disarmament of armed groups. Both of these demands are legitimate, so I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I note that this vote was not subject to a roll-call vote in the Parliament.  In the interests of democracy and transparency, I believe that it is important for me to highlight how I voted on this issue. I chose to abstain on this matter; whilst agreeing with many of the concerns raised within the report, the EU is not the appropriate forum for these.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. Virunga National Park, located on the border with Rwanda and Uganda, is Africa's oldest national park and a UNESCO World Heritage Site known globally for its unique habitats and its rich biodiversity, which makes it the largest biodiversity in Africa.
