Armed groups that are engaged in poaching, deforestation for decades, threaten the park. At the same time, oil fever could have serious social and destabilising effects, given mass poverty, unstable situations, poor governance and regional insecurity.  I support the calls for the European External Action Service to coordinate the diplomatic response of EU Member States and other potential donors in the DRC to help the DRC government refuse to explore for oil and extract it in the territory of Virunga Park and other UNESCO World Heritage Sites in Congo. I support the calls on the Commission and the Member States to ensure the integrity of the park area, for example by increasing their commitments to finance the sustainable preservation of cultural heritage and sustainable economic development and diversification in the region around them.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. Located in eastern DRC, on the border of Rwanda and Uganda, it is the oldest natural park on the African continent. This 790,000-hectare "ecological sanctuary" listed by UNESCO since 1979 is threatened both by armed groups (more than twenty) who, in addition to fighting with the regular army, engage in poaching, deforestation and "other illegal and unsustainable forms of resource exploitation" but also and above all by the prospecting carried out by the company SOCO International , to which the DRC government has granted oil concessions encompassing 85% of the park's surface area. Total is also exploring in the area but would have fulfilled its commitment not to prospect within the park. Of the many endangered species that inhabit this park, the most emblematic is that of mountain gorillas. More than 140 guards have been killed in the service over the past ten years and its director, Prince Emmanuel de Merode, was himself seriously injured on 15 April 2014. For once, the interference of the European Union and its Member States seems to me to be desirable and I voted in favour of this balanced text.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The Virunga National Park in North Kivu is a UNESCO-listed site for its habitats and the richness of its biodiversity unmatched in Africa. The resolution, which I supported, stresses that the park is subject to several dangers. It has been the scene of violent conflicts for more than 20 years and has been poached and illegally exploited by mineral and natural resources. In addition, since 2007, oil concessions encompassing more than 85% of the fleet have been granted to TOTAL and SOCO, the latter being the only company to have prospected the park to date. Parliament therefore calls for every effort to be made to prevent irreversible damage to the park.  In particular, it urges the Commission and Member States to work to preserve the integrity of the park by strengthening their commitment to finance the preservation, economic development and sustainable diversification of the surrounding region and calls on the EEAS to take diplomatic action to help the Congolese government abandon oil exploration and exploitation in the park.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this Resolution on Virunga National Park, a UNESCO World Heritage Site and a more diverse park in Africa, as we consider it important that the European Union and the Member States coordinate joint and effective actions to address the problems of violence arising from the fight for the park's natural resources. The Resolution also urges urgent action to ensure the responsibility of extractive companies in the area and compliance with international standards in social, environmental and human rights matters.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I would like to thank the rapporteur for the work she has done to negotiate this Resolution on the protection of Virunga National Park in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. It refers to the absolute need to avoid irreversible damage to this park that was designated a World Heritage Site by Unesco in 1979 and a World Heritage Site in 1994. I am also sorry that the park has become one of the most dangerous places in the world when it comes to wildlife conservation.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The Virunga National Park in Congo is the oldest natural park in Africa. It is threatened by deforestation, poaching of armed groups and oil exploration by SOCO (out of 85% of the park). Many animal species are threatened. The resolution calls on SOCO to cease all oil exploration, the DRC government to disarm the rebels and respect press freedom and finally to defend human rights and to take binding measures against companies that circumvent national laws and international treaties. So I voted for this text.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report is largely acceptable but some aspects are developed ambiguously and could open up to critical issues, so I abstained.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this resolution because it has been advocated by Parliament for the protection of virunga national park of the Democratic Republic of Congo. Virunga National Park (MSP) in the Northern Kivu and Eastern provinces of the DRC is Africa's oldest national park and a UNESCO World Heritage Site known globally for its unique habitats and its rich biodiversity, which makes it the largest biodiversity in Africa. The park is primarily known for its mountain gorillas, a rapidly endangered species. However, armed groups that are engaged in poaching, deforestation and other unsustainable and illegal use of natural resources have been threatening the park for decades, regardless of its protected natural status, which has led to Virunga being listed as a World Heritage Site. In 2007, the DRC government granted oil concessions for 85% of the park area, while SOCO International plc (SOCO) is by far the only company to carry out exploration activities in the park. Notwithstanding the DRC legislation prohibiting environmentally harmful activities in protected areas, soco exploration licences are exempted from this legislation, which allows 'scientific activities' to be carried out in protected areas. In its resolution, Parliament called for the irreparable damage that may be caused to the Virunga National Park and expressed regret at the fact that virunga national park has also become one of the world's most at-risk places in terms of wildlife conservation.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 The protection of the natural environment plays a prominent role in ensuring sustainable development. The motion for a resolution calls for the need to prevent irreversible damage to Virunga National Park, which was declared a World Heritage Site by UNESCO in 1979 and a world heritage site at risk in 1994. The motion seeks to draw attention to the fact that illegal activity exploring and extracting oil fields could cause irreversible damage to Virunga National Park. It also considers it unacceptable that the French oil company TOTAL and the British oil company SOCO International have won oil production rights in the national park, thus violating a number of international conventions.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 Virunga National Park, in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, is the oldest in Africa, recognized as a World Heritage Site by UNESCO for its habitats and rich biodiversity. Its 790,000 hectares of land produce an economic value of about $48.9 million per year, thus consiting a huge development opportunity for the local community, especially tourism.  Although state laws prohibit harmful activities in protected areas, the sustainable conservation of the park is threatened by a particular derogation in the legislation that leaves room for the possibility of downgrading the area, in whole or in part, for the purposes of oil drilling. In addition, the territory is the subject of continuous and illegal exploitation of natural resources by armed groups, poaching and deforestation, with strong repression of human rights activists and journalists.  The European Union must, through its diplomatic action, help the Republic of Congo to renounce the redefinition of borders and the purpose of the park by supporting the state in developing sustainable energy and economic solutions to preserve its integrity. For these reasons, I wholeheartedly support the European Parliament's resolution.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Virunga National Park, located in northern Kivu Province and the Eastern Province of the Democratic Republic of the Congo, bordering Rwanda and Uganda, is Africa's oldest national park, a UNESCO World Heritage Site and known worldwide for its extraordinary habitats and rich biodiversity, the highest of all African parks.  In addition, the park is famous for its mountain gorillas, a severely endangered species listed in Appendix I to the 1973 Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES). According to the Convention on Biological Diversity, signed and ratified by the Democratic Republic of Congo, the preservation of biological diversity is a problem common to all mankind and is an integral part of the development process: the Convention is legally binding and the signatories are required to implement its provisions.  Despite this, the territory has been threatened for years by armed groups dedicated to poaching, deforestation and other unsustainable and illegal forms of exploitation of the resources that endanger it. The EU must work with its partners to pacify the area and preserve this unique, valuable and extremely infrastructureed environmental resource.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 Virunga National Park (PPV) is africa's oldest national park and is a UNESCO World Heritage Site, and is world-renowned for its unique, most biodiversity-based habitats in Africa. Currently, concessions have been negotiated between the DRC and SOCO (British) and TOTAL (French) in the protected area of the park, which is unacceptable, as irreversible damage will occur in the PVR as a result of oil exploitation. Furthermore, those agreements were made in breach of the Paris Convention on the Protection of The World Cultural and Natural Heritage, the 1992 Convention on Biological Diversity, the Ramsar Convention and Congolese Law. Knowing that PNV currently generates an annual economic value equivalent to USD 48.9 million, and in a stable situation, the park could contribute to economic growth and tourism development and generate an annual value of USD 1 billion, creating 45,000 jobs, I encourage the European External Action Service to take all necessary measures to ensure that SOCO International PLC and its branch in the DRC publicly commit to permanently cease all activities of exploration and exploitation of resources in Virunga Park. I opted to vote in favour of this resolution.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Abstention. The resolution denounces the fact that the DRC has granted some EU oil companies a licence to prospect and extract within the borders of the famous UNESCO-listed Virunga National Park and calls on the EEAS to take action to prevent the park from being derecied. While we agree with the denunciation of the fact itself, we do not see what title and reason the EU has for meddling in the internal affairs of a sovereign state.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. – UKIP abstained on this non-legislative and non-binding resolution. While of course UKIP shares great concern over the exploration for oil in this national park with the possible serious ramifications for protected animals and the environment, and while we would urge the DRC to comply with international law on protected sites, we cannot support the EU being involved. This issue should be handled through negotiations between national governments and at the appropriate and legitimate international level, namely the United Nations. The un-elected and unaccountable EU institutions have no right to interfere in the foreign policy of Member States or the domestic affairs of non-EU countries.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution as we need to do everything we can in order to stop any further damage to the Virunga National Park which is one of the UNESCO World Heritage Sites. It is a site of exploitation of oil and other illegal activities which damage the environment irreversibly and are a threat to many animal species.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 Virunga National Park, founded in 1925 and recognized as a UNESCO World Heritage Site, is Africa's oldest and most biodiversity-rich park. There are no ethnic Congolese representatives among the shareholders of Virunga SARL (neither government, nor civil society or NGOs), although the importance of the park is also known for the livelihood of the local population.  The report calls, among other things, on the EEAS to do everything possible to prevent the exploitation of the park's natural resources. Maintaining it could also create more than 45,000 jobs.  I certainly voted in favour of this report.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the resolution because it stresses, inter alia, that EU Member States have a duty, in accordance with international and European human rights law, to ensure that companies operating within their jurisdiction do not cause or contribute to human rights violations, directly or indirectly, through their business activities. The same companies are also invited to act in accordance with approved codes of conduct and the social and environmental performance standards they set, as well as in accordance with instruments such as ILO Convention 169, THE OECD Guidelines on Multinational Enterprises and the United Nations Guidelines on Business and Human Rights.; We also agree with the resolution because it calls on the Commission and the Member States to take legally binding measures to effectively account for companies that have proved to have circumvented national law and international treaties. Another positive element of the resolution is its call to the Commission, the Member States, the Democratic Republic of Congo and the oil companies interested in oil drilling on the need to protect the current boundaries and neighbouring areas of Virunga Park from the exploitation of fossil fuels.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution on the protection of Virunga National Park in the Republic of Congo is a very positive initiative aimed only at ensuring the preservation of a UNESCO-protected World Heritage Site. As the risks of overexploitation of the region are great, any attempt to protect it should be supported. That is why I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution for the protection of Virunga Park in the Democratic Republic of Congo. The park in question is africa's oldest national park, a UNESCO World Heritage Site and known worldwide for its extraordinary habitats and rich biodiversity. For over 20 years the park and its vicinity have been the scene of violent clashes and illegal mining, the illegal exploitation of its natural resources and poaching of endangered animals, as well as other forms of illegal trade in natural resources, in particular, have financed both the rebels and the official army thus also affecting the harmony of the park itself. I believe that, in this area, the European Union must fight by stressing the absolute need to prevent irreversible damage to the park, and also to ensure the preservation of biodiversity, which is a problem common to all humanity and is an integral part of the development process. That is why I am in favour of this proposal.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ The DEVE Committee resolution, among other things, stresses the absolute need to prevent irreversible damage to the Virunga National Park (VPN), which was designated by UNESCO as a World Heritage Site in 1979, and as a World Heritage Site in Danger in 1994; deplores that the VNP has also become one of the most dangerous places in the world when it comes to wildlife conservation; emphasises that irreversible damage to the VNP could occur as a result of exploration and exploitation of oil or other illegal activities; calls on the Commission and the Member States to further address, in an effective manner, the root causes of armed conflicts and corruption, to support sustainable development and peace-building strategies and projects in the VNP and in the surrounding region; and urges the Commission, the Member States, the Democratic Republic of Congo and the oil companies interested in drilling for oil to protect the current borders and neighbouring areas of the VNP from the exploitation of fossil fuels.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 Virunga National Park is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and is known worldwide for its extraordinary habitats and rich biodiversity. In addition to having a genuine natural heritage, Virunga National Park now produces an annual economic value of $48.9 million: in a stable situation, it could contribute to growth both economically and tourism and produce a value of one billion dollars a year and create 45 000 jobs. Given that, despite its status as a protected natural area, the park has been threatened for years by armed groups dedicated to poaching, deforestation, other unsustainable and illegal forms of resource exploitation – so much so that it has been included in the list of sites declared a world heritage site in danger – I agree with the implementation of actions to protect and protect it.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. – The oldest national park, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, which is globally renowned for its unique habitats and rich biodiversity, making it the most biodiverse park in Africa is a common heritage protected under the Convention on Biological Diversity. The protection of this site is a common concern of humankind and is an integral part of the development process. We have a Convention, which is legally binding, obliging its signatories to implement its provisions, amongst them the issue of oil exploitation in the DRC which is still hampered with an obvious weakness vis-à-vis private actors added to ongoing conflicts of interests. I agree with this motion in calling upon the European External Action Service to coordinate a diplomatic response from the EU Member States. I agree that the Commission and the Member States should uphold the integrity of the Park and support the DRC government in developing sustainable energy and economic alternatives to extractive industries, in improving governance, and in combating poaching, illegal logging, illegal mining and corruption, which are persistent phenomena that risk causing irreversible damage to the Park, which, as I said, is of common concern to humankind.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 What is happening at Virunga Park is of absolute gravity. The exploitation of oil fields is causing irreparable damage to the park, which has become one of the most dangerous places in the world in terms of the conservation of wild species.  Let us remember that this is the Park with the greatest biodiversity in Africa and it is a UNESCO World Heritage Site, its value is invaluable and could create over 45,000 jobs. However, the current situation sees perpetual armed conflicts and corruption, factors that do not allow sustainable environmental and economic development.  The resolution aims to highlight the importance of the park for the livelihood of local populations and indigenous peoples living in neighbouring areas, calling for an end to the exploitation of natural resources. In view of the condition which is destroying the enormous wealth of Virunga Park, I can only vote in favour of the resolution before us.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. Virunga is the oldest national park in Africa, but despite its status as a protected natural space, it has suffered for decades from the threat of armed groups engaged in poaching, illegal logging and other forms of illegal exploitation of resources, leading to its inclusion in the World Heritage List in danger. This report stresses that irreversible damage could be caused as a result of oil exploration and exploitation; considering it unacceptable that concessions in the park were granted in 2007 to the French oil company TOTAL and the British SOCO International, thus transgressing the Paris Convention, the 1992 Convention on Biological Diversity, the Ramsar Convention and Congolese law itself. Since this Resolution calls for legally binding measures to bring to justice companies that have circumvented national laws and international treaties, and calls for the development as much as possible of a comprehensive protection strategy for this park, including the fight against corruption and the investigation of acts of violence committed against active human rights defenders in the DRC , I voted in favour.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ Africa's oldest national park, Virunga, in Congo (a UNESCO world heritage site) is under threat because of the conflict situation in the surrounding region and the situation of illegal mining, illegal exploitation of natural resources such as timber, charcoal etc. and the poaching and trade of endangered animals. The report urges the Commission, member states and the EU’s diplomatic arm to exert the needed pressures on a multitude of levels to see for the protection of this UNESCO world heritage site. As I believe that we should all be responsible for protecting and preserving the environment I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. In this resolution, the European Parliament stresses the paramount importance of protecting Virunga National Park in the Democratic Republic of Congo from irreversible damage. Listed as a World Heritage Site in 1979 by UNESCO, Virunga National Park has been considered an "endangered" World Heritage Site since 1994.  MEPs regret that the exploitation and extraction activities of oil companies result in the park being classified as one of the most dangerous areas in terms of wildlife conservation. They call on Member States and the European Commission to step up their efforts to help the country address the root causes of the country's development, namely corruption and armed conflict. In support of these objectives, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. – UKIP abstained on this non-legislative and non-binding resolution. While of course UKIP shares great concern over the exploration for oil in this national park with the possible serious ramifications for protected animals and the environment, and while we would urge the DRC to comply with international law on protected sites, we cannot support the EU being involved. This issue should be handled through negotiations between national governments and at the appropriate and legitimate international level, namely the United Nations. The un-elected and unaccountable EU institutions have no right to interfere in the foreign policy of Member States or the domestic affairs of non-EU countries.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 Almost a third of sites considered natural heritage are threatened by mining operations or the drilling of energy companies. These areas are the only reserve where species close to extinction can survive Among the places most at risk, according to the WWF, there is also Virunga National Park in the Democratic Republic of Congo.  This is the park with one of the richest and most fragile ecosystems on the planet, home to some of the last mountain gorilla specimens (Gorilla beringei beringei), a species strongly threatened by poaching, civil war and now oil extraction.  I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because I believe that the defence of these unique ecosystems is of fundamental importance to the whole of humanity.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I supported this resolution stressing the absolute need to avoid irreversible damage to the UNESCO World Heritage-listed Virunga National Park. Unfortunately, it has become one of the most dangerous places in the world for wildlife conservation. The park is the scene of intensive poaching, illegal logging, illegal mining, corruption, rape and murder. In the past ten years, more than 150 rangers have been killed in the line of duty. Not to mention death threats, intimidation, arbitrary arrests against all those who denounce the impotence of the state or the lust of oil companies.  I also express my deep concern at the irreversible damage that could be caused to Virunga National Park as a result of oil exploration and exploitation and I call for measures to help protect the park, which is one of the last gorilla reserves, to address the root causes of armed conflict and corruption, and to support sustainable development and peace-building strategies in the Democratic Republic of Congo.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I am bewildered to read what is happening in Virunga National Park. I have no explanation for how European countries offer money to rebels, understand terrorists, so that they can more easily reach the oil reserves in this park.  More recently, we have witnessed a UN conference on climate issues in Paris, it has reached an agreement for the first time to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions. And at the same time, two oil companies are helping to extinction one National Park. I can't let that happen.  That is why I support this motion for a resolution and I sincerely hope that it will not only remain on a piece of paper, but that there will be real action and that these barbaric acts in Virunga will cease. We don't have anything stronger than nature, and I hope she doesn't get revenge someday.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 It is the obligation of each country to respect the environment and to take all necessary actions to preserve it, especially in the case of areas designated as World Heritage Sites.  However, I find it unacceptable that the EU should try to intervene in a country's internal affairs, especially when it comes to exploiting its natural resources to develop its economy, at a time when companies in its Member States are responsible for major natural disasters worldwide.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution calls for irreversible damage to virunga national park, which was declared a World Heritage Site by UNESCO in 1979 and a World Heritage Site at risk in 1994, absolutely necessary.  The motion seeks to draw attention to the fact that illegal activity exploring and extracting oil fields could cause irreversible damage to Virunga National Park. It also considers it unacceptable that the French oil company TOTAL and the British oil company SOCO International have won oil production rights in the national park, thus violating a number of international conventions.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, because it goes in the direction of better protection of a remarkable natural space.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. The Virunga National Park (PNV) was classified as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1979 and as a world heritage site in danger in 1994, being the park with the greatest biodiversity on the African continent. For decades, it has been under threat from armed groups, which practice poaching, deforestation and other forms of illegal and unsustainable exploitation of resources, which have financed armed conflicts in the region.  In 2007, the threat to PNV increased with the allocation of oil concessions, which cover 85% of the park. Allegations are known that SOCO International and its contractors made illicit payments, provided financial support to armed rebels and taken advantage of the fear and violence fomented to facilitate their access to the PNV for oil exploration purposes. This is another painful demonstration of the nature of capitalism. The objectives of profit and economic dominance justify corruption, conflict, violence and the exploitation of the vulnerability of the least developed countries and the poverty of their peoples. Despite condemning SOCO for the activities of prospecting and exploiting PNV resources and asking it to commit itself publicly to canceling them permanently, the resolution is much tougher on the Congolese government than with the British multinational.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 It is regrettable that this park has become one of the most dangerous places in the world when it comes to wildlife conservation. Armed groups are involved in the illegal exploitation of the park's natural resources through mining activities and the production of charcoal, to support military operations, as well as for personal gain. Armed groups are engaged undisturbed in large-scale poaching in order to obtain food and trade in ivory and wild animal meat. Poor discipline, irregular payouts and food shortages have caused more and more military personnel to engage in illegal activities, including artisanal mining, charcoal production and wild poaching.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 In favor of the protection of the park which is an ecosystem to be protected with all our strength.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 It is the obligation of each country to respect the environment and to take all necessary actions to preserve it, especially for areas designated As World Heritage Sites.  However, I believe that it is unacceptable for the EU to try to intervene in the internal affairs of a country, especially when it concerns the exploitation of its natural resources for the development of its economy, at a time when companies in its Member States are responsible for major natural disasters worldwide. For these reasons, I am voting against the report on the protection of Virunga National Park in the Republic of Congo.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The Virunga National Park is a park rich in biodiversity in Africa, and a UNESCO World Heritage site. However, oil and logging concessions were permitted there, especially for the benefit of European companies, in violation of international environmental agreements signed by the DRC. The park has also become the place of illegal practices such as poaching. Moreover, the presence of armed groups that control these concessions give rise to abuse and serious violations of human rights. The Commission has to make active steps and build viable strategies to help protect Virunga National Park and to support sustainable development in the Democratic Republic of Congo. We must emphasise the importance of Virunga National Park, address the root causes of armed conflicts in the region and ask the government of the DRC to protect the park and support development.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution calls for the need to prevent irreversible damage to Virunga National Park, which was declared a World Heritage Site by UNESCO in 1979 and a world heritage site at risk in 1994. The motion seeks to draw attention to the fact that illegal activity exploring and extracting oil fields could cause irreversible damage to Virunga National Park. It also considers it unacceptable that the French oil company TOTAL and the British oil company SOCO International have won oil production rights in the national park, thus violating a number of international conventions.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the need to ensure irreversible damage to this UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1979 and a World Heritage Site in 1994. It is important to note that irreversible damage to this park could be caused as a result of oil exploration and exploitation or other illegal activities. The Congo authorities must work to achieve the conservation of the natural park while ensuring environmentally friendly economic exploitation that ensures the prosperity of the local community living in the area.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I note that this vote was not subject to a roll-call vote in the Parliament.  In the interests of democracy and transparency, I believe that it is important for me to highlight how I voted on this issue.  I chose to abstain on this matter; whilst agreeing with many of the concerns raised within the report, the EU is not the appropriate forum for these.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Resolution on Virunga National Park, a UNESCO World Heritage Site and Africa's most diverse park, as we consider it important for the European Union and the Member States to coordinate joint and effective actions to address the problems of violence arising from the fight for the park's natural resources. The Resolution also urges urgent action to ensure the responsibility of extractive companies in the area and compliance with international standards in social, environmental and human rights matters.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution calling for measures to help protect Virunga National Park in the Democratic Republic of Congo. The park, which has been a World Heritage Site since 1979, must be protected from the dangers posed by oil exploration, armed conflict and corruption. We have called on the European Commission to take action and devise viable strategies to help protect the park and to support sustainable development in the Democratic Republic of Congo.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the resolution on Protection of Virunga national park in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. It is of absolute urgency to prevent irreversible damage to Virunga National Park and put pressure on DRC government not to give license to another oil operator – as SOCO no longer holds the license for exploitation.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution calls for irreversible damage to virunga national park, which was declared a World Heritage Site by UNESCO in 1979 and a world heritage site at risk in 1994. The motion seeks to draw attention to the fact that illegal activity exploring and extracting oil fields could cause irreversible damage to Virunga National Park. It also finds it unacceptable that the French oil company TOTAL and the British oil company SOCO International have won oil production rights in the national park, in breach of a number of international conventions

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Vironga National Park is a UNESCO World Heritage Site as well as Africa's largest biodiversity park. Exploration and exploitation for the purpose of oil exploration as well as other illegal activities can cause irreversible damage to the park. The EU is in a position to organise a diplomatic response from member states and help the Democratic Republic of Congo to contain armed conflict in the park. The Commission should establish a mechanism to ensure the implementation of OECD recommendations on Multinational Companies and the compliance of foreign investors comply with UN human and corporate rights principles.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution due to the fact that despite its status as protected wilderness, the park has been under threat for decades by armed groups that engage in poaching, deforestation and other forms of unsustainable and illegal resource exploitation. As a result, Virunga has been included on the List of World Heritage Sites in Danger. Mass poverty, a weak state, poor governance and regional insecurity would have severe socially and environmentally destabilising effects. According to the 2013 WWF report entitled ‘The economic value of Virunga Park’, the Virunga National Park currently has an annual economic value of USD 48.9 million. In a stable situation, the park could contribute to growth in the economy and in tourism, and could have a value of USD 1 billion per year and create 45 000 jobs.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: in writing. ‒ The Virunga National Park in the Democratic Republic of Congo, a UNESCO World Heritage site,  is endangered because of exploitation of oil and illegal activities such as poaching. The oil concessions not only violate international conventions but have given rise to violent conflicts. The EEAS is therefore strongly encouraged to convince the government to both investigate these breaches of human rights and to persuade oil companies to halt the exploitation of resources in the park. Because of my strong commitment to human rights, and given the urgency of the situation in the Virunga National Park, I have voted in favour of this resolution. By the way, I believe that the euro must be abolished. It leads to dissension and discord in Europe.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution calls for the need to prevent irreversible damage to Virunga National Park. This area was declared a World Heritage Site by UNESCO in 1979 and a World Heritage Site at risk in 1994. The motion seeks to draw attention to the fact that illegal activity exploring and extracting oil fields can cause irreversible damage in the Virunga region. It also considers it unacceptable that the French oil company TOTAL and the British oil company SOCO International have won oil production rights in the national park, thus violating a number of international conventions.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the protection of Virunga National Park in the Democratic Republic of congo, as I believe it is essential to preserve and ensure the sustainability of Africa's oldest national park, which is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.  In this regard, and in order to preserve natural resources and biodiversity, I consider it necessary to prohibit all illegal activities, such as those of armed groups that illegally exploit natural resources and to prevent human rights violations occurring in the area concerned. In this context, the diplomatic response of the European Union and the international community is important in order to fully preserve the natural world wealth and ensure respect for fundamental rights.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – I abstained on this non-legislative and non—binding resolution. While of course UKIP shares great concern over the exploration for oil in this national park with the possible serious ramifications for protected animals and the environment, and while we would urge the DRC to comply with international law on protected sites, we cannot support the EU being involved. This issue should be handled through negotiations between national governments and at the appropriate and legitimate international level, namely the United Nations. The un-elected and unaccountable EU institutions have no right to interfere in the foreign policy of Member States or the domestic affairs of non-EU countries.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of this report. The protection of the national park in the Democratic Republic of Congo is important and the proposed measures are justified.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the resolution as it calls on the Commission to take action to help protect the park, to address the root causes of armed conflicts and corruption, and to support sustainable development and peace-building strategies in the Democratic Republic of Congo.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution calls for the need to prevent irreversible damage to Virunga National Park, which was declared a World Heritage Site by UNESCO in 1979 and a world heritage site at risk in 1994. The motion seeks to draw attention to the fact that illegal activity exploring and extracting oil fields could cause irreversible damage to Virunga National Park. It also considers it unacceptable that the French oil company TOTAL and the British oil company SOCO International have won oil production rights in the national park, thus violating a number of international conventions.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ The Virunga National Park is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and Africa’s most biodiverse park. Irreversible damage could be done to the Park as a result of exploration and exploitation of oil and other illegal activities. The EU is in a position to coordinate a diplomatic response from EU Member States, to help the DRC government to address armed conflicts and support sustainable development in the VNP. The Commission must put in place a mechanism to ensure enforcement of the recommendations of the OECD guidelines for Multinational Enterprises and to ensure that foreign investors comply with the UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights. As a VP of the DEVE committee and shadow rapporteur I voted in favour.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. – The Democratic Republic of Congo is a vast country rich in mineral resources and natural values. As is known, he suffered unscrupulous exploitation during colonial times. It is now a formally free country, but it remains under threat because of the profit-making of multinationals. I therefore voted in favour of the resolution, which seeks to ensure the protection of the national park by reducing mining. It might be timely for former colonialists to think about how they can at least partially repair their damage. There is only one earth that forms a unified ecosystem.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. Virunga National Park, located in northern Kivu Province and the Eastern Province of the Democratic Republic of the Congo, is listed as a world heritage site in danger. This is due to the action of armed groups dedicated to poaching and deforestation. I have chosen to vote in favour of the motion for a resolution because a commitment is needed on the part of the EU and the Member States to preserve the integrity of the park, strengthening the commitment to finance sustainable conservation and economic development and diversification of the surrounding region.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted for this resolution because it defends an ecological sanctuary against threats of oil exploitation. For once, environmental protection may outweigh the financial appetites of multinationals!

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I am sorry about the situation in congo, but declarations from the European Union will not solve anything.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Virunga National Park is Africa's oldest national park known for its unique habitats and rich biodiversity, especially for mountain gorillas that are an endangered species. It is necessary to prevent irreversible damage to the Virunga National Park, which has been on the UNESCO World Heritage List since 1979, and as a world cultural heritage site has been in danger since 1994. Damage to virunga national park may occur as a result of exploration and exploitation of oil and other illegal activities. Fishing in Lake Edward provides about $30 million a year for the benefit of the local community living near it, and according to an independent survey by WWF, more than 50 thousand families use the lake as a source of fresh water. I therefore supported MP Linda McAvan's resolution calling for the protection of Virunga National Park.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I support the motion for a resolution on the protection of Virunga National Park in the Democratic Republic of Congo, because I consider it complete and substantiated, and for the reasons I set out in detail in my speech to the Plenary of the European Parliament.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this resolution. The Virunga National Park, in the Democratic Republic of Congo, has become one of the most dangerous places in the world when it comes to wildlife conservation.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted for this resolution. It aims to defend a UNESCO World Heritage-listed ecological sanctuary, which is now more threatened than ever by a London-based multinational oil company. We owe it to ourselves to protect this park!

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The preservation of this national park is very important. The natural flora and fauna of the national park is already very threatened. The report should help to ensure that conservation is successful. I am therefore in favour of this report.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. Virunga National Park, located in North Kivu province and eastern DRC province on the border of Rwanda and Uganda, is the oldest national park in Africa. It is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and is world-renowned for its rich biodiversity, including mountain gorillas, a critically endangered species. Yet armed groups are engaged in poaching, deforestation and other illegal and unsustainable forms of resource exploitation in the park. In addition, in 2007 oil concessions, located in the park, were granted to the French company Total and the British company SOCO International. This was done in violation of the Paris Convention on the Protection of Cultural and Natural World Heritage.  The resolution considers that "it is essential to prevent the Virunga National Park, (...), from suffering irreversible damage". The resolution "urges the Commission, Member States, DRC and oil companies involved in extraction activities to preserve the current boundaries and territories bordering Virunga Park from fossil fuel exploitation". Nothing questions the greed of the companies involved, however European, nor envisages retaliation. I vote for this text.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the protection of virunga national park in the Democratic Republic of congo. Virunga National Park is Africa's oldest national park and is a UNESCO World Heritage Site. This park has unique habitats and very rich in biodiversity. The famous mountain gorillas, a severely endangered species, live here. The EU must do everything in its power to continue to support the Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo so that the country has energy and economic alternatives to extractive industries, in the fight against poaching, illegal logging, illegal mining and corruption.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as it stresses the need to protect the Virunga National Park in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) from the damage caused by exploration and exploitation of oil and other illegal activities. The resolution focuses on the assistance that the EEAS and the Union as a whole can offer to the Government of the DRC in rejecting and resisting oil exploration and extraction in this world heritage site.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I would like to salute the courage and unwavering will of the park's director, Emmanuel de Mérode, who is constantly fighting to draw the attention of the international community to this remote region, far from the spotlight and from the international scene. These magnificent landscapes are the scene of poaching, illegal logging, illegal mining, corruption, rape, murder; more than 150 rangers, rangers, have been killed in the line of duty over the past decade; these are numerous death threats, intimidations, arbitrary arrests against all those who denounce the impotence of the state, the lust of oil companies.  I call on the DRC authorities to investigate threats and violence against guards, to ensure justice and to prevent irreversible damage to Virunga National Park. Although the British company SOCO International has decided to withdraw from Virunga Park, the Congolese government should not cede this licence to another operator or decide to exploit the oil itself in the name of economic development, which would only fuel lust, violence and conflict.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the European Parliament Resolution on the protection of the Virunga National Park in the Democratic Republic of Congo. The park is Africa’s oldest national park and a UNESCO World Heritage Site, and it is globally renowned for its unique habitats and rich biodiversity, making it the most biodiverse park in Africa. Nevertheless, the park has been under threat for decades by armed groups that engage in poaching, deforestation and other forms of unsustainable and illegal resource exploitation. Therefore I voted in favour of the resolution adopting different measures and stressing the absolute need to prevent irreversible damage to the VNP before it is too late.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 Virunga National Park in the Democratic Republic of Congo is africa's oldest national park, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, africa's most biodiversity park and is particularly famous for its mountain gorillas, a species that is one of the species at risk of extinction listed in Appendix I to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) of 1973. Despite the status of the park as a protected unspoilt natural area, it has been threatened for decades by armed groups that continue poaching, deforestation and other unsustainable and illegal forms of resource exploitation, resulting in Virunga National Park being declared an endangered World Heritage Site. The Democratic Republic of Congo and its surroundings have been in a violent conflict for more than two decades and are a source of funding for both rebels and the official army through illegal mining, the illegal exploitation of the park's natural resources (wood, charcoal) and poaching of endangered species, as well as other illegal trade in natural resources. The Committee on Development therefore proposes in its draft resolution to call on the European Union, its Member States, the European External Action Service, potential donors in the Democratic Republic of congo, the authorities of the Democratic Republic of Congo to do everything possible to protect the park's unique natural assets. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The Virunga National Park is a UNESCO-listed "ecological sanctuary" of 790,000 hectares since 1979, which is threatened by both armed groups (more than 20) who, in addition to fighting with the regular army, engage in poaching, deforestation and "other illegal and unsustainable forms of resource exploitation", but also and above all , by prospecting by SOCO International, to which the DRC government has granted oil concessions covering 85% of the park's surface area. Total is also exploring in the area but would have fulfilled its commitment not to prospect within the park. This motion for a resolution calls for the application of useful measures: that SOCO International plc and its company registered in the DRC permanently cease all exploration and exploitation in Virunga Park that the DRC government cancels oil exploration permits and fights against groups that threaten this sanctuary.  Many endangered species inhabit this park, including mountain gorillas. There is an urgent need for action. I vote therefore for the resolution.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution for the protection of Virunga National Park in the Democratic Republic of Congo. The aim is to ensure the preservation of this World Heritage-listed park, known in particular for its mountain gorillas, a critically endangered species listed in the CITES Convention since 1973. Located in North Kivu province and the eastern province of DRC, on the border of Rwanda and Uganda, it is the oldest park in Africa.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I would have voted in favour of this report because it advocates the preservation of Virunga National Park. The natural flora and fauna of the national park is already severely threatened and sustainably damaged and urgently needs to be protected. The report should help to ensure that conservation is successful.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Africa's oldest national park is on the endangered World Heritage list, with mass poaching and environmentally harmful activities. The EU must also act to make the situation better.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. \u2012 I support the resolution on the protection of virunga national park in the Democratic Republic of congo, because according to all relevant indicators this National Park is threatened by the destruction of flora and fauna that make up its distinctiveness on the basis of which it is listed on the UNESCO World Heritage List and the list of endangered World Heritage.  I believe that the necessary steps should be taken, which this resolution well identifies, in providing financial and organizational resources to ensure the smooth operations of the National Park, protection of integrity, prevention of irresponsible and unacceptable exploitation of resources to the environment and nature, as well as protection from armed groups that threaten the survival of the park. Current activities within the protected area posing a threat must be limited by the actions of the Government of the Democratic Republic of congo in cooperation and with the assistance of the European Union and other interested actors at the United Nations.  Since the National Park represents an important segment of the local economy, it is necessary to do everything necessary to keep the local population actively involved in the protection and enjoyment of the benefits of the park, but also to prevent possible environmental devastation due to the intention of exploiting oil whose sites cover 85 % of the protected area. Protecting the habitat and the associated living world must remain an absolute priority.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. The Virunga National Park is a UNESCO-listed "ecological sanctuary" of 790,000 hectares since 1979, which is threatened by both armed groups (more than 20) who, in addition to fighting with the regular army, engage in poaching, deforestation and "other illegal and unsustainable forms of resource exploitation", but also and above all , by prospecting by SOCO International, to which the DRC government has granted oil concessions covering 85% of the park's surface area. Total is also exploring in the area, but would have fulfilled its commitment not to prospect within the park.  This motion for a resolution calls for the application of useful measures: that SOCO International plc and its company registered in the DRC permanently cease all exploration and exploitation in Virunga Park, that the DRC government cancels oil exploration permits and that it fight against groups that threaten this sanctuary. Many endangered species inhabit this park, including mountain gorillas. There is an urgent need for action. I vote therefore for the resolution.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ The European Union must make more efforts to prevent environmental devastation, violence and exploitation in virungi National Park in Congo, in particular because the illegal exploitation of natural resources involved companies operating in the jurisdiction of the Union's member states, which is a violation of international and European law. It is a series of illegal activities such as poaching, oil exploitation and mining involving armed and rogue groups, as well as an attempt by Congolese authorities to take away the park's protection status through border changes, allowing soco international to exploit oil.   I fully support the call for diplomatic action by EU Member States so that the DRC government abandons exploitation as well as the request for financial support from the Commission, to ensure the diversification and protection of the surrounding area and to support the development of sustainable energy and economic alternatives in the Congo.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. – I support the proposal for a resolution to protect Virunga National Park in the Democratic Republic of congo submitted by Linda McAvan.  In 1979, Virunga National Park was included on the World Heritage List by UNESCO, and in 1994 it was listed as an endangered World Heritage Site and should be specially preserved and protected as such. Although dr congo law prohibits environmentally harmful activities in protected areas, the DRC government has awarded oil concessions, covering 85% of the park's surface, to SOCO international plc, which is the only one to conduct a survey of the park so far. I believe that a race for oil would result in severe destabilization of society and the environment.  According to a 2013 WWF report, Virunga National Park currently has an annual economic value of $48.9 million, and in a stable situation, the park could contribute to economic growth and tourism and reach a value of $1 billion per year and create 45,000 highly needed jobs.  Unfortunately, regardless of its protected wilderness status, the park has been dominated for decades by armed groups engaged in poaching, deforestation and other unsustainable and illegal forms of resource exploitation. Because of all this, Virunga is on the list of endangered World Heritage Sites.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 I am deeply convinced of the importance of rapid international action to protect Congo's Virunga National Park. This park, on the border with Rwanda and Uganda, has many "best": it is the oldest national park in Africa, it is Africa's most biologically diverse park, but it is also most at risk, especially the oil production plans and the criminal activities of various armed groups linked to illegal logging, oil and poaching. These illegal activities finance not only armed rebel groups, but also official military forces. I believe it is absolutely necessary and in the interests of all of us to prevent the destruction of this piece of land. Its devastation would not only mean the loss of a unique and extremely important habitat from an environmental point of view, and the loss of thousands of unique species, it would also mean social disaster, mass poverty in an already broken state, an increase in extremism and regional instability. We have to stop all this.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 Virunga National Park in the Congo is Africa's oldest national park, a UNESCO World Heritage Site known worldwide for its extraordinary habitats and rich biodiversity, the highest of all African parks, and famous for its mountain gorillas, a species seriously threatened.  In addition, the park now produces an annual economic value of $48.9 million, contributing to growth both economically and tourism and creating $45 million. 000 jobs. But, despite its status as a protected natural zone, the park has been threatened for years by armed groups dedicated to poaching, deforestation and other illegal forms of resource exploitation, such as oil concessions, putting Virunga National Park in danger.  I am therefore voting in favour of this motion for a resolution, in the hope that the Commission, the Member States, the Democratic Republic of Congo and the oil companies involved in mining will do everything possible to safeguard the Virunga National Park.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Writing. \u2012 The situation in the Democratic Republic of Congo is very critical not only in view of the humanitarian disaster, but also on the issue of nature conservation. I therefore welcome the initiative in this regard and have supported the resolution.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I fully support this resolution on Virunga National Park in the DRC. Located in North Kivu province and the eastern province of DRC, bordering Rwanda and Uganda, the park is Africa's oldest, World Heritage-listed and world-famous for its unique habitats and rich biodiversity, unmatched in Africa; it is best known for its mountain gorillas. However, it is in danger because of conflicts and the weakness of the state in some regions, which can no longer control what is happening there. So I defend any initiative to protect this heritage of humanity.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non-legislative and non-binding resolution. While of course UKIP shares great concern over the exploration for oil in this national park with the possible serious ramifications for protected animals and the environment, and while we would urge the DRC to comply with international law on protected sites, we cannot support the EU being involved. This issue should be handled through negotiations between national governments and at the appropriate and legitimate international level, namely the United Nations. The un-elected and unaccountable EU institutions have no right to interfere in the foreign policy of Member States or the domestic affairs of non-EU countries.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the protection of Virunga National Park in the Democratic Republic of Congo. This park is the oldest national park in Africa and is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.  Despite its status as a protected natural area, it is threatened by armed groups engaged in illegal exploitation of resources and large-scale poaching, resulting in irreversible damage. The oil company SOCO International has also undertaken, in violation of various conventions, oil activities in the park and its surroundings where a dozen emblematic species live, some of them threatened.  We therefore call on the Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo to abandon oil exploration and exploitation in the park, to cancel oil exploration permits in this area, to reject changes to the park boundaries and to combat any illegal activity. It is clear that at the same time, the country's government will need to be helped to develop sustainable energy and economic solutions for communities that rely heavily on the park's natural resources.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 It is necessary to prevent irreversible damage from being caused to virunga national park in the Democratic Republic of congo, classified as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1979 and as a world heritage site in danger in 1994. This park is transformed into one of the most dangerous places in the world in terms of wildlife conservation. Armed groups participated in the illegal exploitation of the park's natural resources through mining and coal production activities to support its military operations and for personal gain. Large-scale poaching is common for food and to finance war with the marketing of ivory and wildlife meat.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which underlines the importance of preventing Virunga National Park, listed as a World Heritage Site in 1979 and listed as a World Heritage Site in Danger in 1994 by Unesco, which is home to many endangered species, such as the iconic mountain gorilla and the okapi, which is not irreversibly damaged, including as a result of oil exploration and exploitation or other illegal activities. It is unacceptable that oil concessions were granted to the French company Total and the British company SOCO International in 2007, in violation of the Paris Convention on the Protection of Cultural and Natural World Heritage, the 1992 Convention on Biological Diversity, the Ramsar Convention and Congolese legislation.  It is therefore with deep concern that the European Parliament observes the illegal exploitation of the park's natural resources by armed groups who use mining activities to finance their military operations and enrich themselves.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which warns of the absolute need to prevent irreversible damage from being caused to Virunga National Park. I recall that this Park was the first protected area created in Africa (classified a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1979 and a world heritage site in danger in 1994), being one of the two strongholds of the 'mountain gorilla' and the protected area with the greatest biological diversity of the African continent. This resolution emphasizes the situation of danger, practically emergency, in which the preservation of biodiversity in this region is found, noting that such damage may be the result of the exploration and exploitation of oil and other illegal activities. The text therefore calls on the Commission and the Member States to coordinate diplomatic action with the Democratic Republic of congo (DRC) to renounce exploration and oil exploration within the perimeter of the park, as well as in other UNESCO World Heritage sites. It is also important that the EU supports the DRC government in developing energy and economically sustainable alternatives to the extraction industries and combating corruption, poaching and illegal logging.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the protection of Virunga National Park (VNP) in the Democratic Republic of Congo. The resolution stresses the absolute need to avoid irreversible damage to the park, which was designated by UNESCO as a World Heritage Site and was subsequently recognised as endangered; deplores the fact that the VNP has become one of the most dangerous places in the world when it comes to wildlife conservation; stresses that irreversible damage to the VNP could occur as a result of oil exploitation or other illegal activities.

name: György SCHÖPFLIN
text: Writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution calls for irreversible damage to virunga national park, which was declared a World Heritage Site by UNESCO in 1979 and a World Heritage Site at risk in 1994, absolutely necessary. The motion seeks to draw attention to the fact that illegal activity exploring and extracting oil fields could cause irreversible damage to Virunga National Park. It also considers it unacceptable that the French oil company TOTAL and the British oil company SOCO International have won oil production rights in the national park, thus violating a number of international conventions. In view of all this, I voted in favour of the adoption of the motion.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this as it is not for the EU to get involved in foreign affairs

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution today because this is an incredibly stunning area of the world and I want to see it preserved and maintained for generations. The EU is one of the largest contributors to the park, and this pays testament to our desire to see this area preserved. While the DRC Government does have laws which prohibit environmentally harmful activities in protected areas like the Virunga national park, the granting of oil concessions to SOCO International is a source of consternation. There are suggestions that the borders of the national park may be changed in order to accommodate for the oil drilling operations to circumvent the laws which otherwise prevent this from happening. This resolution calls on the Commission, Member States and the oil companies who may be interested in exploring for oil in this area to voice their support for the current borders so as to minimise the damage to the environment here.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Virunga National Park, located in the Democratic Republic of Congo, is Africa's oldest national park, part of the UNESCO World Heritage Site and an area known worldwide for its unique habitats and rich biodiversity, making it considered the most biologically diverse park in Africa. The park is known mainly for mountain gorillas, which are critically endangered species. Although the park has protected wilderness status, it has been threatened for decades by armed groups dedicated to poaching, deforestation and other unsustainable and illegal forms of resource use. Violent conflict has continued in and around Virunga National Park for more than two decades, where insurgents and the official army receive funding mainly from illegal mineral extraction and its natural resources and from poaching. In the light of the above, it is necessary for the Commission and the Member States to take effective measures and necessary steps to persuade the Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo to protect virunga national park and to eliminate all forms of violence and armed conflict.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. Virunga National Park is located in North Kivu and the Eastern Provinces of the Democratic Republic of Congo, on the border with Rwanda and Uganda. It is the oldest national park in Africa and is protected as a UNESCO World Heritage Site.  The world is renowned for its unique habitats and rich biodiversity. The park is especially known for its extremely endangered species of mountain gorillas. Despite its protected wilderness status, the park has been under threat for decades by armed groups dealing with poaching, deforestation and other forms of unsustainable and illegal exploitation of resources.  In addition, there is also a risk of oil fever in this protected area. It could have severe social and environmental consequences and further destabilise the situation in the face of mass poverty, a weak country, a failure of governance and a precarious situation throughout the region. The motion for a resolution stresses the urgent need to prevent irreparable damage in Virunga National Park.  It calls on the Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo to enforce and respect its legislation and regulations prohibiting environmentally harmful activities such as oil exploration and exploitation in protected areas. The Government of the Democratic Republic should also close loopholes in the draft hydrocarbon and nature protection laws that allow natural resources to be searched and exploited in national parks and world heritage sites. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Bart STAES
text: Written. The Virunga National Park (VNP) in the Democratic Republic of Congo is Africa's first national park, a UNESCO World Heritage Site and has been supported by the European Commission and several Member States for 25 years. The illegal trade in raw materials and the exploitation and exploration of oil in the Virunga Park not only cause environmental damage and the destruction of the park, but also increase violence and violation of human rights. The oil concessions of Total and SOCO are also contrary to a lot of (inter)national legislation.  For the umpteenth time, the EU stresses that there is an absolute need to prevent irreversible damage to virunga park. The resolution calls for the European External Action Service to coordinate a diplomatic response and make it clear that what is happening in this park is unacceptable. By focusing on sustainable forest management, economic development of the region, alternative energy and combating illegal logging, the integrity of the park can stand. Furthermore, the resolution calls for active companies (such as SOCO) to respect international human rights law and for binding agreements to be reached on how multinationals make money. For all these reasons, I am voting in favour of this resolution.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: Writing. \u2012 I am very happy to be able to support the European Parliament resolution on the protection of virunga national park in the Democratic Republic of Congo. Virunga Park is the most biologically diverse nature park in Africa, and was listed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1979. Among other things, rare species are also home to endangered mountain gorillas. The resolution draws attention to the threat of irreversible damage to this national park as a result of oil exploration carried out by the British oil company SOCO International in violation of international conventions. The park has become one of the most dangerous places in the world in recent years when it comes to preserving wild species. In the last decade, more than 140 park rangers have been killed while on active duty. The park illegally exploits natural resources by armed groups linked to mining activities, they also participate in large-scale poaching and finance war conflicts from the funds raised, in addition to their own benefit. I consider it necessary to draw attention to this threat and to call on the competent authorities to take measures to prevent illegal interference with the world's protected area, which ultimately leads to social unrest and bloody conflicts.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ Virunga National Park has been designated a World Heritage Site by the United Nations. It is important to preserve the wilderness in virunga national park due to current exploits and exploits for oil wells and other activities.  It should also be noted that members of the European Union, having a duty under international and European human rights laws, must ensure that companies operating within their jurisdiction do not cause or contribute to human rights violations as well as environmental damage.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ Virunga National Park is the oldest national park in Africa. In 1979 UNESCO included UNESCO on the World Heritage List, and in 1994 it was listed as an endangered World Heritage Site.  Virunga National Park currently has an annual economic value of $US48.9 million. Sustainable land, water and wildlife management in Virunga will bring direct and indirect economic benefits to communities that rely in large part on the park's natural resources. Oil exploration and exploitation or other illegal activities could cause irreversible damage to virunga national park. I support this resolution because I consider Virunga National Park to have invaluable value. It is known for its unique habitats and great biodiversity that makes it the most biologically diverse park in Africa. Preserving biodiversity is one of the tasks that humanity should jointly address and is an integral part of the development process.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the protection of Virunga National Park in the Democratic Republic of congo. Virunga National Park is africa's oldest national park, under threat from armed groups dealing with poaching, deforestation and other forms of unsustainable and illegal resource exploitation for decades. I welcome the statement in the resolution that it is essential to prevent irreparable damage to the Virunga National Park, designated by UNESCO as a World Heritage Site in 1979 and as a World Heritage Site at risk in 1994.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 It is the obligation of each country to respect the environment and to take all necessary actions to preserve it, especially in the case of areas designated as World Heritage Sites.  However, I find it unacceptable that the EU should try to intervene in the internal affairs of a country, especially when it concerns the exploitation of its natural resources for the development of its economy, at a time when companies in its Member States are responsible for major natural disasters worldwide.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Virunga National Park, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, is a park with a very high biodiversity that needs to be safeguarded and protected. Unfortunately, the exploitation of oil fields is seriously endangering the many animal species present. In addition, the presence of ongoing armed conflicts and corruption make the economic, environmental and social situation unstable, preventing the development of this area despite its enormous potential (it could create over 45,000 jobs and its economic value could be more than $1.1 billion dollars a year). That is why we voted in favour of the resolution, inspired by the WWF report, because it highlights the importance of the Park for the livelihood of local populations and indigenous peoples. The report also calls for an end to the exploitation of natural resources and encourages the Congolese Government to take more action to protect the environment and prevent the illegal exploitation of resources, both natural and animal energy resources (poaching).

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted without hesitation for the resolution. It is essential to prevent the Virunga National Park, which was declared a World Heritage Site in 1979 and listed as a World Heritage Site in Danger by Unesco in 1994, from suffering irreversible damage.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the text on the protection of Virunga National Park in the DRC. The text stresses the absolute need to prevent irreversible damage to the VNP, which was designated by UNESCO as a World Heritage Site in 1979 and as a World Heritage Site in Danger in 1994. It also deplores the fact that the VNP has become one of the most dangerous places in the world when it comes to wildlife conservation and that armed groups have been involved in illegal exploitation of the park’s natural resources through mining activities and charcoal production used both to sustain their military operations and for personal gain. The text also urges the DRC Government to disarm rebels and restore security in the park region and regrets, furthermore, that the repression of human rights activists and journalists in the DRC has increased. It calls once more on the DRC Government to recognise and respect freedom of the press and media and to uphold the rule of law and human rights.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Virunga National Park is located on the territory of the Democratic Republic of congo and is the oldest park of its kind in Africa. It has been under UNESCO protection since 1978 and is home to many endangered animal species, some of which are among the last specimens on the planet. Unfortunately, at the same time, the same park has become one of the most dangerous places in the world in terms of the conservation of wild animal species. In agreement with the authorities of the Democratic Republic of congo, illegal exploration and extraction of oil in the park and many other illicit activities, such as poaching and ivory trafficking, have been agreed.  At the same time, the park is home to violence linked and insecurable by armed guerrillas, and at the same time serious violations of basic human rights. I support the resolution calling on the European External Action Service to take more decisive steps to persuade the authorities in the Democratic Republic of congo to investigate actions leading to violations of fundamental human rights on their territory, and to take steps towards cutting off cooperation with oil companies exploiting oil in the park, which could otherwise have cardinally negative consequences.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the motion for a resolution on the protection of virunga national park in the Democratic Republic of congo (2015/2728(RSP)) because I believe that the protection of the oldest national park in Africa is very important, as it is the most diverse park in Africa and falls under UNESCO protection.  The conservation of this diversity is of great importance to all humanity, and it is therefore necessary to prevent the illegal exploitation of the park's natural resources through mining activities, charcoal production and by croo.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
